webTitle: Boost for Fulham after Al Fayed raises £350m on Harrods

fields.headline: Fulham score
fields.standfirst:
Boost for football club after Al Fayed raises £350m on Harrods

Football site
fields.trailText: Boost for football club after Al Fayed raises £350m on Harrods
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed has raised £350m by mortgaging Harrods department store in London in a move that could lead to a multimillion-pound windfall for Fulham football club, which he also owns.

The complex deal with Royal Bank of Scotland could also release funds for tentative plans to build a hotel and casino complex in Las Vegas, with a theme around Harrods and Mr Fayed's Ritz hotel in Paris.

"The Royal Bank of Scotland approached us with the idea of raising some money and with Mohamed looking at one or two exciting possibilities worldwide we thought we'd go for it," said Max Clifford, Mr Fayed's spokesman.

Mr Clifford dismissed claims that the main aim of refinancing had been to reduce debt at the Harrods empire.

"Everyone is very happy with the way things are going at Harrods," he said.

Although he refused to elaborate on the opportunities Mr Fayed is considering, Mr Clifford admitted that Fulham football club was likely to be a leading beneficiary of the funds.

"Mohamed wants to turn Fulham into a truly great club capable of competing with the Manchester Uniteds and Arsenals and everyone knows that costs money," he said.

"We hope to hear soon that we have got planning permission for a new £70m stadium and if the side gets promotion to the Premier League as expected, we're going to need to spend more money on players. Everyone knows how expensive football has become and how much money you need to be successful."

The precise debt levels of the Harrods empire are unknown, but the last set of accounts filed at Companies House - for the year to January 29 2000 - show net liabilities of £193m. Pre-tax profits were £38.9m on a turnover of £485m.

The Royal Bank of Scotland deal has seen Harrods create a separate property holding company, Harrods Property, and then sell the freehold of the building in Knightsbridge to it.

Harrods will pay rent to the property firm which in turn will make mortgage payments to Royal Bank of Scotland over a period of 20 years.

Mr Fayed bought Harrods in 1985 as part of the acquisition of House of Fraser, which was later floated off as a separate stock market entity.

The value of the Harrods property has increased significantly since then, and Mr Fayed joins firms such as Arcadia and United Business Media by seeking to realise some of that value by refinancing.

Harrods was last year stripped of its royal warrants, however. The move came after extensive criticism by Mr Fayed of the royal family.

webTitle: Toss of a coin that flipped out the Blues

fields.headline: Toss of a coin that flipped out the Blues
fields.trailText: Perhaps this year's Worthington Cup final was won and lost by the decision, taken before the match, to hold the penalty shoot-out at the northern end of the Millennium stadium, in front of the massed ranks of Liverpool fans. Robbie Fowler won the toss, and the Kop's enthusiasm helped Gary McAllister to guide the opening kick home.
fields.body:
Perhaps this year's Worthington Cup final was won and lost by the decision, taken before the match, to hold the penalty shoot-out at the northern end of the Millennium stadium, in front of the massed ranks of Liverpool fans. Robbie Fowler won the toss, and the Kop's enthusiasm helped Gary McAllister to guide the opening kick home.

Then the cheers turned to whistles as Martin Grainger, the first name on Trevor Francis's piece of paper, stepped forward to become the day's sacrificial victim. His wits blasted to smithereens by surely the loudest outbreak of discouragement in sporting history, Birmingham City's left-back didn't stand a chance.

Cardiff's new stadium has a reputation for holding and amplifying the noise of the crowd, and on this occasion it did for poor Grainger, who was understandably shattered by the reception as he prepared for the ordeal. Placing his kick to Sander Westerveld's left, and at a friendly height, he watched the Liverpool goalkeeper guess correctly and make a comfortable save.

Nothing could console the Birmingham man, an ever-present throughout the tournament and one of their steadiest performers in the 120 minutes of play yesterday. Luckily, he had a companion in his misery when Andy Johnson put Birmingham's sixth kick almost straight at Westerveld to give Liverpool the match.

Johnson, too, had done nothing to deserve the indignity. Coming on after half time as a subsitute for Dele Adebola, he gave point and life to Birmingham's attack, getting under the feet of Liverpool's big central defenders to highly disruptive effect. He and Bryan Hughes, another second-half substitute, abetted by the increasingly troublesome Jon McCarthy on the right wing, galvanised and organised their whole team, forcing Liverpool on to the back foot so effectively that Gérard Houllier's side must have thought back to Thursday night's ordeal against Roma and feared that they were in some sort of recurring nightmare.

In no way did Birmingham deserve the torture of losing in a shoot-out. They had started the match tentatively but grew inexorably in strength and self-belief. Every reverse seemed to stiffen their sinews, particularly the injury to their captain, Martin O'Connor, in injury-time. With their allocation of substitutes already used, O'Connor was forced to stay on the pitch all the way through extra-time, a heroic figure barely able to walk but constantly directing his team mates from the centre circle.

"We've got some big hearts in there," Francis said of his squad. His own passionate commitment was illustrated by his tearful embrace with Johnson. It was not certain whether the manager was consoling the man who had missed the final penalty, or vice-versa.

For Liverpool, this was their second unconvincing performance of the week, and their second big result. As Houllier pointed out, it was also their fourth game in 10 days, and tiredness must certainly have taken a toll of their fluency.

Nevertheless they made and missed plenty of chances, most of them falling to the otherwise impressive Fowler, whose opening goal was a splendid reward for his return to form and fitness. An excellent display by Ian Bennett, Birmingham's young goalkeeper, also had something to do with that, but Liverpool were, as Houllier said, "not lethal enough".

He was delighted to collect his first trophy as Liverpool's manager, just over two years after assuming total control following the departure of Roy Evans. "They say the first trophy is the hardest," Houllier observed. Evans, whose tenure started with a victory in the same competition in 1995, could tell him that it doesn't always work out that way. But the new Liverpool, although still suffering from occasional growing pains, look capable of building on this foundation. Humility and team spirit, qualities notably scarce in the pre-Houllier squad, are the cornerstones on which something significant may yet be built.

fields.headline: Yorke dances to northern soul
fields.trailText: The official time of death was 2.51pm. This was when competition in the Premiership expired three months before its allotted time, the moment when the league we fondly refer to as the most exciting on the planet wheezed into submission.
fields.body:
The official time of death was 2.51pm. This was when competition in the Premiership expired three months before its allotted time, the moment when the league we fondly refer to as the most exciting on the planet wheezed into submission.

As Teddy Sheringham scored yet another Manchester United goal, as the Old Trafford crowd gloated about how it was now 1-6 to the Arsenal, the home side ruthlessly switched off the championship's life-support system.

"I think Arsenal are finished in the league now," said Sir Alex Ferguson after the game, as he manfully tried to suppress a grin at the scene he had just witnessed. "Sixteen points makes it difficult for them. Very difficult."

Difficult for them: as euphemisms go, this was up there with the one about William Hague still being in with a chance come the knockout competition in May.

Arsenal had travelled to the north-west carrying the last few gasps of competitive possibility. A win at Old Trafford would have shaved the deficit to 10 points, another couple of mistakes and you never know, a semblance of life could have been pumped into the corpse of the chase for the championship. But Arsenal don't thrive in the north-west. The last time they had been up there, against Liverpool, they had conceded four. This time it was worse, far worse.

For 45 minutes, this game was a reflection of the Premiership as a whole: there was only one team in it, Manchester United playing the kind of football their rivals could only stand and admire. Certainly that's what Arsenal's defence did.

They turned up dressed in Oxford United's kit, but no one expected Arsenal to defend about as effectively as the side with the worst record in the league. Ferguson reckoned United did not touch the heights they managed in the recent league match against West Ham. Nevertheless, in the first half their movement and speed of thought was as good as has ever been seen in this country. But rarely, even in this Premiership, has the rapier of United's play met with so little resistance.

For 45 minutes, Arsenal's defence -the spine on which the club's success has always been based - played as if constructed of jelly. Watching this, Tony Adams must have been sticking his right arm in the air in horror. Oleg Luzhny spent much of the afternoon playing spot the ball, particularly when Dwight Yorke skipped forward into empty space to score the first of a ruthless hat-trick; Igor Stepanovs missed tackle after tackle; and, just in case you thought it was entirely a Russian conspiracy, Ashley Cole, the new English hope at left-back, was driven to distraction and an early substitution by David Beckham. Arsenal had never conceded more than four in the history of the Premiership, and here they were five down within 40 minutes. No wonder the visitors' section in the stand was pock-marked with empty seats with half an hour to go. They were all anxious to miss the inevitable final contribution from their bete noire, Sheringham.

Afterwards, talk of the destination of the Premiership now redundant, the competition trampled into the mud that passes as a pitch at the theatre of groundsmen's nightmares, attention was entirely focused on Wednesday and how the England players would fare in Sven's debut.

"All seven of ours are injured," smiled Ferguson, reminding us of his reputation on the front line of the battle between club and country. He was teasing, which is just as well for Sven-Goran Eriksson. The new England manager wouldn't want to rely on his Arsenal trio on this form.

David Seaman, carrying more hair than the entire United team, was not at fault for any more than two of the goals; the only conspicuous thing Ray Parlour did was to hobble off with a timely thigh knock; and Ashley Cole suffered the worst 45 minutes of his life. United's boys, by contrast, were purring: the magnificent Wes Brown, David Beckham and Paul Scholes back on form, Nicky Butt looking better with every game. By staying on the bench Phil Neville probably advanced his claim over the hapless Cole.

But there was one man on the pitch who made the real difference. Covering every speck of mud, turning up one moment at left-back, the next at centre-forward: if only Mr and Mrs Keane had given birth to young Roy a few hundred miles to the east, then Sven could rest easy in his bed.

fields.headline: Nationwide round-up
fields.trailText: Mark Williams, who missed the final penalty as Wimbledon were dramatically ousted from the FA Cup on Tuesday, recovered in some style with two goals as his team demolished QPR 5-0.
fields.body:
Mark Williams, who missed the final penalty as Wimbledon were dramatically ousted from the FA Cup on Tuesday, recovered in some style with two goals as his team demolished QPR 5-0.

The bottom 10 in the First Division managed only a single point between them, with Sheffield Wednesday falling back into the relegation places after their 2-0 defeat at Preston . The Lancashire club join two other weekend winners, Nottingham Forest and Sheffield United , one point outside the play-offs.

Millwall stretched their lead at the top of the Second Division, beating last-placed Oxford 2-0, while Walsall , their closest challengers, gave up a 2-0 lead to lose 3-2 at home to Wrexham. Craig Faulconbridge scored the Welsh side's winner in injury-time.

Luton 's recent good form continued at Swindon, where they won 3-1. But they stay third from bottom because Bristol Rovers, above them on goal difference, secured a first home win of the season against Cambridge United .

Most of the matches in the Third Division were tight affairs, with only one team winning by more than a single goal. That team was Shrewsbury who, having previously scored eight away goals all season, beat Rochdale 7-1. The 19-year-old Luke Rodgers, having scored his first goal of the season on Tuesday, hit his first ever hat-trick and was promptly sent off for overdoing the celebrations.

Struggling York eased their relegation worries with a 1-1 draw at Brighton . The Seagulls slip to third thanks to Cardiff 's 4-2 in at Kidderminster yesterday, with three goals coming in the last four minutes and both sides scoring in injury-time.

webTitle: England squad shrunk by midfield injuries

fields.headline: England squad shrunk by midfield injuries
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson's massive England squad for Wednesday's friendly against Spain got a little smaller yesterday when three players pulled out.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson's massive England squad for Wednesday's friendly against Spain got a little smaller yesterday when three players pulled out.

After losing the services of Newcastle's Kieron Dyer, who suffered a recurrence of an old shin injury on Saturday, Eriksson crossed the names of Ray Parlour and Steve McManaman off the list yesterday.

Parlour strained a hamstring during Arsenal's 6-1 defeat at Old Trafford, in which he was substituted, and McManaman has a similar problem. He played for 30 minutes as a substitute during Real Madrid's 2-2 draw with Deportivo la Coruna but, with Real due to play Barcelona this weekend, has decided to rest rather than risk exacerbating the problem.

McManaman has not started for England since the opening game of Euro 2000 against Portugal, when he scored England's second goal in a 3-2 defeat. He was watched by Eriksson in Madrid's Champions League match against Lazio last week and was looking forward to playing against some of his club-mates in the Spain team.

Eriksson phoned McManaman last week to confirm the midfielder's fitness, but they spoke too soon. The problem surfaced only during training on Friday, and was not helped by the former Liverpool player's appearance yesterday.

The withdrawals will significantly reduce Eriksson's midfield options, with more withdrawals likely before Wednesday's game. West Ham's Michael Carrick is considered doubtful, also with a hamstring injury, but will report for duty with the rest of the squad this morning.

Late withdrawals are a fact of life for international managers, particularly for friendlies. But Eriksson has agreed that players from Liverpool, Arsenal, Manchester United and Leeds, the remaining English clubs in Europe, will not play the whole match, a policy that should be rewarded with a good turn-out from those clubs this morning.

Mick McCarthy, the Republic of Ireland manager, has similar problems after two of his senior players, Charlton's Mark Kinsella and Sunderland's Niall Quinn, withdrew from his squad for Wednesday's friendly against Denmark.

Quinn, who also missed the last friendly against Finland in November, is out again with the recurrence of back trouble following Sunderland's defeat at Leicester.

Kinsella, who returned to the Charlton side on Saturday after a knee operation, was another victim of the dreaded hamstring strain. McCarthy has already lost his goalkeeper, Dean Kiely, and Tottenham's Stephen Carr. Yesterday he called up the Stoke City midfielder Graham Kavanagh in an attempt to plug the gaps in his squad.

One of few players to profit from this spate of international injuries is Manchester United's Mikael Silvestre. He has been added to the France squad for the friendly with Germany after Monaco's Philippe Christanval sustained an ankle injury.

fields.headline: Spireites deny crookedness
fields.trailText: Rarely can a pre-match tune have been more appropriate. Judging by the catalogue of financial irregularities levelled at Chesterfield by the FA last week, including non-contract payments to players and falsified gate receipts, this really could be a case worthy of Mulder and Scully. People in this corner of Derbyshire are, in the words of the Catatonia song, starting to worry.
fields.body:
Rarely can a pre-match tune have been more appropriate. Judging by the catalogue of financial irregularities levelled at Chesterfield by the FA last week, including non-contract payments to players and falsified gate receipts, this really could be a case worthy of Mulder and Scully. People in this corner of Derbyshire are, in the words of the Catatonia song, starting to worry.

This season had been shaping up to become one to remember for the Spirerites. Over recent weeks the gap between themselves and stuttering Brighton had grown to embarrassing proportions. Now 2000-01 may be remembered for all the wrong reasons. The spectre of Swindon, relegated for similar offences 11 years ago, hangs over them.

The Chesterfield chairman Darren Brown has spent his time vigorously denying the charges and claiming that they face fewer than half the number of charges reported - 33 compared to 70.

"I think the most serious are the two charges of payments to players and the Luke Beckett contract," he said yesterday. "We have consistently denied these allegations."

Beckett was bought from Chester, with his £150,000 fee set by a tribunal. But the salary he was to have been paid and his signing-on fee have come under scrutiny, with Brown claiming the player signed a new contract in November.

From Swansea to Southport, clubs are preparing cases for and against promotion and relegation. "Going down," chanted Blackpool's supporters as the home players left the pitch at the end of a slightly fortuitous win. Only a post and a dodgy refereeing decision, Steve Blatherwick punching a Richard Wellens cross inside the box, denied Blackpool a point.

"It has begun to affect me personally," said the Chesterfield manager Nicky Law. "This is my first job and I've found it very difficult."

From Swansea to Southport, clubs are preparing cases for and against promotion and relegation. "Going down," chanted Blackpool's supporters as the home players left the pitch at the end of a slightly fortuitous win. Only a post and a dodgy refereeing decision, Steve Blatherwick punching a Richard Wellens cross inside the box, denied Blackpool a point. "It has begun to affect me personally," said the Chesterfield manager Nicky Law. "This is my first job and I've found it very difficult."

webTitle: Sleepy Watford see promotion dream fade

fields.headline: Sleepy Watford see promotion dream fade
fields.trailText: Slowly the realisation is dawning: Watford are going nowhere this season. Indeed, their fine start is all that separates them from a relegation battle. On form - 12 defeats and three draws in their last 19 games - they are among the poorest sides in this division, and here they produced a performance to match.
fields.body:
Slowly the realisation is dawning: Watford are going nowhere this season. Indeed, their fine start is all that separates them from a relegation battle. On form - 12 defeats and three draws in their last 19 games - they are among the poorest sides in this division, and here they produced a performance to match.

Watford were good for five minutes, a period in which they scored twice and proved that, had they performed to their potential, the scoreline would have made Stockport's two previous matches, both 4-0 defeats, seem respectable.

Stockport were never good, though both goals were well taken by Aaron Wilbraham, the 21-year-old who his manager Andy Kilner says is "becoming a top First Division striker".

His first, a nice touch and fine finish from Karim Fradin's cross, was helped by his marker Darren Ward's apparent somnambulance. For his second, a dire end to a dismal match, Watford's entire defence fell asleep to allow the softest of injury-time equalisers. Paul Robinson's lazy, crazy slash at the ball sent Shefki Kuqi free, Robert Page got back to steal the ball only to fall over, and Kuqi presented Wilbraham with a simple finish.

Watford's crossing was appalling and their set pieces were abysmal - but their two goals came from a cross and a set piece. One substitute, Nordin Wooter, centred for Tommy Mooney to volley the first; Another, Peter Kennedy, curled in the free kick from which Allan Nielsen headed the second. It briefly seemed that Watford would kill Stockport off; instead they went back to sleep.

The reaction of the two managers was instructive. "It was a dire game which we should have won," said Graham Taylor, who still dreams of promotion. "But there's no excuse for lack of spirit. We made changes and still I was thinking, 'what the hell else can I do?'"

"If we continue with that kind of performance we'll be OK," said Kilner, whose sole goal is survival. "I don't think we had any poor performances and most of the side played well."

If that was playing well, heaven knows what they are like when playing badly. Watford at least know that it can't get any worse.

webTitle: Savage upstaged by a real chopper

fields.headline: Savage upstaged by a real chopper
fields.trailText: Five minutes from time a helicopter came and hovered over the ground. Perhaps Sven-Goran Eriksson, at Derby 30 miles away, had just heard of an Englishman he had not included. Danny Dichio had recently come on, remarkably adding to Sunderland's threat.
fields.body:
Five minutes from time a helicopter came and hovered over the ground. Perhaps Sven-Goran Eriksson, at Derby 30 miles away, had just heard of an Englishman he had not included. Danny Dichio had recently come on, remarkably adding to Sunderland's threat.

All eyes earlier had been on his team-mate Gavin McCann, an unexpected choice in Eriksson's giant squad, to see if the Swede knew his onions. The 23-year-old looked a crisp delicacy having a rotten day. Little went right for him in a team minus five regulars. With four suspended, there was no need for sympathy, except for those such as him trying to cover for weakness in depth.

Robbie Savage could make anyone's day rotten, tearing about like a Border collie personally responsible for closing down every member of the opposing flock. He ruined John Oster's. Booked earlier for putting a foot in on Muzzy Izzet, Oster flew into a challenge on Savage, who went down like a steeplechaser at Becher's. He then raged at Savage with such vigour that, had the foul not been a second yellow, he would have gone for foot and mouth.

Being upstaged by Izzet is less depressing. He stood above the mediocrity and would have been in the England squad had Kevin Keegan not shunned him into being a Turk. Notwithstanding the exits of Emile Heskey and Neil Lennon, leaving so much less in front or beside, his spirit is undimmed.

Dean Sturridge has helped, bringing the seasoned instincts of a poacher in the manner of Tony Cottee. He rose to head the first goal, making nonsense of Jody Craddock's six-inch height advantage.

Peter Taylor, who went on England duty last night, was at pains to defend Ade Akinbiyi, his more expensive striker, who is under fire from the crowd. Akinbiyi once got the better of Emerson Thome but the manager was right when, in praising his honesty, he said: "He is not always going to look the finished article." Is he ever? At least he was the finishing article, from all of three yards, when Sturridge bundled past the hefty Thome and crossed.

The goals came as a surprise. For most of the first half both sides, fourth and seventh in the land with designs on Europe, seemed happy to manoeuvre for set-pieces, wherein they saw their best chance of scoring. Leicester, as usual, looked better with Steve Guppy wide on the left; if only they would play him as an outright wing.

Sunderland's depletions left them as short of class as Leicester, though Niall Quinn was astute as ever in making space for his unfading control with head, chest and feet. He easily won his battle with Matt Elliott in the no-fly zone, pinging 20-yard headers to team-mates who lacked the belief to capitalise. He is a national treasure. That makes two on the day, one Irish, one Turkish. The helicopter was wasting its time.

fields.headline: Liverpool shoot for silver
fields.trailText: Birmingham City took Liverpool right on to the end of the road in Cardiff yesterday, and in doing so transformed a Worthington Cup final from one which had been merely better than usual into something approaching an epic.
fields.byline: David Lacey at the Millennium stadium
fields.body:
Birmingham City took Liverpool right on to the end of the road in Cardiff yesterday, and in doing so transformed a Worthington Cup final from one which had been merely better than usual into something approaching an epic.

For Trevor Francis and his at first industrious, then inspired Nationwide League side, the journey became a trail of tears as Liverpool, having been forced into extra-time by a penalty, proceeded to win the shoot-out by five penalties to four, the teams having finished level at 1-1 after two hours of patchy but always positive football.

Maybe the first English final to be played in Wales, after the closure of Wembley, was won by the better side overall. That almost goes without saying, given the greater quality and depth of Gérard Houllier's Liverpool squad.

The occasion, however, was given its best dramatic effect by the courageous counter-offensive launched by Birmingham in the first period of extra-time, when it seemed increasingly likely that Liverpool would be beaten by the extra quality Francis's players brought to their game.

That was all the more remarkable considering Birmingham played the extra half-hour with their captain, Martin O'Connor, reduced to a hobble by a knee injury, suffered as a result of the foul by Stéphane Henchoz which enabled Darren Purse to equalise from the penalty spot in the third minute of stoppage-time. By then Francis had used all three of his substitutes.

Had David Elleray taken a similar view of the lunge by Henchoz which sent Andy Johnson flying in the 104th minute, Birmingham might be holding their first major trophy since winning the League Cup in 1963. Elleray, however, judged that this time the Liverpool centre-back had taken the ball.

Andy Johnson's speed and close control had been causing Liverpool mounting discomfort once he had replaced the ineffective Dele Adebola after half-time. And after the persevering Geoff Horsfield had given way to the power in the air of Marcelo, Francis's Brazilian-born Portuguese, Birmingham had a combination up front capable of winning the game.

For much of normal time they took considerable credit for refusing to concede that the goal of typical elan scored by Robbie Fowler just before the half-hour would prove sufficient to take the cup back to Anfield. Yet until Purse's penalty it was hard to see how they were going to transform dogged resistance into goals.

Fowler's beautifully struck goal, along with the industry and intelligence of his all-round performance, may well have won him a place in the England attack against Spain at Villa Park on Wednesday. Sven-Goran Eriksson could hardly have failed to be impressed by Fowler's willingness to cover so much ground yet still be where it mattered when scoring chances arose.

In the 29th minute a long, steepling clearance from Sander Westerveld was touched on by the head of Emile Heskey and the ball bounced once before Fowler looped a 20-yard volley beyond Ian Bennett. Later Vladimir Smicer put a much easier chance wide after another nod down by Heskey.

For a considerable time thereafter, Birmingham struggled to break the grip Dietmar Hamann and Steven Gerrard established for Liverpool between the penalty areas. Even before the goal was scored Gerrard had broken clear past O'Connor, who brought him down and might have been sent off had a mistaken offside flag spared Elleray such a decision.

A strong reason why Liverpool started to lose their way in extra-time was the loss of Gerrard with cramp in the 76th minute. This brought on Gary McAllister, whose careful craftsmanship was not what Liverpool really needed at that stage, with Birmingham beginning to assert themselves as a serious attacking force.

In extra-time Jon McCarthy, playing only his second game back for Birmingham after a second broken leg, became more of an influence on the same wing, but the nearest Liverpool came to falling behind was when another substitute, Bryan Hughes, caught Westerveld out of position with a 35-yard lob which the Liverpool goalkeeper just managed to push wide.

During the last 15 minutes, with Birmingham virtually reduced to 10 men by O'Connor's injury and tiring fast, Liverpool reasserted their earlier authority. Maybe it would have been kinder to the Nationwide side had Hamann's 30-yard shot gone in instead of hitting a post.

In the event Birmingham managed to take the shoot-out to 12 kicks and Andy Johnson did not deserve to be the man who missed the decisive penalty. There was, however, no reason for Francis, his players or Birmingham's roaring supporters to feel blue. This, after all, was the stuff that cup finals should be made of.

fields.headline: Fulham in need of fortifying
fields.trailText: Gillingham's player-manager Andy Hessenthaler was preoccupied with the performance of the referee after the Kent club became the latest fall guys in Fulham's all-dancing, all-singing promotion campaign. However, Jean Tigana must now be pondering the more pressing issue of how his side will cope in the toughest theatre of footballing combat - the Premiership.
fields.body:
Gillingham's player-manager Andy Hessenthaler was preoccupied with the performance of the referee after the Kent club became the latest fall guys in Fulham's all-dancing, all-singing promotion campaign. However, Jean Tigana must now be pondering the more pressing issue of how his side will cope in the toughest theatre of footballing combat - the Premiership.

This hard-fought and somewhat scrappy win brought Fulham a 10th away success in a remarkable campaign and extended their lead in the First Division to 12 points.

The Fulham fans who were chanting "champions" at the end of the game were not being premature, just realistic. They might as well start planning their trips to Anfield, Highbury and Old Trafford now.

The Craven Cottage club entered this encounter in what was, by their standards, bad form - five points from their previous five games - and ended it with their first win at Gillingham for 13 years.

Second-half strikes from John Collins, who capitalised on a defensive mix-up between Adrian Pennock and Mark Patterson, and Luis Boa Morte, who sealed the win two minutes from time, were enough to diffuse a valiant home effort.

Nevertheless, Hessenthaler was incensed by the referee, Steve Baines, who turned down a valid first-half penalty appeal when Collins appeared to foul Marcus Browning inside the area.

"The referee was terrible. He's one of the worst referees we've had down here," Hessenthaler complained. "The assessor said he's not happy with him. We should have had a penalty and even the assessor said the foul was in the box and the man should have gone off."

Fulham's thoughts must now be concentrated on the Premiership. In truth, though they outplayed Gillingham, they will need to improve significantly on this performance if they have hopes of sustaining their presence among the elite.

Both Saturday's goalscorers have Premiership experience. Collins was involved in a relegation dogfight during an unhappy spell at Everton whereas Boa Morte won Premiership and FA Cup winners' medals with Arsenal but was largely a peripheral figure in Arsène Wenger's plans.

They are not the only players in Jean Tigana's stable who have had unhappy or ineffectual experiences at Premiership clubs. Eight of Fulham's starting 11 on Saturday have played in the top flight and among them Rufus Brevett, Kit Symons and Andy Melville have experienced the dejection of relegation.

Tigana will wish to emulate the likes of Ipswich and Leicester who have prospered at the highest level. However the Frenchman has the added pressure of Mohamed Al Fayed's seemingly limitless resources.

Fulham will need to strengthen substantially the quality of their playing staff for the Premiership. Only then will Tigana's footballing faith be truly tested.

fields.headline: Claridge anchors away from Portsmouth
fields.trailText: You felt sorry for Steve Claridge. Though ousted as the Portsmouth manager on Friday, he was put in charge for one last time here while his successor Graham Rix cast a proprietorial eye over the team from the stand.
fields.body:
You felt sorry for Steve Claridge. Though ousted as the Portsmouth manager on Friday, he was put in charge for one last time here while his successor Graham Rix cast a proprietorial eye over the team from the stand.

For 53 minutes Claridge paced on the sidelines until he could bear it no longer and substituted Luke Nightingale so he could do his pacing more constructively around West Brom's back line.

With his left sock pulled up and his right rolled down - a footballing semiotic for meaning business - the 34-year-old added zest but was not at his best. Instead, as a former Birmingham City man who flirted briefly with Wolves, he had to endure an unforgiving crowd.

"Claridge, Claridge, what's the score?" they quizzed as his side feebly slipped two goals behind. The condemned man could do nothing more defiant than empty his nose.

Afterwards he stood dolefully with the press resembling a humiliated schoolboy. Staring intently at the carpet and turning chewing gum round his mouth like a washing machine, Claridge muttered into his chest at first, but soon the words began to bite.

"It's been a bad week, the hardest of my career," he said. "I've learnt who my friends are, and I've lost a lot of faith in human nature. When you give someone a job you give it to them 100%, not 25%. I haven't had a chance. I wish now I hadn't taken the job."

Without naming the club's chairman Milan Mandaric, he made it clear that money was gold dust during his four months as caretaker-manager: "I've only been allowed to buy one player, Jamie Vincent, and I thought he was the best player out there today." Portsmouth lie three points above the drop zone, with two wins in their past 19 league matches.

Two neat goals killed them off. Richard Sneekes threaded the ball through for Jason Roberts to sew up his 15th of the season, and Ruel Fox back-heeled the ball for the defender Adam Chambers to sidefoot the clincher.

A first victory in five games placated the restless fans who had booed Gary Megson after the 2-2 draw with Crewe on Tuesday. "The result was uppermost," the manager opined. "The atmosphere here is strange, a bit tense and worried, which I didn't sense when we were fourth from bottom."

Claridge meanwhile was left to weigh up life under the Rix regime. "It's not a case of whether they want me to stay, it's whether I want to stay," he said morosely, and you sensed a 10th club in 16 years would not be far away.

webTitle: Celtic denied by late Libbra strike

fields.headline: Celtic denied by late Libbra strike
fields.trailText: The Frenchman Marc Libbra came off the bench to score a late equaliser for Hibernian last night, a goal that gives Celtic's hapless pursuers a glimmer of hope in the race for the Premier League title.
fields.body:
The Frenchman Marc Libbra came off the bench to score a late equaliser for Hibernian last night, a goal that gives Celtic's hapless pursuers a glimmer of hope in the race for the Premier League title.

Johan Mjallby's first-half strike had looked like giving Celtic the points and effectively the championship. But, on his debut, Libbra snatched a late equaliser to keep them 14 points behind Martin O'Neill's team while Rangers, victors at Dundee on Saturday, are now 13 points adrift with a game in hand.

Hibernian's manager Alex McLeish enhanced his reputation with his masterstroke in handing the Frenchman his debut. Coincidentally the visitors were the last team to hold Celtic at Parkhead last season - on April 22. But with Russell Latapy and Mixu Paatelainen out, even a below-strength Celtic would not have expected to drop their first points at home this season.

The former Hibs player Didier Agathe, whose every touch was greeted with jeers from the visiting fans, went close in the eighth minute when Alan Thompson found him on the edge of the box and the Frenchman blazed just wide of the post.

Celtic created another good chance three minutes later when Paul Lambert found Chris Sutton in space on the left flank and the striker crossed for Stilian Petrov in the centre, but the Bulgarian's right-foot shot flew just wide of the mark.

Celtic struck in the 23rd minute, Henrik Larsson rising to head Thompson's corner towards the goal only for John O'Neil to deny him on the line. But his Swedish team-mate Mjallby made no mistake to fire home from close range.

webTitle: All change for genius of Cole

fields.headline: All change for genius of Cole
fields.trailText: West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp admits he has had to alter the shape of his team to accommodate the genius of Joe Cole, whom he describes as "a bit of a free spirit on the pitch".
fields.body:
West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp admits he has had to alter the shape of his team to accommodate the genius of Joe Cole, whom he describes as "a bit of a free spirit on the pitch".

In an attempt to bottle this spirit, Bradford's manager Jim Jefferies incorporated a man-marker, Andy O'Brien, though that did not destroy the shape of his team as much as Cole did with his quick feet, lightning pace and awareness of team-mates. And one-on-one with Cole, O'Brien was hopelessly outnumbered.

Towards the end of the first half, three team-mates galloped to O'Brien's rescue to trap Cole on the touchline. But with a pirouette and a swivel of the hips he was free and running at Bradford's defence again.

It was a virtuoso performance by Cole, 19, who made both goals for Frank Lampard, the first with an outrageous backheel and the second with a clever run and pull-back. Lampard is the more likely to start in Sven-Goran Eriksson's first England team against Spain on Wednesday but it would be a shame if Cole were not allowed to sprinkle some of his stardust on the game.

"It would be hard to see where you could play Joey in a 4-4-2 system," Redknapp said, "though in a 4-3-1-2 he could play in the hole. Then again, Paul Scholes is great in there. But as Sven has said, if you've got a talent like Joey's you've got to adjust to take advantage of it, as we have done."

Bradford obviously cannot publicly admit that they are down. But Eoin Jess's effort was their first in over 10 hours of football and, when Lampard's winner went in 15 minutes from time, the sagging shoulders of their players told you that they don't just think it's all over, they know it is.

Their chairman Geoffrey Richmond knows it too. And in launching a scheme to offer supporters 25-year season tickets, he admitted that "nobody knows what the future will bring or which divisions Bradford City will be in as the years tick by".

Their season-ticket plan works out at a fiver a match, which some people might think a bit steep. But Redknapp insists that the Upton Park faithful get fantastic value for money, even though this was their first Premiership win of 2001. "We won't win championships but we do give our fans plenty of entertainment and I couldn't send out a team to play boring football," he said. "Unfortunately some people have a false idea of where this club should be.

"Even when Bobby Moore, Martin Peters and Geoff Hurst were playing, our average league position was 17th, which shows how useless the other eight of us were." The joke would have been lost on Bradford, who would love to repeat their 17th of last season, the last safety spot in the Premiership.

fields.headline: Sink or slim for Hartson
fields.trailText: The new Coventry were launched on Saturday, scrappier, tougher in midfield, more direct. "We have to go back to basics," Gordon Strachan said, recalling another desperate leader heading for oblivion.
fields.body:
The new Coventry were launched on Saturday, scrappier, tougher in midfield, more direct. "We have to go back to basics," Gordon Strachan said, recalling another desperate leader heading for oblivion.

This is Strachan's Plan Z. There will be no signings before the deadline. He will live by these players and this strategy, or Coventry will sink at last, after 36 major years.

It would not be fair to judge them on this performance and this pitch, but even the most sanguine of supporters must be worried. On Saturday Coventry had more shots than they had previously managed in a league game this season and scored as many goals, but the back line looked about as ragged as it has ever been, the wings contributed little and the expensive new spearhead turned out to be rather less sharp than a sky-blue blazer.

Whether through bad luck or bad judgment, Strachan has failed to come up with lasting solutions to Coventry's problems. Colin Hendry, who was meant to be the physically commanding centre-half that Premiership football demands, was busted after one game. Carlton Palmer, who was meant to anchor the midfield, lasted little longer. And Laurent Delorge, a winger bought for £1.25m two years ago, has not been sighted since his debut, except in the treatment room, where he and Steve Froggatt have taken up semi-permanent residence.

Strachan has tried six left-backs this season and this is at least his 11th strike pairing. He and Coventry are now counting heavily on John Hartson, which means the striker is carrying around a disproportionate weight of expectation in addition to all his excess subcutaneous baggage. He has been given the No5 shirt, which is appropriate if only because he is about half the player he was two years ago.

Strachan acted unconcerned, but panic would be a more appropriate response. Unless the striker can recover a little of his dynamism and physical confidence, Coventry will sink like a stone and a half of unwanted adipose tissue.

Hartson did score Coventry's equaliser, a scruffy, ironic response to Jonatan Johansson's cleanly delivered strike 26 seconds into the second half. Marcus Hall's pass somehow eluded John Aloisi's wild swing to reach the far post, where in Alan Curbishley's words Hartson "ends up squirming it in".

Tord Grip can have learned little worth noting except that, however English they sound, he cannot pick Fish and Chippo. Chris Powell was efficient enough in a restricted role, keeping David Thompson quiet. Richard Rufus, whose name Sven-Goran Eriksson has raised with Curbishley, did better, scoring Charlton's first goal and winning the ball off Hartson to start the attack that brought their second.

Powell said he was "ecstatic, really shocked, stunned, all the emotions you can think of" to be included in the England squad. Rufus, one suspects, would have been rather less effusive. When told that Grip had been watching, the defender said: "It's too late now."

It is nowhere near too late yet for Coventry, of course, but the fat boy is warming up.

webTitle: No one can catch us now, says Ferguson

fields.headline: No one can catch us now, says Ferguson
fields.trailText: When Arsenal come together for the galling task of analysing why their challenge to Manchester United has been washed away like a sandcastle at high tide, they will look back on this humiliation, remember the horrors of a record-equalling defeat and shudder with collective embarrassment.
fields.body:
When Arsenal come together for the galling task of analysing why their challenge to Manchester United has been washed away like a sandcastle at high tide, they will look back on this humiliation, remember the horrors of a record-equalling defeat and shudder with collective embarrassment.

By swatting Arsène Wenger's side like an irritating fly yesterday Sir Alex Ferguson's rampant team not only strutted a country mile clear of them at the top of the Premiership but scored six against Arsenal for the first time in nigh on half a century. The gap is now 16 points but in reality there were times here when it looked more like several light-years.

For Arsenal it was nothing short of humiliating, as if they had stumbled into a different, more terrifying world. And if it was not humbling enough to be crushed so comprehensively, suffering the ignominy of conceding five goals inside the opening half and a hat-trick for Dwight Yorke in the first 22 minutes, this effectively ended all questions about the destiny of the Premiership. The open-top bus can be booked, the extra supplies of silver polish ordered; United's seventh title in nine years is now a formality.

"It's our best result of the season," said Ferguson. "Football can make you look a fool but I think that's Arsenal finished now. When you look at the points gap and the goal difference I think it will be impossible for them to catch us now."

Even by their usual haughty standards the sumptuous quality of United's attacking thrusts, in particular throughout an opening 45 minutes that was spellbinding, provided the sort of intoxicating stuff that comes along so rarely that Ferguson must wish it could be bottled.

Combined with a level of Arsenal defending that fluctuated between naive and absurd, the onslaught was almost relentless from the moment, only three minutes in, when Paul Scholes's ingenuity beat Arsenal's malfunctioning offside trap before laying on an open goal for the rejuvenated Yorke.

Old Trafford had waited a long time for Yorke to replicate his best form but after Thierry Henry had snaffled a 16th-minute equaliser, flicking Robert Pires's pass beyond Fabien Barthez with the outside of his left foot, he became the pivotal figure, the foreman in a demolition job. Within two minutes Roy Keane's long ball sent him sprinting clear, in the sort of space that will have given Wenger kittens, to entice David Seaman off his line and slide his shot beyond the goalkeeper.

Not for the first time Arsenal's defence had gone awol and when the bewildering Igor Stepanovs misjudged the trajectory of a long, raking ball from David Beckham, Yorke was off and running again to slip the ball past Seaman for the third, banishing all thoughts of a player on the decline.

The pièce de résistance was concocted on 26 minutes. Yorke made a jackanapes of Stepanovs for the umpteenth time on the touchline and set off on the left before picking out Keane's lung-bursting run with a splendid cross. The captain's finish combined power and precision and, like a funeral procession, Arsenal's fans were already trudging away into the Mancunian gloom.

United's record 6-1 victory against Arsenal had stood since April 1952 and, when Nicky Butt bamboozled Gilles Grimandi on the right to tee up Ole Solskjaer for the fifth, Old Trafford was overcome by the heady prospect of dusting off the history books by emulating, if not bettering, that scoreline.

It did not look like happening, however, for although United remained dominant after half-time they failed to find the same width or penetration. But after Solskjaer had cracked a shot against the upright, Teddy Sheringham, having replaced Yorke on 75 minutes, swept in the sixth in the dying seconds.

Battered and beleaguered, Arsenal had been put firmly in their place. For a side who pride themselves on their parsimonious nature, the case for their defence, without Adams, Keown and co, was frankly indefensible and the inquest into their league campaign promises to be both tortuous and torturous.

"Are you City in disguise?" crowed United's fans, and they could have been talking about York.

"I have had worse experiences but the size of the score makes this a very bad one," said Wenger. "Defensively we were too poor. Nobody was communicating, we had no leaders and there were times when we looked like a youth team.

"We are not into March yet and it hurts me that the title is already over. It's not good for the league and I'm not proud of that."

fields.headline: Loan earns high interest
fields.trailText: Mark Burchill might have been playing for Birmingham City in the Worthington Cup final this weekend; he could have been watching from the bench as Celtic took on Hibernian; instead he finds himself with the fifth-placed club in the Premiership and chasing a place in Europe. How strangely fortunes change in football.
fields.body:
Mark Burchill might have been playing for Birmingham City in the Worthington Cup final this weekend; he could have been watching from the bench as Celtic took on Hibernian; instead he finds himself with the fifth-placed club in the Premiership and chasing a place in Europe. How strangely fortunes change in football.

Burchill was given an immediate start by Ipswich in place of the suspended Marcus Stewart and immediately put a tiger in the Tractor Boys' tank, setting up both their goals and having what looked like a certain penalty turned down as memories of Ipswich Town's wretched start to the year were consigned to the dustbin of history.

"I thought I'd be on the bench to start but the gaffer's put me in and it worked out all right," the 20-year-old Scot said. "Obviously I'm a striker and I want to score goals but if I can't score then I want to set them up for someone else."

If he seemed extra motivated it was only because he was desperate to add to his six international caps. "The Scotland manager Craig Brown has always said that if I play first-team football I'll be in the squad so hopefully if I play well with Ipswich I'll be back in the frame."

Ipswich have him on a three-month loan with an option to buy and although their manager would not reveal the fee being quoted, Birmingham had been asked for £1.5m - a snip at today's prices.

Over 90 minutes George Burley liked what he saw. "I thought Mark did very well. He can be very pleased with his debut in the Premiership. He looked lively, he had a few shots blocked, so overall he contributed a lot of things to the team."

Burchill, in fact, wasted no time in showing why he is such an exciting talent. He may be only 5ft 8in in his socks but he has lightning pace, superb control and the sort of acute positional sense that can unsettle any defence, as he showed in the seventh minute when he accelerated past Paul Gerrard. The goalkeeper simply took his legs away and seemed as surprised as anyone when the referee waved play on.

Everton had clearly come with a point in mind and they settled down to what was heading for a goalless draw when Graham Poll intervened again. Alex Nyarko had already been booked and when he mistimed his tackle on Titus Bramble the referee produced red to send off his seventh player this season.

Walter Smith was not impressed. "He made two fouls in a game that wasn't physical at all - and for someone to get booked twice in the second half can't be justified," the Everton manager said.

Until then Everton had looked reasonably solid, but when Burley began putting on more attackers the visitors had too much to think about and fell behind in the 82nd minute.

First Burchill put in a cross that was headed away by the new England recruit Michael Ball, but only to the onrushing Matt Holland, who half-volleyed it back into the net. Two minutes later Burchill crossed again and Alun Armstrong met the ball with a textbook downward header.

fields.headline: Howey holds out flapping Magpies
fields.trailText: The boos rang across Tyneside in riled recognition that all it took to rekindle Manchester City's slip-sliding season was a gargantuan performance from a pair of man-mountains and a scrap wolfed down by a ravenous Goat.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
The boos rang across Tyneside in riled recognition that all it took to rekindle Manchester City's slip-sliding season was a gargantuan performance from a pair of man-mountains and a scrap wolfed down by a ravenous Goat.

Some 33 years since they last won a league match at St James' Park, the Citizens trumped the Toon with something to spare on Saturday to record their first Premiership success in 11 matches and spice up the relegation scrap. With safety hovering only a tantalising point away, their manager Joe Royle was confident enough even to tempt fate at the end. "I think we're too good to go down," he smiled. "I've never thought anything different."

Newcastle have now gone 23 games without a sniff of a clean sheet, a fact made all the more galling as the visitors' colossal defensive display was masterminded by a former Magpie. Steve Howey was shipped out for £3.5m in the summer; he returned to inspire City's first clean sheet away from Maine Road since November alongside Richard Dunne.

"We desperately needed that," Howey said. "That can be our springboard. We've never had any doubt that we would stay up because we've got the self-confidence to achieve that. You can't buy team spirit. A team with good spirit and average players will beat a side full of great individuals but with poor spirit any day."

After a scrappy first half, brightened only by Wayne Quinn's stinging free-kick that flew just wide, City emerged into the snow flurries to dominate the second period. Tony Grant had already blazed over the bar when Andrei Kanchelskis, a livewire inspiration on the right, picked up a short free-kick, skimmed past a trio of ponderous opponents and squirted a pass through a clueless back line. Shaun Goater poked the ball into the bottom corner.

"Feed the Goat and he will score," came the joyous chant. Darren Huckerby, obviously in need of fattening up, missed an easier chance moments later.

Even then, Newcastle rarely threatened until Warren Barton's goal-bound shot was deflected over the crossbar in the dying seconds by Howey's backside. "I had to get something on the shot," added the defender. "It would have been devastating to have conceded, especially because they didn't deserve to get back into it."

If we defend like that from now on, we'll be all right."

It was hard to say the same of Newcastle. A week training in the La Manga sun was supposed to put colour on Geordie cheeks. But after Alan Shearer's cross was deflected by Danny Granville and Clarence Acuna nodded over an empty net early in the second half, they descended into sloppy lethargy and a third successive defeat.

Shearer's mind was as sharp as ever, but his body could not respond after two months on the treatment table. Kieron Dyer's shin problems re-surfaced; he drowned in the midfield muddle and later hobbled out of the England squad despite his manager's attempts at dissuasion. Shola Ameobi may follow suit from the Under-21s after sustaining a back injury.

"We're a broken outfit," the home manager Bobby Robson admitted. "We looked a yard off the pace. At one point Nobby Solano chased for a ball with [Danny] Tiatto, who started 10 yards behind him and still got there first. And Solano wants to play for his country again?" Peru's coach Julio Cesar Uribe is hoping to tempt the wing out of international retirement after naming him to play Honduras in Miami next month.

fields.headline: Gregory banishes his earthbound Angel
fields.trailText: A day of milestones and millstones for Aston Villa while as far as Derby County were concerned, a grey-haired woman in the main stand, who could barely bring herself to watch the final 10 minutes, cogently summed up the relief provided by three vital points: "We were rubbish but we don't care."
fields.body:
A day of milestones and millstones for Aston Villa while as far as Derby County were concerned, a grey-haired woman in the main stand, who could barely bring herself to watch the final 10 minutes, cogently summed up the relief provided by three vital points: "We were rubbish but we don't care."

This was John Gregory's third anniversary as manager of Villa, which given his chairman's past record might be viewed as a long-term stay. But if Gregory has a guardian angel watching over his relationship with Doug Ellis, it most certainly is not called Juan Pablo.

Here is an Angel who fears to tread in the penalty box, and who was pulled off by Gregory at half-time, all £9.5m worth of him, "for his own good". Rumours that the Colombian may return to River Plate this summer have already been denied, but on Saturday he looked as forlorn as a cat in the rain.

"Pablo is desperately short of confidence. He's probably too keen to impress and is not doing the simple things, but he's got to dig in and he can't run away from it; he's got to face it head on," said Gregory, while expressing the trenchant view that even allowing for "the amount of time the ball is in the air" in the Premiership, six games should have seen the goalless striker settle in by now.

It might also be argued that three years is long enough for a manager to get a firm grip on a club, but this has been a poor season for Villa, wretchedly poor considering their European ambitions.

For long periods, and almost the whole of the second half, they dominated Derby without ever looking convincing, although Andy Oakes saved well from Dion Dublin and Angel's substitute, Julian Joachim.

There had been much chuntering in Birmingham that Sven-Goran Eriksson, present at this match, had chosen to ignore both Paul Merson and Gareth Barry. On this performance the England manager's decision was vindicated. Barry clumsily felled Deon Burton, who duly scored the penalty, and Merson, although he never gave up looking for the ball, rarely hit a decent pass.

As for David Ginola, he was brought on too late. It could be argued that Gregory distrusts flair, unless it is directly related to sweat. If Merson has an off day, and if Ginola is not present, the Villa midfield is distinctly guileless. Angel was clearly used to having the ball at his feet in South America, while Dublin's head remained the prime target for Villa's midfield save for Merson.

Branko Strupar, who began the season so well, but who has just returned from a prolonged spell of injury, had the chances to make the game safe for Derby by half-time, but he is clearly not match fit. "Then we allowed Villa, like we have so many teams this season, to take control," said Craig Burley. "We stopped going forward and just defended deeper and deeper."

Fortunately Derby defended well - notably Danny Higginbotham, who made a number of excellent tackles and interceptions. But against a team with a more clinical cutting edge than Villa, Derby would have been in deep trouble. As it is, they are edging towards safety.

Villa, who have won only two of their past 14 Premiership matches, taking 11 points from 42, have a heel in the relegation mire, but no more. A bit more devil, and considerably more genuine Angel, should see them step clear.

webTitle: Boro fear worst as Draper ends run

fields.headline: Boro fear worst as Draper ends run
fields.trailText: Little brings more delight to Teesside than a Newcastle defeat, but the roars of approval at the announcement of United's result at home to Manchester City choked in thousands of throats as the full implications were recognised.
fields.byline: David Hopps at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
Little brings more delight to Teesside than a Newcastle defeat, but the roars of approval at the announcement of United's result at home to Manchester City choked in thousands of throats as the full implications were recognised.

Terry Venables' precise reorganisation of Middlesbrough had left them unbeaten for 10 league matches and, curiously since we are constantly told Bryan Robson is "still the gaffer", had made Venables the only No2 to win the manager of the month award.

But a first league defeat since early December, coupled with City's unexpected three points, brought a shiver of realisation that Boro are still only one point above the relegation zone. The snow that lashed the Riverside after the final whistle emphasised that their bleak winter is far from finished.

An impending four-match ban for Ugo Ehiogu will not alleviate the situation, encouraging Paul Ince to warn before the match of the dangers of unnecessary sendings-off. Yet Ince is so full of cartoon-like rage - the Elmer Fudd of the Premiership - that it was no surprise he himself was fortunate to stay on.

Southampton's goal three minutes after half-time, sweetly finished from the edge of the area by Mark Draper after James Beattie's cross from the right, stung Ince - at the peak of his game - into an immediate response. A sprint into the area (a rare sight these days) was ended by a reckless challenge from Southampton's keeper Paul Jones.

As goalkeepers can barely look at a forward's feet these days without conceding a penalty, to find Neil Barry allowing Jones to demolish Ince at chest height was ridiculous. Ince tore after the referee and, however inadvertently, made contact; a loss of control that deserved a red card. The yellow that followed was presumably a tacit admission by Barry that he had got it all wrong.

Some wondered whether Venables had got it wrong too. For the first time he played four at the back to combat Southampton's notional front three, although Hassan Kachloul played deeper. But the real defensive disruption occurred around half-time with the loss of Curtis Fleming to a shoulder injury and Steve Vickers because of impaired vision.

Then there was Ehiogu. Called up for an England squad so big it will require crowd-control measures, he did little to underline his worth. His discomfort on a heavy pitch contributed to Boro's nervy opening and he headed an excellent chance wide from Dean Gordon's cross 12 minutes from time.

Alen Boksic forever offered Boro hope, one sublime chip on the half-hour striking the underside of the bar, but Southampton, who had lost a three-goal lead against Tranmere in the Cup in midweek, held out.

Glenn Hoddle, almost white with delight, admitted: "If we had lost this, people would be asking about psychological damage and inquiring if we were going to be dragged into the relegation fight."

Instead the psychological scars are Middlesbrough's. They have barely put a foot wrong for 10 weeks, yet at the first sign of weakness their relegation fears return. Charlton visit on Saturday; victory is now imperative.

webTitle: The greatest night of Cup action you never saw

fields.headline: The greatest night of Cup action you never saw
fields.trailText: The great joy of growing up in the pre-Beatles era was that pop music arrived as a sort of rumour. There was little music radio to speak of in those days, and children's television was still Muffin The Mule, so you relied on word of mouth to excite you about new stuff.
fields.body:
The great joy of growing up in the pre-Beatles era was that pop music arrived as a sort of rumour. There was little music radio to speak of in those days, and children's television was still Muffin The Mule, so you relied on word of mouth to excite you about new stuff.

Some kid at school who had heard a Buddy Holly or Del Shannon record would try to describe it to you, and you would end up tramping all over town to find a record shop that would let you listen to this new tune. (It's all right. You are in the right section. With any luck we will be moving on to football soon.)

Nowadays, with the marketing types getting their talons into children ever younger (coming soon, Unborn Baby Gap), there is little chance of anyone likely to be at all interested - and, more importantly, having access to the money to buy a record - being unaware of it.

It is a little like that with football (there, told you) as well. Those of us tooled up with the technology can now enjoy any number of live games, but though there has been some tremendous action this week - Leeds's thrilling win in Belgium, Manchester United's demolition of Arsenal, the Worthington Cup final penalties - the most exciting night of the week harked back to the days when live televised matches were a rarity, and we had to work a little harder for our football-related thrills.

Because no one was televising the Cup replays between Wimbledon and Wycombe and Tranmere and Southampton, we were left with Jeff Stelling and his Gillette Soccer Special, the post-modern phenomenon that invites us to watch other people watching football.

On Wednesday night, the news from the front line was brought to us by Rodney Marsh, Paul Jewell and Steve Coppell hunched over monitors in the studio. Stone age really, but for once it left all the live action in the shade.

Who would have thought it? With Jewell and Coppell's tendency to be a touch taciturn, if not downright dour, the signs were not good; but the stirring deeds of the lower-division clubs more than compensated for any deficiencies in Sky's talent-booking system.

When I tuned in, the Tranmere match had already finished and the pictures we were seeing were of the Wycombe and Wimbledon players milling around in the centre circle waiting for their penalty contest to begin. These were great scenes for those viewers particularly interested in physiotherapists manipulating calf muscles, or for connoisseurs of water dousing and nose clearance. But the majority of us would possibly rather have seen the penalties themselves.

I considered phoning Sky to say: "Look, hang the agreement. Just once wouldn't hurt. I won't tell anyone if you don't." I half-thought they might do some rapid renegotiation to allow them to stay at Selhurst Park for the penalties. But no. Once water had been taken, muscles loosened and nasal cavities evacuated, the camera switched back to four guys in a studio watching the footy.

In a strange way this topsy-turvy coverage, the exact reverse of what happens when television broadcasts a football match in the conventional way, actually heightened the tension. Rodney Marsh was our guide through the spot-kicks. Someone would step up to take the kick, and Marsh would say something like, "It's so tense. He shoots. Low to the left." Then we would hear a cheer, and our interpreter would say, "Oooooh, that's amazing. Well done, son" - leaving us to decide whether it was the goalie or the penalty taker to whom he was referring.

Because the penalty contest was so attenuated, Sky felt the need to vary the pictures, so at one point we switched back to Tranmere and were able to watch John Aldridge watching the guys in the studio watching the football. This, I guess, must have been a post-post-modern phenomenon. I have rarely enjoyed watching - or rather, not watching - a night of football more.

All this and then the excitement of Sven-Goran Eriksson's first England squad, which covered such a wide spread of English football I was rather surprised not to be included myself. The catholic nature of the squad, offering something for everyone like a New Labour election manifesto, seemed like a clever device to disarm critics, but it didn't stop the football writer Jeff Powell whingeing for a full hour on Sky's Hold The Back Page.

Sven got a somewhat easier ride in an interview with Ian Wright on Radio 5 Live's breezy new Wright and Bright show. The cheeriness of Wrightie and Brightie (as you have to refer to them) is infectious. You can't dislike them - and believe me, as an occasional co-presenter of the show they displaced, I have tried - but someone ought to rid Wrightie of his habit of assuming the vocal mannerisms of his interviewee.

When he interviewed Thierry Henry he started talking like zis, whereas with Sven on Saturday he came dangerously close to doing the Muppets' Swedish chef. Still, should the lads fail to perform against Spain this week, that may be the least of Sven's worries.

fields.headline: £2m SCIE gets the go-ahead
fields.trailText: The new Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE) will be set up this summer with £2m government funding, ministers announced today.
fields.body:
The new Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE) will be set up this summer with £2m government funding, ministers announced today.

The plan, unveiled by the health minister, John Hutton, and the Welsh Assembly minister for health and social services, Jane Hutt, will give SCIE a key role in the government's strategy to raise the quality of social care provision throughout England and Wales.

Its role will be to research and disseminate information to social care professionals about what methods and services work best.

"We are determined to raise standards in social care provision and tackle current variations in care across the country," said Mr Hutton.

"Establishing best practice and disseminating this effectively has been a stumbling block within social care. This has led to inconsistent levels of quality throughout the country. SCIE will determine what works best in social care, allowing us to improve consistency in the quality of practice and service delivery."

The institute will be charged with reviewing research and practice and setting up a database of good, evidence-based methods and services. It will also have to produce best practice guidelines to be disseminated across the sector. The guidelines will feed into the performance-monitoring standards set by the social services inspectorate. They will also inform the general social care council's and the national care standards commission's standards, when those two bodies are set up.

As has been widely predicted, the National Institute for Social Work (NISW) will be setting up SCIE, along with the Department of Health and the Welsh assembly.

"We are committed to raising standards in Wales and welcome participating in extending knowledge about best practice in social care," said Ms Hutt. "We recognise the value in sharing knowledge and working in partnership in this field."

webTitle: Zoff cuts loose but Juve tighten up

fields.headline: Zoff cuts loose but Juve tighten up
fields.trailText: Defence, defence and yet more defence. That's what Dino Zoff has always stood for. So when the coach with the dirtiest smokers' cough in Serie A took over as coach of Lazio, the safety-first approach seemed certain to follow him.
fields.body:
Defence, defence and yet more defence. That's what Dino Zoff has always stood for. So when the coach with the dirtiest smokers' cough in Serie A took over as coach of Lazio, the safety-first approach seemed certain to follow him.

Instead, the opposite has happened. Lazio are loaded; scoring goals for fun, playing loose at the back and looking like no Zoff side has ever looked before. And this weekend the fun continued, as they beat Verona 5-3.

Lazio led 2-0, 3-1 and 4-2 but Verona, who went down to ten men after 53 minutes when Martino Melis was sent off, wouldn't let go - and it was only in injury time, when Hernan Crespo completed his hat-trick, that they were finally safe. Karel Poborsky and Pavel Nedved also scored for Lazio, while Mauro Camoranesi, Alberto Gilardino and Michele Cassato were on target for Verona.

Crespo is now joint top goalscorer in Serie A with 14 goals, the same tally as fellow Argentine Gabriel Batistuta of Roma. But after the game the Lazio striker insisted he had other things on his mind.

"I am happy to have scored three times but I am not thinking about being the top scorer in Serie A," he said. "What I really care about is my team and our chances to finish first at the end of the season."

Zoff wasn't completely happy either. "I was pleased with the way Lazio played during the first half," he said, "but then we became too self-confident and although we were playing 11 against 10, we let Verona play as they wanted."

Juventus destroy AC Milan

When Fabio Capello agreed a new contract with Roma he was given a whopping £2.5m a year salary, a plush villa in the Aventine hills and his own masculine-yet-sensitive aftershave "Don Fabio." Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti clearly coveted similar goodies - but after weeks of hard negotiations he's come up short. Way short.

Under the terms of his new one-year contract extension, Ancelotti will be paid just £750,000 next year. And he doesn't sound completely happy about it, telling reporters: "I've been told that the more you earn, the more people respect you."

But who needs respect, when there's the chance to play for £1m? On top of his new wages, Juventus have worked out a clever bonus scheme whereby the more trophies Carlo wins, the more lira Carlo gets. Qualifying for the Champions League is worth a cool £175,000, as is winning the Coppa Italia. But the really large lucre comes from lifting the Scudetto (£300,000) and the Champions League (£350,000).

And rather cleverly, Carlo has boosted his chances by getting Juventus to agree to bring in two world-class players - Lilian Thuram and Patrick Vieira according to the Italian press - in the close season.

Not that Juventus need reinforcements. Last night they disposed of AC Milan 3-0 with goals from Igor Tudor, Filippo Inzaghi and Zinedine Zidane. It could have been more: Juve, inspired by Alessandro Del Piero were dominant; Milan - Andrei Shevchenko apart - were docile. Juve stay second, while Milan drop to ninth.

"Fortunately for me I scored, because I can't say I played a good match," Zidane admitted afterwards. "Del Piero's return to form has done the team a lot of good. He knows how to get us going forward."

After the game, rumours were swirling around that Alberto Zaccheroni was going to be sacked - rumours quickly denied by AC Milan vice-president Adriano Galliani. "It is time to clear all misunderstandings," he said. "Zaccheroni's job on the bench is not at risk. He can continue his job as he always has." Even so, nobody expects Zaccheroni to be at the club come the summer.

Fatih says farewell

Their relationship had more bust-ups than Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee's marriage (although thankfully not the steamy video available for download off the internet) but finally, after seven stormy months at Fiorentina, Fatih Terim has told president Vittorio Cecchi Gori he's had enough, and resigned.

The news comes as little surprise: Terim had refused to sign an extension to his current contract, and was - according to the rumour mill - going to join Milan at the end of the season. The final straw came after the pair had a stormy meeting following the Viola's 2-2 draw at home to Brescia on Saturday.

Besiktas coach Nevia Scala is favourite to take over at the club after Roberto Mancini was told by the Italian FA he didn't have the necessary qualifications to coach a Serie A team.

Roma win. Again.

"We were unfortunate to lose. We put up one of the best ever displays by an Italian team in England. We showed composure and dominated the game." So said Fabio Capello after Roma's Uefa Cup defeat against Liverpool on Thursday night. But there were no words of regret, no verbal attacks against a dodgy Spanish referee this weekend as his side eased to a 2-0 away win at Vicenza.

The Giallorossi left it late: substitute Vincenzo Montella fired home a left-foot shot ten minutes from time to open the scoring, and Brazilian Emerson added a second three minutes later to ensure the win.

It wasn't all good news for Roma either, as Batistuta limped off after 29 minutes with another knee injury. "Obviously I'm worried because Batistuta is the best striker you could have," Capello admitted afterwards. "It's not the same problem as before. "It's a pulled collateral ligament.

"For the past three weeks he has been training well and we are not lucky," he added. "But I'm happy for Roma, and not only because of how we reacted to Batistuta's injury. We showed we know how to win this kind of match. We are always dangerous, and we never take risks."

Roma stay six points clear of Juventus, with Lazio a further two points back. And with two home games against Internazionale and Brescia and a relatively easy March to follow, don't expect Capello's men to give up their lead any time soon.
