fields.headline: Straw spells out prison plans
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today unveiled a package of supervised rehabilitation schemes designed to break the cycle of repeat offending as part of the government's new crime reduction strategy.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, today unveiled a package of supervised rehabilitation schemes designed to break the cycle of repeat offending as part of the government's new crime reduction strategy.

Prisoners will be offered better drug treatment, education and skills training, and help with jobs and housing on release. But Mr Straw said those who continue to offend would face harsher penalties with judges being able to take greater account of previous convictions when passing sentences.

A third of the £700m programme will be spent on rehabilitation, which will also create 2,500 more prison places.

Mr Straw told the Commons that rules on allowing juries to see evidence were outdated and should be reformed. He said: "We need to make sure that law enforcement agencies have the right tools, that prosecutors and courts are operating with fair and simple rules of evidence and that prisons and probation deliver punishment that works to protect the public and prevent reoffending."

The 10-year crime reduction plan, Criminal Justice: The Way Ahead, states: "One option for simplification would be to allow evidence of previous convictions where relevant."

Ministers believe that 100,000 offenders are responsible for half the country's crime. Around 90,000 people are released from British jails each year, of whom 46,000 have served sentences of less than 12 months. About 60% of those who serve shorter sentences are re-convicted within two years.

Mr Straw told MPs that he wanted to stop re-offending by introducing "rigorous" supervision for those released after short jail sentences.

Under the proposed custody-plus system, criminals would be called back before courts to assess how well they were progressing, for example to check whether they were staying off drugs.

The Conservatives have argued that would mean more criminals released early in their sentence.

However, Mr Straw said it could mean those who would have escaped with a community sentence spending a short spell in jail followed by supervision. Anyone released on licence following a longer sentence would also automatically be back behind bars if they breach their conditions of release.

In a speech at the Peel Community Centre in London's King's Cross earlier today the prime minister, Tony Blair, said the strategy offered prisoners a "new deal" to escape a life of crime.

Mr Blair, the first serving prime minister to visit a jail, said they must seize the opportunity or face the harsh consequences.

"Every prisoner leaving custody who needs follow up support or supervision should get it - whatever the length of their sentence," said Mr Blair. "For those who reject this helping hand the message will be equally clear.

"Rigorously enforced punishments which get progressively tougher the more times an offender returns to court. With prison as an option for those who breach community sentences or offend on bail."

The home office minister, Paul Boateng, said: "The evidence shows prisoners are less likely to reoffend if you do make sure that they are supervised when they leave prison. All prison sentences ought to carry with them an element of supervision and control when they come to an end."

However, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, claimed that custody plus would lead to a further 32,000 prisoners being released early each year.

Home Office figures showed 11,500 criminals were given sentences of between six and 12 months each year, making them eligible for early release under "custody-plus", if it were introduced, she said.

This would add to the 15,000 released early each year under the home curfew scheme and the 5,400 whom Home Office minister Charles Clarke has estimated will receive shorter sentences because of planned restrictions on jury trial, Miss Widdecombe added.

Opposition leader William Hague said the government's plans were just another "eye-catching initiative", which would have little impact on crime.

"Last year 'TB' owned up to being 'perceived as soft' on crime and asked that he be 'personally associated' with 'eye-catching initiatives'," said Mr Hague.

"Only yesterday, Jack Straw's special adviser said that their new crime plan 'doesn't look very impressive'. So when Tony Blair and Jack Straw offer their 10-year strategy for crime today, they hope the public will fail to take their previous record into account."

Other initiatives in the new crime strategy include a "superbobby" bonus for senior police who chose to stay on the beat rather than be promoted to desk jobs.

But Mr Straw was unable to set out his final plans to shake up the court system because Lord Justice Auld, who began a review two years ago, still has not published his report.

Latest Home Office figures show overall crime dropped by a negligible 0.2% in the 12 months to September 2000, but headline-grabbing violent crime rose by 8%.

fields.headline: Main points of prison plan
fields.trailText: The government has announced a 10-year crime reduction plan, which aims to break the cycle of re-offending through supervised rehabilitation services.
fields.body:
The government has announced a 10-year crime reduction plan, which aims to break the cycle of re-offending through supervised rehabilitation services.

The main points of Criminal Justice: the Way Ahead are

 Harsher sentences for persistent offenders with judges able to take their previous convictions into account;

 Jail terms of 12 months replaced by the three-month custody plus sentence  prisoners receive intensive supervision after their release with better drug treatment, education, training and housing support;

 A new joint central body to set out a police service-wide strategic approach to information technology, scientific and technical developments;

 Increasing police numbers, with supperbobby bonuses for senior officers who chose to remain on the beat rather than taking a desk job;

 Allowing private security guards to have a role in public safety  under police supervision;

 An extra 2,500 prison places;

 The creation of a specialist cadre of prosecutors to deal with organised and serious crime:

 Introduction of victim personal statements, so victims (including bereaved relatives in homicide cases) can give a statement in their own words saying how the crime has affected their lives;

 A new role for the crown prosecution service in keeping victims informed about the progress of cases;

 A possible victims fund to ensure victims are more swiftly compensated;

 A consultation on a new victims sharter, to include whether to establish a victims ombudsman to champion victims interests.

webTitle: Croatians jailed for war crimes in Bosnia

fields.headline: Croatians jailed for war crimes in Bosnia
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in Yugoslavia
fields.trailText:
A senior Bosnian Croat official and a Croatian military commander were convicted today of war crimes against Bosnian Muslims, setting a precedent for political responsibility for atrocities committed on the battlefield.
Special report: war crimes in Yugoslavia
fields.body:
A senior Bosnian Croat official and a Croatian military commander were convicted today of war crimes against Bosnian Muslims, setting a precedent for political responsibility for atrocities committed on the battlefield.

The UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague convicted Dario Kordic - the most senior Bosnian Croat official in UN custody - of authorising murders and war crimes against Bosnian Muslims. He was sentenced to 25 years' imprisonment.

The tribunal also convicted Mario Cerkez, a Croat military commander, of war crimes in leading attacks against Muslim villages during the Bosnian war in 1993-94. Cerkez was given a 15-year sentence.

The court said Kordic helped to plan and organise a systematic campaign of ethnic cleansing, driving Muslims from an area the Bosnian Croats wanted to be joined to the newly created state of Croatia. He was the head of the nationalist Croatian political party in his Bosnian hometown and a vice president of the Croatian defence council, which guided the military.

The British presiding judge, Richard May, said Kordic was involved in crimes "characterised by ruthlessness and savagery and in which no distinction was made as to the age of its victims: young and old were either murdered or expelled".

Kordic was found not guilty of being among those who set the policy of ethnic cleansing, but he was "enthusiastic" in carrying out the campaign and played an instrumental part, the judgment said. Although he was only a politician, Judge May told Kordic: "You played your part as surely as the man who pulled the trigger."

The two men were charged with a total of 44 counts of murder, persecution, plunder and other war crimes or crimes against humanity. Kordic was convicted on 12 counts, and Cerkez on 15. They have already spent more than three years in custody, so their prison terms will be reduced accordingly, the court said.

The worst of the massacres was in Ahmici on April 16 1993, when Croatian militiamen stormed into Muslim homes, gunned down entire families and set houses ablaze. Survivors of the bullets were burned alive.

Before the attack began, 356 Muslims and 87 Croatians lived in the village. Immediately afterward, no Muslims remained. Croatian homes were left untouched.

The court found that Kordic was involved in planning that raid, but Cerkez was acquitted in that incident.

Prosecutors had asked that both accused receive life sentences. In a first reaction to the ruling, they said Monday the "light" sentences did not match the severity of the crimes.

"Our view is that the sentences are not appropriate," said prosecutor Ken Scott. Kordic's role "was substantially greater than appears to be in the judgement."

Mr Scott said the ruling shows how difficult it is to punish those who order - but do not participate in - atrocities. Any appeal must be lodged within 15 days.

webTitle: Kennedy plans tax boost for NHS

fields.headline: Kennedy plans tax boost for NHS
fields.standfirst: Lib Dems' alternative budget (pdf)
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, has called for a new 50p in the pound upper tax rate to pay for an increase in health spending.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, has called for a new 50p in the pound upper tax rate to pay for an increase in health spending.

Setting out an alternative budget ahead of the official statement next Wednesday from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, Mr Kennedy announced proposals for a £1,000 pay rise for Britain's worst-off nurses and midwives, and a five year plan for an expansion of doctors and nurses numbers.

Speaking at the launch of the Lib Dems' "alternative budget" this morning Mr Kennedy said: "People know that you can't get something for nothing. The other parties can't keep pretending that you can cut taxes without cutting public services."

The party  which is in coalition alliance with Labour in both the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly  wants to provide an extra 3,300 training places for doctors and an additional 11,400 for nurses and midwives of five years.

Mr Kennedy also pledged to restore free NHS eye and dental check-ups for all, providing 11,000 extra hospital beds over five years to cut waiting times and paying for all long-term personal care for the elderly.

This plan has already been agreed in Edinburgh for Scottish pensioners after the Scottish Lib Dem leader, Jim Wallace, gave Labour an ultimatum.

The revenue garnered from the new top rate of income tax would also pay for a £500m investment in dental services.

On education the party announced a scheme to fund an additional 5,000 secondary school teacher places with the Lib Dems' "penny for education" tax on the basic rate of income tax.

That would also pay for classroom assistants for five to 11-year-olds, and cut class sizes to 25, the party claim.

In a bid to head off criticism of being the only party advocating tax increases, the Lib Dems will also propose an annual "tax contract" with the British people, promising to spell out exactly what public money is spent on, and how any changes have affected income tax payers.

The contract would be posted to every household in the UK.

The Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, said the contract would make the Lib Dems the first party to forego the option of "stealth taxes", which he said boosted the total tax-take but went largely unnoticed by voters because they did not affect income tax.

The proposals come amid a flurry of big policy announcements from all the major parties, stoking up the prospect of an early April election in the wake of Gordon Brown's budget on March 7.

Speaking at the launch of the Lib Dems' "alternative budget" this morning Mr Kennedy said: "People know that you can't get something for nothing. The other parties can't keep pretending that you can cut taxes without cutting public services." The party  which is in coalition alliance with Labour in both the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly  wants to provide an extra 3,300 training places for doctors and an additional 11,400 for nurses and midwives of five years. Mr Kennedy also pledged to restore free NHS eye and dental check-ups for all, providing 11,000 extra hospital beds over five years to cut waiting times and paying for all long-term personal care for the elderly. This plan has already been agreed in Edinburgh for Scottish pensioners after the Scottish Lib Dem leader, Jim Wallace, gave Labour an ultimatum. The revenue garnered from the new top rate of income tax would also pay for a £500m investment in dental services. On education the party announced a scheme to fund an additional 5,000 secondary school teacher places with the Lib Dems' "penny for education" tax on the basic rate of income tax. That would also pay for classroom assistants for five to 11-year-olds, and cut class sizes to 25, the party claim. In a bid to head off criticism of being the only party advocating tax increases, the Lib Dems will also propose an annual "tax contract" with the British people, promising to spell out exactly what public money is spent on, and how any changes have affected income tax payers. The contract would be posted to every household in the UK. The Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, said the contract would make the Lib Dems the first party to forego the option of "stealth taxes", which he said boosted the total tax-take but went largely unnoticed by voters because they did not affect income tax. The proposals come amid a flurry of big policy announcements from all the major parties, stoking up the prospect of an early April election in the wake of Gordon Brown's budget on March 7. fields.headline: The outsiders
fields.standfirst: A former Frinton undertaker and his wild-eyed lieutenant lead Britain's fourth biggest party in the European parliament. They're men with a mission - to get us out of the EU. So how are Jeffrey Titford and Nigel Farage coping with life in the belly of the beast?
fields.trailText: A former Frinton undertaker and his wild-eyed lieutenant lead Britain's fourth biggest party in the European parliament. They're men with a mission - to get us out of the EU. So how are Jeffrey Titford and Nigel Farage coping with life in the belly of the beast?
fields.body:
It is 10.19pm when the party leader rises to make his speech to parliament. When he sits down, the clock has moved on to 10.20pm. There is total silence. It is broken only by the sound of an orgasmic stage-whispered scream of approval from the balcony: "Yessssssssss!" It is coming from the leader's speechwriter: "He did it! He did it! To the second! One minute 30 seconds precisely. Perfect!" By now the next speaker is already on his feet. He is greeted with silence too. Silence is the characteristic response to speeches here, especially when it is well past dinner time in the best city for eating out in Europe.

This is the European parliament in Strasbourg, where the debate - on the harmonisation of laws relating to food supplements - is being attended by precisely 17 of the 626 parliamentarians, plus 18 members of staff, eight people in the public galleries and 33 interpreters (three for each of the European Union's 11 official languages). The vast and stunning egg-shaped chamber is lit for the occasion by enough wattage to illuminate a fair-sized third world capital.

The strict time limit is one of the mercies. Hence the speechwriter's delight: a fraction longer than the allotted 90 seconds and the microphone would have been switched off. But the silence that greeted this particular leader's speech was more than normally profound.

The speaker was Jeffrey Titford of the UK Independence party, which - according to its 7% win of the vote in the 1999 European elections - is the fourth-largest party in Britain. (The big four party leaders are thus Tony Blair, William Hague, Charles Kennedy and Titford.) It is also the only one of the dozens of parties represented in this place totally committed to withdrawal from the EU. Titford was against harmonisation, surprisingly enough, arguing that British law was perfectly adequate. He's always against. He is the clergyman addressing the sinners in the whorehouse. Or Lucifer in the cathedral, depending on your point of view.

Somewhere between a half and three-fifths of Britain's electorate agree with Titford that Britain should seek an amicable divorce from the EU, and in 1999 Ukip (pronounced you-kip) won three MEPs. However, the former party leader, Michael Holmes, has not been sighted in almost a year, partly through ill-health, partly through disaffection. He is rumoured to be on the brink of joining the Greens, leaving just Titford and his sidekick, Nigel Farage.

Holmes's disappearance is merely one strand in a skein of vituperation and hatred that characterises Ukip . Earlier this month, the party's founder, Dr Alan Sked, claimed in the Spectator that the party was now enmeshed with the extreme right. The front page advertised " Ukip and the fascists".

Sked's evidence seemed slender. Much rested on a meeting between Farage and a party member who also belonged to the openly racist British National party. Farage says this was someone recruited by Sked, and that the meeting was to tell the man he was unwanted. If there was serious evidence linking the party with racists, at least 600 people in Strasbourg would be delighted to use it. But even Chris Huhne, the Liberal Democrat MEP who is one of their sternest critics, admits: "They're not fascists, they're not corrupt and they're not morons. Some of their members are headbangers, though."

They certainly are. The party's Scottish organiser has just been kicked off the executive for a year after questioning, in letters to newspapers, the extent of the Holocaust. Farage claims Ukip is the victim of "entryism". For what it's worth, the two men sit dead-centre of the parliament's semi-circle, close to the Lib Dems but at the back: traditional refuge of the most truculent members of any class. They are in a loose alliance known as EDD (Europe of Democracy and Diversities): a ragbag of 16 anti-federalists, comprising six French rustics, four Danes, three Dutch Calvinist ministers and the two Britons, but not rightwingers such as Jean-Marie Le Pen.

Even in the EDD, the Britons are out on a limb. Farage and Titford want Britain out, plain and simple. Thus John Bowis, the former Tory minister who is now an MEP, can say: "They are a tiny, tiny extreme element of a fringe part of the parliament. I just think they're irrelevant." But they may be very relevant in many rural constituencies come the general election. And they do at least have a coherent position - unlike the Tories, whose representatives here are horribly split.

Ukip, however, is an incoherent party, and its internal schisms are certainly worthy of the far right. It was founded in 1993 by Sked, a lecturer at the London School of Economics, and bumbled on quietly until the 1997 election, when it was totally swamped in the anti-Europe market by Jimmy Goldsmith's big-money, high-profile Referendum party. Then Goldsmith died, leaving a vacuum which Ukip filled with vicious infighting. But at the 1999 European elections, it was suddenly well-placed to pick up protest votes. And, since Britain was now using a regional proportional representation system, it was even better placed to turn them into seats. "It was a delicious double irony," says Farage, elected from the south-east region. "For a parliament I want no part of, under a system I despise, I found myself blinking into the cameras at one in the morning saying how proud I was."

With just a few more votes, Ukip might have won five seats. But when Holmes, the abrasive millionaire who had succeeded Sked, was dumped and then had a stroke, only this odd couple were left.

Titford is usually referred to as the Frinton undertaker (Frinton-on-Sea is generally presumed to be a good place for the trade). Actually, he had a string of funeral businesses on the east coast until he sold up in 1989 and retired at 55 to concentrate on sea fishing and golf. He had been in politics before, as a Tory, reaching the dizzy heights of chairman of the public health committee (and vice-chairman of recreation and gardens) on the old Clacton urban district council.

Titford was a bit bored by retirement, but he has now ridden his little anti-Euro hobby-horse out of control. In 45 years of marriage, his job never took him much further than Harwich. Now he is away perpetually, spreading Frinton's world-view, his wife is "supportive but a bit exasperated". Except when talking about Sked ("he's demented"), Titford is an emollient man, a sort of Willie Whitelaw figure, and an ideal leader for such a fractious party - "8,000 members and 9,000 egos", as one supporter put it.

Titford says little, which means he is outshone by Farage, a 36-year-old metals broker with wild eyes and the air of a successful estate agent. Both men are rather obviously British: non-linguists in a building of suave polyglots. Together, they can come over like Caldicott and Charters, the old buffers who kept talking about the Test score while travelling Europe in The Lady Vanishes. But they are not obvious xenophobes (Farage's wife is German) and have a nice - very British - line in self-deprecating humour. Indeed, the Ukip 's European parliament contingent laugh a lot, a rarity in Strasbourg.

They have a fair bit to laugh about. It is not difficult for them to embarrass the establishment, and their most successful ongoing stunt has been to pool the excess on their travel expenses and use it to fund the defence of "the metric martyr", the Sunderland greengrocer prosecuted last month for selling fruit in pounds and ounces. The parliament has demanded the MEPs return £11,500.

Last Wednesday, Titford and Farage were summoned to appear before Richard Balfe, a long-serving Labour MEP who is on the College of Quaestors, a souped-up privileges committee. The meeting was inconclusive. Balfe refused even to confirm it had taken place.

"Can you tell me what the issue is?" I asked Balfe.

"Of course not. It's the College of Quaestors, not a public meeting," said Balfe indignantly.

"Isn't it public?"

"It never has been. Whoever I talked to, [it] is between me and them."

In a Europe full of Balfes, it is not difficult to portray the whole project as ludicrous.

It is easy to subvert the parliamentary process as well. At the EDD group meeting last Tuesday, it was decided on the spur-of-the-moment to turn up en masse at that night's plenary session to try to get the food supplement measure sent back, and thus delayed for ages. It was not a well-planned plot, but the European parliament's sittings are so thinly attended it did not need to be. Their procedural move failed by just one vote: 16-15, with 595 members missing, presumed at dinner.

This would have been a routine oppositional ploy at Westminster, but other (non-British) MEPs were incensed. "Immoral!" they kept saying. The British view is more phlegmatic. It is accepted that the debating chamber is a waste of time. Except for votes (members have to vote to get paid), the room is empty even when it is not dinner-time. "The place where you change minds is in committee," says Huhne. "You can actually alter legislation quite effectively there, and that's where Ukip doesn't play a part. They're a waste of space."

"Yes, it's true," says Richard North, the Ukip staffer who was so proud of his leader's timekeeping. "If you're very, very good, and work very, very hard, you can get to change a couple of words. Wow!"

"I'm supposed to be on the fisheries committee," says Farage. "The cod recovery scheme was introduced with no reference to the committee whatever, because total competence rests with the commission. There's no point in going. We send a staff member to observe instead. We haven't come here to do a Billy Graham bit and convert everybody. We haven't come to change Europe. We've come to find out how it works and what it costs, and take that message back to the British people."

They take the message round tirelessly, despite Mrs Titford's reservations. And there is no doubt it keeps being well received. What that means in electoral terms remains to be seen in May, and in the referendum on the euro that will follow. But clearly few people in Britain doubt that much of what goes on in European institutions is damnable. The question, which we all have to ask ourselves, is whether it is an acceptable price to pay for the greatness of the project.

The two Ukip men left doubt behind long ago. In the members' cafe I asked how they would vote if the European commission proposed a motion in favour of motherhood and apple pie.

"I'd abstain," said Farage, "on the grounds that it's none of Europe's business."

"I'd vote against," said Titford. "There'd probably be a hidden agenda."

fields.headline: Microsoft appeals against anti-trust ruling
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: The US software giant Microsoft began its appeal today against the break-up of the firm for anti-competitive practices.
fields.body:
The US software giant Microsoft began its appeal today against the break-up of the firm for anti-competitive practices.

Some commentators have said that the outcome of the legal showdown, at the US court of appeals for the District of Columbia, may depend as much on the judge who made the original ruling as on the legal arguments.

US district judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's comments outside the courtroom - comparing the Microsoft chairman, Bill Gates, to Napoleon and suggesting company officials were not "grown-ups" - have injected extra controversy into the case.

Legal experts have said the comments have made the job more difficult for government lawyers who are trying to preserve their historic antitrust victory.

William Kovacic, a law professor at George Washington university, said: "Nothing good will co me to the government plaintiffs from all of this.

"In conscious or unconscious ways, the court of appeals will feel fewer inhibitions to second-guess Jackson's findings concerning crucial pieces of evidence."

Microsoft has "a 50% chance of walking completely" thanks to the judges post-trial statements, University of Baltimore law professor Bob Lande said. Before the comments, he gave the government a two-to-one edge. In interviews with reporters and authors writing books on Microsoft's legal ordeal, Judge Jackson made scathing attacks on Mr Gates, the company's legal team and the US district court which is hearing the company's appeal today and tomorrow.

The district appeals court has scheduled seven hours of arguments, which began at 1430 GMT today, and will be completed by tomorrow. This is an unusually large amount of time for the argument, even more than the parties requested.

The extra time will be spent questioning Judge Jackson's factual findings, in which he laid out how he thought Microsoft used anti-competitive practices and harmed consumers, the appellate judges said.

Publicly, the justice department and Microsoft have both played down the significance of Judge Jackson's words.

Generally, appeals are heard by only three judges. One former member of the court, Whitewater prosecutor Kenneth Starr, said it was unprecedented for all the judges to hear it.

Mr Starr, who now works for ProComp, a group financed by Microsoft competitors, said the court had scheduled more time because it wanted to be taken more seriously and reduce the chances of its findings being overturned.

webTitle: BMA slams government for family doctors 'in crisis'

fields.headline: BMA slams government for family doctors 'in crisis'
fields.trailText: Low morale and chronic staff shortages have plunged family doctors into "crisis", the British Medical Association warned today.
fields.body:
Low morale and chronic staff shortages have plunged family doctors into "crisis", the British Medical Association warned today.

GPs are facing a "daily struggle" to give their patients the care they need while trying to take on board government initiatives using "woefully insufficient resources", says the BMA's general practitioners committee (GPC).

GPC chairman Dr John Chisholm has launched a furious attack on the government and called on GPs to start a media offensive on pay and workforce issues.

In an open letter to the UK's 36,000 family doctors, Dr Chisholm said this year's 2.3% pay award was the "last straw" for GPs.

The GPC campaign follows a survey of Scottish GPs, which revealed that 60% were considering a career change or taking early retirement.

More than half said morale was poor and more than 70% said it had worsened in the past five years.

Dr Chisholm is starting negotiations with the health secretary, Alan Milburn, this week in an attempt to drive up a better deal on pay and conditions for GPs.

Dr Chisholm's letter says: "General practice in the UK is in crisis. Morale within the profession has plunged to new depths.

"Quite clearly, this government's interest in the problems of general practice is superficial.

"It has complacently shovelled more and more work on to general practitioners without giving the profession the numbers needed to carry it out. Now we are saying that we have had enough."

As well as dissatisfaction over this year's pay settlement, Dr Chisholm said GPs feel the government is "hopelessly short" of its targets - set in the NHS plan - to increase the number of family doctors by 2,000 within the next five years.

Latest figures show only 110 extra GPs have been recruited in the last year but the BMA claims the government should be looking to take on at least 10,000.

This spring, the GPC will survey all its members to highlight the extent of the problems GPs are facing.

A BMA spokeswoman said: "Dr Chisholm's letter is the opening salvo in a plan of action. The nationwide survey, which we will launch in the next few weeks, will provide us with further evidence."

She added: "Doctors don't traditionally go on strike but they are sufficiently demoralised to think that the normal path of negotiations are not enough.

"It is up to the UK's 36,000 GPs how this campaign progresses."

The Department of Health rebutted the GPC's claims. "The recruitment target set out in the NHS plan is achievable," said a spokeswoman, "and the figure of 2,000 is a floor rather than a ceiling.

webTitle: Nothing to lose but their debts

fields.headline: Nothing to lose but their debts
fields.standfirst: Can you blame students for funding their years at college the smart way - by selling drugs?
fields.trailText:
I have this student I'll call George (because his name is nothing like George). He's one of those undergraduates who make teachers feel they chose the right profession. Loves literature and Hong Kong action movies.

George's last essay was disappointingly listless. What was wrong? Girlfriend trouble? No, he explained. Exhaustion. The week before he had been up till the small hours bartending. During the day, he has a part time office job. He's what they laughingly call a full-time student - class of 2001.
fields.body:
I have this student I'll call George (because his name is nothing like George). He's one of those undergraduates who make teachers feel they chose the right profession. Loves literature and Hong Kong action movies.

George's last essay was disappointingly listless. What was wrong? Girlfriend trouble? No, he explained. Exhaustion. The week before he had been up till the small hours bartending. During the day, he has a part time office job. He's what they laughingly call a full-time student - class of 2001.

Student moonlighting is becoming universal. If you choose to study London (a good place to do it), the sums don't add up unless you earn some money on the side. Registered undergraduates can get an annual £4,500-a-year government-guaranteed, low-interest bank loan (it will be extracted from any subsequent salary over £10,000 per annum). Banks will also allow you a £1,500 overdraft (short-term, high-interest) and you can probably squeeze about the same amount out of your plastic (at extortionate interest). Total income (future debt, that is): around £17,000 over the three years of a normal degree course.

The going rate for accommodation in the capital is around £100 a week. With the £1000 annual tuition fee, rent eats up your bank loan plus some. You still have to live. Some parents help. Not all can.

The good news us that there is a lot of casual work for smart, English-speaking kids. Bar work is a favoured moonlighting option. It only pays the minimum wage. But, as George points out, serving drink keeps you from drinking: the curse of the studying classes.

There are other favourite moonlights. Fast-fingered girls can get as much temping as they want. I have been told of a student working her way through her degree lap-dancing - legendary, I suspect.

I'm more persuaded by reports from reliable source that an increasing number of students are supplementing their income by drug dealing. The defence is obvious. Many students use recreational drugs, particularly marijuana. Dope is cheaper and less anti-social than alcohol. In the closed university environment, dealing is safer than serving pints to yobs at closing time.

And, of course, it pays more than £4.50 an hour. There is nothing new in students supplying to students. I daresay Howard Marks, when he was at Oxford, was Mr Nice to his partying pals. But young Marks had a full grant. What's interesting about the new generation of student dealers (they exist, believe me) is that for them it's what social scientists call "rational choice". They are working their way through college the smart way.

Students should pay their dues like everyone else. But the new funding arrangements have educational consequences. The current level of loans means that moonlighting undergraduates have much less time to read around. This leads to a course of education which is about as free range as a battery farm.

Unless the government increases the loan facility (which would make the future millstone unacceptably heavy), British universities must consider moving to an American-style, four-year course. Students should perhaps be allowed to take as long as they need to complete their degree, dropping in and out of class as finances allow.

There was a report in the Guardian last Thursday that the country's "new universities" ("old polytechnics") are "in crisis", and falling by the wayside. So they should. Frankly, what they offer is not worth £17,000. Another rational choice. Ideally, the 20 or so new universities should be converted into American-style community colleges. That is, low-cost entry points in to the higher education system.

In the American university where I teach, most undergraduates are on full financial aid, and graduate debt-free. Their grants come not from the state but from the college endowment - the billions of dollars that the institution has built up from donations and investments.

William Hague proposes that a corps of major British universities be allowed to build up American levels of endowment. In the pathetic ragbag that calls itself the Tory manifesto, it's the one article of clothing Blair and Blunkett should seriously consider stealing. Either that or legalise pot and license students to sell it.

fields.headline: University shortfalls
fields.standfirst:
Protect poor students then use top-up fees

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Higher education hardly featured in the last election. All parties agreed to "wait for Dearing" - Lord Dearing's review of university funding. Dearing reported shortly after the election but, alas, Labour declined to follow his proposals.
fields.body:
Higher education hardly featured in the last election. All parties agreed to "wait for Dearing" - Lord Dearing's review of university funding. Dearing reported shortly after the election but, alas, Labour declined to follow his proposals. They would have required all students to contribute to their tuition fees, but would have provided maintenance grants for poor students. Labour did the opposite: excusing students from low income homes from an annual £1,000 contribution to tuition fees but illogically requiring them to meet much higher maintenance costs (up to £4,000 or more) through loans. Four years on from the last election, the position of poor students - and the nation's 100 universities - is even grimmer. Hence last week's report from the vice-chancellors setting out four options in which the £1bn shortfall in university funding could be closed.

There are three fundamental problems underlying the crisis in Britain's universities. The first is financial: a fall of almost 40% in resources per student over the last 12 years on top of a 20% fall in the previous 13 years. The second is the slowness with which a university system designed for an intellectual elite is adapting to the challenge of becoming a mass higher-education system. Where a generation ago only about 10% of young people attended university, now 40% of young people aged between 18 and 30 participate in higher education courses. The prime minister wants to lift this proportion to 50%. The third problem is the old pretence, which insisted all universities provided degrees of equal value, has become even more absurd with the emergence of a mass education system.

One reason why the vice-chancellors, who are due to debate the four funding options at the end of this week, are likely to emerge with a fudged consensus is be cause of their diverging interests. Ministers argue their second comprehensive spending review will produce a major investment in science, access courses and general higher-education spending. It will, but it will not make up the shortfall of the previous 25 years of squeeze. Universities have a dilapidated air. Laboratory facilities have been run down, library hours drastically curtailed and academic salaries ruthlessly reduced. Faced with mounting debt, students are becoming far more discriminating about the courses they intend to follow. Several former polytechnics have not just shut courses, but even campuses. Over 50 universities are more than 2% below their student recruitment targets.

What should happen now? The Conservatives want an endowment fund, under which university places would be financed, but they have not explained how the £100bn would be raised. In theory it would give universities more freedom, but the Tories are insisting that they would not allow universities to set their own fees or numbers. Labour, too, is opposed to universities setting their own fees - at least for the duration of the next parliament. The most "inclusive" step ministers could take would be to excuse poor students from both tuition and maintenance costs. This would be much better than the present muddle of exemptions, bursaries and special access deals. It would open the way for a future government to allow universities to set differential fees, knowing poor students would be protected. Both major parties have ruled out a fully funded higher education system. Axiomatically, if standards are not to deteriorate, universities must raise more funds themselves. Top-up fees are the least worst option.

fields.headline: Country of the month: Vietnam
fields.standfirst: Graham Holliday on teaching in Vietnam - a very different and more rewarding country than you might think
fields.trailText: Graham Holliday on teaching in Vietnam - a very different and more rewarding country than you might think
fields.body:
Finding jobs | Salaries | Accommodation and Living Expenses | Teaching | Living | Visas and paperwork | Useful contacts and websites

Introduction
Vietnam: the word may still concoct images of B52's, Jane Fonda and napalm, but now you're more likely to find Britney Spears, Coca-Cola and Manchester United football shirts. Vietnam is still a one party communist state, but take a stroll down any of the increasingly neon-lit streets strewn with advertising hoardings and you'd be hard pressed to think of this as anything but a capitalist society.

Since 1990 and the opening of Vietnam to the outside world, as with almost everything else, English teaching has become a growth market. From Ho Chi Minh City in the south to Hanoi in the north there are an abundance of opportunities for trained professionals and fresh TEFL/TESOL graduates alike.

Finding jobs
There are really only two main destinations for prospective job seekers Ê Hanoi or Ho Chi Minh. Outside of the two big cities the chances of earning a decent living are drastically reduced. The VSO are always recruiting and they will give you a subsistence allowance, although most placements are in the countryside where basic amenities are often lacking.

The British Council are expanding and have an office in Hanoi and a smaller one in Ho Chi Minh. They generally recruit internally, but occasionally there are openings for suitably qualified teachers to work part-time if they are already in the country.

Often the best way to find work is just to arrive in Hanoi or Ho Chi Minh and look around - invariably work can be found. Universities recruit native speakers and some give a small salary, accommodation and help with visa arrangements. There is a burgeoning ex-pat population and Korean, Japanese, Taiwanese and Russian parents are always on the look out for private tutors for their children.

There are opportunities for consultancy work for those with masters qualifications or higher and the relevant experience.

Salaries
A full-time post at a private language school should pay between $1000-$1500 plus airfares and a contribution towards accommodation and insurance. The British Council pay more, together with attractive allowances. Working privately pays anything between $15-$30 per hour. Consultancy work pays considerably more.

It is important to check whether the salary is paid in US dollars or the amusingly named local currency, the dong, as the dong is non-convertible outside Vietnam. The dong has been stable at around 14,000 to the dollar for two years or more now. It is possible to convert dong to dollars internally although the exchange rate may be unfavourable.

Accommodation and living expenses
Ho Chi Minh is a little more expensive than Hanoi. For a rough guide; $200-300 per month should find a pleasant flat and a decent sized house goes for between $300-$500 or more. There is a two-tier system for utilities and travel in Vietnam which means foreigners pay substantially more than locals for almost everything.

If you don't like cooking the cities are a boon, packed with good, cheap restaurants serving excellent healthy food. It is quite easy to get by on $5 a day eating at Com Binh Dan, the Vietnamese street side restaurants. Bia Hoi restaurants also serve great, cheap nibbles and offer some of Asia's best beers for all of 18p a glass. Some of the very best food can be found at the smallest street stalls at ridiculously cheap prices.

International restaurants and cafes are more expensive but, still affordable for the average teacher.

Teaching
As with other Asian countries there is a thirst to learn which can make teaching a very satisfying and rewarding way to earn a living. The private language schools are well stocked with materials.

Oxford University Press has an office in Ho Chi Minh City and textbooks are widely available. Teachers are generally held in high regard and students will be keen to mix socially.

Exams are becoming increasingly important in Vietnam and many students strive to obtain a good score in the hope of going to America. There are a growing number taking the Cambridge suite of exams. IELTS being particularly popular among those wanting to take up scholarships to Australia and the UK.

Living

Hanoi is small and beautiful, yet bustling and noisy whereas Ho Chi Minh is 'a Bangkok in the making'. This sprawling commercial centre boasts a skyline already dotted with fledgling skyscrapers.

A teachers' salary can afford you a comfortable lifestyle combined with an 'exotic' location in which to enjoy it. The three main complaints being traffic, noise and street hassle.

One of the main attractions is learning Vietnamese. It is an extremely difficult language to master, but one of the best ways of giving it a shot is to enrol at a local university class or employ a private tutor. The tones are tricky but most people manage to master enough to get by after some considerable effort.

The Vietnamese countryside is stunning and great fun to travel around by motorbike. The coastline stretches over 2000km and is dotted with some great beaches. The weather is hotter in the south with a dry and a wet season. The north experiences all four seasons from a very hot and humid summer and a damp and cold winter. It may sound surprising, but temperatures can reach as low as 8*C in Hanoi.

Visas and paperwork
To work in Vietnam you need a business visa, your employer must arrange this for you before you arrive. If you are looking for work on arrival then you must convert your tourist visa through your employer. This may sometimes involve a trip to Cambodia or Thailand, but there are normally 'ways' of avoiding this problem. The best thing to do is meet people already working who know the situation in your city and can best advise you as who to contact to 'arrange' something.

Useful contacts and websites

The British Council can be found at: 40 Cat Linh Dong Da District Hanoi Tel: +84 (0)4 843 6780 Fax: +84 (0)4 843 6763 and The British Council 25 Le Duan Street District 1 HCMC Tel: +84 (0)8 8232862 Fax: +84 (0)8 8222105

The Voluntary Service Overseas (VSO) can help in a number of ways

For job vacancies, try Dave's ESL Cafe or the TEFL Professional Network

Graham Holliday is a British Council teacher and freelance writer. You can email him here

webTitle: More time off for staff in tough schools

fields.headline: More time off for staff in tough schools
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers in Britain's most challenging schools will be entitled to six-week paid sabbaticals under plans to be set out by the government this week.
fields.body:
Teachers in Britain's most challenging schools will be entitled to six-week paid sabbaticals under plans to be set out by the government this week.

At a time of continuing concerns about serious teacher shortages, ministers hope they will stop disillusioned and "burnt out" teachers quitting the profession early. In the next few days the first results of teacher union ballots will be announced, and they are likely to lead to industrial action in areas where the worst shortages have led to increased workloads.

The proposals are part of a £92m package of measures to raise teaching standards through better professional development.

New teachers will get more help early in their second or third year as part of a more clearly defined career ladder. The highest drop-out rates are among teachers who have spent five years in the classroom.

Both proposals were recommended to the education secretary, David Blunkett, by the General Teaching Council, which was set up to provide a professional and independent voice for teachers.

The GTC believes all experienced teachers should have the opportunity to take sabbaticals, although the government has decided to limit them initially to those working in "challenging" schools, particularly in inner-city areas.

In its submission to Mr Blunkett, the GTC said: "There is evidence to suggest that sabbatical leave within the working year will foster teachers' professional and personal growth and reduce the risk of early exit from the profession of capable and committed teachers."

The GTC also recommended that sabbaticals should be focused on "achieving positive outcomes for pupils, the teacher and the school. Sabbaticals are an opportunity to gain pedagogic, leadership or management inspiration and should have a direct impact on return."

Teachers would have to get approval for their proposed sabbatical activity in order to qualify for funding, which would help to pay for supply cover during their absence - of up to six weeks. The GTC envisages that sabbaticals would be taken as work placements in business, the voluntary sector or in education bodies.

Overall, the package, to be announced by the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, at a conference on Thursday, is likely to benefit around 70,000 teachers over the next three years. It will also include plans for more bursaries of £700 a time to allow teachers to undertake professional development of their choice, and £3,500 scholarships for around 1,000 teachers to explore good practice.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the second largest teaching union, the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, said: "This is a useful step in the right direction. Professional development is very important for our teaching profession. It is also a big improvement over what Mr Blunkett announced and then dropped last year, which was to give teachers a year off in return for a big pay drop."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, added: "Anything that enables teachers to broaden their horizons by visiting other schools and countries is to be welcomed. But we are looking for a long term policy with proper funding. The money has got to be in place, particularly if supply cover is going to be arranged. I welcome the plans for more targeted support for newly qualified teachers, because after induction you're very much on your own."

webTitle: Quit or be sacked, 'bullying' head told

fields.headline: Quit or be sacked, 'bullying' head told
fields.standfirst:
Governors withdraw support at Westminster Abbey choir school

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The headmaster at the centre of allegations of bullying at Westminster Abbey's choir school is being forced out after the governors unexpectedly withdrew their support.
fields.body:
The headmaster at the centre of allegations of bullying at Westminster Abbey's choir school is being forced out after the governors unexpectedly withdrew their support.

Roger Overend, headmaster for the past four years, was summoned to a meeting in the abbey's Jerusalem Chamber at the end of last week and ordered to resign or face the sack.

He is consulting his union, the National Association of Head Teachers, but is said to have told friends that he knows he will not return.

The move follows months of controversy over the running of the school, with some parents accusing the headmaster of bullying their children. Until last week Wesley Carr, the dean of the abbey and one of the school governors, had given Mr Overend his full support and the abbey dismissed the claims as unrepresentative.

Even the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, has been drawn into the row. On Friday, the very day that Mr Overend was told he would have to go, Dr Carey wrote to a concerned and long-standing worshipper at the abbey, dismissing media reports of trouble at the school as inaccurate.

Parents have been told that the head is taking extended leave but they were offered what was described as counselling by the dean and senior members of the abbey's staff when they returned their boys to the school at the end of the half term break on Friday.

The abbey's choir - in existence for nearly 1,000 years - is world famous for its singing at state occasions, notably the funeral of the Princess of Wales.

But the choir has been in turmoil since the dean dismissed the popular and distinguished former organist Martin Neary three years ago. Although the dismissal was upheld by a subsequent inquiry the dean was criticised for his management style.

The abbey is a so-called royal peculiar, under the Queen's patronage but run by the dean, who is also chairman of the school's governing body.

In recent months four boys have been withdrawn and one expelled from the 37-pupil school, which is next to the abbey and is overlooked by the Department for Education across the road.

There have been persistent allegations of bullying against Mr Overend, including one that he ordered a boy from his bed and harangued him for half an hour for taking a packet of crisps from the canteen. An independent but internal inquiry was held into the incident last autumn, after which the abbey said that "appropriate action" had been taken, but Mr Overend was not disciplined.

Others claim that the headmaster threatened them with legal action over their behaviour during a tour of the United States last autumn.

The fact that the headmaster was not previously subject to disciplinary proceedings or written warnings threatens the abbey with more damaging publicity at a possible tribunal for unfair dismissal.

The school's doctor, Christopher Besse, is understood to have resigned a fortnight ago after his diagnosis that a number of the children were suffering from stress was questioned by the dean.

Only four children were presented at an audition for places earlier this month although up to a dozen new choristers will be required when current pupils leave in the summer.

But the dean and governors are bracing themselves for publication of what is expected to be a critical report into the running of the school by Westminster council's social services department within the next fortnight. A draft copy of the report, already sent to the abbey, is said to suggest its management is not appropriate for the 21st century.

Although the school's deputy headmistress is taking charge for the time being, the dean was yesterday said to have announced to the school on Saturday night that he was in charge.

fields.headline: Warning over care trust plans
fields.trailText: Social care experts are warning the government that social inclusion is under threat from NHS care trust proposals, which have their second reading in the House of Lords today. Linda Steele reports
fields.body:
Social care experts are warning the government that social inclusion is under threat from NHS care trust proposals, which have their second reading in the House of Lords today.

The health and social care bill's plans for merging adult health and social care services in care trusts pose "fundamental problems", according to a joint letter sent today to health minister Lord Hunt. Most important is "a significant risk that the broadly based community and social care model will lose out to a medical/clinical approach", say the eight signatories.

The eight signatories are John Belcher (chief executive, Anchor Trust), Dr Fiona Campbell (co-ordinator, Democratic Health Network), Moira Gibb (president, Association of Directors of Social Services), John Knight (head of external policy, Leonard Cheshire), Mervyn Kohler (head of public affairs, Help the Aged), Gordon Lishman (director general, Age Concern), Rita Stringfellow (chair, Local Government Association social affairs and health executive) and Malcolm Wing (local government service group head, Unison).

"Users' organisations believe that this may jeopardise the principles of social inclusion and enhanced independence which lie behind social care, and undermine the invaluable contribution of services which do not equate disability and old age with ill health."

The authors say that "hard-won principles will not survive unless any new bodies are truly joint [and] reflect an equal partnership," rather than being NHS organisations, as currently planned.

Concerns have been raised that issues such as the abolition of community health councils have obscured a much bigger threat to the future of social care and a social model of health and disability. The letter says that this aspect of the bill received "insufficient attention" in the Commons.

Fiona Campbell, one of the letter's authors, told SocietyGuardian: "A social model of disability and care has been developed, with pressure from user groups, that doesn't see disability and old age as being equated with illness but looks at people holistically. If you're in the health service, you obviously see [service users] as patients.

"People may have a range of health and social care needs but they have other needs - they might go to adult education classes or the library and may need support [getting] those. Good social workers will know about other services, and can look at providing a package of support which recognises older or disabled people as active citizens who aren't just patients on the receiving ends of medical services."

The letter also calls for "real debate" on matters such as accountability and funding. "Service users must be clear about who is responsible for their care," it says. "This will not require only transparent complaints procedures, but governance and management arrangements that enable local councils to maintain proper democratic accountability to local people for the services they delegate into the care trust."

It says safeguards are needed to protect resources from the "wider clinical implications of the NHS". Fears have been voiced elsewhere that important personal social services that promote independent living, such as assisting disabled people with daily washing and dressing, could lose out financially to acute health services.

fields.headline: The Speedo story
fields.standfirst: After 73 years honing swimwear design, Speedo is turning to leisurewear. Julia Day tells the story.
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: After 73 years honing swimwear design, Speedo is turning to leisurewear. Julia Day tells the story.
Feb 26: Speedo moves into leisurewear
fields.body:
From silk swimsuits in any colour so long as its navy, to the techno Fastskin bodysuit that made waves at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, Speedo has spent 73 years honing the design of its swimming kits.

Now Speedo is turning its attentions away from the pool and is relaunching as a leisurewear company.

And not before time. The move comes years after sportswear giants Nike, Adidas and Reebok began diversifying into the leisurewear market.

Last year Adidas restructured into three divisions, one of them to concentrate solely on lifestyle clothing, after scrapping plans to launch a men's fashion brand. The brand already sells everything from fragrance to toiletries to eyewear.

Speedo began life in the land of sun, sea and surf, Australia. In 1928, Sydney-based MacRae Knitting Mills launched Speedo as the brand name for its swimming costumes.

The company created a revolutionary design - the 'race-back' style - featuring a high, narrow back panel for the silk and cotton suits.

The suits sparked the longest unbroken sponsorship in world sport - between Speedo and the Australian swimming team, beginning at 1948 London Olympics and continuing today.

In 1957 Speedo notched up another first - a nylon costume developed in association with Australian freestyle stars Dawn Fraser and Lorraine Crapp.

The method is teaming up with the world's swimming elite also continues - many helped develop the Fastskin body suit which propelled Speedo into hot water at the 2000 Olympics.

Bad-boy of British swimming Mark Foster had his Olympic accreditation withdrawn after he broke the British Olympic Association rules and wore a Speedo Fastskin suit, reported to improve performance by up to 3%.

The incident happened after a six-month row over the Speedo brand appearing on the suits.

The British swimming squad were given special permission shortly before the games to wear the suits on the strict condition that the Speedo logo was not visible.

Speedo owner Pentland Group controls a stable of brands, including Ellesse, Berghaus, Red or Dead, Mitre, Kickers and holds the exclusive worldwide footwear licence for the LaCoste brand.

The company was founded in Liverpool in 1932 by the Rubin family and was first floated on the London Stock Exchange in 1964.

It remained a public company for 35 years until November 1999 when it was privatised. It's headquarters remain in the UK.

The family still preside over the empire - R Stephen Rubin is chairman and Andrew K Rubin is chief executive.

In 1999 its sales were estimated to be around £675m, showing a growth of approximately 9.7%.

It employs 3,200 people in offices in Australia, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Italy, Korea, the Netherlands, Taiwan, Thailand, US and Vietnam.

The group's brands are sold in more than 120 countries directly by Pentland Group companies or are represented by licensees and distributors.

webTitle: Return of Powell, Kuwait's conquering hero

fields.headline: Return of Powell, Kuwait's conquering hero
fields.standfirst:
Even with the Desert Storm chief as US secretary of state, Kuwait's future remains uncertain, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText:
Even with the Desert Storm chief as US secretary of state, Kuwait's future remains uncertain, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown.
Special report: Iraq
fields.body:
In a region seething with anti-American sentiment, Kuwait remains Washington's staunchest supporter.

Ten years after US and allied troops drove out Iraqi invaders, the tiny but oil-rich state is entirely dependent on America's military might to defend it from its predatory northern neighbour.

Little wonder then that Colin Powell, the allied commander during Operation Desert Storm, has been given a hero's welcome in his new role as US secretary of state.

But the ceremonies and speeches of undying friendship are tinged with nervousness. Kuwaiti officials know that their pro-Washington stance is at odds with most regional diplomacy, and hugely unpopular with the Arab masses.

Also, they cannot be sure that US foreign policy, as it evolves under President George Bush, will continue to give them a cast-iron security guarantee. All overseas frontline deployments of American troops are highly unpopular with the US electorate, whose distaste is shared by the new president.

The new uncertainties were recently underlined by the previous President Bush - the present incumbent's father, who was in the White House during Desert Storm in 1991. He told an audience of Kuwaitis and US service personnel that "the United States will never let Kuwait down". But, rather more to the point, he said he had no idea if his son would send more troops to the region.

Kuwait has good reason to be apprehensive. Ten years after his abortive invasion and annexation, Saddam Hussein continues to claim the emirate as an Iraqi province. And with Baghdad continuing to defy the west and the United Nations over economic sanctions and arms control, the region remains in a state of constant armed alert.

The Kuwaitis' bitter memories of the events of 1990-91 are kept fresh by the sabre-rattling of their northern neighbours, and by the continuing trauma of the brutal invasion.

One in five of the 1.9m population are said still to suffer some form of stress - and 605 are still missing, believed murdered or imprisoned in Iraq.

There is little doubt that Secretary of State Powell is personally committed to the continued defence of the country his forces liberated 10 years ago.

But the soldier who in 1991 could concentrate all his attention on a single objective is now a diplomat who must balance his priorities.

In the Middle East, the containment of the perceived Iraqi threat remains a prime US priority. But it's not just a question of basing troops in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. It is also about bringing about rapprochement with Iran, to provide another buffer against Saddam's ambition.

One of the main problems for US diplomacy in the region is that Saddam is once again a popular hero, seen to be standing up to American and Zionist imperialism. His bombastic talk of sending a volunteer army to fight the Israelis is rhetorical hogwash, but it goes down well with the huddled masses of the Arab world.

Neither Bush nor Powell show any signs of sharing Bill Clinton's fervent attachment to the Middle East peace process. Indeed, the new secretary of state is said by close observers in Washington to believe strongly that the Persian gulf should be the focus of US regional diplomacy.

Nevertheless, after five months of near-continuous violence, the Israeli-Palestinian issue is forcing itself to the top of the state department agenda.

Powell clearly has little taste for involving himself in a new round of negotiations. But he has shown some signs of exasperation with the intransigence of both sides. He has urged the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to clamp down on extreme elements and, in recent days, pointedly called on Israel to ease its punitive economic blockade of the occupied territories.

The irony of the latter call is that America is enforcing a western economic blockade on Iraq; a policy widely seen in the Arab world as a collective punishment more brutal even than Israel's. After his first official trip to the Middle East as secretary of state, Powell will be more aware than ever that diplomatic and political balance is an elusive objective in that turbulent region.

fields.headline: Speedo moves into leisurewear
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: The 73-year-old brand is shedding its aquatic image to tap the mainstream leisure market, writes Julia Day.
Comment: the Speedo story
fields.body:
Speedo, legendary purveyor of the kind of skimpy swimwear adored by Rod Stewart, is shedding its aquatic image.

The 73-year-old brand, which is also responsible for some of the most hi-tech competition-wear in the market, is being revamped in a bid to tap the mainstream leisure market.

A new brand name has been devised for a range of trendy clothing to be launched next year.

However, the Speedo tag will remain emblazoned on the sports-based swimwear.

"We are relaunching to become more of a leisurewear brand. But we will keep the sporting heritage in swimming because that is what Speedo is all about," said a company spokeswoman.

She said the move into leisurewear would not dilute the brand's sporting heritage.

"We will continue with sporting products but we are bringing leisurewear more to the forefront," she added.

The technical expertise used to produce Speedo sportswear, such as its controversial bodysuits for swimmers, will be employed in the production of its leisure clothing.

Its decision to diversify comes two weeks after the company closed one of its factories in Australia.

And it comes years after giant sportswear names including Nike and Adidas extended their ranges to include everything from handbags to spectacles.

The leisurewear range will be based initially around clothes to wear to the beach - including t-shirts and shorts - but is likely to extend to a wide range of casual clothing.

Speedo's two recently opened stores in London's Covent Garden and Nottingham will stock the new brand, which is also likely to be available in other stores.

The range will be promoted by advertising and PR campaigns.

Speedo parent company Pentland Group owns a portfolio of apparel and footwear brands, including Ellesse, Berghaus and Kickers.

webTitle: Full text of Nick Brown's statement to the Commons

fields.headline: Full text of Nick Brown's statement to the Commons
fields.trailText: "As my right honourable friend Baroness Hayman reported on 21 February, the first case of foot and mouth disease in the United Kingdom for 20 years was confirmed on the evening of last Tuesday 20 February in pigs at an abattoir and in cattle on a neighbouring farm near Brentwood in Essex.
fields.body:
"As my right honourable friend Baroness Hayman reported on 21 February, the first case of foot and mouth disease in the United Kingdom for 20 years was confirmed on the evening of last Tuesday 20 February in pigs at an abattoir and in cattle on a neighbouring farm near Brentwood in Essex.

"The number of confirmed cases of foot and mouth disease rose to nine this morning. Two further cases, bringing the total to 11, have been confirmed early this afternoon. Today's cases are first, in sheep at Hatherleigh near Okehampton, Devon, at another farm in the same ownership as the one confirmed yesterday; at Bromham, near Chippenham, Wiltshire in sheep at an abattoir which received animals from the Devon source; in a pig farm between the two cases in Northumberland, which is likely to have been windborne spread; and at a sheep and cattle farm near the Welsh border in Herefordshire which had also received sheep from Devon. Infected Area restrictions are being imposed. A decision was taken at lunchtime today to kill the remaining animals on the several premises in Devon under the same ownership, and one neighbouring farm, as dangerous contacts.

"Investigations are continuing into a number of other premises where there is reason to believe there may be disease. The Government's overriding priority is the containment and eradication of this disease.

"On February 21, the United Kingdom government and the European Commission acted swiftly to prohibit temporarily the export of live animals, meat, fresh milk and other animal products from the UK. Given the acutely infectious nature of foot and mouth disease, this was a necessary step in helping to prevent the spread of the disease to other countries. We are able to export non-susceptible animals and their products provided they meet certain conditions and are accompanied by veterinary certificates. Appropriate certificates are now available for issue from MAFF animal health offices.

"We immediately ceased issuing export health certificates for export to third countries for any animals or products which cannot also be exported to other EU member states. This applies whether or not the import conditions for a given country would allow us to export.

"We are urgently tracing all exports of FMD susceptible animals from areas under suspicion to other member states, since February 1 but before the export ban came into effect. The EU commission have been kept informed at every stage, along with our EU partners. I shall be updating the council of agriculture ministers tomorrow. In particular we advised the German authorities of a consignment of sheep from the Devon outbreak and these were slaughtered by the German authorities yesterday.

"Some of the cases have been on premises which are associated with substantial movements of animals. The confirmation of the cases in Northumberland on Friday February 23 showed that the disease was not confined to Essex, and had been in the country longer than had at first been apparent. In these new circumstances, the chief veterinary officer advised that stringent controls were needed. After discussion with the food and farming industries, and with the devolved administrations, I announced later on Friday 23 February that there should be a seven-day standstill of livestock movements throughout Great Britain. This exceptional measure was imposed at 5pm on Friday, and is due to expire at midnight this Friday March 2.

"The department of health and the food standards agency have confirmed that foot and mouth disease has no implications for human health or food. "The disease causes serious loss of condition, and therefore commercial value, to the main farmed animal species of cattle, pigs and sheep. The presence of disease also blocks our export markets. The disease is highly infectious between animals. It can be transmitted by movements of people and vehicles. Unlike classical swine fever with which we had to deal in East Anglia last year, it is carried through the air.

"Firm control measures had to be taken. The Government is well aware of the disruption the temporary "controlled area" in Great Britain has caused to farming, the food chain and the wider rural community. I pay tribute to the responsible approach that the industry and the public are taking.

"During the course of this week, the state veterinary service, under the chief veterinary officer, will continue its huge task of tracing and controlling the disease. They have been assured of all the resources they need for that task. The government is calling on the private veterinary profession and other country's state veterinary services for assistance.

"Baroness Hayman, the minister of state, will be meeting industry representatives tomorrow with the chief veterinary officer. Amongst other matters, they will discuss whether it is possible, consistent with a rigorous approach to the control of disease, to allow for some tightly controlled movement of livestock for slaughter. Consideration is also being given to the temporary closure of footpaths and rights of way.

"We are keeping in the closest touch with the retailers and food producers, to ensure that there should be no serious disruption to food supplies. I am grateful to consumers who have, as I have requested, continued their normal pattern of buying.

"The House will know that the policy of successive governments has been that compensation is paid only for animals which are slaughtered for disease control purposes - in the case of foot and mouth disease, at full market value. foot and mouth disease presents a relatively clear clinical picture. Incubation periods tend to be short. I therefore hope that movement restrictions necessary for disease control will not have to be too protracted.

"The government is determined to eliminate this disease. I, my ministerial team and my department's staff will give this work the highest priority. I welcome the firm support we have received from the industry, from people throughout the country, from our European partners, and from others further afield, in our efforts to do so."
