fields.headline: Rough at the top
fields.standfirst: Tempestuous scenes involving Deportivo and Real Madrid - and a word or two about the game as well
fields.trailText: Tempestuous scenes involving Deportivo and Real Madrid - and a word or two about the game as well.
fields.body:
There was something funny going on in La Coruña on Saturday night. It was Carnival weekend - and to add to the fun, league leaders Real Madrid were in town to face their nearest rivals, Deportivo.

The city's women seemed to have chosen a new line in make-up. Not for them the showpiece of the MaxFactor catalogue, though - blue and white stripes were the order of the day. Meanwhile, kids let off fireworks and threw stones - mostly in the direction of the Real Madrid team coach (the bus, not the Man in the Moustache) which was left with a smashed window and a bemused security official, who told El País: "I don't know where all the hatred comes from."

Then Real Madrid's superstars stepped into the firing line - as Steve McManaman got off the bus, he was viciously attacked by some flying chewing gum and promptly pulled out of the England squad.

But while there was lots of fun along the beach - appropriately enough, just a stone's throw from the ground - the real excitement was inside the Riazor itself, full for the first time since last season's sensational Championship clincher. With Depor four points behind leaders Real Madrid, this was the season's biggest game so far, somehow even managing to make people forget Barça's visit to the Bernabéu next week. No split loyalties here, even for the Galician Robert Carlos fan, "quoted" in El País: "I love you a lot Roberto!" she screamed, "but don't you dare take the three points off us".

The man with the monster thighs may not have ridden off with all three points, but Depor could count themselves more than a little unlucky to only get a 2-2 draw after hitting the woodwork (metalwork, surely?) four times. Real Madrid's sporting director Jorge Valdano admitted as much in this morning's AS: "They took us to the cleaners".

Madrid were 1-0 up in just six minutes, Helder connecting with Míchel Salgado's cross to send a quality header past keeper Jacques Songo'o. There was just one problem - Helder plays for Depor.

Javier Irureta's side, with Djalminha at the heart of everything, responded in style, only to find Iker Casillas in inspired form, while Roy Makaay and Fran each missed a sitter. Then, on the stroke of half-time, things went horribly pear-shaped again. Mauro Silva seemed to have pulled off the tackle of the season (ooer missus) on Guti, but referee Andradas Asurmendi - a classic black-bearded Basque if ever there was one - pointed to the spot and Luis Figo did the rest to make it 2-0.

Figo, though, was kind enough to give Depor the chance to get back into the game early in the second half with an oafish challenge on Djalminha - the Brazilian clipped a cheeky penalty á la Dwight Yorke past a bemused Iker Casillas.

It didn't stop there, either, as Depor continued to pile on the pressure. Víctor and Enrique Romero both hit the post and old man Donato curled a free-kick against the bar as Depor rattled up 24 shots on goal.

Javier Irureta's side did finally get the goal they deserved, though. Diego Tristán had limbered up for the match by visiting a Casino and gambling away £30,000 in midweek. He may not have had much luck at the wheel, but his meticulous "preparation" certainly paid off on the pitch - Tristán grabbed an equaliser with a superb finish six minutes from time.

Valencia and Barca keep up the pressure

Valencia and Barcelona both took advantage of Saturday's result to edge a couple of points closer to the top two.

In a game that had more Argentinians than Evita Perón, it was a Norwegian (and a giant one at that), John Carew, that stole the show with a fine hat-trick during Valencia's 3-1 win over Villarreal.

Life at the Mestalla is a lot rosier these days, with Valencia looking set to progress in the Champions League after two impressive performances against Manchester United and president Pedro Cortés confident, at last, that Héctor Cúper will put pen to paper to sign a contract extension for next year.

No such harmony at Barcelona, despite a 5-0 demolition of AEK Athens in midweek and a comfortable 3-0 victory over John Benjamin's Real Sociedad on Sunday. Not only was the Nou Camp as empty as Bryan Robson's Tactical Awareness drawer, but the in-fighting continues, too - this week it was Patrick Kluivert and, yet again (yawn), comedy keeper Richard Dutruel's turn to moan.

But while the Dutchman has "sorted out" his differences with Serra Ferrer, the comedy keeper looks likely to be leaving at the end of the season. If, that is, he doesn't mysteriously disappear first, only to turn up in a ditch somewhere in the Catalonian countryside.

The shock news in Barcelona this week concerned Serra Ferrer's own position. Joan Gaspart told Radio España that the mallorquino will keep his job "if we achieve sporting success and the team ends up having a brilliant season". Wow. But hang on a minute, what exactly constitutes a "brilliant season" (bearing in mind that Bobby Robson was given his marching orders after winning 3 out of 4 trophies, scoring over 100 league goals and being runners-up in the league)? "That's something that Serra Ferrer and I will analyse when we get the chance," he said. Glad that's clear, anyway.

Real Soceidad's defeat was all the more difficult for John Benjamin to take in view of the weekend's other results down the bottom.

Real Oviedo boss Radi Antic and midfielder Victor Onopko prepared for the visit of bottom-placed Osasuna by joining the City of Oviedo Symphonic Orchestra, while Stan the Man psyched himself up for another match on the bench with a trip to the El Plaza night-club (or so my spies tell me). But by Sunday it was Osasuna who were on song (boom boom), coming back from 2-0 down to win 3-2.

Meanwhile, something funny's going on with Racing Santander: after hammering Barça and losing out by a single goal to Real Madrid, they grabbed another surprise win, 2-1 against Mallorca. Apparently dead and buried just three weeks ago, a win next week against fellow strugglers Numancia - who lost 3-1 in Bilbao on Sunday - would see Gregorio Manzano's men pull themselves out of the bottom three.

Elsewhere this weekend, Valladolid continued their unbeaten home record with a 2-0 win over Zaragoza, Málaga beat Las Palmas 2-1, and there were draws involving Spain's other three Uefa Cup heroes - Alavés and Celta finished 2-2 while Rayo Vallecano drew 1-1 with Espanyol.

After some fantastic performances in Europe this week, the sporting press has been quick to proclaim, once again, that Spanish football is the best in the world. With the national side about to touch down in Birmingham, British fans might be about to found out just how good they are. And with Steve McManaman - the man Iván Helguera rates as "England's best player" - out, the Spanish are looking forward to a comfortable win. Just so long as their boys can avoid that dodgy British beef.

It was Carnival weekend - and to add to the fun, league leaders Real Madrid were in town to face their nearest rivals, Deportivo. The city's women seemed to have chosen a new line in make-up. webTitle: London march cancelled as disease spreads

fields.headline: London march cancelled as disease spreads
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The Countryside Alliance march on London next month has been cancelled to prevent the further spread of foot and mouth disease, its organisers said today.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance march on London next month has been cancelled to prevent the further spread of foot and mouth disease, its organisers said today.

Chief executive Richard Burge said a decision had been made to act "properly and responsibly" and demonstrate solidarity with the farming community.

More cases of foot and mouth disease were confirmed today, bringing the total to 12 so far, as the mass incineration of thousands of animal carcasses continued.

"Large sections of the rural community are finding themselves unable to come on the march," Mr Burge said.

"They have a major crisis to resolve and that is where they need to be, not tramping the streets of London."

Ministry of agriculture officials confirmed outbreaks of the highly contagious disease in Bromham, Wiltshire and at a farm in Hatherleigh, Devon.

Both cases were related to an outbreak at Burdon farm, Highampton, Devon, a spokesman said. The south-west outbreak is the first to affect sheep.

Three more farms - a pig farm in Northumberland, a sheep and cattle farm in Herefordshire and another in Devon - were also confirmed to be infected.

The outbreak at Burdon farm has sparked fears that the disease may have spread to Europe. The sheep and cattle farm is part of a chain of 13 in Devon and Cornwall owned by a sheep dealer who exports animals to Europe.

The European commission has been warned that infected animals could have been sold abroad but it is not known how long the disease has been spreading at the Devon farm or when sheep were last exported to Europe.

In a statement to the Commons today Agriculture minister Nick Brown said the government was urgently tracing all exports of susceptible animals from suspect areas to EU member states.

The latest cases have dashed hopes that the disease had been contained by slaughtering and a seven-day ban on livestock movement.

Farming leaders called it a "nightmare scenario" and the National Farmers' Union south-west regional director, Anthony Gibson, said he feared the latest outbreak could be even worse than the one in 1967, when more than 400,000 animals were slaughtered.

Until the weekend, confirmed outbreaks of the disease had been confined to two clusters in Northumberland and Essex. Animal carcasses were today burning in the infected areas.

More than 2,000 pigs, sheep and cattle have so far been culled nationwide.

fields.headline: Benn attacks New Labour marketing
fields.trailText:
5pm: Tony Benn has launched a withering attack on New Labour marketing, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 23: Labour joins text message frenzy
fields.body:
Tony Benn has launched a withering attack on New Labour marketing, likening life as an MP to "being an Avon lady".

The Labour MP for Chesterfield lashed out at the party's attempts to control the media.

"I receive a personalised fax from Labour HQ every morning saying 'Mr Benn welcomes compulsory homework for pensioners', or whatever the latest gimmick is, and I'm expected to fax it on to my local paper," said Mr Benn in an interview with the Radio Times.

"You're like an Avon lady being told what to say when you knock at the front door," he added.

Mr Benn said the personalised faxes had stopped recently.

But he added that the control was "destructive of the political process and led to people switching off".

He added that modern politics was "all marketing, show business and advertising" and said viewers received a distorted view of politics because coverage was so personality-based.

Mr Benn also criticised the BBC, saying: "It's broadly true that the BBC doesn't seem to want any debate on Europe."

He said he was depressed by TV's obsession with personalities, saying it was bad for democracy.

"The coverage has changed. It's all about personalities, Mandelson or cabinet splits. I find it very discouraging.

"Political leaders and the media agree to concentrate on an agenda and neglect issues that don't fit into that pattern," he said.

"Coverage is shallow, personal and abusive," he added.

He noted that he believed himself to have been invited and then "uninvited" to participate in a discussion programme because of pressure from the Labour party.

In the interview, Mr Benn also revealed that he was "completely taken in" in his interview with Ali G.

The MP lost his temper with the comedian, believing him to be an example of idiot "yoof" TV at its worst.

"It's a very clever political programme," he said. "It helps viewers see the nonsense of the prejudice they read in the tabloids."

webTitle: Analysis: The Porton Down laboratory experiments

fields.headline: Guinea pigs' grievance
fields.standfirst: Experiments undertaken at the laboratories of Porton Down have left a legacy of doubt. Now ministers must decide if an inquiry is needed
fields.trailText: Defence ministers are wondering whether to stir the ashes of British military history to find out if service personnel used as human guinea pigs in chemical warfare experiments are now suffering from disease as a result.
fields.body:
Defence ministers are wondering whether to stir the ashes of British military history to find out if service personnel used as human guinea pigs in chemical warfare experiments are now suffering from disease as a result.

More than 20,000 were put through test programmes in the laboratories of Porton Down, Wiltshire between 1916 and the present day. Indeed, the defence establishment conducted the world's longest programme of chemical warfare experiments on humans.

Poisons, including nerve gas and mustard gas, chemical weapons and protective drugs were tested on humans in myriad, often horrific, experiments. A full study would have to establish whether each type of chemical caused later ill-health.

But Porton's legacy is about more than a scientific inquiry. This issue is also about people's confidence in the ability of the Ministry of Defence (MoD) to deal fairly with the medical complaints of contemporary military personnel. The MoD has been criticised by former soldiers, sailors and air crew who believe that their ill-health has been caused during their period of service.

They have waged long and often bitter campaigns against officialdom which, many of them feel, has ignored their claim for compensation and apology. In the 1980s, former servicemen claimed that they had developed cancers and other diseases as a result of exposure to radiation from nuclear weapon tests abroad. In the early 90s, veterans of the Gulf war against Iraq began to experience mysterious illnesses. At first, the MoD denied that the war had anything to do with their diseases. This stonewalling bred accusations of cover-up as well as public cynicism. Labour in 1997 seemed to learn the lesson and promised a new beginning on the issue of Gulf war syndrome. Labour ministers pledged to be more open and give medical help quickly to veterans.

Recently, pressure has been building on another front. More and more of those tested at Porton have been coming forward to complain. Around 250 joined the Porton Down veterans' support group. Their lawyer is now preparing a case against the MoD.

And for the past 18 months, Wiltshire police have been investigating the Porton experiments in a criminal inquiry. They have been looking at allegations that some volunteers were duped into undergoing gas tests by being told they were helping to find a cure for the common cold. The detectives have also been looking at the death of Ronald Maddison, a 20-year-old airman, in a 1953 nerve gas experiment. Following moves by the police, his inquest could soon be re-opened - a remarkable development for a death which occurred nearly 50 years ago.

Defence ministers were forced to consider a health study because of this Wiltshire police inquiry. In November, a senior MoD official wrote and asked the Medical Research Council (MRC) for "urgent assistance and advice on establishing the feasibility of an epidemiological study into the health of service volunteers who attended Porton Down for various trials over a great many years.

"The background to this suggestion is a continuing inquiry by the Wiltshire police into the way in which some of these trials were conducted." The civil servant noted Wiltshire police had uncovered evidence which they believed showed that Porton volunteers were suffering "unusual ill-health" because of their attendance at Porton Down and participation in the trials programme. The MoD appears to accept the nub of the question: "Whilst we are sceptical about police claims, equally there is insufficient scientific evidence on which they could be either confirmed or refuted.

"Our ministers have therefore decided that work should be set in hand to establish whether there is any basis to suggestions that Porton volunteers have encountered premature mortality or unusual ill-health related to their exposures. We believe that a soundly based epidemiological study will be the only way to establish these facts."

The official line is that a study of whether Porton volunteers have died prematurely or suffered cancer is feasible but that it would be much more difficult to look generally at Porton volunteers' health. "Experience from our Gulf war veterans epidemiological projects suggests that very high numbers of people serving in the armed forces many decades ago will be lost to follow up.

"Questions of ethics, consent on the part of the individual to participate in a study, follow up of NHS records, or the alternative of a questionnaire-based study, with the additional uncertainties of response rate, suggest to us that this may not be a worthwhile exercise." But that is to side-step the issue of whether Porton has caused illness which while not life-threatening may have ruined former volunteers' quality of life.

Once they have received the MRC's advice, ministers will decide whether to go ahead with the study. The MoD realises that unless former guinea pigs are seen to be treated in the fairest way possible their sense of grievance may grow.

The Porton experiments happened a long time before the Blair government came to power, so it is surely in ministers' own interest to get the credit for acting to clear up an apparent injustice from the past.

Gassed - British Chemical Warfare Experiments On Humans At Porton Down, by Rob Evans, will be published in paperback by Stratus in March.

webTitle: Income tax taboo: a recipe for inequality

fields.headline: Income tax taboo: a recipe for inequality
fields.standfirst: As political party leaders prepare to sign off the final drafts of their forthcoming election manifestos, we can be sure that one phrase will not be penned: 'this party shall increase taxation', writes Lisa Harker
fields.trailText: As the party leaders prepare to sign off the final drafts of their forthcoming election manifestos, we can be sure that one phrase will not be penned: "this party shall increase taxation", writes Lisa Harker.
fields.body:
The electorate is widely believed to be intolerant of tax increases, a view that appears to be bolstered by such events as the recent Bristol referendum on council tax. Labour attributed its defeat in the 1992 election to its tax and spend pledges - memorably described by one of its own party members as "the longest suicide note in history". When it comes to elections politicians believe that people will not vote for parties who promise to raise taxes. Consequently taxation has been a common fighting ground during election campaigns.

Interpreting public opinion on taxation is a subtle art. Consecutive British social attitude surveys show that the majority of the public support increases in taxation to fund improvements in health, education and social benefits. And in the 1983, 1987 and 1992 general elections the majority of the population voted for parties (Labour, SDP, Liberal Democrats) that promised to raise taxes or keep the status quo. But for two decades general elections have been won by parties advocating low taxation and it has become conventional political wisdom that tax increases spell electoral disaster.

In 1997 New Labour was so keen to shed its tax and spend image and demonstrate its ability to handle the economy responsibly that it pledged to stick to Tory spending plans for the first two years in office and not to raise income tax. In government, New Labour actually reduced income tax - by lowering the basic rate of tax to 22% and introducing a 10p starting rate. But other taxes did rise, as they had done under the previous government. New Labour continued where the Tories had left off, increasing excise duties and reducing tax reliefs and allowances. With smoke and mirrors, the government sought to give the impression of cutting taxes when actually increasing them.

There was no doubt that taxation needed to rise. The UK is not a high tax country - we pay proportionally less tax than any other EU government except Ireland and Spain. And, particularly after public spending fell in real terms during New Labour's first two years, public services desperately required investment. Increasing income tax has remained a taboo, however. But it would be wrong to assume that the forthcoming election will be a re-run of the 1997 election as far as tax and spend is concerned. Four years on the political landscape is entirely different. New Labour is now making the case for increased public spending and for targeted tax cuts for families with children rather than across the board. Rather than promote the case for reducing taxation per se, both main political parties are making the case for "responsible" tax cuts.

But - with the exception of the Liberal Democrats who support an increase in the top rate of income tax - the main political parties are unlikely to pledge to income tax increases at the next election.

Does it matter? The failure to make the positive case for taxation has long-term consequences for governments' ability to raise sustainable funding. Ultimately governments can not afford to dodge the issue; they will need to be more up-front about tax. As the Fabian Society's tax commission argued, the legitimacy of taxation will only be achieved when citizens understand better how their taxes are spent. But the failure to increase income tax also has consequences for British society.

Over recent decades inequality in Britain has increased faster than any other industrialised country, with the exception of New Zealand. Income tax cuts favouring the better off have contributed to a failure to stem or reverse the rise in inequality: the richest 20% of households are now paying a lower proportion of tax than they were 20 years ago, while the poorest 20% are paying more. If Britain is to become a more equal society policy makers will need address this lack of fairness in the tax system.

 Lisa Harker is research director at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

Labour attributed its defeat in the 1992 election to its tax and spend pledges - memorably described by one of its own party members as "the longest suicide note in history". When it comes to elections politicians believe that people will not vote for parties who promise to raise taxes. Consequently taxation has been a common fighting ground during election campaigns. Interpreting public opinion on taxation is a subtle art. Consecutive British social attitude surveys show that the majority of the public support increases in taxation to fund improvements in health, education and social benefits. And in the 1983, 1987 and 1992 general elections the majority of the population voted for parties (Labour, SDP, Liberal Democrats) that promised to raise taxes or keep the status quo. But for two decades general elections have been won by parties advocating low taxation and it has become conventional political wisdom that tax increases spell electoral disaster. In 1997 New Labour was so keen to shed its tax and spend image and demonstrate its ability to handle the economy responsibly that it pledged to stick to Tory spending plans for the first two years in office and not to raise income tax. In government, New Labour actually reduced income tax - by lowering the basic rate of tax to 22% and introducing a 10p starting rate. But other taxes did rise, as they had done under the previous government. New Labour continued where the Tories had left off, increasing excise duties and reducing tax reliefs and allowances. With smoke and mirrors, the government sought to give the impression of cutting taxes when actually increasing them. There was no doubt that taxation needed to rise. The UK is not a high tax country - we pay proportionally less tax than any other EU government except Ireland and Spain. And, particularly after public spending fell in real terms during New Labour's first two years, public services desperately required investment. Increasing income tax has remained a taboo, however. But it would be wrong to assume that the forthcoming election will be a re-run of the 1997 election as far as tax and spend is concerned. Four years on the political landscape is entirely different. New Labour is now making the case for increased public spending and for targeted tax cuts for families with children rather than across the board. Rather than promote the case for reducing taxation per se, both main political parties are making the case for "responsible" tax cuts. But - with the exception of the Liberal Democrats who support an increase in the top rate of income tax - the main political parties are unlikely to pledge to income tax increases at the next election. Does it matter? The failure to make the positive case for taxation has long-term consequences for governments' ability to raise sustainable funding. Ultimately governments can not afford to dodge the issue; they will need to be more up-front about tax. As the Fabian Society's tax commission argued, the legitimacy of taxation will only be achieved when citizens understand better how their taxes are spent. But the failure to increase income tax also has consequences for British society. Over recent decades inequality in Britain has increased faster than any other industrialised country, with the exception of New Zealand. Income tax cuts favouring the better off have contributed to a failure to stem or reverse the rise in inequality: the richest 20% of households are now paying a lower proportion of tax than they were 20 years ago, while the poorest 20% are paying more. If Britain is to become a more equal society policy makers will need address this lack of fairness in the tax system.  Lisa Harker is research director at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

fields.headline: Brothers in arms
fields.standfirst: Canada's equivalent of the Labour party is, unlike its British counterpart, anti-free trade and plans to protest against the forthcoming Americas summit, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: Ottawa dispatch:Canada's equivalent of the Labour party is, unlike its British counterpart, anti-free trade and plans to protest against the forthcoming Americas summit, writes Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
The leader of the opposition New Democratic Party, Alexa McDonough, and her dozen MPs shifted uncomfortably in their seats and held their applause this week as the British prime minister, Tony Blair, passionately promoted free trade in a speech to the Canadian parliament.

The NDP, Canada's far less successful version of the British Labour party, is so opposed to free trade that Ms McDonough recently announced it would join the anarchists, environmentalists, trade unionists and other anti-globalisation protesters who have circled April 20-22 in their calendars for a post-Seattle reunion.

This is when the biggest free trade summit since the protesters overran the World Trade Organisation talks in Seattle last December will be held in Quebec City.

Leaders from 34 countries, including US President George Bush, Mexican President Vicente Fox Quesada and Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chrétien will discuss a hemispheric free trade zone that would stretch from the shores of the Arctic Ocean to the tip of Patagonia. (The only leader left off the invite list is Cuba's Fidel Castro.)

In his visit, Mr Blair showed how distantly related the two leftwing parties really are. After he praised free trade and vowed to propose new and closer trading ties between the European Union and the Americas, Ms McDonough told reporters the British prime minister didn't mean it, and went on with her plans to join the crowds expected to converge on Quebec City.

The strategy is part of a plan to revamp the party's image after it won only 8.5% of the popular vote in the autumn federal election and dropped from 21 to 13 seats in the House of Commons.

The idea is to look younger, more radical, less "establishment" as well as to challenge the "unfettered power of corporations to shape our lives", as Ms McDonough put it at the press conference where she announced she and her MPs would take a stand against the summit, adding she hoped none of them would be arrested.

Svend Robinson, the MP assigned to lead the caucus protest, said he hopes the demonstration will give the NDP a more radical identity. Mr Robinson, a prominent gay rights activist who has already been arrested once, says the MPs will be peaceful protesters and the possibility that others may get violent shouldn't keep them away.

"Surely we cannot allow protests, peaceful protests, to be hijacked by the threat that some may not be prepared to respect the importance of nonviolence."

But summit organisers don't believe all protesters will follow the example of the mild-mannered NDP. Just in case, they are clearing the local jail of 500 criminals to make room for new detainees.

A three-metre security wall is being erected around a large portion of Quebec's historic old city. It will be manned by as many as 5,000 police officers, included Royal Canadian mounted police officers from across the country. The largest security operation in Canadian history is already drawing sharp criticism from human rights groups.

Protesters, including the NDP, will be forced to stay in special zones far from the trade delegates. In the end, the MPs may find parliament an easier place to have their voices heard: at least there is no tear gas.

fields.headline: Guardian's Weekend goes glossy
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: The Guardian is to turn its Weekend colour supplement into a glossy magazine as it revamps its Saturday edition.
fields.body:
The Guardian is to turn its Weekend colour supplement into a glossy magazine as part of a major revamp of its Saturday edition.

Under editor Katherine Viner, Weekend will increase the number of its editorial pages by 60%, allowing for greater coverage of beauty, fitness, wellbeing and relationships.

From April 21, Weekend will also incorporate the Guardian's Space magazine - currently published on Thursdays - giving it extra coverage of homes and gardens.

And the Editor, whose new editor Michael Hann was appointed last week, will move from Fridays to Saturdays.

"Weekend and the Editor regularly come top of all our readership surveys for Guardian sections," said Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian.

"We're going to nearly double the amount of editorial pages in Weekend and publish it in a new, glossy format.

"Moving the Editor to Saturday will give us later deadlines, enabling us to do the job of summing up the week even better.

"Together with our sports and travels sections, the Guide, the Review and Jobs and Money, it will be an unbeatable package," Mr Rusbridger said.

The changes will be promoted with a marketing push produced by the Guardian's creative agency, BMP DDB.

"We have done extensive research on our weekday and weekend readership, which shows there is room for growth on Saturdays," said Marc Sands, marketing director at Guardian Newspapers.

"People have more time on Saturdays to digest the many elements of the Guardian.

"This has prompted our strategy to invest in Weekend and move the Editor to Saturdays, when readers have more time to enjoy it," he added.

webTitle: Charities call for scrapping shorter jail terms

fields.headline: Charities call for scrapping shorter jail terms
fields.trailText: Penal reform charities have called for shorter jail sentences to be scrapped after the government announced plans for short-term prisoners to serve more of their time under intensive supervision in the community. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Penal reform charities have called for shorter jail sentences to be scrapped after the government announced plans today for short-term prisoners to serve more of their time under intensive supervision in the community.

A leaked memo to the home secretary, Jack Straw, outlined the custody-plus scheme to cut all sentences of a year or less to just three months, with offenders placed under supervision for several months on their release.

The Howard League for penal reform and the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro) said such two to three-month prison sentences should be completely replaced by community schemes.

Frances Crook, director of the Howard League, said such jail terms would do nothing to break the cycle of offending and were purely about punishment.

Ms Crook also criticised proposals that would allow judges to take previous convictions into account when passing sentences. "We don't want to see someone sent to prison for five years because they've sprayed their name on a wall again."

A Nacro spokesman added: "How will sending a persistent offender, who has been in and out of jail, to prison again break the cycle of crime?"

However, both charities broadly welcomed the plans to provide prisoners with better drug treatment, education and skills training, and help with jobs and housing on release, which are part of the government's new 10-year crime reduction strategy.

A spokesman for the Association of Chief Officers of Probation added: "It is very important that short sentenced prisoners are monitored and directed towards the services they need on their release. It is a gap we have long be concerned over."

"Intensive community supervision of prolific offenders, often in conjunction with the police, can have a powerful effect - getting offenders to change their behaviour and to take up drug or employment services that are offered at the same time. The challenge is to get prison, police, probation and local specialist services, like drugs, to co-ordinate together within short time scales."

"Once in place, the benefit in the overall offending rate would be significant and easily demonstrable."

But the Howard League said these extra services must not lead to offenders being sent to prison simply to get an education.

"That has happened with young offenders since detention and training orders were introduced last April," she said. "These orders are the prototype for custody-plus, with half the sentence served in prison and the other half in the community. But there is evidence that magistrates thought 'wow these kids haven't been in school for years but if we lock them up they'll get an education'."

fields.headline: Chrysalis rethinks Puremix.com
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Chrysalis's £4m online music radio venture has been rescued, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Chrysalis's ambitious £4m online music radio venture has been rescued from certain death, saving face for its founders Keith Pringle and Ande MacPherson.

Puremix.com will be shut down on Wednesday and mothballed into another Chrysalis company, online sports network Rivals.net.

Leaks suggested that Puremix, 65%-owned by Chrysalis, would be completely shut down after just three months.

Now, while it has been confirmed that the site will be shut down on Wednesday, this is said to be a temporary measure while Rivals.net, which is 50% owned by Chrysalis, redefines the business model.

Only four of the 33 staff, including co-founders Mr MacPherson and Mr Pringle, will move over to Rivals.net to work on transforming Puremix into a network of music fan sites. The rest have been made redundant.

Puremix.com launched amid a sea of hype in November last year, claiming to be the UK's first ever multi-channel internet radio station.

It took the unusual step of developing 40 different music channels that were tailored to users' personal tastes, and opted not to tie Puremix into Chrysalis Radio and its ready-made audience.

In the months leading up to its heavily promoted launch, Puremix created media speculation by refusing to give any details of its launch other than bandying around the codename Ride the Tiger.

Rivals.net spokesman Mark Terry said it had always planned to launch a music network but would now spend a few months working on how it can do that with Puremix's technology.

It is undecided at this stage whether Rivals.net, a joint venture between Chrysalis and the US sports site Rivals.com, will keep the name Puremix.

"We believe we can develop a similar proposition for music as we've done with sport - a fan-based community-oriented network," said Mr Terry.

Rivals.net operates 350 independent sports websites within its network.

webTitle: Little sign of panic buying meat

fields.headline: Little sign of panic buying
fields.standfirst:
Stocks expected to last if public shops as normal

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Supermarkets, independent butchers, and processed food manufacturers were preparing contingency plans over the weekend to switch from British to imported supplies of pork, lamb and beef, but panic buying failed to materialise.
fields.body:
Supermarkets, independent butchers, and processed food manufacturers were preparing contingency plans over the weekend to switch from British to imported supplies of pork, lamb and beef, but panic buying failed to materialise.

They said there was enough British meat in the supply chain to cover the current ban on the movement of livestock, if consumers stick to normal patterns of buying.

Supermarkets reported adequate stocks, with the exception of a few areas where people appeared to have responded to reports in some newspapers about the possibility of shortages.

Sainsbury's said its buyers had checked branches across the country and found that people were buying as normal. Panic buying might make "a good story, but it's not true from what we've seen", said a spokeswoman, Mandy Percy.

Sales of red meat have been flat for some time. The season for British new lamb is coming to an end and new season lamb would start coming from New Zealand over the next couple of months even if there were no foot and mouth crisis.

Sainsbury's were confident of continuity of supply. "There is still plenty of beef, and extra pork will come from Northern Ireland. These are supply chains that already exist," said Ms Percy. Sainsbury's was not expecting any changes in prices.

Asda and Tesco said it was business as usual with no evidence of panic buying. "We're 100% confident we've got supplies to keep everything as normal," said Zaria Pinchbeck, spokeswoman for Asda. The company buys all its meat in the UK but said switching to foreign suppliers presented no difficulties. It had also ordered 200,000 frozen turkeys in case of a sudden surge in demand.

Ready meals and processed foods such as meat pies depend largely on meat from the UK. Supplies would be disrupted by the end of the week unless manufacturers started sourcing meat from overseas, but the food chain was very flexible, according to a spokesman for the Food and Drink Manufacturing Federation.

Consumers appeared to have taken on board government reassurances that there was no need for panic and that foot and mouth disease represented no risk to human health. The food standards agency said it was possible that some infected meat might have gone on sale in the few weeks before the first case was confirmed but that eating infected meat posed no risk to people. Leftover food should not be fed to pets, however.

Despite reports from the supermarkets and independent retailers' associations that people were shopping as usual, some of the tabloid papers ran stories about a widespread rush to stock up.

"Britain was gripped by panic buying yesterday, amid fears of looming meat shortages," the Sunday Mirror said.

"Sales of fresh meat soared yesterday as shoppers rushed to fill their baskets fearing the foot and mouth outbreak will cause shortages," according to the Sunday Express.

The Daily Mail and the Daily Express led their front pages on Saturday with the idea that there might be shortages.

A few instances of panic buying were reported. Waitrose said that at one branch in Henleaze, Birmingham, there had been a 50% increase in demand for fresh meat. Kwik Save in Stirchley, Birmingham, sold out of frozen meat by lunchtime on Saturday.

But Asda said its customer service hotline was very quiet. Retailers were watching in case the prophecies of scarcity became self-fulfilling as they had done in the fuel crisis last autumn, but felt the picture this weekend looked different.

"In the petrol crisis people did panic buy food, but it was staples, like bread and milk, not meat," Ms Pinchbeck said.

fields.headline: C4's M&S film fails to attract
fields.trailText: 4.15pm TV overnights: A Channel 4 documentary about Marks & Spencer failed to whip up much interest last night. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A documentary about Marks & Spencer's recent troubles failed to whip up much interest last night, pulling in fewer than 2m viewers.

Channel 4's Inside Marks and Spencer charted the firm's rise from humble 19th Century beginnings to high street hegemony and recent decline.

But the documentary managed just 1.8m viewers and a 7% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

It was beaten by a BBC2 repeat of 1970s second world war documentary The World at War, which drew 2.1m.

Channel 4 had more success from 9pm last night with a repeat of Monty Python's Life of Brian. The film had 2.6m and a 12% share.

Another movie repeat, Clint Eastwood cop flick Magnum Force, also did well last night on Channel 5 from 9pm.

Magnum Force took 2.2m and an 11% share.

BBC1 drama Monarch of the Glen completed its eight-week run between 8.10 and 9pm.

The light-hearted drama, which stars Richard Briers and Susan Hampshire, finished with 6.9m, averaging a respectable 6.85m and 25% share across its run.

But Monarch of the Glen was still left trailing far behind ITV Sunday night stalwart Heartbeat, which has averaged 12.9m and a 47% share over the past eight weeks.

From 9pm last night, BBC1 drama Best of Both Worlds lost 600,000 viewers in its second episode.

The second instalment of the three-parter, which stars Alive Evans as an air stewardess with husbands in two countries, slipped to 4.7m.

On Friday night from 9pm, new BBC2 documentary Middle Classes: Their Rise and Sprawl got the better of a Friends repeat and the return of sitcom Spaced on Channel 4.

Middle Classes had 2.8m and a 12% share; while Friends pulled in 2.3m and Spaced had just 1.7m.

webTitle: Design Museum appoints Rawsthorne as director

fields.headline: Design Museum appoints Rawsthorne as director
fields.trailText: 4pm:The Financial Times's architecture and design critic is joining the Design Museum as its director, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Alice Rawsthorne, the Financial Times's architecture and design critic, is joining the Design Museum as director.

Ms Rawsthorne left her staff job as the paper's entertainment industry correspondent 18 months ago to work freelance as a critic with an architecture and design focus.

"I've been obsessed with architecture for years and it was something I'd always wanted to write about. My degree is also in art and architecture," she said.

"I've been really happy in all my jobs at the FT, but this was just such a good opportunity."

Ms Rawsthorne has worked for the FT for almost 15 years, in a variety of jobs from marketing correspondent to Paris correspondent. Before leaving to pursue a career as a critic, she was entertainment industry correspondent.

She has been a trustee of the Design Museum for the past nine years and has done a stint as deputy chairman.

fields.headline: Michelin food guide
fields.standfirst: The restaurant world waits nervously for this week's publication of the new Michelin food guide. Here's our guide to the best sites on the culinary companion and its stingy star ratings
fields.trailText: The restaurant world waits nervously for this week's publication of the new Michelin food guide. Here's our guide to the best sites on the culinary companion and its stingy star ratings.
fields.body:
1. The latest Michelin food guide, France's foremost gastronomic handbook, had a few surprises in store for top Gallic chefs this year.

2. The guide, which awarded 21 French restaurants the coveted three stars (one fewer than last year), will be officially unveiled this Friday.

3. The 100-year-old handbook, renamed the Red Guide this year, released the details early to quash rumours.

4. It's not easy to attain the holy grail of the culinary world and then hang on to it. Alain Ducasse, until last year the only chef to hold a total of six of the food bible's stars, was stripped of three of them at his Monte Carlo eatery, the Louis XV.

5. But as a consolation prize, he did collect three stars for his Paris flagship outfit at the Plaza Athénée hotel.

6. This year's rising star is a black-hatted chef from Savoie, Marc Veyrat, 50 and only the third chef in the history of the guide to receive three stars for two separate establishments.

7. The iconoclastic cook bases his creative cuisine on herbs, roots and wild flowers from the Alps. Detractors say his bills are as high as the nearby mountains.

8. So has the whole of the foodie world gone mad? First, it was the cows. Now they've started burning pigs in droves. But that was after they named an Englishman the new head of France's elitist guide.

9. There aren't that many three stars in the UK, but this year the bad boy of English cuisine, Francophile Gordon Ramsay, was awarded his three stars in recognition of his work at his eponymous restaurant in London's Chelsea district.

10. And surprisingly, a couple of Indian outfits and some pubs were also given the much sought-after gastronomic accolade in this year's British edition.

webTitle: Powell walks tightrope in the Middle East

fields.headline: Powell walks tightrope in the Middle East
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, moved cautiously during his first visit to the Middle East yesterday, pleasing Palestinians by calling on Israel to lift its siege of their cities, while backing the Jewish state's demand for an end to violence.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, moved cautiously during his first visit to the Middle East yesterday, pleasing Palestinians by calling on Israel to lift its siege of their cities, while backing the Jewish state's demand for an end to violence.

The balancing act, during a visit that lasted less than 24 hours, came amid reports that the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, had opened up "channels of communication".

By the time Mr Powell landed in Amman, Jordan, yesterday afternoon on the next leg of a whistle-stop tour of the region, both Israel and the Palestinians were claiming to have made their case with the new US administration.

But the precarious situation Mr Powell left behind asserted itself almost immediately when Palestinian gunmen pumped 20 bullets into a car driven by a Jewish settler north of Ramallah, wounding the motorist. An Israeli woman motorist, also from the Jewish settlement of Ateret, was shot in a separate attack.

Minutes earlier, Mr Powell had told a press conference with Mr Arafat in Ramallah that both sides must move away from violence, and that Israel must lift its siege of the West Bank and Gaza as soon as possible. "It places great hardship on Palestinian families, and does nothing to quiet the security situation in the region," Mr Powell said.

Diplomats say Mr Powell's focus on Israel's punitive blockade of the West Bank and Gaza is meant to stop the hardline Mr Sharon from enacting even harsher measures against the Palestinians once he forms a government.

In diplomatic circles there is growing concern about the economic hardships of ordinary Palestinians, and the precarious financial state of Mr Arafat's administration.

Mr Powell tempered his comments by sympathising with complaints about attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers. In Jerusalem,after a meeting with Mr Sharon, Mr Powell said he was disturbed by Israeli army predictions that the five-month uprising, which has claimed more than 400 lives, would continue to escalate.

Mr Powell said: "We all have to work hard... to bring the violence under control, to get out of this terrible spiral of increasing violence, where we have violence, counter-violence, provocation, counter-provocation. It is time for all leaders in the region to do everything possible to control passions."

The statement was welcome news to Mr Sharon who refuses to end a blockade of Palestinian areas that has stopped more than 100,000 day workers going to their jobs in Israel, or to release some £37m in tax revenues owed to the Palestinians until Mr Arafat reins in the field commanders of the uprising.

"The Palestinian Authority must take immediate action to stop terror and violence," Mr Sharon said. "I will conduct negotiations with the Palestinian Authority following the cessation of hostilities.

Officially, Mr Sharon refuses to hold negotiations with the Palestinians unless Mr Arafat calls on militia commanders to hold fire against Jewish settlements, and until there is a halt to the drive-by shootings on Israeli motorists in the West Bank. Yesterday, however, he confirmed that his emissaries had been holding secret talks with Palestinian leaders. "There are channels of communication," Mr Sharon said.

 An Israeli army sniper who killed a 14-year-old Palestinian this month was jailed for 49 days by his commanding officer, the army said yesterday.

fields.headline: A load of old pants
fields.trailText: Inside Marks And Spencer | Glam And Glitter | Natural World
fields.body:
Fings ain't what they used to be, part one. Once, Marks and Spencer had a 15% share of the British clothing market and, more famously, sold a third of all women's underwear in the UK. From its penny bazaar beginnings, overseen by Michael Marks, a Jewish refugee (or, as he would be called today, a scrounging asylum seeker), to its prime position as the nation embodied on the high street, M&S was seen as the best of British. Its success has reflected the rise and sprawl of the middle classes (to coin a phrase), the meritocratic and entrepreneurial possibilities that successive governments have publicly enthused about, and the notion that management and workforce can work harmoniously, profits and people both being important to the company.

Yet a mere three years on from M&S's fall from grace, this already sounds like ancient history. As the impressive Inside Marks And Spencer (Sunday, Channel 4) charted, M&S's gusset has gone all bobbly and it'll need more than a Remington Fuzzaway to sort it out.

Telling the company's story in an interesting, accessible and jolly way, the documentary boasted a gaggle of talking heads, from Sir Richard Greenbury, who presided over the downturn and became a victim of the internecine boardroom war, to Marjorie and Olive, who worked for the company for years and mused "There were sales assistants and M&S girls. They were a different class." Inside Marks And Spencer had the pace and insight of a business programme, and the warm, beating heart of a social history documentary.

There were wonderful details - how avocados were first sold with leaflets explaining what they were - and broader brushstrokes which highlighted the part the Marks family's Jewishness, and the company's relationship with the nascent nation of Israel, played in M&S's success.

Aside from some odd production choices - superfluous reconstructions, a model in her pants on a staircase, and an uneven, occasionally intrusive soundtrack - Inside Marks And Spencer was enjoyable and intelligent. Because of its subject matter, it was more than a documentary about a shop. It was a documentary about a nation of shopkeepers.

Fings ain't what they used to be, part two. Specifically, the smooth-skinned, bright-eyed boys of glam rock, the subject of Glam And Glitter (Channel 5, Sunday), a mildly distracting history of crimes involving the excess use of eye shadow. From Marc Bolan to some bloke who looked like Ronnie Wood's dad, what Glam And Glitter made clear was that drugs are not good for the skin. Either that, or in the 1970s, they used sulphuric acid as make-up remover.

While fings - and indeed, things - change and the land endures, rivers do neither and both. Before you panic, I'm not getting all Buddhist on you or returning to The Joy Of Paradoxes, I'm simply making a point about permanence in perpetual change. (Zen-like profundity and cheeky humour in one review - how lucky you are.)

Following the Timeless Thames from its source in a boggy field in Cirencester to even more boggy fields before it meets the North Sea, Natural World (BBC2, Sunday) was an absolute joy. Its narrative was as irresistible as a river current, the images it boasted were often downright beautiful, rarely veering into cutesy territory, and, as a narrator, Ian McShane was quite perfect. (You're as surprised as I that I've written those words in that order, but there you go.) You might not choose to be left alone on a barge with him, but McShane - whose voice shifted through heretofore unidentified degrees between languid and lazy - was ideal as a companion from the Cotswolds to Essex.

A particular strength of Natural World was its scope. Not only did it take care to place Old Father Thames in history, from the Magna Carta to the Millennium Dome, it elegantly glided from flood-meadow flowers through high-rise swan nests to the water vole's last refuge from the vicious American mink. Then there was the casual conclusion that since London is sinking faster than Venice, the river could claim the city like a zealous suitor. A deceptively gentle documentary, Natural World showed as many perspectives on the Thames as the river itself had hues, and almost as many undercurrents.

fields.headline: GQ editor slams 'bizarre' claims of rival
fields.trailText:
3pm: GQ editor Dylan Jones has hit out at the claim that the lads' magazine culture was tainting every men's title, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 23: Esquire editor blasts lads' mags
fields.body:
The editor of GQ, Dylan Jones, has hit out at Esquire editor Peter Howarth's claim that the lads' magazine culture was tainting every publication targeting men.

Mr Jones said the claims of Mr Howarth - who edits GQ's rival upmarket men's magazine Esquire - were "bizarre".

"We go to LA twice a year to meet publicists and agents and we find our relationships get better and better," he said.

Although Mr Jones acknowledged that GQ and Esquire were increasingly different from the so-called "lads' mags" like FHM, Maxim and Loaded, he disagreed that they had had a negative effect on magazines' ability to attract celebrities.

"We are a different breed from Maxim and FHM and although they acknowledge that, publicists also understand that lads' magazines fulfil an important function.

"There are so many outlets now, but the demand among readers for celebrity seems to double almost daily.

"Far from being reluctant, publicists seem to be happy to explore other outlets," he said.

Mr Howarth last week claimed that the lads' magazine explosion in the mid to late-90s had damaged relationships between more upmarket "glossy" magazines and celebrity agents.

Men's magazines showed slumping fortunes at the last magazine ABCs, in which Esquire lost 39% of its circulation and Arena lost 21.3%.

webTitle: Kennedy plans tax boost for NHS

fields.headline: Kennedy plans tax boost for NHS
fields.standfirst: Lib Dems' alternative budget (pdf)
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, has called for a new 50p in the pound upper tax rate to pay for an increase in health spending.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, has called for a new 50p in the pound upper tax rate to pay for an increase in health spending.

Setting out an alternative budget ahead of the official statement next Wednesday from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, Mr Kennedy announced proposals for a £1,000 pay rise for Britain's worst-off nurses and midwives, and a five year plan for an expansion of doctors and nurses numbers.

Speaking at the launch of the Lib Dems' "alternative budget" this morning Mr Kennedy said: "People know that you can't get something for nothing. The other parties can't keep pretending that you can cut taxes without cutting public services."

The party  which is in coalition alliance with Labour in both the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly  wants to provide an extra 3,300 training places for doctors and an additional 11,400 for nurses and midwives of five years.

Mr Kennedy also pledged to restore free NHS eye and dental check-ups for all, providing 11,000 extra hospital beds over five years to cut waiting times and paying for all long-term personal care for the elderly.

This plan has already been agreed in Edinburgh for Scottish pensioners after the Scottish Lib Dem leader, Jim Wallace, gave Labour an ultimatum.

The revenue garnered from the new top rate of income tax would also pay for a £500m investment in dental services.

In a bid to head off criticism of being the only party advocating tax increases, the Lib Dems will also propose an annual "tax contract" with the British people, promising to spell out exactly what public money is spent on, and how any changes have affected income tax payers.

The contract would be posted to every household in the UK.

The Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, said the contract would make the Lib Dems the first party to forego the option of "stealth taxes", which he said boosted the total tax-take but went largely unnoticed by voters because they did not affect income tax.

The proposals come amid a flurry of big policy announcements from all the major parties, stoking up the prospect of an early April election in the wake of Gordon Brown's budget on March 7.

fields.headline: Gottlieb to steer OMD Europe
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: OMD Europe has named Colin Gottlieb chief executive as it gears up for a major restructure, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
OMD Europe, the media buying giant whose clients include Sony and McDonald's, has confirmed the appointment of Colin Gottlieb as chief executive as it gears up for a major restructure.

Mr Gottlieb, a founding partner of the OMD-owned Manning Gottlieb Media, will spearhead the company's efforts to become a recognised European media brand.

Until recently, OMD Europe was made up of a network of diverse media companies spread across the continent.

This structure made it difficult for OMD to attract international clients.

As part of the restructure, OMD Europe is to relocate from Paris to a London headquarters.

There are also plans to simplify the company's complicated reporting structure.

Until now, major decisions about the company had to be approved individually by its three major shareholders, the advertising agencies TBWA, BBDO and DDB.

"Our agency shareholders have created a new framework that has tremendous potential," said Mr Gottlieb.

"It is my job to unlock that potential and provide them with a truly integrated European media network, which sits at the top table as a supplier of solutions to major international advertisers."

Mr Gottlieb will report to OMD president Daryl Simm until a worldwide chief executive is hired.

webTitle: Extract: The Trial of Henry Kissinger (III)

fields.headline: A nation betrayed
fields.standfirst: In his explosive new book, The Trial of Henry Kissinger, Christopher Hitchens argues that the former US secretary of state should be prosecuted for crimes against humanity. Here, in our second exclusive extract, he explains why Kissinger should  be held responsible for the bloody invasion of Cyprus
fields.trailText: In his explosive new book, The Trial of Henry Kissinger, Christopher Hitchens argues that the former US secretary of state should be prosecuted for crimes against humanity. Here, in our second exclusive extract, he explains why Kissinger should be held responsible for the bloody invasion of Cyprus
