Part one: Why has he got away with it?

In Years of Upheaval, the second volume of his trilogy of memoirs, Henry Kissinger found the subject of the 1974 Cyprus catastrophe so awkward that he decided to postpone consideration of it: "I must leave a full discussion of the Cyprus episode to another occasion, for it stretched into the Ford presidency and its legacy exists unresolved today."

In most of his writing about himself, Kissinger projects a strong impression of a man at home in the world and on top of his brief. But there are a number of occasions when it suits him to pose as a sort of Candide: naive, ill- prepared for and easily unhorsed by events. No doubt this pose costs him some self-esteem. It is a pose, furthermore, which he often adopts at precisely the time when the record shows him to be knowledgeable, and when knowledge or foreknowledge would confront him with charges of responsibility or complicity.

Kissinger now argues, in the long-delayed third volume of his memoirs, Years of Renewal, that he was prevented and distracted, by Watergate and the meltdown of the Nixon presidency, from taking an interest in the crucial triangle of force between Greece, Turkey and Cyprus. This is a bizarre disclaimer: the proximity of Cyprus to the Middle East was a factor never absent from US strategic thinking, and there was no reason of domestic policy to prevent the region from engaging his attention. Furthermore, the very implosion of Nixonian authority, cited as a reason for Kissinger's absence of mind, in fact bestowed extraordinary powers upon him.

When he became secretary of state in 1973, Kissinger took care to retain his post as special assistant to the president for national security affairs, or national security adviser. This made him the first and only secretary of state to hold the chairmanship of the elite and secretive Forty Committee, which considered and approved covert actions by the CIA. Mean while, as chairman of the National Security Council, he held a position where every important intelligence plan passed across his desk. His former NSC aide, Roger Morris, was not exaggerating by much, if at all, when he said that Kissinger's dual position, plus Nixon's eroded status, made him "no less than acting chief of state for national security".

Kissinger gives one hostage to fortune in Years of Upheaval and another in Years of Renewal. In the former, he says plainly: "I had always taken it for granted that the next intercommunal crisis in Cyprus would provoke Turkish intervention." That is, it would at least risk the prospect of a war within Nato between Greece and Turkey, and would certainly involve the partition of the island. That this was common knowledge may not be doubted by any person even lightly acquainted with Cypriot affairs. In the latter volume, Kissinger repeatedly asks the reader why anyone (such as himself, so burdened with Watergate) would have sought "a crisis in the eastern Mediterranean between two Nato allies".

These two disingenuous statements need to be qualified in the light of a third, which appears on page 199 of Years of Renewal. Here, President Makarios of Cyprus is described without adornment as "the proximate cause of most of Cyprus's tensions". Makarios was the democratically elected leader of a virtually unarmed republic. His rule was challenged, and the independence of Cyprus was threatened, by a military dictatorship in Athens and a highly militarised government in Turkey, both of which sponsored rightwing gangster organisations on the island, and both of which had plans to annex the greater or lesser part of it. Several attempts had been made on Makarios's life. To describe him as "the proximate cause" of the tensions is to make a wildly aberrant moral judgment.

This same judgment, however, supplies the key that unlocks the lie at the heart of Kissinger's presentation. If the elected civilian authority (and spiritual leader of the Greek Orthodox community) is the "proximate cause" of the tensions, then his removal from the scene is self-evidently the cure for them. If one can demonstrate that there was such a removal plan, and that Kissinger knew about it in advance, then it follows logically that he was not ostensibly looking for a crisis - as he self-pityingly asks us to disbelieve - but for a solution. The fact that he got a crisis, which was also a hideous calamity for the region, does not change the equation. It is attributable to the other observable fact that the scheme to remove Makarios, on which the "solution" depended, was in practice a failure. But those who willed the means and wished the ends are not absolved from guilt by the refusal of reality to match their schemes.

It is, from Kissinger's own record, as well as from the record of the subsequent official inquiry, easy to demonstrate that he did have advance knowledge of the plan to depose Makarios. He admits as much himself, by noting that the Greek dictator Dimitrios Ioannides, head of the secret police, was determined to mount a coup in Cyprus and bring the island under the control of Athens. This was one of the better-known facts of the situation, as was the more embarrassing fact that Brigadier Ioannides was dependent on US military aid and political sympathy. His police state had been expelled from the Council of Europe and blocked from joining the EEC, and it was largely the advantage conferred by his agreement to "home port" the US Sixth Fleet, and host a string of US air and intelligence bases, that kept him in power. This policy was highly controversial in Congress and in the American press, and the argument over it was part of Kissinger's daily bread long before Watergate.

Thus it was understood in general that the Greek dictatorship, a US client, wished to see Makarios overthrown and had already tried to have him killed. (Overthrow and assassination, incidentally, are effectively coterminous in this account; there was no possibility of leaving such a charismatic leader alive, and those who sought his removal invariably intended his death.) This was also understood in particular . The most salient proof is this. In May 1974, two months before the coup in Nicosia, which Kissinger later claimed was a shock, he received a memorandum from the head of his state department Cyprus desk, Thomas Boyatt. Boyatt summarised the reasons for believing that a Greek junta attack on Cyprus was imminent. He further argued that, in the absence of a US representation to Athens, warning the dictators to desist, it might be assumed that the United States was indifferent to this. And he added what everybody knew - that such a coup, if it went forward, would beyond doubt trigger a Turkish invasion.

Prescient memos are a dime a dozen in Washington after a crisis; they are often then read for the first time, or leaked to the press or Congress. But Kissinger now admits that he saw this document in real time, while engaged in his shuttle between Syria and Israel (both of them within half an hour's flying time of Cyprus). Yet no démarche bearing his name or carrying his authority was issued to the Greek junta.

A short while afterwards, Kissinger received a call from Senator J William Fulbright, the chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee. Senator Fulbright had been briefed about the impending coup by a senior Greek dissident journalist in Washington named Elias P Demetracopoulos. He told Kissinger that steps should be taken to avert the planned Greek action, and he gave three reasons. The first was that it would repair some of the moral damage done by the US governments indulgence of the junta. The second was that it would head off a confrontation between Greece and Turkey in the Mediterranean. The third was that it would enhance US prestige on the island. Kissinger declined to take the recommended steps, on the bizarre grounds that he could not intervene in Greek "internal affairs" at a time when the Nixon administration was resisting pressure from Senator Henry Jackson to link US-Soviet trade to the free emigration of Russian Jewry. However odd this line of argument, it still makes it impossible for Kissinger to claim, as he still does, that he had had no warn ing.

So there was still no high-level US concern registered with Athens. The difficulty is sometimes presented as one of protocol or etiquette, as if Kissinger's regular custom was to whisper and tread lightly. But again I remind you that Henry Kissinger, in addition to his formal diplomatic eminence, was also head of the Forty Committee, and supervisor of covert action, and was dealing in private with an Athens regime that had long-standing CIA ties. Boyatt's memoranda, warning of what was to happen, were classified as secret and have still never been released. Asked to testify to a Congressional hearing, he was at first forbidden by Kissinger to appear. He was only finally permitted to do so in order that he might avoid a citation for contempt. His evidence was taken in "executive session", with the hearing room cleared of staff, reporters and visitors.

Events continued to gather pace. On July 1 1974, three senior officials of the Greek foreign ministry, all known for their moderate views on the Cyprus question, publicly tendered their resignations. On July 3, President Makarios made public an open letter to the Greek junta, which made the direct accusation of foreign interference and subversion. He called for the withdrawal from Cyprus of the officers responsible.

Some days after the coup, which eventually occurred on July 15 1974, when challenged at a press conference about his apparent failure to foresee or avert it, Kissinger replied that "the information was not lying around in the streets". Actually, it almost was in the streets. But more importantly, it had been available to him round the clock, in both his diplomatic and his intelligence capacities. His decision to do nothing was therefore a direct decision to do something, or to let something be done.

To the rest of the world, two things were obvious about the coup. The first was that it had been instigated from Athens and carried out with the help of regular Greek forces, and was thus a direct intervention in the internal affairs of one country by another. The second was that it violated all the existing treaties governing the status of Cyprus. The obvious and unsavoury illegality was luridly emphasised by the junta itself, which chose a notorious chauvinist gunman named Nicos Sampson to be its proxy "president". Sampson must have been well known to the chairman of the Forty Committee as a long-standing recipient of financial support from the CIA; he also received money for his fanatical Nicosia newspaper Makhi (Combat) from a pro-junta CIA proxy in Athens, Savvas Constantopoulos, the publisher of the pro-junta organ Eleftheros Kosmos (Free World). No European government treated Sampson as anything but a pariah, for the brief nine days in which he held power and launched a campaign of murder against his democratic Greek opponents. But Kissinger told the US envoy in Nicosia to receive Sampson's "foreign minister" as foreign minister, thus making the United States the first and only government to extend de facto recognition. (At this point, it might be emphasised, the whereabouts of Makarios were unknown. His palace had been shelled and his death announced on the junta's radio. He had in fact made his escape, and was able to broadcast the fact a few days afterwards - to the irritation of certain well-placed persons.) In his 1986 memoir The Truth, published in Athens in 1986, the then head of the Greek armed forces, General Grigorios Bonanos, records that the junta's attack on Cyprus brought a message of approval and support, delivered to its intelligence service by no less a man than Thomas A Pappas - the chosen intermediary between the junta and the Nixon-Kissinger administration.

In Washington, Kissinger's press spokesman Robert Anderson flatly denied that the coup - later described by Makarios from the podium of the United Nations as "an invasion" - constituted foreign intervention. "No," he replied to a direct question on this point. "In our view there has been no outside intervention." This surreal position was not contradicted by Kissinger when he met with the ambassador of Cyprus and failed to offer the customary condolences on the reported death of his president - the "proximate cause", we now learn from him, of all the unpleasantness. When asked if he still recognised the elected Makarios government as the legal one, Kissinger doggedly and astonishingly refused to answer. When asked if the United States was moving towards recognition of the Sampson regime, his spokesman declined to deny it. When Makarios came to Washington on July 22, the state department was asked whether he would be received by Kissinger "as a private citizen, as Archbishop, or as President of Cyprus?" The answer? "He [Kissinger] is meeting with Archbishop Makarios on Monday." Every other government in the world, save the collapsing Greek dictatorship, recognised Makarios as the legitimate head of the Cyprus republic. Kissinger's unilateralism on the point is without diplomatic precedent, and argues strongly for his collusion and sympathy with the armed handful of thugs who felt the same way.

It is worth emphasising that Makarios was invited to Washington in the first place, as elected and legal president of Cyprus, by Senator J William Fulbright of the Senate foreign relations committee, and by his counterpart Congressman Thomas Morgan, chairman of the house foreign affairs committee. Credit for this invitation belongs to Elias Demetracopoulos, the Washington-based dissident journalist, who had long warned of the coup. He it was who conveyed the invitation to Makarios, who was then in London meeting the British foreign secretary. This initiative crowned a series of anti-junta activities by this journalist, who had already profoundly irritated Kissinger and become a special object of his spite. At the very last moment, and with very poor grace, Kissinger was compelled to announce that he was receiving Makarios in his presidential and not his episcopal capacity.

Since Kissinger himself tells us that he had always known or assumed that another outbreak of violence in Cyprus would trigger a Turkish military intervention, we can assume in our turn that he was not surprised when such an intervention came. Nor does he seem to have been very much disconcerted. While the Greek junta remained in power, his efforts were principally directed to shielding it from retaliation. He was opposed to the return of Makarios to the island, and strongly opposed to Turkish or British use of force (Britain being a guarantor power with a treaty obligation and troops in place on Cyprus) to undo the Greek coup. This same counsel of inertia or inaction - amply testified to in his own memoirs - translated later into strict and repeated admonitions against any measures to block a Turkish invasion. Sir Tom McNally, then the chief political adviser to Britain's then foreign secretary and future prime minister, James Callaghan, has since disclosed that Kissinger "vetoed" at least one British military action to pre-empt a Turkish landing.

This may seem paradoxical, but the long-standing sympathy for a partition of Cyprus, repeatedly expressed by the state and defence departments, makes it seem much less so. The demographic composition of the island (82% Greek to 18% Turkish) made it more logical for the partition to be imposed by Greece. But a second-best was to have it imposed by Turkey. And, once Turkey had conducted two brutal invasions and occupied almost 40% of Cypriot territory, Kissinger exerted himself very strongly to protect Ankara from any congressional reprisal for this outright violation of international law, and promiscuous and illegal misuse of US weaponry. He became so pro-Turkish, indeed, that it was as if he had never heard of the Greek colonels. (Though his expressed dislike of the returned Greek democratic leaders supplied an occasional reminder.)

Not all the elements of this partitionist policy can be charged to Kissinger personally; he inherited the Greek junta and the official dislike of Makarios. However, even in the dank obfuscatory prose of his own memoirs, he does admit what can otherwise be concluded from independent sources. Using covert channels, and short-circuiting the democratic process in his own country, he made himself an accomplice in a plan of political assassination which, when it went awry, led to the deaths of thousands of civilians, the violent uprooting of almost 200,000 refugees, and the creation of an unjust and unstable amputation of Cyprus which constitutes a serious threat to peace a full quarter-century later. On July 10 1976, the European Commission on Human Rights adopted a report, prepared by 18 distinguished jurists and chaired by Professor JES Fawcett, resulting from a year's research into the consequences of the Turkish invasion. It found that the Turkish army had engaged in the deliberate killing of civilians, in the execution of prisoners, in the torture and ill-treatment of detainees, in the arbitrary punishment and detention of civilians, and in systematic acts of rape, torture, and looting. A large number of "disappeared" persons, both prisoners of war and civilians, are still "missing" from this period. They include a dozen holders of US passports, which is evidence in itself of an indiscriminate strategy, when conducted by an army dependent on US aid and matériel.

Perhaps it was a reluctance to accept his responsibility for these outrages, as well as his responsibility for the original coup, that led Kissinger to tell a bizarre sequence of lies to his new friends the Chinese. On October 2 1974, he held a high-level meeting in New York with Qiao Guanhua, vice-foreign minister of the People's Republic. It was the first substantive Sino-American meeting since the visit of Deng Xiaoping, and the first order of business was Cyprus. The memorandum, which is headed "Top secret/sensitive/exclusively eyes only", has Kissinger first rejecting China's public claim that he had helped engineer the removal of Makarios. "We did not. We did not oppose Makarios." (This claim is directly belied by his own memoirs.) He says: "When the coup occurred I was in Moscow", which he was not. He says: "My people did not take these intelligence reports [concerning an impending coup] seriously," even though they had. He says that neither did Makarios take them seriously, even though Makarios had publicly denounced the Athens junta for its coup plans. Kissinger then makes the amazing claim: "We knew the Soviets had told the Turks to invade", which would make this the first Soviet-instigated invasion to be conducted by a Nato army and paid for with US aid.

A good liar must have a good memory: Kissinger is a stupendous liar with a remarkable memory. So perhaps some of this hysterical lying is explained by its context - by the need to enlist China's anti-Soviet instincts. But the total of falsity is so impressive that it suggests something additional, something more like denial or delusion, or even a confession by other means.

 Extracted from The Trial of Henry Kissinger by Christopher Hitchens, to be published by Verso, price £15, in May. © Christopher Hitchens.

It was the first substantive Sino-American meeting since the visit of Deng Xiaoping, and the first order of business was Cyprus. The memorandum, which is headed "Top secret/sensitive/exclusively eyes only", has Kissinger first rejecting China's public claim that he had helped engineer the removal of Makarios. "We did not. We did not oppose Makarios." (This claim is directly belied by his own memoirs.) He says: "When the coup occurred I was in Moscow", which he was not. He says: "My people did not take these intelligence reports [concerning an impending coup] seriously," even though they had. He says that neither did Makarios take them seriously, even though Makarios had publicly denounced the Athens junta for its coup plans. Kissinger then makes the amazing claim: "We knew the Soviets had told the Turks to invade", which would make this the first Soviet-instigated invasion to be conducted by a Nato army and paid for with US aid. A good liar must have a good memory: Kissinger is a stupendous liar with a remarkable memory. So perhaps some of this hysterical lying is explained by its context - by the need to enlist China's anti-Soviet instincts. But the total of falsity is so impressive that it suggests something additional, something more like denial or delusion, or even a confession by other means.  Extracted from The Trial of Henry Kissinger by Christopher Hitchens, to be published by Verso, price £15, in May. © Christopher Hitchens.

fields.headline: Murdoch signs Loudcloud deal
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: News Corp has linked up with a web services company to develop internet businesses, reports Amy Vickers.
Jan 29: Prophets of doom at online news profits
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch is back in the internet game less than a month after he pulled the plug on News International's internet division, axing more than 200 staff.

The media giant has signed a deal with Loudcloud, an internet services company run by former Netscape founder Marc Andreessen, to develop a number of web-based businesses.

Loudcloud will provide the infrastructure upon which News Corp will be able to build stronger and more consistent sites.

In the past, News Corp has made a number of bad internet investments.

The turning point came late last year when it ditched many investments including its £690m alliance with online health network WebMD.

That decision that left News Corp with losses of £140m.

In the UK, News International's internet division, run by Murdoch's son-in-law Alasdair McLeod, is now effectively defunct after all the websites were moved closer to each respective paper and Revolver.com was turned into the Times Appointments.

Auction site FiredUp.com operates as a ghost site handling a bare minimum of auctions.

Mr Murdoch's love/hate relationship with the web has been well documented.

At the start of 1999, he was a self-confessed internet heretic but, by the end of the year, he was a convert, pledging to invest around £2bn in internet ventures.

The Loudcloud deal was announced to analysts during the internet company's two-week roadshow.

This was aimed at generating interest in Loudcloud's imminent stock market flotation.

The tie-up has been the subject of speculation for a number of weeks but has not yet been announced publicly.

fields.headline: India braces itself
fields.standfirst:
New earth tremors in northern India have raised the ominous spectre of further earthquakes to come for the country's stricken people, says Luke Harding

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: New earth tremors in northern India have raised the ominous spectre of further earthquakes to come for the country's stricken people, says Luke Harding in New Delhi.
fields.body:
It started with a sudden jolting just before 8am yesterday. There were two tremors a few seconds apart. The walls of our precariously built third floor flat started wobbling and the floor began to heave up and down.

This time we knew exactly what to do. Without hanging around, we scooped up our two children - Tilly, aged three and a half, and Ruskin, eight months - and ran out onto our roof terrace. We stood under a blue sky made fresh by overnight rain, admired the flourishing pot plants and took a deep breath.

Across New Delhi, India's earthquake spooked capital, residents poured onto the streets. It was almost as if the city's 12m people had uttered a great collective cry of: "Oh no, not again."

In the end the tremors which billowed across north India and Pakistan yesterday were not the harbinger of disaster, as we had feared. The earthquake's epicentre in Afghanistan, close to the Tajikistan border, was deep underground. The quake measured 6.7 on the Richter scale, strong enough also to startle residents in Afghanistan's capital Kabul out of their beds.

But the tremors were far less destructive than those that ripped across the western state of Gujarat in India exactly a month ago. At least 30,000 people were killed in the previous quake. The earlier tremors, which were felt across the subcontinent were different - stronger, more intense, and endlessly long. Our bed swayed to and fro for at least two surreal minutes, while we tried to figure out what this sudden and unwanted upheaval meant.

But it is no fun living in an earthquake zone, as India is rapidly discovering. Over the past month, the Indian papers have been full of gloomy prognostications about what would happen if an earthquake struck the capital directly.

What is worse, rumour has it that a catastrophic earthquake will engulf Delhi in April. It is no secret that many of the capital's buildings have been poorly constructed, using inferior materials. There has been no planning whatsoever. The city has just expanded southwards, in a chaotic matrix of pseudo-baroque farmhouses and high rise flats.

Were an earthquake to strike the region, all these slipshod buildings would collapse, entombing not only tenants but also Delhi's avaricious landlord class who tend to live in the ground floors of the buildings they have constructed. The results would be more devastating than in Gujarat, where the worst affected region, Kutch, is one of the least populated parts of the whole country.

The reason that Delhi is at such high risk is because of its location at the centre of a high intensity earthquake zone known as Triple Plate Junction. It is the meeting point of three giant tectonic plates - the Indo-Pak, the western Himalayan and the Arabian. Already, after two earthquakes in one month, residents are developing a healthy sense of fatalism - a sensible attitude, of course, encouraged anyway by orthodox Hinduism.

The response from the authorities towards the prospect of a quake far greater than the Kutch disaster has, predictably, been feeble; at times it has even been comic. Police in Gujarat, for example, have locked up several astrologers on the grounds that they had been inciting panic by predicting another earthquake.

A government committee has been set up to examine the much-criticised official response to the Gujarat disaster, which in the first 48 hours was pathetically slow. But the committee's conclusions, if they ever are any, are likely to be consigned to a drawer, only to be dug out after the next catastrophe.

Delhi residents can only hope that the brooding rumours about April are wrong. But for the next few months at least they will sleep more fitfully than before, with darker, more troubling dreams filled with images of collapsing ceilings and disappearing walls.

fields.headline: Jill Dando murder trial opens
fields.trailText: The man accused of killing TV presenter Jill Dando appeared in court today for the first day of his murder trial.
fields.body:
The man accused of killing TV presenter Jill Dando appeared in court today for the first day of his murder trial.

Barry George, 40, was led into the dock of the Old Bailey's maximum security Court Number One in front of a packed public gallery and about 50 reporters. The man who was to marry Dando, gynaecologist Alan Farthing, and her fellow BBC Crimewatch presenter Nick Ross were among those at the court.

Mr George, of Fulham, west London, stood briefly to confirm his name. He is charged with murdering 37-year-old Dando on the doorstep of her home in Fulham on April 26, 1999. Mr George - who calls himself Barry Bulsara in tribute to dead singer Freddie Mercury, whose real name it was - appeared in court last month to plead not guilty to the charge.

Michael Mansfield QC, is defending Mr George at the trial, which is expected to last up to six weeks.

Dando's murder sparked a public outpouring of grief, with condolence messages flooding into the BBC. The corporation received 9,400 emails in the 30 hours after her murder.

In her career at the BBC, Dando had presented news programmes and was best known for hosting the shows Holiday and Crimewatch.

webTitle: Social services benefit from audit by people with disabilities

fields.headline: Social services benefit from audit by people with disabilities
fields.trailText: Enabling people with disabilities to audit social services gives them more power to shape care packages and provides local authorities with a more honest assessment of service users' needs, a project in Hampshire has found. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Enabling people with disabilities to audit social services gives them more power to shape care packages and provides local authorities with a more honest assessment of service users' needs, a project in Hampshire has found.

The Hampshire consumer audit project trains disabled people to evaluate the effectiveness of community care services. As the auditors have personal experience of these services they appreciate other users' needs and help them to get their views across to commissioners and service providers.

The scheme, set up by the Southampton centre for independent living (SCIL) in 1996, has carried out seven audits of social service departments across Hampshire. Social workers say it has improved their understanding of the impact that good and bad care packages have on users' lives.

User-led monitoring of social services has been criticised as "tokenistic" by mental health charities. Dr Diana Rose, a researcher for the Sainsbury centre for mental health, said some commissioners undermined such audits. "They don't provide users with the training or resources necessary to carry out a robust evaluation, so their findings can easily be ignored," she said.

But SCIL co-ordinator Neil Luckett said its audits were based on the 12 basic needs of disabled people: housing, transport, technical equipment, personal assistance, education and training, employment, income, information, advocacy, counselling and appropriate health care. Auditors check that services make a difference in these key areas to ensure people with disabilities have the same opportunities as non-disabled people.

"Auditors receive thorough training in areas such as interview techniques over seven weeks, which goes towards a level two NVQ in information and communication technology," said Mr Luckett.

"We also pay them £33 per day and reimburse their expenses as they are providing a valuable service. For many this is their first experience of paid employment. Some have moved on to part-time work elsewhere."

Bev, who uses a wheelchair, said working as a consumer auditor had boosted her confidence and helped her to come to terms with her disability. "I feel we've made a real difference to users' lives and by helping them we're also helped ourselves as service users. They feel able to speak openly because we've been in similar situations. With social workers they're wary that criticism could lead to the withdrawal of that service," she explained.

She said social services had acted on their recommendations. "In our audit of mental health services in East Hampshire, we found service users wanted access to a day centre that was 20 miles away because many of their friends used it. We advised the council to sell their current day centre to pay for a minibus to take them to the other one and it did."

Geoff Humphreys, project manager for Portsmouth social services, said the SCIL audit was far more robust and informative than previous surveys by social workers and the University of Portsmouth. "We believe the consumer audit represents service users' true feelings whereas previous studies have only given us guarded answers or what they think we want to hear," he said.

The audit, completed two weeks ago, found that service users preferred assessments to be carried out by social services rather than private external agencies. "This fed into our best value review. We will now ensure that quality assurance is at the heart of contracting," commented Mr Humpreys.

The audit's findings also provided a useful baseline to improve services before the council is subjected to a joint review in 2002, he added.

Neil Luckett said SCIL hoped to involve more ethnic minority users in auditing in the future. "At the moment they're sealed in their communities and don't get involved in volunteering or focus groups. Hopefully, by offering them training and employment we can overcome their reluctance."

fields.headline: Holloway moves to Loftus Road
fields.trailText: Ian Holloway was today named as the new manager of First Division strugglers Queens Park Rangers.
fields.body:
Ian Holloway was today named as the new manager of First Division strugglers Queens Park Rangers.

Holloway, who made more than 200 appearances for the Loftus Road club between 1991 and 1996, was sacked as manager of Second Division Bristol Rovers last month and takes over from Gerry Francis, who resigned a fortnight ago.

Rovers almost won a play-off place under Holloway last season, but endured a dramatic change of fortune this season, failing to win a home game prior to his departure on January 30.

Rangers themselves are currently fourth bottom of the First Division and were on the wrong end of a 5-0 drubbing at Wimbledon on Saturday. But Holloway remains confident of achieving success.

"I totally believe in my heart we can stay up," the 37-year-old said. "We've had some cruel injuries but I think with determination and belief it's amazing what you can achieve.

"I can't wait to take it on and I feel we can kick on from this. QPR was a huge part of my playing career and I felt so proud. Anybody that watched me play could see what I was - whole-hearted and determined. The players have got to work hard and they'll get honesty and enthusiasm from me and hopefully that will rub off."

Holloway has signed a one-and-a-half year contract with Rangers with options for an extension. He will take charge of first-team affairs tomorrow morning and will work alongside his former mentor Francis, who has become the club's director of football.

The former Rovers boss refused to comment on the future of Iain Dowie, who has been working as Francis' assistant until last week.

webTitle: BBC boosts presence at Dando trial

fields.headline: BBC boosts presence at Dando trial
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: The BBC is expected to deploy extra crews to ensure its coverage of the Jill Dando trial is not disrupted by a work to rule, reports Jason Deans.
11.30am: Dando trial adjourned
Feb 21: BBC staff to work to rule
fields.body:
The BBC is expected to deploy extra camera crews today to ensure its news coverage of the Jill Dando murder trial is not disrupted by a work to rule.

Broadcasting union Bectu, which launched the industrial action this morning over new expenses rules, is expecting BBC managers to book double the usual number of camera crews to cover for staff returning to base for lunch.

As part of the work to rule, Bectu members will be returning to their BBC office for lunch if they are working less than five miles away, in protest against a £6 limit placed on meal expenses claims.

That could leave the corporation without camera crews on important breaking stories.

These include the Dando murder trial at the Old Bailey, which is less than five miles away from news headquarters in TV Centre, west London.

Union members could take up to two-and-a-half hours for the round trip across the capital.

In normal circumstances they would have a 60-minute lunch break.

A BBC spokesman said however that news crews at the Old Bailey would be able to go to nearby Bush House for lunch and he did not foresee any disruption.

Unions say other stories that could be hit by the action include prime minister Tony Blair's visit to Pentonville Prison and the foot-and-mouth crisis.

"They are going to have to double the crew to cover these stories," said a senior Bectu source.

"The BBC is saying staff can only spend £6 on lunch in order to save money but it is going to cost them a lot to get this news footage."

Bectu called the work to rule for today after its BBC members voted in favour of industrial action over the new expenses rules announced earlier this month.

Feb 21: BBC staff to work to rule

fields.headline: Yell.com launches first TV ads
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Yell.com, the internet arm of the Yellow Pages, has unveiled its first TV advertising campaign, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Yell.com, the internet arm of the Yellow Pages, is bucking the current trend towards belt-tightening among dot.coms by spending millions of pounds on its first-ever TV advertising campaign.

The news comes as Yellow Pages owner BT prepares to float or demerge the company in a bid to reduce its debt load.

Companies frequently launch big consumer advertising campaigns ahead of a sale or flotation in the hope of increasing the value of the brand.

The 30-second TV advert, created by Partners BDDH, introduces the slogan, "Don't search, just Yell.com".

Featuring music from Elastica, it shows five situations in which people could have benefited from using Yell.

The adverts break on March 1 and will be broadcast nationally until April 4.

The TV ad is backed by a series of online teaser ads that use stick drawings in a series of cartoons to highlight the services offered on Yell.

The pop-up ads, called superstitials, feature a stick man facing a series of problems that could have been solved by Yell.com. At the end of each cartoon, users are given the opportunity to click onto the Yell.com home page.

"Superstitials have proven to be more effective than banner ads, and only a handful of companies have used them so far," said John Hayward, director of consumer communications at Yell.

"We have tried to move the quality of superstitial ads a little further by using the full capability offered by the technology, and create a truly entertaining and campaignable idea."

fields.headline: Losing the Saudi cyberwar
fields.standfirst:
The Saudi government's attempts to filter the internet for its citizens are narrow-minded, unrealistic and, it seems, doomed to failure, says Brian Whitaker

Full text of new Saudi government regulations
fields.trailText: The Saudi government's attempts to filter the internet for its citizens are narrow-minded, unrealistic and, it seems, doomed to failure, says Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
The authorities in Saudi Arabia, who recently boasted that they had found a way to censor the internet, are now licking their wounds in a cyberwar against an opposition group based in London.

It is only two years since the authorities decided - nervously - to connect their country to the internet. They were worried, right from the start, that internet users could not be trusted to stay away from pornographic, gambling and other "undesirable" websites.

So they spent vast sums on a computer system at King Abdulaziz City of Science and Technology in Riyadh, which has Saudi Arabia's only recognised link to the internet, to filter out offending material. In May last year, Dr Fahd al-Hoymany, director of the monitoring system, announced triumphantly that his team had succeeded in blocking all major pornographic sites.

But that was not the whole story. They were quietly using the same technology to block politically sensitive sites which criticised the Saudi government.

The Saudis' internet censorship works in two ways. First, it caches approved web pages in a 500-gigabyte storage system. This allows the most popular pages to be accessed quickly without the system having to check their suitability each time. It also means that what users in Saudi Arabia see is not the original page on a server outside the country, but a copy on the computer in Riyadh.

Requests for pages that are not stored in the cache are passed to the second stage of the system, supplied by a US-based company, Websense, which lists and can filter out 30 categories of potentially unsuitable sites. Maintaining the list of banned sites is a mammoth task for the team in Riyadh, because of the need for regular updating.

Among those they tried to ban was a website belonging to the London-based Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia (MIRA). As its name suggests, the site is certainly not pornographic, though it does contain some highly unflattering profiles of Saudi princes.

For a while, MIRA and the Saudi authorities played a cat-and-mouse game. Each time the site was blocked, MIRA moved to a new web address. It usually took the authorities a week to find the new address and block it. In the meantime, MIRA's problem was how to communicate its new address to web users in Saudi Arabia.

That, according to Dr Saad Fagih of MIRA, has now been solved - and it's the opposition's turn to claim victory. MIRA's solution - like the Saudis' censoring system - consists of two stages. The first is some technical tweaking of port numbers which allows MIRA to switch its website almost instantly to any one of 64,000 addresses without having to register a new domain name.

The second is a smart way of telling people where to find the site. Users simply send a blank email to islah@islah.org and within 60 seconds or so they get an automated reply giving the current address. Provided that users send their message by webmail - Hotmail, Yahoo, etc - there is no way the authorities can stop it, Dr Fagih says (if you try this, bear in mind that MIRA's site is in Arabic, so you may see a lot of question marks or weird symbols if your web browser doesn't support Arabic script).

As proof of his victory over Big Brother in Riyadh, Dr Fagih says the number of hits on the site has leapt from 20,000 a day to 75,000. What is more, he claims that Big Brother has finally abandoned its efforts to block the site (he knows this, he says, because MIRA's technicians are able to hack into the computer in Riyadh and check).

Belatedly, the Saudi authorities have also recognised that their expensive censoring system may not be as effective as they thought. But their response has been bizarre. On February 12, the Council of Ministers laid down new internet rules for the kingdom. Among other things, these ordered internet users to refrain from accessing data containing the following:

 Anything contrary to the state or its system
 News damaging to the Saudi Arabian armed forces
 Anything damaging to the dignity of heads of states
 Any false information ascribed to state officials
 Subversive ideas
 Slanderous or libellous material

At one level, this is almost a self-parody, providing abundant ammunition for all those who decry Saudi Arabia as a backward, medieval country with more money than sense. It smacks of the attitude found in Britain a few hundred years ago among those who believed the masses should not be taught to read in case they got some unsuitable ideas into their heads.

At another level, it demonstrates that the Saudi government is living in a fantasy world where internet users are endowed with magical powers which allow them to determine whether a web page contains false information, subversive ideas or libellous material even before they have looked at it.

fields.headline: England unveil new kit
fields.standfirst: Click here to see the new shirt, as modelled by a certain Man Utd midfielder
fields.trailText: England's new football kit has been unveiled today ahead of the friendly with Spain at Villa Park on Wednesday.
fields.body:
England's new football kit has been unveiled today ahead of the friendly with Spain at Villa Park on Wednesday.

Sven-Goran Eriksson's first match in charge will see the strip worn for the first time, and it will be used by England teams at all levels.

The new design incorporates part of the cross of St George but is otherwise traditional in appearance, with white shirt and socks and navy shorts. The goalkeepers will wear all black. The new outfits are to be 20% lighter than previously in an attempt to improve comfort.

The new kit will go on sale from April 23rd.

webTitle: Food co-op adds care services to an expanding menu

fields.headline: Food co-op adds care services to an expanding menu
fields.trailText: A pioneering food co-op in West Yorkshire has added childcare, counselling and employment training to its menu in a bid to tackle the underlying causes of poor health in the local community - poverty, crime and isolation. David Batty reports
fields.body:
A pioneering food co-op in West Yorkshire has added childcare, counselling and employment training to its menu in a bid to tackle the underlying causes of poor health in the local community - poverty, crime and isolation.

The co-op in Ovenden, one of the most deprived estates in Halifax, now provides a drop-in service to teenage prostitutes as well as the full range of cheap fresh produce you would normally expect from such a scheme.

"This area has a high teenage pregnancy rate and high unemployment, with a lot of mental and sexual health problems. It's been crying out for this kind of service," says project manager and local resident Karen Jowett.

The project began in 1999 as a weekly fruit and veg stall before opening a shop in the local Frank Swires health centre last August. Ms Jowett says: "We organised a survey of 3,000 local residents, which found that most of them could not afford to buy fresh fruit and vegetables."

There are now 243 members who pay an annual £1 membership fee to buy food for up to a third less than supermarket prices. Some can also get food on prescription from the resident GP at a further 10% discount.

GP Dr Suryagopal Sukumaran says his patients now eat far more healthily. "They can go to the shop straight after a consultation. Children buy apples from there rather than getting bags of chips from the fish shop."

But it's clear to Ms Jowett that poor nutrition is not the only cause of poor health in the community. "I'd suffered from depression before joining the project," she says. "And many of our customers are on low incomes and have housing and debt problems. Others are coping with drug habits or domestic violence. But there are few services to deal with those problems."

The project has helped to bridge this gap by teaming up with local sexual health advisory service, the Brunswick Centre. Social workers have given co-op volunteers training in basic counselling skills, offer telephone advice and also run a drop-in service at the shop every fortnight.

"We provide counselling on sexual health, including HIV, as well as child abuse," says Ms Jowett. "There's a problem with teenage prostitution in the area and we regularly see about 12 boys and girls aged between 13 and 16. The gay community also uses the co-op as a safe meeting place."

There is also a parent and toddler group, which will eventually become a day nursery. "There's a lack of affordable childcare in this area. We hope to break the cycle of violence for those parents stressed out with their kids because they have no support," adds Ms Jowett.

Rob Clegg, programme director of the North Halifax partnership, which set up the co-op with a government regeneration grant, says: "The co-op provides the local community with a more holistic approach to health - from healthy eating to counselling. As a viable business, it's also helping to regenerate the area, helping people develop skills and get into work."

Co-op volunteers have access to employment training provided by the Co-operative Wholesale Society, which fitted out the shop. "We have one 25-year-old single-mother who had never had a job before she came to work here," says Ms Jowett. "We've given her IT skills, till and stock control training, so she stands a much better chance of getting paid work. We also produce a work report for all volunteers to show prospective employers.

"Our aim is to get people out of their houses and involved in the community to improve the quality of life for everyone."

fields.headline: Newspaper pays out to ITV
fields.trailText: 12.30pm:The News of the World has apologised over reports that ITV's Tonight programme had sent the five men accused of the murder of Stephen Lawrence on an all-expenses paid luxury holiday, writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.body:
The News of the World has made a public apology in the high court over reports that ITV's Tonight programme had sent the five men accused of the murder of Stephen Lawrence on an all-expenses-paid luxury holiday.

Julian Pike, representing News Group Newspapers, apologised on behalf of the News of the World, which acknowledged that the allegations, made in April 1999, were untrue.

It agreed to pay damages - believed to be less than £10,000 - to a charity nominated by Granada TV, the company behind Tonight.

The paper has also agreed to pay legal costs and undertook not to repeat the allegations.

The first ever programme of Tonight with Trevor McDonald, presented by Martin Bashir, featured interviews with the five suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder trial.

The News of the World story, published after the programme had aired, claimed that Granada had paid out £23,000 in a "sweetener" that had included luxury trips to Scotland and a "golfing jaunt", in a bid to persuade the men to be interviewed.

The paper published a "breakdown" of all the costs allegedly incurred by Granada, which included £17,500 on limousines, £300 on champagne and £800 for two sets of golf clubs.

Granada said that the only payment made had been £25 per head for each of the five for accomodation.

"We've always said that these allegations were ridiculous. We are pleased that the newspaper has now apologised, and accepted that its story should never have been written," said Jeff Anderson, Granada's controller of current affairs and editor of Tonight at the time.

webTitle: Jazz FM moves into the black

fields.headline: Jazz FM moves into the black
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Jazz FM has reported a £60,000 before-tax profit, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Jazz FM has reported a £60,000 before-tax profit - the first time in its 10-year history that the station has been in the black.

Announcing the interim profits, chairman Sir Harry Roche attributed much of the growth to the increase in CD sales, which account for 58% of total turnover.

Jazz FM, formerly owned by Golden Rose, was launched in 1990 and consists of a London-based station and a north-west service.

Over the past two years the station has refined its output to make it more mainstream and has reported record listening hours.

But the company's expansion plans took a knock when the Radio Authority rejected its bid for the west midlands analogue licence.

Jazz FM's financial director Alistair MacKenzie said the company had put in a bid for the analogue licence for west and south Yorkshire, which was to be awarded in June.

fields.headline: Blair unveils 10-year crime plan
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, has unveiled a package of rehabilitation schemes designed to turn the 100,000 most persistent offenders away from a career in crime, as part of a new 10-year strategy to cut crime.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, has unveiled a package of rehabilitation schemes designed to turn the 100,000 most persistent offenders away from a career in crime, as part of a new 10-year strategy to cut crime.

Prisoners will be offered better drug treatment, education and skills training, and help with jobs and housing on release. But those who continue to offend will face harsher penalties with judges being able to take greater account of previous convictions when passing sentences, warned Mr Blair.

A third of the £700m programme will be spent on rehabilitation and 2,500 more prison places will also be created.

Prisoners will face tougher supervision on release under the plan, which will be announced by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in the Commons this afternoon.

Speaking at the Peel Community Centre in London's King's Cross, Mr Blair said the plan offered prisoners a "new deal" to escape a life of crime.

But Mr Blair, the first serving prime minister to visit a jail, said they must seize the opportunity or face the harsh consequences.

"Every prisoner leaving custody who needs follow up support or supervision should get it - whatever the length of their sentence," said Mr Blair. "For those who reject this helping hand the message will be equally clear.

"Rigorously enforced punishments which get progressively tougher the more times an offender returns to court. With prison as an option for those who breach community sentences or offend on bail."

Mr Blair said the proposals would end the "revolving door" system of justice, which sees the same hard-core of offenders repeatedly return before the courts.

Ministers believe that 100,000 offenders are responsible for half the country's crime. Around 90,000 people are released from British jails each year, of whom 46,000 have served sentences of less than 12 months. About 60% of those who serve shorter sentences are reconvicted within two years.

"We have to stop the revolving door which then keeps sending them back to crime," said Mr Blair

The government believes the Criminal Justice Act 1991 prevents judges from taking sufficient account of criminals' re-offending when sentencing them, leading to a string of short and ineffective spells in jail.

The prime minister's comments came after a leaked memo to Mr Straw suggested today's proposals could highlight previous failings on crime, a key battle ground in the coming election.

Opposition leader William Hague said the government's plans were just another "eye-catching initiative", which would have little impact on crime.

"Last year 'TB' owned up to being 'perceived as soft' on crime and asked that he be 'personally associated' with 'eye-catching initiatives'," said Mr Hague.

"Only yesterday, Jack Straw's special adviser said that their new crime plan 'doesn't look very impressive'. So when Tony Blair and Jack Straw offer their 10-year strategy for crime today, they hope the public will fail to take their previous record into account."

The home office minister, Paul Boateng, said all offenders would be subjected to intensive supervision following release from jail.

"The evidence shows prisoners are less likely to reoffend if you do make sure that they are supervised when they leave prison. All prison sentences ought to carry with them an element of supervision and control when they come to an end," he said.

However, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, claimed the strategy would lead to a further 32,000 prisoners being released early each year.

Her comments came after the leak of a memo suggesting the government is planning to link intensive supervision after release with a "custody-plus" scheme to cut all sentences of a year or less to just three months.

"This latest leak is a smoking gun on Labour's failure to deliver on law and order. Labour are soft on crime and they know it," said Miss Widdecombe.

Home Office figures showed 11,500 criminals were given sentences of between six and 12 months each year, making them eligible for early release under "custody-plus", if it were introduced, she said.

This would add to the 15,000 released early each year under the home curfew scheme and the 5,400 whom Home Office minister Charles Clarke has estimated will receive shorter sentences because of planned restrictions on jury trial, Miss Widdecombe added.

Other initiatives expected to announced by the home secretary include a "superbobby" bonus for senior police who chose to stay on the beat rather than be promoted to desk jobs.

Latest Home Office figures show overall crime dropped by a negligible 0.2% in the 12 months to September 2000, but headline-grabbing violent crime rose by 8%.

webTitle: Surfers face £60 bill to access MSN site

fields.headline: Surfers face £60 bill to access MSN site
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Microsoft has underlined the growing concerns about the long-term economic viability of "free" internet portals by indicating that it may soon seek to charge users of its hugely popular MSN site.
fields.body:
Microsoft has underlined the growing concerns about the long-term economic viability of "free" internet portals by indicating that it may soon seek to charge users of its hugely popular MSN site.

Microsoft plans to develop extra services on MSN and then charge users up to £60 per year for using the site. Neil Holloway, managing director of Microsoft UK, said www.MSN.com and www.MSN.co.uk received more than 8.5m unique visits in December, making them Britain's most visited sites ahead of rivals such as Yahoo and Freeserve.

MSN receives 200m visits every month on a worldwide basis. Even so, it is thought to be unable to transform those visits into a profit from advertising and sponsorship revenues alone.

Demanding that users pay to receive the service would make it profitable almost immediately if surfers were prepared to pay. Subscription models for online content sites have not met with much success. The Wall Street Journal and several pornography sites are among the few exceptions.

A decline in online advertising spending and a slowdown in the wider economy has forced leading content sites to look at introducing charges, at least for premium services. Hotmail, the free email service used by tens of millions of people worldwide, is likely to remain free but fees could be charged for more specialised services.

fields.body:
Students who only work during holidays (and who have not claimed Jobseekers Allowance in the current year) and do not expect to earn more than their personal allowance (£4,895) in any one tax year can complete a P38.

The form, which is available from your local tax office, needs to completed and given to the employer who will then not deduct tax.

fields.headline: Royal bank woos soccer's wealthy
fields.trailText: The royal bank Coutts & Co is opening a special department to help the kings of football such as Manchester United's David Beckham and Roy Keane manage their multi-million pound salaries.
fields.body:
The royal bank Coutts & Co is opening a special department to help the kings of football such as Manchester United's David Beckham and Roy Keane manage their multi-million pound salaries.

Its football unit, to be formally launched next month as part of a wider attempt by the Queen's bank to increase its clients from entertainment and sport, will have three full-time workers.

The footballers will be offered advice on how to take out five-year mortgages, to ensure that players can buy their homes as quickly as possible while they are still earning high salaries. Advice on disability insurance plans, how to pay less tax and retirement funds will also be available.

Coutts & Co says the aim of the football unit is to ensure players end their professional careers with enough to live on. Around 60 footballers have already joined the unit.

Coutts spokeswoman Julie Cooper said: "We cannot say who these footballers are because one of the reasons why they join us is to ensure complete discretion.

"There was a time when footballers were known for wasting all their money and ending their careers bankrupt. But that is all in the past; footballers are much more sensible now. They want to find the best ways to manage their money and we can offer them a complete service with specialist advice."

Ian Turland, one of the football unit's senior private bankers, said: "Coutts has always looked after successful people and we have always had clients from this sector. But this new strategy allows us to focus on footballers' specific needs.

"There's been a huge influx of money to the game over the last eight years and it's arguable that there's never been a better time for them to manage their money properly.

"It's all about giving them a structure to their financial life. They only have about 12 years in their career at the top and we have to ensure they make the most of that."

The football unit is part of the bank's sports and entertainment department. Coutts & Co has been hit by negative publicity recently, alleging that a number of high profile customers such as Andrew Lloyd Webber and Phil Collins have closed their accounts.

fields.headline: Let's get together
fields.standfirst: What does a merger between two charities do for their public profile?  Nicola Hill  reports on the outcome for a clutch of the recently-joined
fields.trailText: What does a merger between two charities do for their public profile? Nicola Hill reports on the outcome for a clutch of the recently-joined.
fields.body:
Charity mergers are on the increase. A good move for cutting costs but what about raising funds? Does two plus two always equal four?

Two big brands, the Cancer Research Campaign and Imperial Cancer Research Fund, are currently discussing a merger. At a local level, both have voluntary fundraising committees and high-street shops. At a national level, the two have large fundraising departments which have fought to distinguish themselves in order to attract loyal support.

The drive to merge is coming from scientists who believe that pooling funds will increase their chances of curing cancer. Director of the Cancer Research Campaign, Gordon McVie, says: "There is a fundraising folklore that two charities raise more than a merged one but this has never been rigorously tested. We have written to all our shops, supporters and volunteers and discussed the issue with a representative group who thought that there is no way forward without collaboration.

"There is a good match with our fundraising strengths and weaknesses and finally people will stop asking why there are two cancer charities competing against each other."

Last September two HIV charities, Terrence Higgins Trust and London Lighthouse, merged. The director of marketing, Joanna Van Driel, is expecting donations to drop this year and income targets have been cut. "People will think 'you have merged so you don't need so much money'. It is understood throughout the organisation that two fundraising charities merging will not increase our non-statutory income," she says.

"On top of the usual challenges of fundraising, we are working with an unpopular cause and fighting the misconceptions that the epidemic is over and that we are well funded because of the glitz associated with individuals who support the cause."

However, Van Driel does see some benefits as the two charities had previously used different methods of fundraising. The new charity has tried to retain supporters by holding on to both names - it is now called Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse.

Two other big cancer charities, Macmillan Cancer Relief and Marie Curie Cancer Care, considered a merger last year but decided against it. Macmillan's chief executive, Sir Nicholas Young, who has just announced his resignation, said: "If two and two can't be shown to equal at least four, then there is a danger that the merging charities may help fewer people than they did apart."

Parentline Plus is the result of a merger between the National Step-families Association and Parentline. Chief executive, Dorit Brown, says the experience has been very positive from a fundraising perspective. She found that key funders saw the benefits of a merger: "As a result, many provided a much greater level of investment than they had for each of the previous charities."

The Royal Philanthropic Society and Rainer Foundation merged five years ago to form RPS Rainer. Director of fundraising and marketing, Ruth Whitbread, says: "There is always a fear with mergers that one or other group of supporters will disappear but from our experience they don't as long as the reason for a merger is a sound one and is explained to them."

Unlike corporates that tend to change their branding and name to form a new company, charities tend to cling on to some of their identity, even if it makes the name longwinded. Van Driel of Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse says the charity simply didn't have any money to rebrand. Terrence Higgins Trust had already merged with a number of regional charities in the previous year - so it could have proved costly. In fact some of the services offered by the charities have retained their original name but now have pooled resources. Whitbread says that RPS Rainer deliberately chose not to rebrand having consulted across both organisations.

So communication seems to be the key. At a time when the public and the media are questioning the number of charities and criticising fundraising costs, mergers should be a popular choice. Brand loyalty will be retained if the reason for the merger is robust and supporters are fed the right message.

fields.headline: New England, same old Nevilles
fields.trailText: So what do you think of Sven's new England? Judging by your emails so far, you are reasonably impressed with his mammoth 31-man squad.
fields.body:
So what do you think of Sven's new England? Judging by your emails so far, you are reasonably impressed with his mammoth 31-man squad.

But not everyone is happy. Matthew Carson from New York reckons: "Neville should not be allowed anywhere near an England shirt. It's like turning the clock back 30 years." Unfortunately for us, he doesn't tell us which Neville he is talking about, or why picking Gary or Phil would be like going back to 1971. Perhaps it's got something to do with their haircuts.

Meanwhile, Carsten Riel writes in from Denmark. "I'm very much interested and curious about what's going to happen, how impatient you will be, members of the press and all the football crazy nation," he says about - as if you hadn't guessed already - Sven-Goran Eriksson being appointed as England coach.

But Carsten warns us not to expect too much. "What you do not seem to know is how far away you are from the highest standards of national team football," he says. "You haven't achieved anything since 1966, not even been close. Two semi-finals you'll say - and I'll say that's just not good enough.

"Please, for the sake of all of us around Europe, who loves England for many and obvious reasons, please change your perspective in viewing the game. You seem like the board in Barings Bank a couple of years ago, not knowing what has hit you.

"You need to give Eriksson a chance so that you can get inspired, so that you may learn a few things," he adds. "And if you think he is too slow, try to remember what he took over - remember the last match on Wembley."

Liverpool v Roma: The aftermath

"A real mockery and a farce of astronomical proportions," is Paul Lebon view of the final stages of Liverpool's Uefa Cup second leg match against Roma. He calls for the Spanish referee to be reprimanded or struck off - and he's not the only one.

"I've been watching football for the past 30 years and I've never seen an international referee doing what Mr Aranda did, changing his mind in such a ridiculous way," says Corrado from Italy.

But Corrado has an - ahem - interesting explanation for the referee's behaviour.

"In the past years the Spanish have had a problem with Italians and not only in football," he says. "I think there's a kind of jealousy versus Italians since we are so similar but superior in every field ... ask their gorgeous women, for example.

"Anyway, after thanking you for listening," he continues. "I hope Liverpool win the Uefa Cup and you can be sure I will keep on doing what I always did with Spanish women."

Meanwhile, Colin Moneypenny says that Italian fans and journalists should not be upset at the playing of Arriverdici Roma at the end of the match.

"It's very unlikely this was a jibe at the defeated Italians but rather a tribute to the Liverpool fans' song originated in Rome in 1977 - We're on our way to Roma - and reprised in Rome in 1984 and last week during our 2-0 away win at the Olympic Stadium.

"Even if, as I doubt, the DJ was having a joke, then it is a mild-mannered action when compared to the appalling policing and mistreatment of Liverpool supporters in Rome on the club's last two visits to the Olympic Stadium," he continues.

"I don't recall too many Italian journalists being too offended by that. And given their dreadful and violent record on welcoming visitors - not just from Liverpool - any Roma fans upset about the unfriendliness of a song would be in contention for winning the Uefa Cup for hypocrisy.

"Our friends from Italy may have had their ears marginally offended but at least none of them had to attend the Royal Hospital in a way that I, and others, once became familiar with their San Giacomo Hospital."

Chesterfield: a supporter has his say

Last week, the FA charged Chesterfield with financial irregularities - a decision that has Roger Orwin understandably worried.

"I hope that before judgment is passed and punishment dealt out, that the FA will consider who it is that they will actually be punishing," he says.

"The fantastic start to the season that Chesterfield have had is the just reward for those fans who have come through the turnstiles as regular as clockwork even during less successful times.

"Even though the full nature of the offences is yet to be revealed, it seem pretty clear that they are primarily of a financial nature and should be punished accordingly," he adds.

"If the management / board at the club have acted irregularly it is they who should be punished and not the fans as is so often the case."

fields.headline: Dando trial adjourned
fields.trailText: 11.30am The trial of the man accused of murdering Jill Dando has been adjourned at the Old Bailey until this afternoon, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The trial of the man accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando has been adjourned at the Old Bailey until this afternoon.

Barry George, 40, who denies the charge, was led into the dock of the historic, oak-panelled Court Number One in front of a packed public gallery and about 50 reporters.

Mr George, who was wearing a blue jumper and blue shirt and was carrying a bible, stood briefly to confirm his name.

Three artists sat at specially designated seats near to the front of the court.

Mr George is charged with murdering 37-year-old Miss Dando on the doorstep of her home in Fulham, west London, on April 26, 1999.

Miss Dando's fiance, gynaecologist Alan Farthing, and BBC Crimewatch presenter Nick Ross were among those present.

Prosecuting is senior Treasury counsel Orlando Pownall, while high-profile barrister Michael Mansfield QC is defending Mr George.

Mr Justice William Gage is presiding over the trial, which is expected to last up to six weeks.

The proceedings are set to generate huge interest among the media and the public, with queues to the courtroom expected to form from dawn every day.
fields.bodyText: The trial of the man accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando has been adjourned at the Old Bailey until this afternoon. Barry George, 40, who denies the charge, was led into the dock of the historic, oak-panelled Court Number One in front of a packed public gallery and about 50 reporters. Mr George, who was wearing a blue jumper and blue shirt and was carrying a bible, stood briefly to confirm his name. Three artists sat at specially designated seats near to the front of the court. Mr George is charged with murdering 37-year-old Miss Dando on the doorstep of her home in Fulham, west London, on April 26, 1999. Miss Dando's fiance, gynaecologist Alan Farthing, and BBC Crimewatch presenter Nick Ross were among those present. Prosecuting is senior Treasury counsel Orlando Pownall, while high-profile barrister Michael Mansfield QC is defending Mr George. Mr Justice William Gage is presiding over the trial, which is expected to last up to six weeks. The proceedings are set to generate huge interest among the media and the public, with queues to the courtroom expected to form from dawn every day.

fields.headline: Billy's Britons beat Hollywood stars
fields.standfirst: A-list lose out to teenager but Gladiator takes the lion's share at Bafta awards
fields.trailText: A-list lose out to teenager but Gladiator takes the lion's share at Bafta awards
fields.body:
London was like a suburb of Los Angeles last night as no fewer than 15 A-list Hollywood stars descended on the Bafta awards - only to have their noses bloodied. Not only were Russell Crowe and Tom Hanks beaten to the best actor awards by an almost unknown teenager but Hilary Swank and Juliette Binoche were pipped for best supporting actress by another Brit, Julie Walters.

But it was not all good news for British actors. The predicted posthumous award to Oliver Reed for his role as the fighting master in Gladiator was not to be, compounding the disappointment at his failure to win an Oscar nomination.

Achievement

However, the huge Hollywood contingent, which also included Robert De Niro, Annette Bening and Robert Altman, did not seem too upset having spent the weekend schmoozing at Tina Brown's star-studded Talk magazine party, as well as three celebrity brunches.

Gladiator won best film, best cinematography and best production design but its British director, Ridley Scott, was beaten to best director by Ang Lee for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. The Chinese film also won a Bafta for best costume design.

Julia Roberts as expected, walked away with best actress for Erin Brockovich, another good pointer towards the Oscars, while Steven Soderbergh's Traffic won two awards including best supporting actor for Benicio Del Toro. He beat Albert Finney to that award but Finney was consoled by picking up the academy fellowship, essentially a lifetime achievement award.

The biggest turn-up for the books, however, was in the Carl Foreman award for most promising British newcomer where Pawel Pawlakowski, the director of the sublime asylum seeker love story Lost Weekend, came out on top of probably the toughest shortlist in 10 years. Not only was he up against Daldry and Lee Hall, the writer of Billy Elliot, but he also had to contend with Simon Cellan-Jones, whose film Some Voices has been a massive sleeper hit in America.

Last year the only American star of any wattage to attend the Baftas was Kevin Spacey for American Beauty - and he was only there because he was shooting a film in London at the time. Last night, by contrast, there were limo jams in the West End as the biggest names in Hollywood queued to be ushered up the red carpet into the slightly less than salubrious environs of the Odeon Leicester Square for the ceremony. Unlike the cinema's paying patrons, the stars were not allowed to bring popcorn inside. Chilled bottles of champagne did, however, await them at their seats.

Bafta's chairman, Simon Relph, said the presence of A-list names like Russell Crowe, Tom Hanks, Juliette Binoche and Christina Ricci showed that the decision to move the ceremony to before the Oscars had paid off. With Altman, Bening, Swank, Goldie Hawn and Hugh Grant also making the transatlantic trip, it is clear that for the first time the studios are taking the awards seriously, although they have yet to spend even a fraction of a percentage of the money that is lavished on the members of the American Academy to secure their Oscar votes.

However, Mr Relph said the Baftas were not trading in decades of tradition in order to be a mere barometer for the Oscars. "Our awards - which are the only other truly international awards apart from the Oscars - continue to be a celebration of excellence by the British Academy which reflects British film-makers' and cinema-goers' ongoing passion for the movies." A Bafta award was no longer a consolation prize for not picking up an Oscar, Mr Relph said, but was now setting the agenda for others to follow.

Even so, for years the Baftas barely registered on Hollywood's radar, coming as they did in April, a month after the real business of the Oscars had been decided. Their main purpose was as a balm to the little band of British film-makers who returned battered and beaten from the Oscars each year, having learned to their cost that the Americans use the Academy Awards to celebrate their own - and often bland, middle-of-the-road American studio films at that.

Not all of the crowds thronging Leicester Square last night had been drawn by the big American stars who had flown in from California. There was a huge cheer in the run-up to the awards when Albert Finney's car was spotted - he is also in the running for an Oscar as best supporting actor for Erin Brockovich - and the residents of nearby Chinatown were out in force to greet Michelle Yeoh, the star of Ang Lee's martial arts blockbuster Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which was nominated for no fewer than 14 awards.

While London played host to Hollywood, the French lived up to their reputation for perversity, particularly when it comes to all things Anglo-Saxon, by snubbing Tinseltown and all its works in their César awards at the weekend.

Despite dominating the foreign language category with Billy Elliot and American Beauty, the British fared little better, although the actor Charlotte Rampling did pick up a prize for her contribution to cinema.

The biggest winner was Le Gout des Autres (The Taste of Others), a beautifully written tale of mismatched couples, which won four awards, including best film just ahead of the thriller Harry, He's Here To Help, for which Sergi Lopez won best actor. The best non-French film was In the Mood for Love, Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai's take on David Lean's classic story of thwarted love, Brief Encounter.

webTitle: How to stop the virus spreading

fields.headline: How to stop the virus spreading
fields.trailText:
Do
• Disinfect vehicles that may come into contact with susceptible animals.
• If you are a horse rider, keep off bridleways and farmland.
• Cancel rambles in affected areas and stay away from farmland.
• Keep your dog under control.
fields.body:
Do
 Disinfect vehicles that may come into contact with susceptible animals.
 If you are a horse rider, keep off bridleways and farmland.
 Cancel rambles in affected areas and stay away from farmland.
 Keep your dog under control.

Don't
 Organise or attend events where there is contact between susceptible animals.
 Hold meetings on farmland in the affected areas or between members of the farming community.
 Visit farms in the affected areas. If you must, stay away from grazing land and animals.
 Feed swill to susceptible animals.
