webTitle: In brief: Ralph Fiennes to team up with Cronenberg

fields.headline: Ralph Fiennes to team up with Cronenberg
fields.standfirst: Plus: Matt Dillon signs up Depardieu and Skarsgard for directing debut; Hilary Swank helps Al Pacino with Insomnia; Jodie Foster weighs up western
fields.trailText: Plus: Matt Dillon signs up Depardieu and Skarsgard for directing debut; Hilary Swank helps Al Pacino with Insomnia; Jodie Foster weighs up western
fields.body:
 Ralph Fiennes looks set to team up with director David Cronenberg for the psychological thriller Spider. Adapted by Patrick McGrath from his own 1991 novel, the film will star Fiennes as a man in meltdown as he puzzles over his mother's unexplained death. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the film will shoot this summer in England and Toronto and will be budgeted around the $10m (£6.86m) mark. For director Cronenberg, it's a step back to intimate, smaller-scale pictures after his brief, and ultimately fractious, flirtation with the sequel to Basic Instinct late last year.

 Gerard Depardieu and Stellan Skarsgard are the latest big names to land roles in Matt Dillon's directing debut Beneath the Banyan Trees. Co-written by Dillon with Lost Highway writer Barry Gifford, the film, which also stars James Caan and Natascha McElhone (see earlier story), began shooting last week in Cambodia.

 Last year's Oscar winner Hilary Swank is to star alongside Al Pacino in the remake of the 1997 Norwegian thriller Insomnia (see earlier story). To be directed by Memento creator Christopher Nolan, the film relocates the action to a summery Alaska of almost permanent daylight. Swank, who can be seen from Friday in the supernatural thriller The Gift, will play the role of a local police officer.

 Jodie Foster is mulling over a starring role in the feminist western One Hundred Years On, about a woman beating off invaders at a remote prairie cattle ranch. Foster will produce the picture at Paramount but the studio is reportedly eager to secure her services as an actor as well. At present Foster is bogged down in work on David Fincher's siege thriller Panic Room.

fields.headline: The Baftas reborn
fields.standfirst:
The decision to reschedule the Baftas a month before the Oscars may yet prove to be a deft compromise between acknowledging Hollywood's pulling power and retaining British identity, says Guardian Unlimited Film editor Xan Brooks

Guardian Unlimited Film
fields.trailText: The decision to reschedule the Baftas a month before the Oscars may yet prove to be a deft compromise between acknowledging Hollywood's pulling power and retaining British identity, says Guardian Unlimited Film editor Xan Brooks.
fields.body:
What a difference a month makes. In 2000, the Bafta awards ceremony went out after the Academy Awards and barely registered a blip on the Hollywood radar. This year, the organisers moved the date back by a month and - hey presto! - transformed it into a genuine international event.

Last night the Odeon Leicester Square played host to a galaxy of Hollywood players, including Russell Crowe, Tom Hanks, Robert De Niro, Robert Altman, Annette Bening and Kate Hudson. One year earlier, American Beauty star Kevin Spacey was the sole A-list ambassador from across the Atlantic.

In PR terms then, the 2001 Baftas has proved a major coup. But at what cost? In shifting its date, in hitching its wagon so firmly to the Academy circus, has Britain's premier film award ceremony turned into Hollywood's warm-up act? Instead of a showcase for the best in homegrown cinema, will the Baftas now become (like the Golden Globes, the New York Critics awards, et al) just another pointer towards Oscar night?

The jury is still out. But this year, at least, the Baftas appear to have got the balance right. Last night's event conspired to have it both ways. On the one hand it laid on a star-spangled spectacular the likes of which the West End has rarely seen, and lavished most of its principal honours on the American-backed (and Oscar-tipped) Gladiator. On the other it kept the flag flying by handing out a brace of high-profile awards to last year's bona fide British hit, Billy Elliot. A

At times this amounted to breathtaking gall. The Bafta organisers lured best actor nominees Russell Crowe (for Gladiator) and Tom Hanks (for Cast Away) across to Leicester Square and then proceeded to hand the award to 14-year-old Jamie Bell, who isn't even nominated for an Oscar.

Seated in the posh seats, Hanks may have whistled his approval, but the experience must have been akin to being invited to a slap-up supper and then seeing the servant boy run off with the main course.

All of which suggests the start of a new special relationship, one that allows little Bafta to hop into bed with its Oscar cousin while keeping its dignity intact. Other nations are not so tolerant. Take France, which has long railed about the dominance of Hollywood movies.

On Saturday night the Gallic film industry presented its Céesars in a rigorously isolationist ceremony that even managed to snub Hollywood in their Best Foreign Language Film category (which they presented to Wong Kar-Wai's In the Mood For Love).

In the opinion of many French film-makers, the European production industry must stay pure and fortified or run the risk of becoming America's lap-dog. But perhaps there is a third way, a middle-ground; a means of acknowledging Hollywood's publicity muscle and popular appeal and weaving slyly it into a homegrown framework. Time will tell if the Baftas has found it.

fields.headline: Aussie icons under siege
fields.standfirst: The demise of Speedo's last Australian factory is symptomatic of the pressures of the global economy on homegrown favourites, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: 26 February: The demise of Speedo's last Australian factory is symptomatic of the pressures of the global economy on homegrown favourites, writes Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
If you are an Australian male moderately committed to getting fit you are almost certainly sauntering along the poolside or beachside in a little black pair of trunks this summer, like every summer. Across the top of the back will be white lettering, declaring "Manly" or "Bondi" depending on where you are a surf lifesaver. And round the front will be a little Speedo label.

For Australians, Speedos simply are swimming trunks, or "swimmers". People wear them when popping down to the shops. Famous swimmers wear whole Speedo suits in the pool. But late last week, the company revealed itself to be just the latest in a faltering line of iconic Australian products buffeted by globalisation.

Speedo, now owned by a British-based business, announced the closure of its last Australian factory. Their employees were offered a pie and summarily dismissed. All Speedos, even the many unique Australian designs, will now be imported into the country, probably from south-east Asian sweatshops.

At the same time, the country's premier airline, Quantas - lovingly nicknamed the "flying kangaroo" - announced it would cut 1,500 jobs. The news was met with the customary approval by Australian money markets and market analysts, who applauded a leaner, lighter national carrier, unencumbered by all that baggage of Australian workers.

It is hard to convey just how prized such companies are by people in Australia. Though the major loss of jobs profoundly affects every community, few Britons would shed tears if British Airways, for instance, made its middle managers redundant. Nor would the public weep if 50 women in the Midlands who stitched together Gola trainers were given the boot.

As a relatively small and young country (in terms of white settlement anyway), Australia patriotically treasures its unique products, from Victa lawnmowers to Vegemite, as symbols of its national identity. Its floundering currency is nicknamed the "little Aussie battler" as it slides further against the mighty greenback.

And so public sentiment seems to readily turn to thoughts of protectionism when these icons are diluted or disappear in the choppy waters of global market competition. "We think that Queensland should be growing bananas and Tasmania growing apples and Western Australia milking cows," wrote one impassioned commentator in the Sydney Morning Herald last week.

This desire to protect Australia's still significant manufacturing and farming sectors leads to political support for the anti-globalisation, pro-protectionism message carried by Pauline Hanson's One Nation party. The surging patriotic-protectionist spirit is currently encouraging the two major parties to, rhetorically at least, almost totally disavow the neoliberal economic orthodoxy, particularly as there is a federal election looming.

Of course, as some Australian brands fade away, others are on the rise. Australian vines are blooming: cleverly branded and easily palatable Australian wines are set to outsell French wines on the British market by the end of this year. Australian surf wear companies, including Mambo and Billabong, are triumphant examples of entrepreneurial, trendsetting global brands.

Some directly cash in on the fondness for old-fashioned, distinctively Australian products. If you imagine Richard Branson had an Australian patriot for an uncle, entrepreneur Dick Smith would be that man. His face is plastered all over his distinctive range of all-Australian products.

He brought out his own match range, Dickheads last year, in protest against foreign takeovers of Australian companies. Swedish match company Intermatch Sweden Aktiebolag now own Redhead matches, another ex-Australian icon.

A message on the Dickheads box says: "We would have to be complete dickheads to let most of our famous Australian brands be taken over by foreign companies. Brands such as Vegemite, Aeroplane Jelly, Arnott's, Speedo and Redhead Matches are in overseas hands. This means the profit and wealth created goes overseas and robs our children and grandchildren of a future."

Smith says: "We've done very well because people are very concerned about Australia being sold off and so we've got lots of free publicity out of it, but the multinationals spend hundreds of millions on what's just propaganda. It's like Germany in the '30s."

Unfortunately, even Dick Smith's unbridled patriotism doesn't please every loyal Australian. Smith's "Buy Australian" label shows the country's flag with his smiling face superimposed on top. "This is a flag under which people fought and died," said Ausflag spokesman Harold Scruby recently. "I think it's heraldic graffiti."

Australian surf wear companies, including Mambo and Billabong, are triumphant examples of entrepreneurial, trendsetting global brands. Some directly cash in on the fondness for old-fashioned, distinctively Australian products. If you imagine Richard Branson had an Australian patriot for an uncle, entrepreneur Dick Smith would be that man. His face is plastered all over his distinctive range of all-Australian products. He brought out his own match range, Dickheads last year, in protest against foreign takeovers of Australian companies. Swedish match company Intermatch Sweden Aktiebolag now own Redhead matches, another ex-Australian icon. A message on the Dickheads box says: "We would have to be complete dickheads to let most of our famous Australian brands be taken over by foreign companies. Brands such as Vegemite, Aeroplane Jelly, Arnott's, Speedo and Redhead Matches are in overseas hands. This means the profit and wealth created goes overseas and robs our children and grandchildren of a future." Smith says: "We've done very well because people are very concerned about Australia being sold off and so we've got lots of free publicity out of it, but the multinationals spend hundreds of millions on what's just propaganda. It's like Germany in the '30s." Unfortunately, even Dick Smith's unbridled patriotism doesn't please every loyal Australian. Smith's "Buy Australian" label shows the country's flag with his smiling face superimposed on top. "This is a flag under which people fought and died," said Ausflag spokesman Harold Scruby recently. "I think it's heraldic graffiti." webTitle: Want a hospital? Buy it on tick

fields.headline: Want a hospital? Buy it on tick
fields.standfirst: Labour is having a love affair with PFI, and for some health managers it is 'the only show in town'. Faisal Islam  runs some tests on the long-term future of NHS funding
fields.trailText: Labour is having a love affair with PFI, and for some health managers it is 'the only show in town'.Faisal Islam runs some tests on the long-term future of NHS funding
fields.body:
When the health secretary, Alan Milburn, announced an investment of £3.1bn to build 29 new hospitals a fortnight ago the Labour heartlands must have jumped with joy. At last their hard-earned taxes and the impossibly large government surplus were going into a decent programme of NHS renewal. Tangible fruits of the prime minister's 'accidental' Breakfast With Frost commitment to raise health spending to EU levels were at last being seen, were they not?

Surprisingly perhaps, the money will come not from the Treasury's overflowing coffers, but from groups of private sector construction companies. These consortiums will be repaid by a government commitment made on behalf of future generations of taxpayers, to lease back the hospital's service for the next 30 years. This gigantic hire-purchase agreement for the long-term future of public health is the private finance initiative (PFI).

As customers of Radio Rentals may be aware, if you have the money, then outright purchase of a television and video is better value for money than that special monthly rental deal, even if you get to keep the machines at the end. This is particularly the case when, as a government, you can borrow far more cheaply than anyone else.

Throw in complaints about cutbacks on bed numbers, poor hospital design, general doubts about value for money and public finances that have never been in such rude health, and the case for PFI looks ever weaker. However, for health service managers wanting to replace late Victorian monoliths with shiny new super-hospitals, the controversial initiative appears to be 'the only game in town'.

And Milburn's recent announcement concerned not just an increase in the number of PFI hospitals, but a substantial expansion of their scope.

Private sector involvement in the National Health Service in general has massively increased under this government. Last week it was reported that NHS use of private beds has trebled since Alan Milburn signed a concordat with the private sector last October. The bill could reach some £4bn over this year, from £1.25bn last year.

The PFI has invoked the greatest ire because its original rationale seemed to have been a wheeze to get vital public spending 'off-book'. It came in very handy during Labour's two-year departmental spending freeze.

'We had to get the hospital building programme started. If you like...we had to create a market in PFI because there was not a market,' Milburn told the health select committee in November last year.

It's a fallacy to suggest, as many Cabinet ministers have, that PFI brings in extra investment from the private sector. That conclusion can only be reached because of the particular accounting methods used for public spending. On a theoretical, and increasingly on a practical level, PFI can only be justified if it garners private sector expertise and effort through appropriately allocating risks and rewards.

At its heart is the idea of incentivisation, and allocation of risks to the bodies best capable of handling them. By specifying contracts in terms of outputs, for example the supply of a hospital premises, the public sector will benefit from the animal spirits of the profit-searching private sector. These urges constantly seek out innovative ways to economise, and so increase productivity, in the public sector. A flexible approach will help promote innovative responses to the challenge of the ageing population, for example. That's the theory anyway. The practice, so far, does not bear out this vision.

Incentives have not been aligned as they might. There was the well-publicised finding that the first wave of PFI hospitals contained 30%t fewer hospital beds than had been planned in 1996.

Last August The Observer revealed that Sir Stuart Lipton, the government's 'design tsar' described PFI hospitals as disastrously poor 'urban disasters'. Far from being given more opportunity to innovate design to meet changing needs, the same pool of hospital architects is used, and consulted far less.

Official evidence of savings from PFI depends heavily on conjecture about the value of 'risk transfer' and the notional value attached to the cost of providing the investment in the public sector - the public sector comparator. Putting a value on risk transfer is tricky, but there is some evidence that the transfer is having some success. Most PFI hospitals are now coming in on schedule.

However, many medical professionals claim that contracts are practically risk free. Hospital trusts would never be allowed to go bankrupt, so there is no risk to the consortiums' funds. The money markets appear to concur with this view: the rate at which they lend money to PFI initiative is falling towards the rate offered to government.

Labour's favourite think-tank, the Institute of Public Policy Research, is finalising details of an 18-month commission into PFI.

Scant evidence of value for money over equivalent Exchequer-funded hospitals has been heard. Furthermore the extent of any savings are unlikely to exceed the millions spent on legal advice and consultancy. The devil is in the detail of the contracts rather than the introduction of PFI per se, according to one submission. For the latest tranche of projects, the Department of Health has guaranteed that bed numbers will not decrease. An emerging view, at least among think-tanks, is that PFI has not been given enough scope to prove its money saving credentials. Truly innovative private sector solutions require management over a wider scope of services, they say. Doing this provides incentives for intelligent use of the whole gamut of health services.

Similarly, as health is a labour-intensive sector, true efficiency savings will only be seen when PFI's are in charge of a large proportion of NHS staff. Only 30% of NHS costs come from the areas where PFI's are now operational.

Milburn went some way down the first route with the announcement that third wave PFI hospitals will integrate primary and intermediate facilities in the local community 'to help ensure more seamless care for local patients'.

But the Rubicon that is yet to be crossed is the provision of clinical services under PFI arrangements. It is being actively considered by the IPPR. But there was a concrete commitment to avoid it in Labour's last manifesto.

Bringing together October's concordat, Labour's love affair with PFI, and the withdrawal of private health tax breaks, brings us to something approaching the Canadian health system. It is free at the point of delivery, and therefore not privatised, but serviced by a multitude of private sector providers. It may be some way off yet, but Labour's new manifesto may provide some clues.

fields.headline: IPC Media loses faith in women's portals
fields.trailText: IPC Media is conducting a strategic review of its women's website BeMe.com, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
IPC Media is conducting a strategic review of its women's website BeMe.com and has admitted it no longer believes in the broad portal model for the women's market.

Speaking to MediaGuardian.co.uk, IPC director of communications Julie York said IPC would make a number of changes to BeMe.com, the most significant of which would be to integrate IPC's stable of women's magazines into the website.

"It's been a year of learning for us and we've concluded that the broader portal model does not work," said Ms York.

"We're redefining BeMe.com and focusing on what we're good at."

Despite plans to shore up the internet presence of IPC's women's magazines, such as Marie Claire, Nova, Now and Essentials, the brand BeMe.com will remain, added Ms York.

As part of an ongoing process review, Ms York acknowledged there may be job cuts but stressed it would not affect more than three people.

Beme.com, which launched last year, claims to be notching up more than 2.5m page impressions per month.

It signed up to sponsor Channel 4's Ally McBeal in a £3m deal and has forged ties with other websites including MSN.

IPC's re-evaluation of Beme comes amid a tumultuous time for the online women's market.

Earlier this year NatMags ditched plans to launch women's portal UK.Women.com while Associated Newspapers axed the generic media portal CharlotteStreet.com in favour of femail.co.uk.

Ms York is keen to point out that the review of BeMe.com will not be extended to other IPC websites, such as NME.com and UnmissableTV.com.

IPC spent £25m last year on developing digital projects and has secured £15m to spend on digital media this year.

Meanwhile, IPC is working on its first simultaneous print and online magazine project, codenamed Project Spider, which will launch next month.

Project Spider, a mass market fortnightly technology-based magazine targeted at male internet users, will launch with a £2m marketing push.

webTitle: Comment: prison is not the answer to high crime rate

fields.headline: Instead of hellholes
fields.standfirst: Imprisoning more and more people is not the answer to our high crime rate, but restorative justice may be
fields.trailText: Imprisoning more and more people is not the answer to our high crime rate, but restorative justice may be.
fields.body:
Brixton prison last month; Stoke Heath young offenders institution last week; these are only the latest in a dismal list of prisons slated by the chief inspector of prisons. The director general of prisons has himself denounced some of them as hellholes. The prison population is higher than in most western European countries, yet we have one of the highest crime rates. Given what we know about prisons - the ultimate social exclusion - it is not unlikely that the crime rate is partly because of the large numbers processed in the schools for crime. Most hardened criminals are hardened in prison. The younger they are when locked up, the more they reoffend.

But the government's response, expected to be announced today by Tony Blair when he makes the first prime ministerial visit to a prison, is: 2,500 more prison places, and more locking up of unconvicted children as young as 12.

This cannot be joined-up thinking: as an election approaches, it is vital to return to first principles. Firstly, we must accept that as only 3% of crimes lead to conviction, sentencing has only a marginal effect on the crime rate (apart from the immorality of punishing one person for what others may do). Crime reduction belongs in social policy, not in more and more prisons, as Mr Justice Penry-Davey recognised when interviewed on the Today programme last week, after being mugged by a gang of youths.

The criminal process should therefore focus on each individual case, and in particular on the restoration (or improvement) of the vic tim's well-being, as far as that is possible. Many victims have said that they would like the chance to tell the offender the effects of his actions, and to ask questions which only he or she can answer. The offender should have the opportunity to apologise, and to show that it is meant, by making reparation. Before compulsion is used he should have a chance to do this voluntarily, outside the starchy atmosphere of the courtroom - that way it will mean more to him and to the victim.

What should the reparation consist of? It could be compensation, repairing damage, or service to the community - of a useful, not a degrading sort, because we must respect offenders' humanity, while condemning their acts. But what many victims want is that he should actively try to improve his chances of not reoffending, through skills, courses, literacy, numeracy or drug treatment programmes, for example. Mr Blair is expected to announce more of these today, but if these are what many young offenders need, as they certainly are, why go to the counter-productive expense of sending them to prison first?

This approach, known as "restorative justice", is all very enlightened, but will it work? It has now been tried in many western countries, and even where it produced no change in reconvictions, it is considered worthwhile for the sake of improved treatment of victims. Admittedly it won't be suitable in every case, but in New Zealand, which has pioneered it for 10 years for all juvenile offences except homicide, research has shown reduced reoffending.

Public opinion, despite stereotypes to the contrary, favours non-custodial measures more than prison; the 1998 British Crime Survey found that victims were two to one in favour of them for crimes like burglary and mugging. Many people like reparative measures, and the thought of an offender being sent to prison can deter some victims from reporting crimes.

If offenders get a sentence discount for helping the police or pleading guilty, why not also for accepting responsibility and taking part in a process which can be helpful to victims? A victim of sexual harassment, for example, might like to be able to choose a process which encouraged the perpetrator to admit his act, so that she could tell him assertively why it was unacceptable, rather than one where the stakes were so high that he denies everything and tries to get off, and has a good chance of doing so because it is his word against hers.

We have to face the fact that there is a balance between severity of punishment and getting at the truth. The extreme example of this is South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission; nearer home, if an offender faces an automatic minimum sentence under a "three strikes and you're out" law, he has no reason to plead guilty, and every incentive to try to get off, which may include putting his victim through an ordeal in the witness box, or intimidating her, or even killing her.

Courts will still be necessary to oversee the process, to determine guilt where the accused denies the offence, and to detain the few who pose such a risk of further serious crime that this is the only way of protecting the public. But restorative justice has been developing in this country and others for 15 years; research shows that most victims are satisfied at seeing some good come from the harm they suffered, and most offenders think it is fair.

 Restoring Respect for Justice, by Martin Wright, is published by Waterside Press.

webTitle: If you need a GP, you'll have to cough up

fields.headline: If you need a GP, you'll have to cough up
fields.standfirst: Few pieces of legislation have attracted as much criticism as the health and social care bill, which will be one of the last pieces of legislation to reach the statute books before the election. Small wonder, then, that the government is keen for it to escape attention over the next few weeks, writes Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Comment: Few pieces of legislation have attracted as much criticism as the health and social care bill, which will be one of the last pieces of legislation to reach the statute books before the election. Small wonder, then, that the government is keen for it to escape attention over the next few weeks, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Few pieces of legislation have attracted as much criticism as the health and social care bill, which will be one of the last pieces of legislation to reach the statute books before the election. Small wonder, then, that the government is keen for it to escape attention over the next few weeks.

Already the bill has attracted ferocious opposition from Labour backbenchers, Liberal Democrats and Tories, not to mention organisations as diverse as the British Medical Association, the Local Government Association and patients' rights groups.

It is hard to know which bit of the bill has provoked the most concern. Could it be clause 59, which gives ministers unprecedented powers to sit on statistics and hamper efforts to show how individual hospitals and health authorities are performing?

What about the way the same clause gives the health secretary discretion over the way sensitive patient information is shared between medical organisations, prompting fears that this will lead to the commercial exploitation of medical data? Then there was the bill's original proposals to abolish community health councils, the bodies that act as patients' champions. These were so contentious the government had to drop them.

But what really seems to have caused the most concern is the fact that the bill extends the remit of the private finance initiative to the primary healthcare sector - chiefly GPs' surgeries. Ministers are now predicting that the scheme will generate £1 billion to be spent on renovating up to 3,000 of the UK's 10,000 surgeries.

Many doctors already lease premises from private landlords, so you could argue that introducing PFI is really just more of the same. But the large corporations behind the PFI consortiums are responsible to shareholders and are focused on maximising profits. PFI's advocates have always found it difficult to counter the argument that the public ends up paying well over the odds for services.

The bill also paves the way for huge private-sector involvement in the long-term care sector. Supporters argue this will mean a more efficient and cheaper service for a sector in desperate need of an overhaul. But the number of patients' complaints emanating from long-term care homes is proportionately higher than those coming from public bodies.

And it's not as if NHS hospitals built under the PFI have been a raging success. Cumberland, the country's first PFI hospital, for example, has suffered a litany of problems. Perhaps it shouldn't be surprising that this government is so keen on PFI. But there is now genuine concern among health experts that one day patients will have to pay for a range of primary healthcare services. Of course, Labour says it's totally opposed to this. But then it once said that about PFI.

fields.headline: Labour removes 1.2m young from poverty
fields.trailText: More than 1.2m children have been lifted out of poverty as a result of government policies introduced since the last election, according to a comprehensive audit of deprivation published today by the Child Poverty Action Group.
fields.body:
More than 1.2m children have been lifted out of poverty as a result of government policies introduced since the last election, according to a comprehensive audit of deprivation published today by the Child Poverty Action Group.

It says Labour ministers' record over their first two years in office was "dire for poor children". They implemented plans inherited from the previous Conservative administration to cut income support for lone parents.

This was "arguably the first real-terms cut in the level of social assistance paid to any group of claimants since social assistance was introduced in 1948".

But reforms to the tax and benefits systems over the past two years will lift 1.2m children out of poverty - defined by the CPAG to include households living at below 50% of average income.

"Possibly another 320,000 will have been lifted out of poverty as a result of their parents obtaining employment. So Labour may have halved child poverty in five years," the CPAG audit says.

Its figures are based on computer modelling techniques to predict the consequences of government policies before they show up in national statistics. The latest official data - based on a household income survey in 1998-99 - showed no reduction in child poverty compared with 1996-97, when 35% of children were living in poverty.

The CPAG said: "If the rate of progress achieved in the last two years is maintained, income poverty ... could be ended in 10, not 20, years' time, as aimed for by the government. However, the task of ending child poverty will get harder, as the least poor are the first to be lifted above the poverty line.

"Whilst policies to tackle income poverty are measurable and more immediate, poverty is also about the quality of children's lives. The jury is still out on the government's success in tackling inequalities and disadvantage in areas such as health, education and neighbourhood renewal."

It warned that effective action to eradicate child poverty was not compatible with tax cuts. More than 600,000 extra children could have been lifted out of income poverty had the £2.4bn spent on cutting the basic rate of income tax from April last year been used to increase benefits for the poorest children.

Martin Barnes, director of CPAG, said: "After a poor start during its first two years in office, substantial progress in reducing child poverty has been made. But progress should be seen against the horrendously high levels of poverty the government inherited."

fields.headline: Mattel conjures up Harry Potter game
fields.trailText: Wannabe wizards will be able to cast their own spells in a new Harry Potter game from Mattel, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Wannabe wizards will be able to cast their own spells in a new Harry Potter game from Mattel.

Based on the game Harry and his friends play in the JK Rowling books, Casting Stones will be available in shops this autumn to coincide with the November release of the film Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.

The launch of the game signals the start of the merchandising bonanza surrounding the movie.

And it follows last week's £95m tie-up between the film's maker Warner Bros and Coca-Cola.

The set includes fake stones that are thrown like dice, two spell cards and a pouch that doubles as a casting mat onto which players throw the stones.

A card game based on the Quidditch game played in the best-selling books is also being launched this month.

Mattel is developing a wide range of Harry Potter toys and has launched two Harry trivia games and two jigsaw puzzles so far.

An avalanche of Harry Potter merchandise is expected to launch as the year progresses.

The deal is likely to change the way films are marketed. Coke will establish on-going literacy programmes around the world instead of promotions in fast-food outlets.

webTitle: In brief: Cannes Film Festival plans Coppola tribute

fields.headline: Cannes Film Festival plans Coppola tribute
fields.standfirst: Plus: Hannibal hangs on for third week at US box office; Grinch team to work on another Dr Seuss adaptation
fields.trailText: Plus: Hannibal hangs on for third week at US box office; Grinch team to work on another Dr Seuss adaptation
fields.body:
 This year's Cannes Film Festival looks set to honour maverick film-maker Francis Coppola with a tribute that will include the director's cut of his Vietnam phantasmagoria Apocalypse Now. Coppola has a long and affectionate relationship with the festival. He won the Palme d'Or for both Apocalypse Now in 1979 and The Conversation in 1974, and served as the head of the jury in 1996. According to Screen Daily, the line-up for this year's festival is also taking shape. Expected to be in the running at Cannes 2001 are films from Hal Hartley (Monster), Zhang Yimou (Happy Times), Nanni Moretti (La Stanza del Figlio), Jean-Pierre Jeunet (Amelie From Montmartre) and the evergreen, eightysomething Eric Rohmer (L'Anglaise et le Duc). Other treasures in store may include screenings of David Lynch's trouble-plagued Mulholland Drive (originally commissioned as a TV pilot) and the long-awaited adaptation of Captain Corelli's Mandolin. Human Nature, a madcap fantasy from the Being John Malkovich team of Charlie Kaufman and Spike Jonze, is also tipped for inclusion.

 If it's Monday it must be another story about Hannibal eating up the box office. Sure enough, Ridley Scott's runaway hit camped at the top of the US chart for an impressive third weekend running, its three day takings of $15.8m (£10.85m) pushing its total eighteen day gross to $128.5m (£88.24m) from the North American market. Add that to the estimated $200m (£137.34m) already amassed from worldwide receipts and you have a monster hit indeed. At the more low-rent end of the scale, 3,000 Days to Graceland, a heist comedy starring Kevin Costner and Kurt Russell, debuted at number four with a mediocre $7.1m (£4.87m). But the week's biggest loser was undoubtedly the live action/cartoon cocktail Monkeybone, starring Brendan Fraser, which opened outside the top ten with a paltry $2.6m (£1.78m). Considering the film's budget was around the $70m (£48m) mark, this represents a major crisis for backers Fox. "Everybody's a little sad," admitted distribution head Bruce Snyder in what one imagines is a masterclass of corporate understatement.

 Universal and Imagine have booked top comedy gurus Alec Berg, Jeff Schaeffer and Dave Mandell to overhaul Dr. Seuss's The Cat in the Hat, which was optioned last year as a vehicle for Tim Allen, in a deal thought to be worth seven figures. Having enjoyed last year's biggest hit with The Grinch, Imagine/Universal are keen to capitalise on the new interest in Seuss. Berg, Schaeffer and Mandell all worked on the Grinch but cut their teeth as mainstay writers and producers on the classic US sitcom Seinfeld.

fields.headline: ITV's Public Property axed
fields.trailText: <8> 8.30am :ITV has axed its answer to Big Brother, Public Property, half way through its run after it flopped in the ratings, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
ITV has axed its answer to Big Brother, Public Property, after just five weeks.

The decision to put the show on the scrapheap was taken just half way through its run because it flopped in the ratings.

Presented by Kaye Adams, it was watched by just 1.5m viewers - a fraction of the audience of hit afternoon shows such as Countdown or The Weakest Link.

Public Property was the first show to cash on the sensational popularity of Channel 4's reality TV show Big Brother which made household names of contestants such as Nasty Nick.

Made by Anglia TV, it featured a selection of contestants of random ages, who were ordered to perform various tasks by a panel of audience members.

The contestants range from 20-something Rebecca and Carla through middle-aged Marvin to elderly Marcia, who were given tasks by the audience to change their lives.

But the series, which went out at teatime was panned by the critics.

The Mirror's Charlie Catchpole memorably said the show "makes watching paint dry seem as exciting as white water rafting".

An ITV spokeswoman confirmed that the show had had its run "shortened" to make way for the one of the two daily episodes of the reincarnated Crossroads.

She said: "Public Property was a completely innovative show - the first reality show to go out at tea time. It probably didn't really find its audience in the way we'd hoped it would."

But she said ITV wanted to "take a step backwards and think about where we're taking it."

webTitle: Web soap to make TV debut

fields.headline: Web soap to make TV debut
fields.trailText: 8.30am Online Caroline, Freeserve's interactive soap opera, is to be broadcast on TV, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Freeserve internet drama that had 45,000 users glued to their computer screens last year is to be broadcast on TV.

Online Caroline enabled web users to interact with the characters of the 24-episode drama, which mixed a sinister plot with elements of comedy.

The drama allowed viewers to send emails and phone messages to Caroline and the other characters, who then replied to the messages.

Now the company behind Online Caroline, digital entertainment company XPT, has produced nine three-minute episodes for TV.

XPT managing director, ex-BBC2 commissions and strategy executive Tom Harvey, is negotiating with television companies to broadcast the programmes.

The original Online Caroline was filmed on a TV-quality digital camera, allowing it to be tailored for TV.

XPT has also sold the rights to distribute and licence Online Caroline's internet, TV and phones applications across all countries outside the UK to Distraction Formats.

Freeserve owns the rights to Online Caroline in the UK.

A sequel to Online Caroline is in production and will launch on the web at the end of the year.

XPT is also developing an "immersive" drama for the web, based around a Greek holiday.

It will enable viewers to go on a virtual Greek holiday and where all is not quite what is seems.

On the eighth day of the holiday, users are lured to a menacing timeshare property from which they may - or may not - return.

fields.headline: The feud
fields.standfirst: They are old rivals, both used to squaring up over the respectable middle ground of the tabloid market, but last week the fight turned nasty.  Roy Greenslade  reports from the front line of the war between the Daily Mail and the Express
fields.trailText: February 26: Roy Greenslade reports from the front line of the war between the Daily Mail and the Express.
fields.body:
Dateline: A newsagent's somewhere in the south of England ...

It was still dark when The Box arrived. I watched as the newspaper delivery van cruised to a halt. A lithe young man sprang out and slid open the side door. In a swift, practised movement he heaved quires of papers on to his shoulder, tottered three steps into the doorway and dropped the bundle inside. There was no indication yet that this was anything other than a normal morning. Mr Patel took his knife from under the counter and began to cut the bindings as more bundles were carried from the van.

Then, instead of the usual goodbye grunt, came the moment I had been waiting for. "Something extra for you today, Pattie," said the young man. And there it was. The Box. The latest deadly weapon in the century-long circulation war between the Daily Express and the Daily Mail.

As the van pulled away, I stepped from my hiding place behind a hedge at No 42 ***** (names and addresses have been changed or concealed to protect the innocent). Posing as if I was a customer studying the magazine rack, I noted Mr Patel's explosion of joy as he realised what The Box was all about. It was designed to look like a carton of tissues, only bigger. On top was a slogan: "Stronger Than Ever: Wipe Away Those Fears." Inside were wrap-around Daily Mail front pages, headlined "A Cleaner, Brighter Daily Read: Save £9.90 on home delivery."

The centre pages showed a reproduction of the Guardian's story which revealed the seedy truth about the pornographic empire run by the Express's new owner, Richard Desmond. It urged Express readers to try "a cleaner alternative" instead.

Mr Patel smiled. He was being asked to persuade buyers of the Daily Express to sign up for a cheap six-week trial of the Daily Mail. In return, he would receive £5 and, if he won more recruits than anyone else, his shop would get a £5,000 re-fit.

I eavesdropped as he explained the offer to his wife. "But we only sell 18 Expresses," she said. "Well, that's £90," said Mr Patel. "And it doesn't say there's anything wrong in signing up Mirror and Sun readers as well. Who'll know?" I made my excuses and left. I had witnessed, at the front line, the impact of the Mail's newest attempt to boost its sales, a tactic used first in Scotland and now extended across Britain.

Opening my Express on Tuesday, I observed that Desmond and his editor, Chris Williams, were not going to take the assault lying down, accusing the Mail of "plumbing the depths by spreading endless lies about the Express and attempting to undermine our distribution system".

Lies? It's hard to agree about that. The Mail literature about Desmond's pornographic activities, Express staff leaving, others being made redundant and plunging sales were surely accurate.

As for distribution, the Mail's initiative is legally watertight if ethically suspect, because retailers are getting an incentive to encourage their customers to switch titles. It is, according to circulation staff in other papers, a very clever ploy but utterly ruthless and hugely expensive. In response, the Express has hit back in the paper with features about the Rothermere dynasty, owners of the Mail since it was founded in 1896. The profiles ran over old ground, about the first Lord Rothermere's 1930s fascism and the third Lord Rothermere's colourful private life.

Next day came the more contentious matter of the fourth, and current, Lord Rothermere's fathering of a child out of wedlock more than 13 years ago. This revelation first appeared in Punch a couple of years ago, but no national paper would touch it then.

At the time, the old convention which protected newspaper proprietors from scrutiny in rival papers held firm. In breaking that custom, Desmond and Williams show just how desperate their situation has become. They obviously feel they have nothing to lose.

They also have a point in illustrating the Mail's double standards: as a self-appointed virtuous champion of family values it has tended to stigmatise single parenthood. Just because the rich can afford to provide well for their illegitimate offspring does not justify sneering at poor philanderers.

Then again, on the admittedly shifting scale of values, most people would probably argue that the pornographic exploitation of women is far worse than the hypocrisy of a paper promoting standards its owner has failed to uphold.

To equate Rothermere's moment of youthful indiscretion with Desmond's life-long career as a pornographer is patently wrong. But this is war and, in war, everyone suffers, the innocent and the guilty and those somewhere in between. What is unusual, and rather enjoyable, is that for once the generals, Desmond and Rothermere, find themselves taking the flak rather than the poor bloody infantry.

Who, though, is more likely to win? One doesn't really need to be a veteran circulation war correspondent to answer that. The Mail group is richer. The Daily Mail is selling 2.4m to the Daily Express's 950,000, while the Mail on Sunday is selling 2.3m to the Sunday Express's 870,000. Rothermere heads a team with vast experience, huge resources and awesome manpower. Desmond heads a team without any national paper experience, few resources and dwindling manpower.

David may have beaten Goliath, but it's hard to imagine what secret weapon Desmond can utilise. He has sacked the reps, the people on the ground who maintain contact with newsagents and who are the Mail's key players in turning newsagents into Mail persuaders.

He has lost a circulation director and a marketing director. In further cost-cutting moves, he has let it be known that he intends to make 50, and maybe 100, journalists redundant.

His company is ham-strung by a printing contract with Regional Independent Media at its Lancashire plant which means it loses money. He has failed to raise anticipated funds by selling off the Express's half of the London print centre because the Telegraph group won't agree to his sale price. Desmond may think he is a tough negotiator but Telegraph deputy chairman Dan Colson is in a different league.

In other words, the Express is in terrible shape. That begs another question, of course. Why is the Mail bothering to spend so much money on crushing a rival which is, to all intents and purposes, already beaten?

It might appear cynical to call on the philosophy of WC Fields, about never giving a sucker an even break. But cynicism is relevant when talking of newspaper competition: the spur to the Mail's action is based on the fact that it smells defeat. Desmond's ownership gives it a chance it never had before. The Mail has seized on its opponent's Achilles heel.

Historical context is relevant too: the Mail played second fiddle in sales terms to the Express until 1982, and didn't really pull ahead until Paul Dacre became editor a decade later.

Any newspaper historian can point to two excellent examples of struggling papers with falling circulations that have come back from the dead to triumph, such as the Sun and the Mail itself.

But we also need to view the Mail's wish to dispense with the Express once and for all as a prelude to the battle it wishes to pursue next, with the Daily Telegraph. Dacre sees that paper as his main competitor in future.

Many Express journalists will smile ruefully at this turn of events. Only four months ago, it was Dacre who was promising them a good future when the Mail's owners made a serious bid to buy their paper. Now the putative saviour is trying to kill them off.

Though there may not be much sympathy for Desmond, there is considerable understanding for the Express staff. Williams, a former Mail executive, and his journalists have been producing a lively paper, and they certainly deserve better back-up than Desmond is providing.

Seen from the other side, there is also, as the Express illustrated on Friday with a piece entitled "Hate Mail", any number of people who have a deep loathing of the Mail and all its works.

One of the celebrities quoted was Stephen Fry, regarded as a gentle man who rarely loses his temper. But he cannot bear the Mail's ethos, saying: "It typifies everything that is most shaming about this country in terms of its lurches towards xenophobia and fear: everything in the name of the family, that horrible capital F for family. It's become what the state was for a Stalinist: everything that is done in the name of the family is acceptable."

This tirade is a reminder that, as successful as the Mail undoubtedly is, it arouses violent passions, as I discovered when I defended the paper last week after it lost a libel action. The more powerful a paper, the more the public distrust it, including many of those who buy it.

Not that such considerations will affect Mr Patel and his ilk. They stand to make a tidy sum by cajoling their customers into buying the Mail at cut price for six weeks. Desmond says he will retaliate. But how? When he bought the Express in November, he said everything was OK at the Express. It isn't now.

One doesn't really need to be a veteran circulation war correspondent to answer that. The Mail group is richer. The Daily Mail is selling 2.4m to the Daily Express's 950,000, while the Mail on Sunday is selling 2.3m to the Sunday Express's 870,000. Rothermere heads a team with vast experience, huge resources and awesome manpower. Desmond heads a team without any national paper experience, few resources and dwindling manpower. David may have beaten Goliath, but it's hard to imagine what secret weapon Desmond can utilise. He has sacked the reps, the people on the ground who maintain contact with newsagents and who are the Mail's key players in turning newsagents into Mail persuaders. He has lost a circulation director and a marketing director. In further cost-cutting moves, he has let it be known that he intends to make 50, and maybe 100, journalists redundant. His company is ham-strung by a printing contract with Regional Independent Media at its Lancashire plant which means it loses money. He has failed to raise anticipated funds by selling off the Express's half of the London print centre because the Telegraph group won't agree to his sale price. Desmond may think he is a tough negotiator but Telegraph deputy chairman Dan Colson is in a different league. In other words, the Express is in terrible shape. That begs another question, of course. Why is the Mail bothering to spend so much money on crushing a rival which is, to all intents and purposes, already beaten? It might appear cynical to call on the philosophy of WC Fields, about never giving a sucker an even break. But cynicism is relevant when talking of newspaper competition: the spur to the Mail's action is based on the fact that it smells defeat. Desmond's ownership gives it a chance it never had before. The Mail has seized on its opponent's Achilles heel. Historical context is relevant too: the Mail played second fiddle in sales terms to the Express until 1982, and didn't really pull ahead until Paul Dacre became editor a decade later. Any newspaper historian can point to two excellent examples of struggling papers with falling circulations that have come back from the dead to triumph, such as the Sun and the Mail itself. But we also need to view the Mail's wish to dispense with the Express once and for all as a prelude to the battle it wishes to pursue next, with the Daily Telegraph. Dacre sees that paper as his main competitor in future. Many Express journalists will smile ruefully at this turn of events. Only four months ago, it was Dacre who was promising them a good future when the Mail's owners made a serious bid to buy their paper. Now the putative saviour is trying to kill them off. Though there may not be much sympathy for Desmond, there is considerable understanding for the Express staff. Williams, a former Mail executive, and his journalists have been producing a lively paper, and they certainly deserve better back-up than Desmond is providing. Seen from the other side, there is also, as the Express illustrated on Friday with a piece entitled "Hate Mail", any number of people who have a deep loathing of the Mail and all its works. One of the celebrities quoted was Stephen Fry, regarded as a gentle man who rarely loses his temper. But he cannot bear the Mail's ethos, saying: "It typifies everything that is most shaming about this country in terms of its lurches towards xenophobia and fear: everything in the name of the family, that horrible capital F for family. It's become what the state was for a Stalinist: everything that is done in the name of the family is acceptable." This tirade is a reminder that, as successful as the Mail undoubtedly is, it arouses violent passions, as I discovered when I defended the paper last week after it lost a libel action. The more powerful a paper, the more the public distrust it, including many of those who buy it. Not that such considerations will affect Mr Patel and his ilk. They stand to make a tidy sum by cajoling their customers into buying the Mail at cut price for six weeks. Desmond says he will retaliate. But how? When he bought the Express in November, he said everything was OK at the Express. It isn't now.

fields.headline: Kirch in Formula One driving seat
fields.trailText:
10.45am: German media giant Kirch has secured £680m to take a controlling stake in the body that owns Formula One TV rights. By Jason Deans.
Feb 23: Kirch closes in on Formula One
fields.body:
German media giant Kirch has said it has secured the £680m needed for it and EM.TV to take a controlling stake in the body that owns Formula One TV rights.

Kirch had to raise the money to finance an EM.TV option to buy 25% of SLEC, the trust run by Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone.

The deal would give the two German media companies control of 75% of SLEC, after Kirch earlier this month agreed to pay £379m to buy half of EM.TV's existing 50% stake in the trust and a 25% holding in the firm itself.

But the acquisition could still be vetoed by either Mr Ecclestone or motor sport governing body the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile, both of whom have expressed opposition.

The FIA opposes any move to put Formula One on pay television and delegates could vote on the Kirch Formula One deal at a general assembly in Paris on March 30.

Kirch said it had completed the financing necessary to buy the SLEC stake, but declined to give further details.

The acquisition of the SLEC stake forms part of an agreement between Kirch and EM.TV designed to bail the latter out of its financial problems.

EM.TV has seen its share price fall 90% in six months after it ran up £1.4bn in debt to the Formula One stake and Muppets producer Jim Henson.

fields.headline: Letters show Monty as 'repressed gay'
fields.standfirst: Second world war hero had platonic love for soldiers and boys, claims friend and biographer
fields.trailText: Second world war hero had platonic love for soldiers and boys, claims friend and biographer.
fields.body:
"This sort of thing may be tolerated by the French, but we're British - thank God."

So decreed Field Marshal Montgomery as he urged the House of Lords not to legalise gay sex and warned that the 1967 homosexuality bill would be a "charter for buggery".

More than 30 years on, the gay age of consent has been equalised to 16, homosexuals are allowed to serve in the military - and Britain's most famous wartime general has been outed as a repressed homosexual who had "quasi love affairs" with boys and men, according to a new book.

The Full Monty, by his official biographer, Nigel Hamilton, claims that Montgomery felt passionately about fellow soldiers and boys, some not yet in their teens.

Professor Hamilton, whose official life of Montgomery was in 1981 awarded the Whitbread prize for biography, has drawn on hundreds of letters to and from Montgomery. He admits there was no proof of any physical relationship with any of the young men who wrote, but argues that any act would have been illegal and could have spelt ruin for the wartime hero.

"Don't forget homosexuality was outlawed from 1885 to 1967. Those who did act on their instincts could, like Oscar Wilde, be imprisoned and ruined," he said yesterday from Boston, where he works at the University of Massachusetts.

"He acted very negatively to the change in the law - calling it a 'charter for buggery'. He was extremely worried by it, and psychologically that suggests the law had been an essential crutch in his struggle with his own homosexual feelings."

Rumours about the sexuality of the man who won the battle of El Alamein in 1942, turning the tide of the war in north Africa, have previously circulated.

As early as 1976 - five years after his death - one earlier biographer, Lord Chalfont, noted his "predilection for the company of young men".

Last night, Montgomery's only son, Viscount David Montgomery, dismissed the new claim as being "absurd, appalling, and complete psychobabble".

Another biographer, Alistair Horne, author of The Lonely Leader, commented: "This sounds to me like Hamilton is rehashing his old work for a tabloid readership.

"I served under Montgomery in the Middle East and I have absolutely no evidence whatsoever of repressed, or any other kind, of homosexuality."

Prof Hamilton, who was befriended by the field marshal at age 11 and knew him well for the last 20 years of his life, has no doubt of the nature of Monty's feelings.

"These were quasi love affairs. He became really passionately involved with these young men - and then, more and more, boys, who he would call 'my sons'. They were nothing of the kind, of course, but in his own personality he would frame them in this way.

"I myself have more than 100 very loving letters from him. My relationship with him wasn't sexual, in the sense that it wasn't acted upon, but I had been through enough years at British boarding schools to know what kind of enormous affection and feeling he had for me.

"And I wasn't alone, this was a consistent pattern in Monty's life." One boy was Lucien Treub, Montgomery's "little Swiss friend", who met him at 12, and told Hamilton how the general would bathe him personally and rub him down so he would not catch cold. "I've interviewed him several times and he was quite clear he didn't feel there was any molesting going on, but it's a tricky area," Prof Hamilton said.

Born in 1887, Montgomery was married for 10 years from 1927, but the academic described this an "an aberration" in what had otherwise been a life devoted entirely to being with men.

He added that he had pondered on whether to write about Monty's sexuality when his acclaimed three-part biography was published in the 1980s, but felt that his main aim was to restore the field marshal's military reputation "at a time it was being systematically trashed: I didn't want to detract from that".

Sexuality under scrutiny

Historical figures whose sexuality has been the subject of debate:

TE Lawrence

The soldier and writer claimed, in The Seven Pillars of Wisdom, that he was whipped and raped by a Turkish officer in the first world war. In 1992 his biographer Lawrence James described it as a "homoerotic fantasy", but said Lawrence was homosexual in his later years.

Jane Austen

In 1996 an incestuous relationship was suggested by Terry Castle of Stanford University: the novelist's letters showed "the passionate nature of the sibling bond". She never married, and shared a bed with her sister - but that was not unusual at the time. Austen scholars dismissed the claim.

Daphne du Maurier

Married and a mother of three, the novelist had an affair with the actress Gertrude Lawrence, an authorised biography said in 1993. She had her first fling with a teacher nicknamed "Ferdy", and was torn between "Cairo", or heterosexuality, and "Venice", or lesbianism.

William Shakespeare

Ever since Oscar Wilde claimed the Elizabethan playwright was in love with a boy actor, Willie Hewes, critics have claimed he was gay - relying on his sonnets for justification.

Leonardo da Vinci

The ultimate renaissance man has long been held to be gay ,and in 1476 he was tried and acquitted of sodomy. In 1998, an academic suggested bisexuality in Leonardo's "intense relationship" with a courtesan in his 60s.

fields.headline: IPC swoops for BBC strategy chief in TV move
fields.trailText: 10.15am: IPC has poached the BBC's head of financial and commercial strategy as part of its move into television. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Magazine giant IPC has poached the BBC's head of financial and commercial strategy in a move that signals its determination to extend its presence into television.

Julian Drinkall is to join IPC as group strategy director.

IPC chief executive Sly Bailey said Mr Drinkall had been appointed to play a "critical part in the evolution of IPC from a magazines to a media business".

Mr Drinkall, who joined the BBC in 1998, was directly involved with the licence fee renewal process as the BBC's head of strategy.

He was later promoted to head of financial and commercial strategy, taking on overall responsibility for the BBC's financial activities.

He has also worked at BBC Worldwide and BBC Online.

Appointing an executive from the world of broadcasting is a signal that IPC is considering moving towards incorporating television into its strategy in a more coherent way.

Mr Drinkall told MediaGuardian.co.uk he wanted to form alliances with media companies to take IPC's highest profile brands onto television, including acquisitions where appropriate.

He indicated that long-running speculation of joint ventures between IPC and music broadcaster MTV could gather pace.

"Music is obviously one of IPC's main strengths and key to its long-term strategy," he said.

IPC last year reorganised itself as a "media-neutral, brand-centric" company in the first indication the company needs to move away from its reliance on paper-based magazines.

This month's magazine ABCs were depressing for several sections of the consumer press, and IPC, Britain's largest magazine publisher, is looking at ways to reduce its reliance on paper.

Several of IPC's largest sectors, in particular women's weeklies and home and leisure, saw their circulations fall at the last ABCs.

webTitle: Two films share major laurels at French Cesars

fields.headline: Two films share major laurels at French Cesars
fields.trailText: The Oscar-nominated The Taste of Others and the acclaimed thriller Harry, Here's Here to Help were the big winners at France's biggest film awards ceremony on Saturday
fields.body:
The Oscar-nominated The Taste of Others and the acclaimed Harry, He's Here to Help split the main awards at the 26th annual Cesar awards on Saturday night. In an increasingly congested awards calendar, France's equivalent of the Oscars were announced the night before Britain's Baftas in a ceremony at the Theater des Champs in Paris.

Directed by Agnes Jaoui, the relationship drama The Taste of Others took four awards, including Best Film and Best Script (for Jaoui and husband Jean-Pierre Bacri). A pungent relationship drama, the movie could yet take the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film at next month's Academy Awards.

Released to glowing reviews in Britain last year, the black comedy-thriller Harry, He's Here to Help also performed well, with Dominik Moll winning Best Director and Spanish-born star Sergi Lopez walking away with the Best Actor award. Dominique Blanc was named Best Actress for her role in Stand-by, while Wong Kar-Wei's In the Mood For Love scooped the award for Best Foreign Film, beating out Sam Mendes's highly tipped American Beauty.

fields.headline: Which? gets new marketing chief
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The Consumers Association has hired News International's new media marketing chief to boost Which? magazine's profile. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
The man responsible for marketing websites for the Times and the Sun has been hired by the Consumers Association in a bid to boost Which? magazine's profile.

His appointment comes amid continued speculation that the watchdog is set to launch a TV version of its magazine.

Geoff Hurst, who was News International's marketing director of new media brands, joins the Consumers Association as marketing director, replacing David Sneesby.

It is understood he take on a larger remit than that of his predecessor. His broader strategic role will include joining the organisation's corporate management group.

Mr Hurst will be looking to establish the Consumer Association and Which? magazine brands across new media platforms.

Before his tenure at News International, he worked at BT and headed up the Yellow Pages team.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Terri Paddock's new media

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Terri Paddock
fields.trailText: By Terri Paddock, director of whatsonstage.com, which relaunches today.
fields.body:
Favourite websites?

Amazon. As a user I adore it. The site is so quick and well laid out, but I've had problems using it as a novelist. They really weren't hi-tech and well organised; they wouldn't accept material by email, and it was very frustrating. I do really like iamdb, which is an excellent resource for movie information. You can check out exactly what people in the industry are doing, research films while they are still in production, and find out if people have made up stuff about producing the next Hollywood blockbuster.

Last online purchase?

A personalised travel guidebook from Tailorbook. You give them the places which you are interested in visiting and they compile and dispatch a customised guidebook.

Most recent technological faux pas?

I had problems trying to send an email via a hyperlink when I was surfing the net. You have to enable your email package to work with your software package.

Ever been in a chat room?

Yes, on my own website, I like to listen to people's opinions about theatre productions.

Main news source on the web?

I tend not to look for general news but go for specific updates on the theatre or news from the US. I check CNN and Playbill which is a fantastic site for New York theatre reviews.

Most useful site on the web?

The Spotlight is really useful. I also like Dictionary for checking things if I'm writing.

Which site is least likely to succeed?

I think so many business are failing, not because they have flawed business models or bad funds, but because the market has turned so dramatically. The backlash has gone too far. A lot of people can't make it now because of circumstances beyond their control. I still think it's almost riskier to be in a PLC than a start-up. At least with a start-up you know the management are there and are going to make it work any way they can.

Time spent on the web?

All day every day.

Least useful site on the web?

The Spark is fun but not useful.

Do you use a screensaver?

A picture of my two-year-old niece.

Most irritating thing about the web?

Spam. I'm inundated with it. It also means I get a lot of viruses. I was sent the Anna Kournikova one three times! I also get annoyed when search engines aren't updated and have so many dead links.

Do you still bother with old media?

Yes. I trained as a journalist and still read at least three papers every day.

 Terri Paddock is the director of What's on stage which relaunches today.

webTitle: Will the BBC ever be out of danger?

fields.headline: Will the BBC ever be out of danger?
fields.standfirst: Commercial rivals have the knives out for the BBC, and even culture secretary Chris Smith is 'deeply worried' about plans for a more populist service. To protect its back, the corporation must ensure its governors are truly independent, says  Steven Barnett
fields.trailText: Commercial rivals have the knives out for the BBC, and even culture secretary Chris Smith is 'deeply worried' about plans for a more populist service. To protect its back, the corporation must ensure its governors are truly independent, says Steven Barnett.
fields.body:
Is the BBC about to lose its freedom? For nearly 75 years, since its foundation as a public corporation, the Beeb has managed to steer an independent route between the clutches of the state on the one hand and the suffocating embrace of the commercial marketplace on the other. Of course, there have been times when it stepped over the line - a little too close to government during the 1930s and late 1980s, a little too commercialised during the 1960s. But these were periods of adaptation, which protected it from any large-scale interference.

For all the compromises it has had to make to fend off periodic calls for privatisation, the BBC has been allowed to pursue its own vision of public service broadcasting. It has not had its agenda determined by those who are driven by different objectives - whether they be incumbent governments wishing to suppress uncomfortable information, or commercial companies trying to boost shareholder dividends. It has been a fascinating journey of institutional endurance, and British culture has been enormously enriched by it.

Those days may be numbered. Reading through some of the responses to the government's white paper on communications, and listening to recent ministerial statements, it is increasingly clear that the knives are out for the BBC. It is in severe danger of being caught between the self-interested animosity of commercial rivals and the less self-interested, but equally threatening, moves towards government intervention.

The issue that has crystallised this problem is whether the BBC should come under the auspices of the proposed pan-industry regulator, Ofcom. This new body has, to widespread approval, been proposed by the government to regulate the private-sector communications industry. To some surprise - and to the BBC's relief - the government decided that, apart from taste and decency, and complaints, the BBC should continue to be regulated by its board of governors and not be swept up within Ofcom's remit.

This has not gone down well with the BBC's competitors, who see Ofcom as a perfect vehicle for restraining the BBC's overzealous tendency - as they see it - to encroach on commercially valuable territory. None of them put it in such blunt terms, of course, and their arguments are ostensibly logical and sensible. The words "level" and "playing field" were much in evidence.

ITV, for example, believes the proposals do not meet the objectives of "clarity, coherence and a level playing field". It is worried that "significant changes" to BBC television schedules (for example, moving Omnibus from BBC1 to BBC2) will "reduce their distinctiveness, and result in unfair competition for commercially funded single public service channels". In other words, the new regulator should have the power to force the BBC to leave Omnibus where it is and thus make BBC1 less of a threat to ITV.

BSkyB, predictably, complains about "the continued incursion of BBC licence-fee-funded services into areas which the market is well able to serve". It wants Ofcom to ensure that new BBC services "do not duplicate similar commercial channels". We can safely assume that a BSkyB definition of "similar" means anything currently supplied or planned by BSkyB, regardless of the quality of its content.

Channel 4 continues the theme by arguing that a single regulator is "the only logical response" to convergence. It then turns the argument on its head and suggests that allowing the BBC to operate independently risks "marginalising and ultimately ghettoising it" - although it offers no convincing arguments as to why.

The Radio Authority wants to see all broadcasting brought within a single regulator by the next renewal of the BBC charter (2006), while the ITC - which has speedily assumed the role of Ofcom-in-waiting - is cleverly opaque. It calls for an effective process "to ensure that the BBC's obligations and contributions to the range of public service provision are considered as a whole with those of the commercial public service broadcasters". The current proposals allow Ofcom to comment on BBC services but not to dictate terms to the corporation. Is the ITC happy with that? Recent statements suggest not, but it can't be too blatantly expansionist.

Of the significant non-broadcaster observers, only the National Consumer Council follows the commercial broadcaster line that the BBC should lose its independence, although curiously it is one of the staunchest supporters of public service broadcasting. Despite this, it is happy to see Ofcom deciding that "a particular service should be provided by a commercial PSB provider, rather than the BBC" if that would serve the consumer interest.

This illustrates one of the key problems with the pan-regulator argument. To assume that industry regulators can operate purely according to the best interests of end-users - with no consideration for the trading conditions or profitability of the companies they regulate - is to misunderstand the history of regulation. Every regulator is under intense pressure to relax the economic burden on private companies. Ultimately, all regulators must compromise in the face of the private sector's determination to generate profits and create jobs.

But the fundamental difference in this case is the attempt to lump a publicly funded institution, which has a unique heritage and a parliamentary mandate, together with the whole of the private sector. Any diktat from Ofcom to a commercial operator to make more current affairs, or children's programmes, or experimental drama will always invite the response: "The BBC's got public money and a charter. Tell it to do it. We can't afford it." Why should Ofcom allow the BBC to compete for soccer highlights, pilot a new quiz show, introduce a new soap opera or commission a new police drama series?

All of these could be - indeed, have been - significant BBC contributions to our viewing choices, and help to cement the BBC's place as a broadcaster of universal appeal. Hand the BBC over to Ofcom and, as night follows day, there would follow a systematic erosion of its popular base until it became precisely the kind of American-style unwatched public broadcaster which Channel 4 warns against. At that point, the licence fee - and therefore the BBC - dies. It's not difficult to level the playing field if we don't mind barren land.

So what of government action? In mounting his defence, culture minister Chris Smith is being forced into promises of government intervention. For example, asked at the select committee inquiry two weeks ago about why the BBC should be able to change schedules or formats without reference to the commercial sector, Smith replied: "Where there are significant changes to the nature of a channel, then that is a matter which ultimately would have to be considered by the secretary of state." He gave a similar assurance at a Channel 4/NCC sponsored seminar last Monday.

In policy terms, this may be no more than restating an announcement made last June that the secretary of state will have the power to judge "material changes" to existing BBC services against a set of published criteria. But it further legitimises a worrying and increasing tendency towards ministerial intervention in, or comment on, BBC affairs. Smith, for example, was described as being "deeply worried" about plans for a more populist BBC1, and as being "incensed" about the Nine O'clock News move. He has expressed concern about the number of BBC reruns and the inadequacy of cost-cutting plans. He likes to make his feelings known.

That's not how it used to be. Eight years ago, for the Guardian, I interviewed three former home secretaries about their relationship with the BBC (in the days when the Home Office was the responsible department). They were all agreed about the need to remain silent on BBC matters. In the words of Willie Whitelaw: "It is a very important tradition that the home secretary does not, by the very nature of his office, apply pressure on the BBC. I would never publicly, when I was home secretary, make criticism of the BBC." As a firm supporter of the BBC, Smith's involvement is (mostly) benign, but his successors' may be less so. It is a dangerous precedent.

So is there a middle way between the rock of commercial self-interest and the hard place of government intervention? The answer is yes, and it lies in an overhaul of the board of governors. In its white paper response, Bectu calls for "a clear and meaningful separation of the governors from the management of the BBC", including a separate secretariat and a more tightly drawn PSB remit. This is perfectly consistent with the demands of the commercial sector that the BBC be tied more closely to specific programming promises, but maintains the fundamental principle of BBC independence.

It should also satisfy those, such as the Campaign for Quality Television, which supports the BBC but is known to have reservations about issues such as transparency and the programme commissioning process.

Precisely what the mechanisms of scrutiny would be, and how it might guarantee more transparency and a proper accountability for the expenditure of public money, are urgent questions in the run up to the next charter renewal. Whatever the answer, sacrificing the BBC's unique freedom to invigorate our public culture on the altar of a "level playing field" is not it.

 Steven Barnett is professor of communications at the University of Westminster.
