fields.headline: Welcome to the new audio galaxy
fields.standfirst:
Jane Austin on why music could soon be totally digital

More net news
fields.trailText: Jane Austin on why music could soon be totally digital.
fields.body:
As a marketing and distribution tool for musicians, websites are challenging conventions of fan loyalty, copyright (thanks to Napster), and brand image.

Firstly, they have replaced the official fanclubs. Gone are the days of the drummer's aunt sitting in a makeshift office in the spare bedroom sifting through bags of mail. Now there tends to be two types of site - the official initiative from the record company and the alternative fan or "stalker" sites.

Although the revenue raised from the official sites is presently insignificant, the information and the database that is subsequently generated from the site are extremely valuable. Via the web, record companies and fans have become the publishers of their own magazines.

According to Marcus Vinton, executive creative director of digital communications for the Ogilvy and WPP Group, the past few years have seen a fundamental and radical shift in the way the music industry markets brands online. "The new marketing mix has come to utilise the web and other digital channels for their artists as brands in their own right. The web is a highly targeted tool providing a depth of content that could never be reached through conventional 'off-line' channels," he explains.

A successful web presence can do wonders for bands. But as Mark Richardson, managing director of Independiente Records, who represent Travis and Paul Weller, says: "The prosperity of the site involves a huge investment in terms of time. The most important thing is that the talent is involved. Two of the most successful sites currently are Travis's and Radiohead's - mainly because the bands have creative control over them."

Top of the range musician websites include the David Bowie's four-year-old BowieNet - the first music-based, artist-supported ISP; U2's offering - a digital cornucopia of graphics, information, videos and downloading facilities; and Clinic's for its track Second Line. However, Vinton believes that the majority of sites show little functionality or understanding of their commercial equity: "In general, the entertainment industry sites are among the least entertaining. George Harrison's new offering at least is fun and a natural extension of his own beliefs and inspirations. However, the web is still vastly under-used by the industry."

Harrison's new website which is promoting the re-release of his 70s album All Things Must Pass, features pissing, giggling gnomes, screaming guitar solos, and all things Monty Python-esque. It is a relief to see that a seasoned rocker is not trying to be edgy or hip - witness the image of a hirsute Harrison on the home page sporting a sun hat and wellies, while being pissed on by a laughing garden gnome.

The quiet Beatle, who is more likely to be found gardening than surfing the global freeway, had complete disregard for the medium at the start of the project. But he agreed with the design team at @radical.media, that the prospect of making a music video "hurt". Consequently, the website project was more appropriate.

Creativity aside, the main issue currently affecting musicians' online offerings is the Napster ruling. This week witnessed a judgement to prevent Napster operating as an unrestricted independent. "Ironically Napster has been penalised for doing no more than wanting to share its love of music," adds Vinton. "The company helped over 50m community members to do this with other people's music, for free, and threatened to undermine some of the most powerful divisions in the world. Today many artists have a far more mature understanding of their musical rights as well as a belief that their generation has a natural and demographic need to communicate online."

Richardson of Independiente Records sees the Napster ruling as an attempt to set a legal precedent. He says: "The ruling is about copyright paranoia. It is no different to when kids tape the radio, or the arguments against videos when they were first introduced. Most musicians' sites only have 30 seconds of the track as that legally negates the payment of any royalties, or the music is encrypted so that you can't copy it. Whereas the issue with Napster is that it allows you to have a copy of the track. But you can easily go into any high-street retailer and buy the technology to allow you to download music.

"Downloading music doesn't take away anything from record sales. The fan will always buy the CD because they are loyal to the band and because the quality of the download isn't great. Radiohead put all of its Kid A album on Napster and it still went to number one in the US."

Others disagree. Drew Leavy, a consultant with digital strategy consultancy Decipher, believes that mp3 will have a detrimental effect on CD sales. "I used to buy four CDs a month, but now I download everything, and I haven't bought a CD in six months. It's a logical choice. Why pay £15 for a lump of plastic, of which the band gets very little, when you can download?

"The UK record companies and retailers have to be more realistic about pricing, and it will be the retailers who will suffer most. The true fans will still buy the CD, but why should you buy something by a band you're iffy about when you can download? In general, fans are into the band, they don't give a toss about record companies' copyright and profit. Fans are loyal to bands who show that they want their music to be freely available.

"The ruling against Napster is not the be-all and end-all of digital music. The net is now an audio galaxy and record companies have to come to terms with the digital format. As compression, storage and audio standards improve and the net becomes more creative, record companies will really have to prove their validity."

Undoubtedly, digital marketing, production and distribution will change the way music works in the future. Ultimately it will redefine the relationship with the consumer, because multi-channel opportunities offer solutions that could potentially exist completely in a digital environment.

Looking ahead, Vinton predicts that in 2005 more than 50% of the nation will have access to a digital TV platform and t-commerce will be worth approximately £275m in the UK alone. The future may well witness hybrid MTV-type broadcasts, structured as pay-per-view models, or with a personalised download service. Because of this it is possible that a strategic alignment of labels could end up challenging high-street music retailers.

fields.headline: The perils of playing around in traffic
fields.trailText: Site statistics can be a perilous business. Only last week, e-district admitted that its reported users, page impressions and revenues may not have been quite as healthy as they appeared.
fields.body:
Site statistics can be a perilous business. Only last week, e-district admitted that its reported users, page impressions and revenues may not have been quite as healthy as they appeared. CEO Steven Laitman was suspended pending an investigation and the board requested that trading in the company's shares be suspended. The board's statement continued: "It is not clear over what period of time this overstatement has occurred."

Traffic, numbers of users and impressions have always been a murky world. Ironic, isn't it? The net was always supposed to be about openness - there would be precise and exact guides to exactly what people looked at, where they looked and how often.

Except it hasn't worked out like that.

Site editors and managers often bandy about terms such as "hits" and "pages" and "users" like confetti. But how many people actually know what any of this means?

Here's a starting point: contrary to popular belief, a hit is not the same as a page impression. A hit denotes a single element of a page, so if a page has lots of graphics or boxes on it, loading each one counts as a hit - and one page could equal 20 hits. It's a meaningless figure; shame it's such a great word that people keep using it.

A page impression is a file or collection of files - to this date probably the most reliable way of compiling stats. It's essentially the collection of different bits that make up the page that you're reading: all the words, graphics and files.

Of course, it doesn't differentiate between the sites which get loads of impressions because they're great and the sites which get loads of impressions because they are badly designed and impossible to find anything on - what if it's a site that takes you through seven clicks before finally arriving at your destination?

After that, the term "user" should be pretty straightforward. Isn't it one person, visiting a site looking at some pages and then disappearing? Well, no, actually. Theoretically 100 users from one company could all visit the same site, but because their computers all go through the company server (which has one number assigned to it, or IP address) that could count as one person.

There are other issues, too. Some internet service providers cache popular pages. What this means is that the front page of a site which perhaps doesn't change that often is stored by the ISP to speed up the site for users. Some observers estimate that without caching, page views per site could be doubled.

So it is not for lack of numbers that the whole business gets confusing. As Michael Nutley, editor of New Media Age, explains: "The point is not that you can't collect the numbers but that nobody knows what they mean."

At least part of the problem is the perceived lack of standards. TV broadcasters accept the Broadcast Audience Research Bureau (Barb) figures, largely because they all fund them, as do radio broadcasters, who fund Radio Joint Audience Research (Rajar). For magazines and newspapers there's the ABC. But for the net?

You'd assume, from the lack of sites that actually produce regular audited figures, that there are no standards that mean anything. But that's actually not the case. ABC//electronic produces both standards and audited figures for online publications. If there's an industry standard, this is it. Last week, Press Gazette called for the ABCE//electronic to become the standard so that sites can start to move on to a level playing field. "ABCE//electronic is a start to making websites not only accountable to advertisers and site owners but also to staff and journalists who work for them."

So far Guardian Unlimited is the only online publisher to audit its monthly page impressions officially through ABCe.

The commercial implications are enormous. Advertising agencies want reliable and realistic figures before parting with their cash. For journalists and editors working on sites it's increasingly the case that stats can be a vital part of the editorial process - editors who know them live for their figures and for knowing how much an article or audio is worth.

But ABCE//electronic is only the starting point. The future raises enormous questions: what if having thousands of disparate users is not as valuable for advertisers as having fewer, more specialised users? What if page impressions will become only as important as much more personal information: how long does a user spend on a site? What do they look for? And how do you measure that? Viewer panels, like the broadcasters?

But right now, I'd settle for industry standards.

 Simon Rogers is deputy editor of Guardian Unlimited.

For magazines and newspapers there's the ABC. But for the net? You'd assume, from the lack of sites that actually produce regular audited figures, that there are no standards that mean anything. But that's actually not the case. ABC//electronic produces both standards and audited figures for online publications. If there's an industry standard, this is it. Last week, Press Gazette called for the ABCE//electronic to become the standard so that sites can start to move on to a level playing field. "ABCE//electronic is a start to making websites not only accountable to advertisers and site owners but also to staff and journalists who work for them." So far Guardian Unlimited is the only online publisher to audit its monthly page impressions officially through ABCe. The commercial implications are enormous. Advertising agencies want reliable and realistic figures before parting with their cash. For journalists and editors working on sites it's increasingly the case that stats can be a vital part of the editorial process - editors who know them live for their figures and for knowing how much an article or audio is worth. But ABCE//electronic is only the starting point. The future raises enormous questions: what if having thousands of disparate users is not as valuable for advertisers as having fewer, more specialised users? What if page impressions will become only as important as much more personal information: how long does a user spend on a site? What do they look for? And how do you measure that? Viewer panels, like the broadcasters? But right now, I'd settle for industry standards.  Simon Rogers is deputy editor of Guardian Unlimited. simon.rogers@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The 23rd Guardian Student Media Awards
fields.trailText: Now in their 23rd year, the Guardian Student Media Awards recognise and reward the very best student journalists, editors, and photographers.
fields.body:
Now in their 23rd year, the Guardian Student Media Awards recognise and reward the very best student journalists, editors, and photographers.

If you've spent time and effort at university getting experience in journalism and want the opportunity to build a future in the industry, this could be your answer. However limited your resources, our experienced judging panel will recognise the kind of imagination and energy which will drive a successful career. They know, because they've been in your position. And if you're successful, pretty soon you could be in theirs.

Prizes

Prizes include work experience at the Guardian, cash and free flights from Easyjet. There is also a prize for an overall winner, which will include an extended work placement at the Guardian and Guardian Unlimited and a subsistence award of £1,000 for the duration of the placement.

Judges include:

Alan Rusbridger, editor, the Guardian; Jon Snow, Channel 4 News; Andrew Marr, BBC political editor; Alastair Campbell, press secretary to the prime minister; Tony Elliott, publisher, Time Out;

Jeremy Vine, presenter, Newsnight; Eamonn McCabe, photographer, the Guardian; Luisa Nitrato-Izzo, picture editor, Marie Claire; Tony Chambers, art director, GQ; Martina King, managing director, Yahoo;

Ekow Eshun, journalist; Ben Olins, editor, Hotdog magazine; Scott Mansun, editor, Ministry magazine; George Alagiah, presenter, BBC News; Clare Balding, presenter, BBC TV & Radio 5 Live;

Nicky Campbell, presenter, Radio 5 Live; Sankha Guha, travel television presenter, and Ashley Highfield, BBC director of new media.

Previous winners include:

Andrew Rawnsley; Esther Oxford; Libby Brooks; James Wood; David Sharrock; Rachel Newsome and Emily Barr.

Award categories

This year's awards have 13 categories, including student newspaper, student magazine, student reporter, student feature writer, student photographer, student publication designer, student website, student critic, student sports journalist and student travel writer.

The Shoestring Award is given to a publication that receives less than £5,000 in funding from its union but makes up in originality and ideas for what it lacks in budget.

The Diversity Award is for a student journalist whose work has either presented an accurate picture of the diverse nature of British culture or has highlighted racial inequalities.

The student campaign/campaign journalist award is for an ongoing editorial campaign or campaign journalist within a magazine or newspaper that has been instrumental in exposing an issue, scandal or corruption.

How to enter

For an application form, write to: The Guardian Student Media Awards, PO Box 415, St Albans AL4 OYW.

Tel: 01727 865395. For further information check Guardian Student Media Awards.

All work must have been published since September 1 2000; the closing date for entries is July 20 2001.

webTitle: Profile of independent producer Jane Hewland

fields.headline: She scores!
fields.standfirst: A chance comment gave indy producer Jane Hewland the idea for Dream Team, Sky's football soap.  Maggie Brown  looks at her career, and finds out what life is like for the woman who makes programmes about video games and raunchy air hostesses - and whose main inspiration is her son
fields.trailText: A chance comment gave indy producer Jane Hewland the idea for Dream Team, Sky's football soap. Maggie Brown looks at her career, and finds out what life is like for the woman who makes programmes about video games and raunchy air hostesses - and whose main inspiration is her son.
fields.body:
Jane Hewland is sitting in a windowless office, lined with purple football shirts, in a grim warehouse off the Old Kent Road. Demolition is taking place all around - it's a far cry from the LWT tower, with its views up and down the Thames, where she made her name before abruptly quitting 11 years ago.

In the media equivalent of losing a winning lottery ticket, Hewland handed back her portion of those now famous golden handcuff share options which made multimillionaires of a lucky few former LWT colleagues, from Greg Dyke and Christopher Bland to Melvyn Bragg. But she's looking contented.

For here on the Old Kent Road it is two minutes from Millwall football ground. This is where her cult Sky One football soap, Dream Team, is based. It's the one which breaks the rules by taking Premier League footage and then colouring one team's shirts purple to make them look like Dream Team's Harchester United. She also pays real footballers to turn up at Millwall to film close contact shots.

Hewland's creation, the UK's first football soap - with believable football, and lots of tabloid storylines - has just been given a renewed vote of confidence from Sky One's fresh management team, after a tricky year. A fifth series, upped to 32 hours, on top of the 200 episodes already made, has been ordered, to run twice a week, and will sit alongside a new Australian teen soap. There will be repeats, branded as half-hour Harchester United TV (a spoof on MUTV), running this summer.

In between, Hewland International, her production company, is making a BBC Worldwide educational drama, called Goal, for foreign students of English, using football as bait. And ITV has paid her a compliment by commissioning its own series, Footballers' Wives - from the team behind the sensational Bad Girls. "There'll be as much football in it as there was oil in Dallas," growls Nick Elliott, ITV's drama controller and another LWT multimillionaire.

Hewland has also just landed a 13-hour drama order from Sky One, for Mile High, about the raunchy antics of air hostesses, due for screening in early 2002. "The top factual shows are Airport and Airline, and they can't show what really goes on. We were onto drunken pilots ages ago," she observes with a happy smile.

Hewland has a reputation for being creative, highly intelligent and ahead of the game, but a little wacky - and not just because she walked away from £9-10m in March 1990. "She's a very, very bright woman, and dangerously fearless," observes Elliott. "The thing was," says Hewland, "I was too stupid. I realised later that if I had got them to sack me, I would have kept the shares. I got nothing out of it. God, I don't mind. It's very weird, you get to a certain age [she was 40 then], it's nothing to do with talent, but there are periods of your life when nothing you touch works. I'd worked incredibly happily up to that point."

Greg Dyke, then her LWT boss, had made her controller of current affairs in 1988 but it hadn't worked out. "I hugely admire Greg but I guess I was a John Birt person, brought up through that system."

Last year was another iffy period. She failed to win an ITV soap commission with her ideas about flashy Essex millionaires. And under Sky One's general manager, David Bergg, the hotshot scheduler lured from ITV, Dream Team faced the axe. But it was Bergg who walked the plank.

"The spirit there [at Sky One] is just so different now," says Hewland. "For the past year, we've been dealing with a bunch of completely confused people trying to put the best face on it, all trying desperately to defend their corner. But now everyone is relaxed and happy, it is back to the basics, Sky as it was in 1997 [when Dream Team, commissioned by Lis Murdoch, began]. I know it is much harder for them now that Channel 4 has got its act together on the entertainment side, but the way forward is to offer a version of the [brash] Fox network."

As for David Bergg's vision of Sky One, appealing to the Sunny Delight ITV family audience? "I really don't think there is any point in trying to be another ITV or BBC because Sky hasn't got the money. Audiences go to BBC first, then ITV, so why go to Sky? Also, what did you think about Harry Enfield going to Sky? For audiences it's like, 'So that's the only one which would have him.' It's counterproductive," she says.

"Whereas if you start with something that's your own brand, that you build, then you've got something to offer - cult viewing which people know they can't get anywhere else. It was that way with Ibiza Uncovered, Prickly Heat, and The Simpsons and Friends, before they were flogged elsewhere.

"I never took Mile High near David Bergg. He didn't want long-running series. I was arguing that with BBC and ITV news both going to 10 pm we had a gift. We have to go in there and try and clean up with long-running brands, particularly on Sky because people sample it only when the terrestrial channels don't satisfy."

The evening before our interview Hewland dipped back into her earlier cerebral life: she was at the House of Lords for a recorded brainstorming session called by Lord [John] Birt. He's writing his memoirs and has reached 1972/73 and the famed creation of Weekend World and its "mission to explain".

"Weekend World was a fantastic education for everyone who worked on it, and that's shown by the fact that they've gone out and run the rest of British television. Whether it was at all significant for the audience I can't tell. It was like a giant university compound for the media establishment," she says.

By 1987, when Birt went to the BBC, she'd already joined forces with Janet Street-Porter to create the slick Network 7, for Channel 4, the foundation of the "yoof" programming genre. "The first person to do anything is a fool, because they always fuck up. Then everyone else comes along. Network 7 is the only thing I've done where being first worked."

As for being a businesswoman? "It has taken me 10 years to learn how I should have started. First of all, I didn't have a partner. You have to have somebody to bat ideas about. I had this huge wake-up call last year. There was a TV discussion where David Baddiel said he'd got 13 hours of television from Sky One and Lynda La Plante flipped, saying: 'How can people like you get 13 hours? I have to beg for four.' I thought: 'Oh my God, I am looking at what I can become.' I tend to be very hands on. But then you are limited to what you yourself can do. I'm aiming to be a proper businesswoman."

The inspiration for her best ideas, she says, comes from her son, Harry, now at Edinburgh University, whose father is Nick Evans (author of The Horse Whisperer). Hewland secured her company finances in the early 1990s with Channel 4's Gamesmaster, the first series to catch the video games mania: "Being a mother inspired me." In December 1990, she bought a Nintendo set with robot and laser, as specified by her son, and played duck hunt. "I thought: 'Bloody hell, this could be good television.'"

Dream Team and her interest in football sprang from Harry, though the format was conjured up in one brief exchange with ex-Sky executive David Hill, now running Fox. He said: "I'm going to make you a very rich woman. What are the two things our viewers love? Football and soap. Do a soap about football."

As for Mile High, "Again, it comes from Harry - I was helping him with his A-level geography on noise pollution when in a little street in Hillingdon we saw a British Airways hostess get off a bus, go into a little pebbledashed house."

British television drama, she says, is in a time warp. "Love in a Cold Climate and Take a Girl Like You were getting just 22% share on a major channel. They are massively over-resourced. Where is the Network 7 approach, the kick up the backside?"

She makes Sky's drama for £150,000 an hour, a quarter of ITV prices. "We have a gang-writing set up here, like America." Is Hewland about to have the last laugh, ending up richer than the handcuff millionaires from her own efforts? "No I'm not. But I don't mind. I mean, what would I do with it? I wouldn't give up for any money the experience of going out and learning the things I have learned." Is Harry coming into the business? "I dreamed at first that was the way it would go. But no. He did his gap year here and he saw how fallible I was."

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
 Calling on all Freeservers, please buy books from BOL; that was the message from Freeserve management last Tuesday when it pleaded with staff to open BOL accounts for themselves and two of their friends. "It's free and it's an order," wrote "Honest" John Pluthero, urging staff to spend up to £20 each with BOL (but only if bought through the Freeserve site).

Graciously, Freeserve has offered to reimburse staff and their friends for the cost of the books, which could end up seeing £20,000 disappearing from its marketing budget. Why is it doing this? Because BOL has started fretting that its expensive tenancies are not working, and Freeserve wants to prove BOL wrong. Not your average run-of-the-mill promotion though, is it? More to the point, will all these new account holders be converted into loyal customers? Time will tell.

 Speaking of ramping up figures, the scandal of all scandals rocked the internet community last week with the suspension of Steve Laitman of e-district for allegedly telling a few porkies about site traffic. Er, but hang on a minute, since when have internet companies ever told the truth? Take for instance, the liberal over-use of the term "hits", designed to confuse unsuspecting types that easily fall for the "hits equals users" myth.

The PR following the Madonna gig webcast did just that, with many media outlets falling for the touted 9m user "audience" figure when insiders said there was no way any more than 25,000 people were able to view the webcast. So there you have it, new media is all a pack of loose fabrications, and quite frankly, we all need to start asking more probing questions. Rant over.

 Congrats to the affable new media supremo Paul Zwillenberg on the birth of his first offspring, Ottavia Eden. Not one to waste any time, cyberdad Paul has already succeeded in teaching her how to use the mousepad on his Sony Viao. She hasn't quite worked out how to doubleclick yet, he sighs, but it can't be too far off now. And he's already thinking about teaching her coding as a first language. Who's betting that Barbie dolls and tea party sets will be banned from the Zwillenberg household?

 It's official. The web has become art. Starting March 6, Tate Britain is showing a Reuters-sponsored ceiling of digital star constellations that represent the stock market. Sound a bit dull? Not if you get your kicks from following technology stocks. As each individual star on the planetarium-like roof will represent a listed company, and the aim is to mirror stock market developments, it will be fascinating to watch the technology stocks divebomb - surely represented as a shooting star? - and see which stars start clustering up together prior to a merger.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of Media Guardian.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Susan Nickson
fields.trailText: Susan Nickson, twenty-two-year-old scriptwriter of BBC2 series Two Pints Of Lager And A Packet Of Crisps.
fields.body:
Newspapers: The Runcorn Weekly News, to see which people I went to school with have died of a heroin overdose, or had a baby, and the Daily Star so I can criticise the grammar. I don't read nationals - I've not found one that suits me.

Magazines: At university, to numb my brain, it was either Woman's Own or Chat. Now, I buy Heat to keep up with the showbiz gossip, but I'm annoyed because they only gave my show three stars out of five.

Books: In my house, we keep a library on a shelf by the toilet, so every time I've had a curry I've had a good fix of Virginia Woolf or Jane Austen. I love Philip Larkin. I discovered his poetry had naughty words, and thought, "cool"! I love Bridget Jones's Diary.

Television: I'm a massive fan of This Morning with Richard and Judy. I've got no parents in Britain at the moment, and they've taken over the role for me. I've got to watch Coronation Street - the biggest sacrifice of my life was missing the live episode when I was stuck on a bus.

Radio: Radio 2 - I'm getting so old. Radio 1 doesn't appeal because the music is very bland, but loved Chris Evans when he did Too Much Gravy.

Films: For Valentine's day, my boyfriend ordered the Casablanca video. I thought it would be the most romantic evening , but I was so disappointed. When she got on the plane at the end, I thought, don't do that you stupid woman, he should have gone.

Ads: They stop you from watching programmes, but I like the one for the Bathmatic device, which shows an old man in the bath, grinning at the camera. Another scary one is Gloria Hunniford trying to sell life insurance. She comes on and says you're all going to die, but here's a free carriage clock.

New media: It's brilliant, but a lot of working hours are lost to it. I go to a site where there's a message board for your home town. I go to Runcorn, but mostly it's messages from people who've left, saying, get out!

 Twenty-two-year-old scriptwriter Susan Nickson's series Two Pints Of Lager And A Packet Of Crisps starts tonight on BBC2.

I discovered his poetry had naughty words, and thought, "cool"! I love Bridget Jones's Diary. Television: I'm a massive fan of This Morning with Richard and Judy. I've got no parents in Britain at the moment, and they've taken over the role for me. I've got to watch Coronation Street - the biggest sacrifice of my life was missing the live episode when I was stuck on a bus. Radio: Radio 2 - I'm getting so old. Radio 1 doesn't appeal because the music is very bland, but loved Chris Evans when he did Too Much Gravy. Films: For Valentine's day, my boyfriend ordered the Casablanca video. I thought it would be the most romantic evening , but I was so disappointed. When she got on the plane at the end, I thought, don't do that you stupid woman, he should have gone. Ads: They stop you from watching programmes, but I like the one for the Bathmatic device, which shows an old man in the bath, grinning at the camera. Another scary one is Gloria Hunniford trying to sell life insurance. She comes on and says you're all going to die, but here's a free carriage clock. New media: It's brilliant, but a lot of working hours are lost to it. I go to a site where there's a message board for your home town. I go to Runcorn, but mostly it's messages from people who've left, saying, get out!  Twenty-two-year-old scriptwriter Susan Nickson's series Two Pints Of Lager And A Packet Of Crisps starts tonight on BBC2.

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.standfirst: Media Monitor by John Kampfner
fields.trailText: Media Monitor by John Kampfner
fields.body:
Political journalists are most interested in sleaze and scandal, and are bored by policy. That has been the consistent complaint of this government, and John Major's for that matter. So how true is it?

Romeike Media Intelligence, a Swedish media monitoring company which has covered a succession of elections in Scandinavia and Germany, has just begun an in-depth survey of the news priorities of our newspapers at the start of the UK campaign. Its first assessment is based on data from January 11 to February 14. It shouldn't be taken as comprehensive, and some of its work betrays a certain innocence about Westminster, but it still provides some interesting data.

The firm's methodology is straightforward. It includes all the dailies and Sundays, plus the Evening Standard, the Spectator and the New Statesman. It takes the two top-placed political stories in each publication - which after all is probably how most casual readers glean their information and make their judgments. Commentaries and leader articles are excluded. It bases its assessment on a strict textual analysis of each piece. The grades go from +1, the most positive coverage possible, down in decimal points to -1 (awful). Zero is neutral. According to its calculations, headlines count for half the impact of a story, a reasonable assumption.

This was the period dominated by Peter Mandelson's resignation. In that time, Labour had nearly twice as much coverage - about 450 stories - against the Conservatives' 250. However, the overall impact on Labour was worse, at around -0.3, according to Romeike's scale. The Tories went just into negative, at around -0.1, which for an opposition at this stage of the political cycle is unimpressive. As for the Liberal Democrats, they rarely wavered from the neutral line, because they were mentioned so rarely.

On sheer number of mentions, sleaze was way out ahead, being the main theme in about 130 of the most eye-catching stories that month; election campaign coverage was about half that, followed by the EU (Tony Blair admitting the two-year euro deadline), then internal party machinations and, behind that, tax at about 50 stories.

As for the issues that cast each of the parties in a good or bad light, there were interesting findings that seem to confirm the perceptions in each of the party headquarters. For the Tories, tax easily played best, with education and immigration helping them only marginally. Tellingly, they gained little benefit from stories on sleaze, Europe, the health service, or the election campaign.

For Labour, education was streets ahead (this was the period just preceding the announcements on specialist schools, and Alastair Campbell's "bog standard comprehensives" comments). Every other issue caused a problem. Sleaze was terrible all round - close to the worst possible rating of -1. Health was only marginally difficult, with immigration, defence, tax and the EU all having a stronger negative impact.

This first batch of statistics gives some early clues about the way the campaign proper will be covered. First, news coverage reinforces negative perceptions about politicians and politics in general. It is extremely hard to get a "good news" story running for any length of time. Second, unlike the 1997 campaign, Labour will not find it easy to dictate which stories should run throughout the day. Third, the Conservatives are still struggling to match Labour in terms of quantity of top stories.

And while, overall, the balance of the top stories appears slanted towards them, it doesn't seem to be enough of a gap to make a significant impact on undecided voters. Fourth, William Hague is quoted three times as often in Tory-related stories as Tony Blair is in Labour ones, suggesting that the prime minister might be less of a control freak than the leader of the opposition. And fifth, the Liberal Democrats are getting nowhere. Their main contribution over this period was for Norman Baker to hasten Mandelson's demise - something the party leadership in Cowley Street now rues.

Perhaps the most glaring conclusion is that all the negative coverage for Labour hasn't made the blindest bit of difference in the polls. What does that say about the impact of newspaper front pages?

ITV will delay News at Ten tomorrow night so that Popstars band Hear'Say can play at the Brit Awards. P3

A severe shortage of capacity is set to force ITV to delay launching on digital satellite TV until next year. P24

DAILY MAIL

Internet users face a massive rise in costs after Microsoft revealed it was planning to start charging for web services. P7

DAILY EXPRESS

As advertising watchdogs receive a record number of complaints over raunchy adverts, an expert in trends asks have we gone cold on the hot selling power of sex? P24-25

fields.headline: I was a student hack
fields.standfirst: They are squalid, cramped and full of rubbish, but they are also a traditional proving ground for some of the country's top journalists.  Guy Adams remembers his time on a student newspaper
fields.trailText: They are squalid, cramped and full of rubbish, but they are also a traditional proving ground for some of the country's top journalists. Guy Adams remembers his time on a student newspaper.
fields.body:
The great thing about student newspapers is how little they change. Ask a few Fleet Street veterans about their student days. Most will talk of the time they drank cheap beer in dingy union bars, flirted with radical politics and cut their journalistic teeth pestering overworked academics.

My own university career, which ended last May, followed a pretty similar pattern. When I wasn't studying English I spent most of my time at the Steel Press, Sheffield University's student newspaper, concocting scoops for the next edition and picking up the pieces from the last.

In keeping with the great tradition of student newspapers, ours was created in a truly disgusting office. Buried deep in the bowels of the student union, it was tiny and filthy, with just enough room for four people to be seated at any one time (we had upwards of 15 section editors) and foot-high piles of rubbish on every table.

Notes, clothes, library books and letters to the editor would be lost as soon as they touched the desk. Bills would go unread and unpaid for months, and once - to my eternal horror - a three-week-old solicitor's letter emerged from the mouldy remains of take-away curry. We never dared to clean up the office after that.

Our publishing equipment consisted of three ageing Apple Macs - two of which crashed on an hourly basis - and a scanner which took 15 minutes to load a single photograph. Production nights, fraught with tension lest the computer should breathe its last, usually descended into a drunken mess.

On such evenings it was the editor's duty to make a contrite call to the printers, pleading for our run to be rescheduled. Sometimes - if they had been paid within the last quarter - the printer agreed. More often he stuck his fingers up, we crossed ours, and I prayed that the worst howlers were buried on the inside pages.

Working for the Steel Press was nerve-racking, frustrating, and frequently disastrous. We were the antithesis of professionalism (either overburdened with stress or unsteady on drink) and unhindered by everyday rules of journalistic practice. Complete editorial redesigns took place on the whim of a bored designer, two-page features would be typed straight onscreen by a tardy writer and sent to the printers without so much as a glance from our sub-editor. But the paper always went out and we, at least, loved it.

Therein, I think, lies both the greatest strength and the biggest weakness of student media: professionalism. While a few of the better-funded student newspapers employ a full-time editor, most are voluntary set-ups that leave the utterly inexperienced student hack to sink or swim in a hands-on environment.

This gives campus publications many of their worst hallmarks: dull news agendas, preachy editorials, predictable features and fawning interviews. But often it delivers work that is incisive, original, hard-hitting and entertaining. Student journalists embark on an incredibly steep learning curve and, as long as this doesn't overwhelm them, they are blessed with an unparalleled opportunity to experiment.

In a world where the same old material is churned out to ever more frequent deadlines, student writers offer a breath of fresh air, and when things go well, working in the student media is fantastic. But at other times it can be hugely demoralising. Like most members of the fourth estate, student hacks are frequently vilified and rarely praised. They shift thousands of papers every issue but the audience remains concertedly cynical - and often downright hostile.

Sometimes, when things went wrong and our inbox filled with critical emails, I would wonder why we bothered. Once or twice the Steel Press letters page became an undiluted rant against the editorial team - a decent reflection of our mailbag, but perhaps not the best way to market the paper.

This is where the Guardian Student Media Awards come in. For more than 20 years, student journalists have been treated to an annual event that heaps praise onto their battered egos and reminds them that someone, at least, appreciates the hard work. They have also enjoyed an almost unique chance to meet colleagues from rival publication, and leading journalists from the national press.

Despite the ever-growing number of media back-slapping ceremonies, the Guardian's awards remain well respected. Winning one will not catapult the humble student into Fleet Street, but it does open a few doors and has launched enough successful careers to be taken seriously by the people that matter.

In that vein, the obvious parting shot is to offer sage advice on how to pick up some silverware, but that isn't an easy thing to do: in all journalism, especially student journalism, it's best to stand out from the crowd rather than blithely follow advice. Learn from others, but be sure to strike out on your own.

Whatever the result, you are, to quote Mark Firth - editor of Heat magazine and a former award winner - cutting your teeth in "the best breeding ground for anyone wanting to be a journalist. Bar none."

 Guy Adams was student reporter of the year in 1999 and 2000.

webTitle: Laura Barton on her student journalism days

fields.headline: Hungry for words
fields.standfirst: Fancy a career in journalism? Then get ready to burn the midnight oil on the student newspaper and work in the media for free to get experience. But it's well worth it, says  Laura Barton
fields.trailText: Fancy a career in journalism? Then get ready to burn the midnight oil on the student newspaper and work in the media for free to get experience. But it's well worth it, says Laura Barton.
fields.body:
You'd better like photocopying. And faxing. And crouching on your haunches rooting through half-filed back-copies of Homes & Garden or the Ormskirk Advertiser, or whichever publication accepted your grovelling application for work experience, in search of an article from 1983 about tobogganing. If you're considering a career in journalism, it pays to spend your holidays making milky coffee, answering telephones and taking notes for a local or national publication.

The idea occurred to me halfway through my first year at university, when everyone else was already muttering about being investment bankers and management consultants. I sent off a handful of letters, and was lucky to get a stint on both the Observer and Vogue. While the rest of my friends were earning a bit of pocket money, working in pubs, cafes and factories, I was kipping on a friend's floor in London, and trying to pull off a convincing impression of a hotshot young journo.

My first experiences of professional journalism did not go swimmingly. During my first week at Vogue, I spent the majority of my time covered in photocopier ink, and trying not to be scared by the whippet-thin ladies with their chic pointy shoes and their glossy pony hair. I took the stairs so I wouldn't have to stand next to them, primped and perfumed in the morning, as they caught the lift. I also succeeded in hanging up on Nicholas Coleridge, king of the Condé Nast empire. Twice.

At the Observer, I was placed in the newsroom, to assist on a riveting story about road transport changes. Most of my day was spent discussing pedestrianisation with city councils. Blabbering away on the phone, in a room full of people, takes a bit of getting used to. The reporter I work-shadowed told me that journalism is all about attitude, the clothes you wear, and the sort of pose you strike. I like to believe this isn't true.

The second summer, I went abroad to work on a music magazine in Canada. It was a tiny office, no more than 10 people, and we spent all day listening to records. They even let me do some writing. It was bliss. Back at university, I edited the student paper and started a magazine before I began to have doubts about whether this was really the career for me.

I wasn't entirely sure I had the sort of ruthless edge that journalists are supposed to possess. I didn't think I'd ever grasp shorthand, or get a place at journalism school. I just liked writing. I didn't want to keep a bottle of scotch in the bottom drawer of my desk, or turn up on people's doorsteps while they were trying to grieve. In short, I decided that it was a nasty business and I'd rather be a hairdresser.

Shortly after my speculative telephone call to the Vidal Sassoon training academy I won an award which landed me some work experience at the Sunday Telegraph Magazine, which was a fantastic four weeks. I won't lie, it was yet more filing and photocopying, and researching for other people's articles on the internet and in the library, rifling through cuttings files for information about David Hockney and Stephen King.

But for the first time, I felt that I was actually part of the publication; they let me sit in on their features meetings and help on the fashion shoots, pressing clothes for a rock chic shoot at a biker convention. They also let me interview a couple of fashion designers.

In September, I moved to the Guardian, and it's here I've been happiest (she says, kissing ass). It's like any job - six months down the line I'm still finding out everyone's name, and how to use the computers, and where everything is. I still feel nervous when I speak to my section editor.

It's a bit different from student journalism. Deadlines are tougher, the need for accuracy greater. I've had letters of complaint from Chaucer experts and pigeon societies, to name but two, and it's still the most mortifying thing in the world to know you've got it wrong and let everyone down.

There are jobs that pay better, and jobs with more sociable hours, and jobs where you don't have to spend all day faxing publishers, or phoning MPs and celebrities. But it's worth every summer you worked for nothing while your friends were playing beach volleyball, and every all-nighter you spent at the student paper surviving on chocolate digestives.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Interactive advertising's latest news

fields.headline: Chat with your television
fields.standfirst: As the brave new world of interactive advertising gets nearer, Claire Cozens reports on the latest developments
fields.trailText: As the brave new world of interactive advertising gets nearer, Claire Cozens reports on the latest developments.
fields.body:
Low-fat spreads and cook-in sauces may not seem like the stuff revolutions are made of. But that is exactly how a new advertising campaign from foods giant Unilever is being billed by its creators. The new campaign, for Olivio spread and Colman's sauces, is to be the first interactive campaign to appear on ITV - and it is being described as the coming-of-age of interactive advertising.

Interactive advertising has already spawned more first-to-market claims than even the most diligent industry observer can remember. We've had the first interactive car ad, the first interactive ad you can play games on and the first interactive ad for a charity. But most have been restricted to niche channels, so for Britain's biggest commercial broadcaster to get in on the act is a milestone.

The campaign is the result of a deal between Unilever and Carlton. Jane Marshall, chief executive of Carlton's interactive operation Carlton Active, helped put the deal together. "It's about finding ways to add extra value to advertisers," she says. "Our audience research shows that viewers have been interacting with services like Teletext for years so they're comfortable with the idea."

What does an interactive advertising campaign actually look like? The answer, initially, is much like a normal advert. Unilever is using its standard commercials for Olivio and Colmans, so anyone watching on a standard TV will not notice any difference.

But anyone watching on interactive digital television or with an ONdigital box will see a strip appear on screen saying that the ad is interactive. By pressing a button on their remote control they can shrink the broadcast ad to a box that fills a quarter of the screen, with the rest of the space dedicated to interactive content. Advertisers will then entice the viewer with product promotions, recipe ideas, competitions - anything to get them thinking of the product they are trying to sell. The idea is that the advertiser gets the viewer's attention for several minutes rather than just for the 30-second slot they've paid for.

Unilever has been something of a pioneer of interactive advertising. The UK's first interactive commercial, broadcast last March, was for its Chicken Tonight brand, and the company has set up its own portal, called the Creative Kitchen, on Sky's Open service. Users can order recipes and money-off vouchers and take part in quizzes and prize competitions. Meanwhile, Unilever can gather information about the user's habits and preferences.

Advocates of interactive ads insist they are much more effective than ordinary commercials. Ian Kenny, digital communications director at Ogilvy, the agency behind Unilever's interactive advertising campaign, says, "Our research shows the Chicken Tonight campaign was 70% more effective than the average direct response TV campaign [with a phone number viewers can call] and the rate of redemption from the voucher was four times higher than average. That could be put down to novelty value, but further campaigns have achieved similar results."

But even Kenny admits that advertising agencies will have to come up with something pretty entertaining if they are to continue to lure viewers away from the programmes they are watching. "At the moment it's a direct marketing exercise but we will see much more sophisticated content coming through," he says. "Companies could put together short films and viewers will soon be able to bookmark ads, so they can come back to it once the programme has finished."

But not all advertisers are convinced that interactive TV is a good thing. The Abbey National last week said it would cut its TV advertising budget after research showed many digital viewers use the commercial break to do their banking or shopping, skipping the ads altogether.

With so much competition for consumers' attention, advertisers have to work pretty hard to keep people listening to their message.

webTitle: The Brit Awards live on the web

fields.headline: Brits without the polish
fields.standfirst:
Remember the 1985 debacle when the Brit Awards were broadcast live? This year, it's going live again, but on the web. Sean Dodson on its likely success

More net news
fields.trailText: Remember the 1985 debacle when the Brit Awards were broadcast live? This year, it's going live again, but on the web. Sean Dodson on its likely success.
fields.body:
It's the glitziest night in the UK's musical calendar, a four-hour marathon of mutual backslapping, mumbled speeches and occasional fist fights. Tonight in Earls Court, the great and the good of the British music industry will grace the annual Brit Awards, but to see it on TV, you'll have to wait until tomorrow.

Since 1985, the Brits have traditionally been shown on TV the night after the ceremony. Back then, a disastrous pairing of Sam Fox and Mick Fleetwood, as co-hosts, put paid to the idea that a live show would work in front of a TV audience.

But tonight the first live pictures of the Brits in 16 years will be transmitted - only this time, they will be on the internet.
Tonight's exclusively online show will feature the presentation of the four key awards; Best UK artist, Best International artist, Best Female and Best Male artist. For the rest, the Brits have hired Kate Thornton to loiter backstage and catch the winners after they've collected their prizes. Four webcams will be placed in the backstage and entrance areas - even Brandon Block, the hapless DJ who gained notoriety for last year's fracas with Ronnie Wood, will meet and greet the stars. As an online show, its makers claim, it will have a level of access that TV has never enjoyed.

This is the first time the Brits have used the internet to show live video. It's an ambitious plan that led the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) to sign a two-year partnership deal with Done & Dusted, the production company that brought us the record-shattering Madonna webcast from the Brixton Academy last November.

Not so long ago production crews like Done & Dusted were a set of hired guns you'd get in to televise your event, but the coming of interactive entertainment is changing that. Now a company such as Done & Dusted is more like the driving force. No longer does it merely film the pictures, it offers to manage an event's commercial opportunities.

Although the Brits designs its own site and manages the content, the webcast is very much Done & Dusted's show. "The last thing we wanted was to produce another TV programme," says Paul Morrison, the company's managing director. "If you want TV, then watch TV. What we offer is a non-linear interactive experience."

Done & Dusted was formed three years ago by Hamish Hamilton, who will also direct tomorrow night's TV show on ITV.

Last year he was joined by Morrison, the former MD of the large marketing company that put Virgin into the V2000. This combination of editorial skill and commercial acumen, they say, is helping Done & Dusted forge a new role for production companies. "We're an events-driven broadcasting company with a commercial arm," explains Morrison.

Hamilton directed his first large-scale webcast two years ago. The company filmed Robbie Williams in Slaine Castle in Ireland in front of 100,000 people. But it sharpened its teeth last summer on the festival circuit and last year it claimed to have filmed more than 300 artists as it brought the likes of V2000 and Creamfields to computer screens. The company has also produced concerts for Sky's interactive service.

Although ambitious, this year's Brit Awards is still a trial run. But with the contract for the TV rights due to expire this year, a full-blown Brit Awards, live on the internet, could be not far away. If tonight's webcast is successful, something like a full show could be here by next year. "We've got to respect the role that television needs to play in this," says Adrian Pettett, who gave up his job as publisher of Loaded to join Done & Dusted. "The TV broadcast goes out in 67 other countries, but we are able to give people an as-near-as-damn-it experience. But the key thing with the internet is that it doesn't matter where you are, be it Tokyo, New York or Paignton in Devon. It's going out on the night live. It's not pre-edited, it's not polished or shiny. But it's interactive, you can choose which camera to watch. It's not the full show live, not yet. But this is only year one."

To reach a global audience, the Brits and Done & Dusted needed a global player, so The Microsoft Network (MSN), which also worked with Madonna, was brought in on a similar two-year deal. Although the Brits has its own site, brits.co.uk, to reach a global audience from one concert you need a company with a massive reach and a marketing clout to match.

"The trouble with the TV footage is that you have to wait and get it edited," says Tracy Blatcher, marketing manager for MSN. "The juicy bits are taken out. But we're not going to edit anything. It will be far more exciting because people don't know what the results are going to be, we won't have a chance to read the papers."

Madonna's gig received 4.5m consecutive streams during the concert, rising to 10.8m over the two-week period following the show. For the Brits, MSN has promoted the event with a 160m banner advertisements, about the same number it gave to Paul McCartney's 1999 Cavern Club concert. MSN will carry the Brits on 24 of its sites worldwide. It predicts that nearly 2m will watch some element of the Brits online.

"Madonna changed things," adds Pettett. "It changed perceptions about the value of working online. Madonna's sales of her album went up by 86% in the week after the show."

The BPI clearly hopes to generate similar revenues by putting the Brits online and has signed a deal with Amazon, which paid an undisclosed six-figure sum to become the Brits etail partner. The Brits, a registered charity, will also receive a bounty for every CD purchased when clicked through from the site. Revenue has also been raised through selling SMS rights to the event. BT Cellnet paid another undisclosed six-figure sum. Users will be able to vote via text messages for the first time. This allows record companies to appeal directly to the fans. Further syndication rights are also in the offing.

Which all leads to the rare case of an entertainment website that's making money. The plan next is to convert the official site into a year-round music portal. Especially as it looks as if an online Brits could be profitable. Already, the Classical Brits are held in June, and a number of other award ceremonies tied to the brand are rumoured to be in the pipeline.

"Brands know that their traditional TV advertising isn't really working. But big events like the Madonna gig allow kids to feel part of something, and going online makes them part of a community," says Morrison.

For the BPI, hosting a virtual award ceremony with strong commercial potential is the best way of putting on a united front after a period of deep unease over the internet. "A few years ago the record industry was cagey, nervous and threatened by the internet," says a spokesperson for the Brits. "But now its seems to have absorbed most of the adverse effects and is trying to expand into new media. I suppose this online show is part of that."

But for the Brits, and especially for Done & Dusted, it's about setting new standards, and breaking more records. For them, the audience for online entertainment is not restricted by appetite, only by bandwidth.

fields.headline: A model of private respectability
fields.standfirst:
She may be famous, but Naomi Campbell says she's entitled to privacy. To prove it, she's taking the Mirror to court, but editor Piers Morgan couldn't be happier, says Guy Adams

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: She may be famous, but Naomi Campbell says she's entitled to privacy. To prove it, she's taking the Mirror to court, but editor Piers Morgan couldn't be happier, says Guy Adams.
fields.body:
Poor Naomi Campbell. The 30-year-old supermodel has never enjoyed a great press, but lately her stock has fallen to a new low. Now she finds herself on top of Fleet Street's celebrity hit-list, embroiled in an increasingly acrimonious legal dispute with the Mirror.

It all started earlier this month, when she was spotted taking part in the increasingly popular celebrity sport of therapy. Blurred, long-lens pictures of Campbell leaving a Narcotics Anonymous meeting in Fulham were splashed across the Mirror's front page, alongside an article describing her "courageous bid to beat her addiction to drink and drugs".

Incensed by the article, Campbell got her sometime PR agency, Freud Communications, to set up an exclusive interview with the Sunday Times, in which she announced that the Mirror ("a struggling tabloid newspaper") would be served a writ under the EU's new Human Rights Act.

Thus the celebrated clothes-horse became the first person to use the new legislation against a British newspaper. She is unlikely to be the last: under the act, which came into force last October, any member of the public will have their human rights infringed if a publication intrudes on their private life, where there is no public interest.

The law was first tested by Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones against Hello! magazine last November. The couple successfully convinced the Court of Appeal that Hello! had a case to answer for printing unofficial photographs of their New York wedding.

That case continues, and is less than straightforward: Douglas and Zeta-Jones had previously sold the picture rights for the wedding to OK! magazine for £1m. Hello! argues that this compromised their right to privacy.

Campbell's case is also vulnerable. Just two days after her Sunday Times interview, she threw a celeb-packed party at Mr Chow's restaurant in Knightsbridge to launch her own brand of perfume. "It's a MIRACLE!" yelled the Mirror. "In the greatest comeback since Lazarus, Naomi Campbell recovers from the appalling stress caused by our revelation ... to shamelessly flog her new perfume."

To Mirror editor Piers Morgan, the badly timed party came as no surprise: "If you took any typical week in Naomi Campbell's life over the past 10 years you'd find something like this," he says. "She is one of the most shameless self-publicists in celebrity history, and has thrown herself into the public eye like no one since Marilyn Monroe. Frankly we couldn't choose a better test case than this one."

Morgan says that his original article was run sensitively, and in cooperation with Campbell's Elite model agency: "We could have done a come-on, asking people who had snorted coke with her to come forward, but we didn't. It was a very sympathetic article and I am amazed that she took such exception."

He also argues that drug-taking is an illegal activity: "It is against the law and when someone, a role model, breaks the law the press have a duty to expose them."

This last argument has been well-used, but it does cast the addict as a criminal rather than victim. In her original Sunday Times interview, Campbell argued (albeit without mentioning drugs) that press exposure can damage a victim's chances of recovery.

"When someone is having medical treatment, they should have a right to privacy," she said. "I'm doing this for everyone out there who needs and wants to keep their anonymity when dealing with something like overeating, anorexia or depression."

Anyone who agrees (and there are plenty of experts that do) will be pleased to learn that now that the new Human Rights Act is in place, the right to privacy is virtually guaranteed to become enshrined in English law.

If Campbell, Douglas and Zeta-Jones do not succeed, then someone else will. At this point a precedent will have been set, making the Press Complaints Commission's current privacy rules more or less defunct.

A High Court ruling delivered by Dame Elizabeth Butler Sloss last month granted anonymity to the killers of James Bulger under article two of the new act. It should be treated by the newspaper industry as a whole, and paparazzi in particular, as something of a warning shot.

But for now, at least, the Mirror's howitzers will remain firmly trained on Campbell. Last week came the news - reported in every national newspaper - that she had been banned from the Voyage fashion boutique for being rude to staff. No doubt Piers Morgan could hardly believe his luck.

Incensed by the article, Campbell got her sometime PR agency, Freud Communications, to set up an exclusive interview with the Sunday Times, in which she announced that the Mirror ("a struggling tabloid newspaper") would be served a writ under the EU's new Human Rights Act. Thus the celebrated clothes-horse became the first person to use the new legislation against a British newspaper. She is unlikely to be the last: under the act, which came into force last October, any member of the public will have their human rights infringed if a publication intrudes on their private life, where there is no public interest. The law was first tested by Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones against Hello! magazine last November. The couple successfully convinced the Court of Appeal that Hello! had a case to answer for printing unofficial photographs of their New York wedding. That case continues, and is less than straightforward: Douglas and Zeta-Jones had previously sold the picture rights for the wedding to OK! magazine for £1m. Hello! argues that this compromised their right to privacy. Campbell's case is also vulnerable. Just two days after her Sunday Times interview, she threw a celeb-packed party at Mr Chow's restaurant in Knightsbridge to launch her own brand of perfume. "It's a MIRACLE!" yelled the Mirror. "In the greatest comeback since Lazarus, Naomi Campbell recovers from the appalling stress caused by our revelation ... to shamelessly flog her new perfume." To Mirror editor Piers Morgan, the badly timed party came as no surprise: "If you took any typical week in Naomi Campbell's life over the past 10 years you'd find something like this," he says. "She is one of the most shameless self-publicists in celebrity history, and has thrown herself into the public eye like no one since Marilyn Monroe. Frankly we couldn't choose a better test case than this one." Morgan says that his original article was run sensitively, and in cooperation with Campbell's Elite model agency: "We could have done a come-on, asking people who had snorted coke with her to come forward, but we didn't. It was a very sympathetic article and I am amazed that she took such exception." He also argues that drug-taking is an illegal activity: "It is against the law and when someone, a role model, breaks the law the press have a duty to expose them." This last argument has been well-used, but it does cast the addict as a criminal rather than victim. In her original Sunday Times interview, Campbell argued (albeit without mentioning drugs) that press exposure can damage a victim's chances of recovery. "When someone is having medical treatment, they should have a right to privacy," she said. "I'm doing this for everyone out there who needs and wants to keep their anonymity when dealing with something like overeating, anorexia or depression." Anyone who agrees (and there are plenty of experts that do) will be pleased to learn that now that the new Human Rights Act is in place, the right to privacy is virtually guaranteed to become enshrined in English law. If Campbell, Douglas and Zeta-Jones do not succeed, then someone else will. At this point a precedent will have been set, making the Press Complaints Commission's current privacy rules more or less defunct. A High Court ruling delivered by Dame Elizabeth Butler Sloss last month granted anonymity to the killers of James Bulger under article two of the new act. It should be treated by the newspaper industry as a whole, and paparazzi in particular, as something of a warning shot. But for now, at least, the Mirror's howitzers will remain firmly trained on Campbell. Last week came the news - reported in every national newspaper - that she had been banned from the Voyage fashion boutique for being rude to staff. No doubt Piers Morgan could hardly believe his luck.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Andrew Neil answers criticism

fields.headline: 'This is fantasy'
fields.standfirst: Andrew Neil - editor-in-chief of the Scotsman titles and Sunday Business - replies to criticism in last week's Media section from Paul Murphy, the Guardian's financial editor
fields.trailText: Andrew Neil - editor-in-chief of the Scotsman titles and Sunday Business - replies to criticism in last week's Media section from Paul Murphy, the Guardian's financial editor.
fields.body:
The Guardian's constant critique of capitalism is that it does not encourage enough long-term investment. Press Holdings, owners of the Scotsman group of newspapers in Edinburgh and Sunday Business in London, eschews quick returns, takes a long-term horizon and invests big in its newspapers. So you might think we would warrant a small plaudit from the Guardian. No chance.

Instead, its financial editor, Paul Murphy, unleashes a diatribe of distortion, untruths and sheer malevolence masquerading as serious analysis. Even by the notoriously bitchy and inaccurate standards of contemporary media journalism, he set a new record. He found it "extraordinary" that the Scotsman should hold a presentation in London, "several hundred miles away" from its market, depicting it as an unnecessary extravagance in the "fussy, expensive" Dorchester Hotel. In fact, 60% of the Scotsman's revenues from display advertising are now booked through the London agencies.

We had already briefed the Scottish media community about the remarkable success of the paper's relaunch, with sales over 100,000 for the first time in its 183-year history. Now we were in London to spread the same good news.

Since its relaunch last May, the Scotsman has outsold the tartan editions of all the London broadsheets combined, which makes the London ad agencies a very important constituency for us. We are aiming for a substantial rise in London revenues on the back of our increased sales. So there was nothing "extraordinary" about our presentation to them.

Murphy claims that when I became publisher of Press Holdings in 1999, I took a "punishing attitude to costs" and "slashed" budgets "across the board" in Edinburgh. This is fantasy financial journalism, the opposite of the truth. Costs rose overall by 8% in 1999, and by a further 11% in 2000. Within these overall increases, editorial budgets increased by £1m in 1999, and another £1m in 2000. Promotional spending on our three Edinburgh titles similarly soared by £1m for each of these two years.

Since I became editor-in-chief in 1996, editorial budgets on our three Scottish titles have increased by 50%, and promotional spend by more than 100%. Some cuts! Some punishment! Despite this substantial investment, sales of the Scotsman continued their long-term decline. So last spring we decided on a radical makeover of the paper and a price-cutting strategy to introduce the new Scotsman to new readers. The result is a 33% rise in sales and a 15% increase in advertising revenues. No newspaper in the land can match this double whammy.

Murphy remains in fantasyland when he turns his bile on Sunday Business. The charge is that I cavalierly doubled the price of Sunday Business to £1, yet refused to give the price rise any promotional back up, so sales collapsed. Wrong on all counts. As a small-circulation, upmarket niche product, the paper was underpriced at 50p; as I said at the time of the price rise in February 2000, if we could not make it work at £1 then we did not have a business. A £500,000 TV and direct mail campaign supported the price rise. This was money well spent.

Audited sales of Sunday Business in the six months after we went to £1 averaged 67,000 - an increase of 5,500 on the six months before the price rise (bulks were the same in both periods). To double the price of a newspaper and increase sales by nearly 10% is a remarkable achievement, unprecedented in British publishing. These figures are a matter of public record.

The gentle slide in sales happened long after the price rise. By early last autumn, it was clear that sales were not returning by enough from the usual summer downturn, a trend which was not reversed by another £250,000 promotional spend in October.

I had already concluded during the summer that the paper needed to be refreshed and taken to the next stage of its development with a relaunch. But the editor, Jeff Randall, informed me that he was leaving to join the BBC early in the new year. I had no choice but to postpone the relaunch until then, with a new editor and a reinvigorated paper.

We are in the process of revamping section one with improved comment and analysis, inventing a new investment section to replace the existing section two, and developing a colour magazine. The new package will be unveiled on March 11, supported by a major TV, radio and direct mail campaign.

We are confident that the relaunch of Sunday Business will be as successful as the relaunch of the Scotsman. But Murphy claims that our owners are throwing many millions into a publishing black hole, with no prospect of return. We are grateful for his concern but it is uninformed. The Scotsman Group has made healthy profits every year since the Barclay family bought it in 1996. We could have made even more if we had screwed down budgets for short-term gain, as the previous owners had done. But we are fortunate in having owners who believe in investing in their titles for the long term.

It is a strategy that has already built asset value: the Scotsman Group and Sunday Business are already worth far more than the sums invested in them. As we build on our Scottish successes, and invest further in Sunday Business, the value of our papers will rise further. As a private company, long-term asset value matters more than short-term profit.

Why the Guardian would devote a page-one puff, a cover story and a two-page spread to a small, niche publisher is a mystery. Why it would choose the most unflattering picture of me it could find to illustrate the two-page diatribe - it was blown up to make it look as if my eyes had been nibbled out by Hannibal Lecter - is a further mystery.

But the biggest mystery of all is why the Guardian would publish a blatant attempt to drive a wedge between my proprietors and me. Whatever the motive, it has failed. The Guardian's desire to come between us and do us down, simply makes us even more determined to succeed.

fields.headline: Let's get together
fields.standfirst: What does a merger between two charities do for their public profile?  Nicola Hill  reports on the outcome for a clutch of the recently-joined
fields.trailText: What does a merger between two charities do for their public profile? Nicola Hill reports on the outcome for a clutch of the recently-joined.
fields.body:
Charity mergers are on the increase. A good move for cutting costs but what about raising funds? Does two plus two always equal four?

Two big brands, the Cancer Research Campaign and Imperial Cancer Research Fund, are currently discussing a merger. At a local level, both have voluntary fundraising committees and high-street shops. At a national level, the two have large fundraising departments which have fought to distinguish themselves in order to attract loyal support.

The drive to merge is coming from scientists who believe that pooling funds will increase their chances of curing cancer. Director of the Cancer Research Campaign, Gordon McVie, says: "There is a fundraising folklore that two charities raise more than a merged one but this has never been rigorously tested. We have written to all our shops, supporters and volunteers and discussed the issue with a representative group who thought that there is no way forward without collaboration.

"There is a good match with our fundraising strengths and weaknesses and finally people will stop asking why there are two cancer charities competing against each other."

Last September two HIV charities, Terrence Higgins Trust and London Lighthouse, merged. The director of marketing, Joanna Van Driel, is expecting donations to drop this year and income targets have been cut. "People will think 'you have merged so you don't need so much money'. It is understood throughout the organisation that two fundraising charities merging will not increase our non-statutory income," she says.

"On top of the usual challenges of fundraising, we are working with an unpopular cause and fighting the misconceptions that the epidemic is over and that we are well funded because of the glitz associated with individuals who support the cause."

However, Van Driel does see some benefits as the two charities had previously used different methods of fundraising. The new charity has tried to retain supporters by holding on to both names - it is now called Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse.

Two other big cancer charities, Macmillan Cancer Relief and Marie Curie Cancer Care, considered a merger last year but decided against it. Macmillan's chief executive, Sir Nicholas Young, who has just announced his resignation, said: "If two and two can't be shown to equal at least four, then there is a danger that the merging charities may help fewer people than they did apart."

Parentline Plus is the result of a merger between the National Step-families Association and Parentline. Chief executive, Dorit Brown, says the experience has been very positive from a fundraising perspective. She found that key funders saw the benefits of a merger: "As a result, many provided a much greater level of investment than they had for each of the previous charities."

The Royal Philanthropic Society and Rainer Foundation merged five years ago to form RPS Rainer. Director of fundraising and marketing, Ruth Whitbread, says: "There is always a fear with mergers that one or other group of supporters will disappear but from our experience they don't as long as the reason for a merger is a sound one and is explained to them."

Unlike corporates that tend to change their branding and name to form a new company, charities tend to cling on to some of their identity, even if it makes the name longwinded. Van Driel of Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse says the charity simply didn't have any money to rebrand. Terrence Higgins Trust had already merged with a number of regional charities in the previous year - so it could have proved costly. In fact some of the services offered by the charities have retained their original name but now have pooled resources. Whitbread says that RPS Rainer deliberately chose not to rebrand having consulted across both organisations.

So communication seems to be the key. At a time when the public and the media are questioning the number of charities and criticising fundraising costs, mergers should be a popular choice. Brand loyalty will be retained if the reason for the merger is robust and supporters are fed the right message.
