webTitle: British fund to educate every Commonwealth child

fields.headline: British fund to educate every Commonwealth child
fields.trailText: A multimillion-pound fund to ensure that every child in the Commonwealth receives a primary education will be announced by the government today to mark the Queen's jubilee next year.
fields.body:
A multimillion-pound fund to ensure that every child in the Commonwealth receives a primary education will be announced by the government today to mark the Queen's jubilee next year.

Gordon Brown will use a speech to the global children's conference in London to announce the launch of the fund, which is designed to help 75m of the 120m worldwide who are not currently in school.

The chancellor's pledge is an attempt by the government to show that the next stage in the debt relief campaign for the world's poorest nations should be a commitment by the rich countries of the north to meeting the United Nations targets for poverty reduction.

These include universal primary eduction, halving the number of people in absolute poverty and reducing infant mortality for children under five by two thirds. Mr Brown's announcement on education is part of a twin-tracked government approach with the new global fund to supply cheap drugs to developing countries, which was revealed in the Guardian last week.

The Queen has always fostered close ties with the Commonwealth, and the government believes that linking the new fund to the celebrations to mark her 50 years on the throne will raise the political profile of education and enhance the prospects of securing big financial donations from the private sector.

Mr Brown will say today: "The British government will create, in Her Majesty's jubilee year, a fund to speed the introduction of universal primary education in the Commonwealth. It is a fund to help the 75m children in Commonwealth countries who lack a basic education, by building fair and effective education systems and creating new opportunities for girls and disadvantaged groups. We will call on business to support this effort."

Today's conference will be attended by James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, Horst Kohler, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, and Carol Bellamy, head of the UN's children's agency, Unicef. The government hopes it will give fresh impetus to the debt campaign by focusing on specific actions required by countries and organisations to meet the 2015 development goals.

Aid organisations have argued for many years that increasing the numbers of girls in school is a key to development. However, many developing countries have seen school rolls falling, in part because budget cuts have forced their governments to impose fees for education that many families have been unable to pay.

Mr Brown will also intensify his campaign for the big drug companies to support the scheme under which developed nations and the international organisations would guarantee to buy drugs produced cheaply for poor countries.

fields.headline: Street's storylines 'must improve'
fields.standfirst:
ITV wants producers of long-running soap to respond to rejuvenated EastEnders
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV's network executives, worried about an onslaught from the BBC's regenerated EastEnders, have told producers that storylines must improve, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Coronation Street is in danger of fading as fast as the froth on a pint at the Rovers. ITV's network executives, worried about an onslaught from the BBC's regenerated EastEnders, have told producers that storylines must improve.

As part of a wide-ranging review of all ITV's long-running series, drama bosses held talks about the Street last week. While executives will present a united front in public, it is understood that concerns were expressed in private: ITV bosses found "room for improvement" in a recent long-term storyline plan.

The whisperings surrounding Coronation Street are damaging for Granada: the series is a cash cow, generating millions in merchandising and overseas sales. Yet as the broadcaster that styles itself the "home of the soaps" faces up to problems at Britain's oldest series, it is experiencing teething troubles at its newest. The budget for Trafalgar Road, inherited when the broadcaster took over Lord Hollick's TV interests last year, has been slashed.

These chinks in ITV's soap armour come at a time of increased competition between the broadcasters. Coronation Street is no longer invincible: BBC1's EastEnders, which gains a fourth weekly episode later this year, has achieved critical acclaim with a series of strong storylines and the successful introduction of a new family. The Street's critics feel it has not responded enough to the challenge posed by its own fourth episode.

While it still tops the ratings with a regular 16m viewers, the ITV network wants Granada to ensure these figures are maintained.

Grant Mansfield, Granada's director of programmes, insisted that last week's meeting was routine, and said Coronation Street was in a strong position. "The challenge is to continue on the arc of success. We want to go into middle age with the same determination as we approached it."

But disgruntled former writers say that despite the success of big "events" such as the recent 40th anniversary live episode, the programme has lost its way in recent months.

A number of senior writers quit shortly after the executive producer, Jane Macnaught, was appointed two years ago. All, including some who were regarded as the "voice of the Street", are understood to have been unhappy at the way Ms Macnaught, whose background was in entertainment programmes, wanted to develop the series.

Producers of Trafalgar Road are being forced to launch the series on a lower than expected budget. Granada inherited the series when it took over Lord Hollick's United Productions, which had successfully bid for one of ITV's two free daytime soap slots. Carlton won the other, with a revived version of Crossroads - due to start on March 5.

United promised a substantial "start-up" cash injection, believed to be about £4m, to boost the £10m from the network. But the landscape changed when Lord Hollick sold his television business to Granada - which already owns Yorkshire TV, the producers of Emmerdale. With two soaps already on its books, Granada did not need Trafalgar Road as much as United, and the programme's budget was cut to £2m.

But the landscape changed when Lord Hollick sold his television business to Granada - which already owns Yorkshire TV, the producers of Emmerdale. With two soaps already on its books, Granada did not need Trafalgar Road as much as United, and the programme's budget was cut to £2m.

webTitle: Soap quest to repeat Popstars formula

fields.headline: Soap quest to repeat Popstars formula
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV, astonished at the runaway success of its docusoap-cum-talent search Popstars, is transferring the idea from pop to soap. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
When TV producers spot a hit, they are rarely slow to find ways of copying it. ITV, astonished at the runaway success of its docusoap-cum-talent search Popstars, is transferring the idea from pop to soap.

Soapstars, to be launched later this year, will seek to find a new family for one of ITV's serial dramas, probably Emmerdale.

As in the original, the soap version will feature a panel of judges. Its composition has yet to be decided.

Auditions for the new series will be held later this year. Popstars hopefuls had to be under 25, but as ITV is looking for an entire family for Emmerdale, aspiring actors of all ages will be allowed to take part. Claudia Rosencrantz, ITV's controller of entertainment, who commissioned the series from LWT, said that participants would not have to have any drama background.

Soapstars will track the hopefuls from the mass auditions to a more intensive stage in which they will be put through roleplay scenarios and other drama exercises to assess their suitability for the parts. The series will follow the writing process by which the chosen few are integrated into the soap, and their eventual on-screen debut. The composition of the family has yet to be decided, but it will involve about four or five characters.

Emmerdale has been chosen because it is the most flexible of ITV's soaps. Since last autumn it has been on air five days a week, and therefore requires more characters to drive the storylines along.

An ITV spokeswoman said: "Since the success of Popstars we have been looking at taking the format forward. Soapstars is a terrific way to do that, and involve a much broader range of participants."

webTitle: Mail and Express back off from smear campaigns

fields.headline: Mail and Express back off from smear campaigns
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The arch-rival owners of the Daily Mail and the Daily Express have called a truce in their dogfight just as it was getting dirty, it emerged yesterday. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The arch-rival owners of the Daily Mail and the Daily Express have called a truce in their dogfight just as it was getting dirty, it emerged yesterday.

After Richard Desmond's Express spent most of last week raking over the personal lives of the Rothermere family, the Mail has run up the white flag. It is understood that the wife of the Mail owner, Lord Rothermere, could not stomach the increasingly personal attacks in the rival paper.

The Mail has agreed not to brand Mr Desmond a pornographer (he has interests in the Fantasy Channel and a string of pornographic magazines and websites) as long as the Express calls a halt to the muck-raking. The Express camp is jubilant: the Mail blinked first.

The climbdown came after an acrimonious campaign of commercial and editorial mud-slinging.

The Mail had launched a particularly robust promotion to attract Express readers after Mr Desmond bought the title last November. It gave away copies of the Mail to Express readers, with a mock wraparound front cover detailing the sleazier side of Mr Desmond's business interests and featuring a picture of a 78-year-old woman from one of his porn websites.

It also offered retailers £5 for each Express reader who switched to the Mail - an expensive and ruthless operation.

The Daily Express, under a new editor, Chris Williams, responded with a series of articles last week about the Rothermere dynasty, which has controlled the Mail since it began in 1896.

In a double-page spread, written anonymously, it detailed the first Lord Rothermere's support of fascism in the 1930s, and attacked the third Lord Rothermere's infidelity.

The Express then highlighted the story of the current Lord Rothermere's illegitimate child, a revelation that first appeared in Punch magazine two years ago but received little further coverage at the time. This story, according to reports yesterday, particularly upset Lord Rothermere's wife, Claudia.

A meeting was arranged at the Howard hotel in London between Murdoch MacLennan, the managing director of Associated Newspapers, parent company of the Mail, and Mr Desmond.

A gentlemen's agreement was reached which means that the newspapers will not engage in any more personal attacks on proprietors.

The bitter circulation war will continue, though. The Express is heavily promoting its links with Mr Desmond's OK! magazine, while Hello!, OK!'s rival, has joined up with the Mail.

And it seems likely that the Express will continue its attacks on the Mail's editorial content - under a piece headlined Hate Mail last week, it ran a series of anti-Mail quotes from prominent personalities.

It is a tough battle: the Mail's circulation rose to 2.48m a day in January, while the Express, once the dominant player in the middle market, is trailing at below 1m.

webTitle: 'Congested' London drops in world league table

fields.headline: 'Congested' London drops in world league table
fields.trailText: London has become a worse place to live in the past 12 months because of transport congestion, overcrowding, rising crime, high prices and stress.
fields.body:
London has become a worse place to live in the past 12 months because of transport congestion, overcrowding, rising crime, high prices and stress.

A survey published today shows London ranks 40th in the world when assessed for quality of life, compared with 34th last year.

The study ranks 215 cities based on 10 criteria ranging across political, economic and social environment, health care, education, recreation and transport. Vancouver came top of the list followed by Zurich, Vienna, Copenhagen and Sydney. Bottom of the list are Brazzaville and Pointe Noire in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which has been devastated by civil war.

Ten EU capital cities including Paris, Berlin, Brussels, Dublin and Amsterdam rank higher than London, as do Los Angeles and San Francisco. New York, Washington DC and Barcelona all fall below London in the list, as do the other UK cities surveyed; Birmingham and Glasgow are in joint 59th place. Switzerland and Germany each have three cities near the top of the list.

Quality of life is generally higher in smaller cities with efficient transport systems, said Yvonne Traber, senior researcher at William M Mercer which conducted the survey.

She said: "The larger conurbations have generally struggled to maintain the same degree of efficiency despite their extensive metro, rail and bus networks. Peak time congestion in particular has tended to lower their scores.

"Among the top-ranking cities differences in quality of life are barely discernable. All score highly on the basic comforts of life, with crime levels and pollution having a moderate effect on the scores."

There is better news for Londoners when it comes to recreation. The capital has a wider choice of restaurants, theatre, cinema and leisure options than any other city in Europe. London lies ninth in the world on this measure. New York, Los Angeles and Sydney are the top three.

When measured on transport alone, however, London plummets to 55th, behind Hong Kong as well as nine other EU cities.

Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, said: "The findings of the survey are disappointing but perhaps not surprising. My first budget is primarily a policing budget and will bring an additional 1,050 police officers on to the street.

"I have also produced a far-reaching transport strategy which will bring major improvements to an infrastructure that has been scandalously neglected over the last decade or so."

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No 1826 The Brits
fields.trailText: No 1826 The Brits
fields.body:
Age: Nobody can remember. Nearly as old as Ready Steady Go! probably.

Appearance: Televised fancy-dress party for nine-year-olds who like showing off.

Bitch! You know very well the Brits has a serious purpose: You mean to advertise the Mick Fleetwood/ Samantha Fox school of professional stage presentation?

That's so unfair: Ah, so you allude to the Brits' mission to sell British pop music to overseas markets who have shown commendable indifference towards Billie Piper and Steps?

They have old people on, too: Not as often as they used to. Gone are the halcyon days when Sting and Annie Lennox won everything and we could blowtorch our effigies of Phil Collins.

But they've still got David Gray, Radiohead and U2 lined up for this year. Not to mention a nomination for Santana: Come to think of it, yes.

Oh, come on, at least it's an opportunity to behave badly on television: Well, it would be if all the interesting bits weren't censored. Like when Jarvis Cocker launched his stage invasion during Michael "Messiah" Jackson's routine.

I can tell you're a jaundiced individual who has long since lost touch with the thrills of pop music: Listen son, I was there when "the kids" rioted at Rock Around The Clock and PJ Proby split his trousers on stage. You'll be telling me next that Ronan Keating is the new Gene Pitney.

Oooh, will Ronan be at the Brits?: Keating has an unquenchable lust for publicity, so he's probably been camping out at Earls Court for the last five days doling out soundbites to any TV news crew that walks past.

How dare you! My mum says Ronan is the greatest pop star since Rick Astley: My point exactly.

At least the new ultra-slick Brits organisation won't allow cynics like you to spoil the party: I fear you're right. No more dead sheep dumped outside by the KLF, bearing a note reading: "I died for you. Bon appetit!" It's tragic, frankly.

fields.headline: The outsiders
fields.standfirst:
A former Frinton undertaker and his wild-eyed lieutenant lead Britain's fourth biggest party in the European parliament. They're men with a mission - to get us out of the EU. So how are Jeffrey Titford and Nigel Farage coping with life in the belly of the beast? Matthew Engel reports from Strasbourg

Special report: the European parliament
fields.trailText: A former Frinton undertaker and his wild-eyed lieutenant lead Britain's fourth biggest party in the European parliament. They're men with a mission - to get us out of the EU. So how are Jeffrey Titford and Nigel Farage coping with life in the belly of the beast?  Matthew Engel reports from Strasbourg
fields.body:
It is 10.19pm when the party leader rises to make his speech to parliament. When he sits down, the clock has moved on to 10.20pm. There is total silence. It is broken only by the sound of an orgasmic stage-whispered scream of approval from the balcony: "Yessssssssss!" It is coming from the leader's speechwriter: "He did it! He did it! To the second! One minute 30 seconds precisely. Perfect!" By now the next speaker is already on his feet. He is greeted with silence too. Silence is the characteristic response to speeches here, especially when it is well past dinner time in the best city for eating out in Europe.

This is the European parliament in Strasbourg, where the debate - on the harmonisation of laws relating to food supplements - is being attended by precisely 17 of the 626 parliamentarians, plus 18 members of staff, eight people in the public galleries and 33 interpreters (three for each of the European Union's 11 official languages). The vast and stunning egg-shaped chamber is lit for the occasion by enough wattage to illuminate a fair-sized third world capital.

The strict time limit is one of the mercies. Hence the speechwriter's delight: a fraction longer than the allotted 90 seconds and the microphone would have been switched off. But the silence that greeted this particular leader's speech was more than normally profound.

The speaker was Jeffrey Titford of the UK Independence party, which - according to its 7% win of the vote in the 1999 European elections - is the fourth-largest party in Britain. (The big four party leaders are thus Tony Blair, William Hague, Charles Kennedy and Titford.) It is also the only one of the dozens of parties represented in this place totally committed to withdrawal from the EU. Titford was against harmonisation, surprisingly enough, arguing that British law was perfectly adequate. He's always against. He is the clergyman addressing the sinners in the whorehouse. Or Lucifer in the cathedral, depending on your point of view.

Somewhere between a half and three-fifths of Britain's electorate agree with Titford that Britain should seek an amicable divorce from the EU, and in 1999 Ukip (pronounced you-kip) won three MEPs. However, the former party leader, Michael Holmes, has not been sighted in almost a year, partly through ill-health, partly through disaffection. He is rumoured to be on the brink of joining the Greens, leaving just Titford and his sidekick, Nigel Farage.

Holmes's disappearance is merely one strand in a skein of vituperation and hatred that characterises Ukip. Earlier this month, the party's founder, Dr Alan Sked, claimed in the Spectator that the party was now enmeshed with the extreme right. The front page advertised "Ukip and the fascists".

Sked's evidence seemed slender. Much rested on a meeting between Farage and a party member who also belonged to the openly racist British National party. Farage says this was someone recruited by Sked, and that the meeting was to tell the man he was unwanted. If there was serious evidence linking the party with racists, at least 600 people in Strasbourg would be delighted to use it. But even Chris Huhne, the Liberal Democrat MEP who is one of their sternest critics, admits: "They're not fascists, they're not corrupt and they're not morons. Some of their members are headbangers, though."

They certainly are. The party's Scottish organiser has just been kicked off the executive for a year after questioning, in letters to newspapers, the extent of the Holocaust. Farage claims Ukip is the victim of "entryism". For what it's worth, the two men sit dead-centre of the parliament's semi-circle, close to the Lib Dems but at the back: traditional refuge of the most truculent members of any class. They are in a loose alliance known as EDD (Europe of Democracy and Diversities): a ragbag of 16 anti-federalists, comprising six French rustics, four Danes, three Dutch Calvinist ministers and the two Britons, but not rightwingers such as Jean-Marie Le Pen.

Even in the EDD, the Britons are out on a limb. Farage and Titford want Britain out, plain and simple. Thus John Bowis, the former Tory minister who is now an MEP, can say: "They are a tiny, tiny extreme element of a fringe part of the parliament. I just think they're irrelevant." But they may be very relevant in many rural constituencies come the general election. And they do at least have a coherent position - unlike the Tories, whose representatives here are horribly split.

Ukip, however, is an incoherent party, and its internal schisms are certainly worthy of the far right. It was founded in 1993 by Sked, a lecturer at the London School of Economics, and bumbled on quietly until the 1997 election, when it was totally swamped in the anti-Europe market by Jimmy Goldsmith's big-money, high-profile Referendum party. Then Goldsmith died, leaving a vacuum which Ukip filled with vicious infighting. But at the 1999 European elections, it was suddenly well-placed to pick up protest votes. And, since Britain was now using a regional proportional representation system, it was even better placed to turn them into seats. "It was a delicious double irony," says Farage, elected from the south-east region. "For a parliament I want no part of, under a system I despise, I found myself blinking into the cameras at one in the morning saying how proud I was."

With just a few more votes, Ukip might have won five seats. But when Holmes, the abrasive millionaire who had succeeded Sked, was dumped and then had a stroke, only this odd couple were left.

Titford is usually referred to as the Frinton undertaker (Frinton-on-Sea is generally presumed to be a good place for the trade). Actually, he had a string of funeral businesses on the east coast until he sold up in 1989 and retired at 55 to concentrate on sea fishing and golf. He had been in politics before, as a Tory, reaching the dizzy heights of chairman of the public health committee (and vice-chairman of recreation and gardens) on the old Clacton urban district council.

Titford was a bit bored by retirement, but he has now ridden his little anti-Euro hobby-horse out of control. In 45 years of marriage, his job never took him much further than Harwich. Now he is away perpetually, spreading Frinton's world-view; his wife is "supportive but a bit exasperated". Except when talking about Sked ("he's demented"), Titford is an emollient man, a sort of Willie Whitelaw figure, and an ideal leader for such a fractious party - "8,000 members and 9,000 egos", as one supporter put it.

Titford says little, which means he is outshone by Farage, a 36-year-old metals broker with wild eyes and the air of a successful estate agent. Both men are rather obviously British: non-linguists in a building of suave polyglots. Together, they can come over like Caldicott and Charters, the old buffers who kept talking about the Test score while travelling Europe in Strangers on a Train. But they are not obvious xenophobes (Farage's wife is German) and have a nice - very British - line in self-deprecating humour. Indeed, the Ukip's European parliament contingent laugh a lot, a rarity in Strasbourg.

They have a fair bit to laugh about. It is not difficult for them to embarrass the establishment, and their most successful ongoing stunt has been to pool the excess on their travel expenses and use it to fund the defence of "the metric martyr", the Sunderland greengrocer prosecuted last month for selling fruit in pounds and ounces. The parliament has demanded the MEPs return £11,500.

Last Wednesday, Titford and Farage were summoned to appear before Richard Balfe, a long-serving Labour MEP who is on the College of Quaestors, a souped-up privileges committee. The meeting was inconclusive. Balfe refused even to confirm it had taken place.

"Can you tell me what the issue is?" I asked Balfe.

"Of course not. It's the College of Quaestors, not a public meeting," said Balfe indignantly.

"Isn't it public?"

"It never has been. Whoever I talked to, [it] is between me and them."

In a Europe full of Balfes, it is not difficult to portray the whole project as ludicrous.

It is easy to subvert the parliamentary process as well. At the EDD group meeting last Tuesday, it was decided on the spur-of-the-moment to turn up en masse at that night's plenary session to try to get the food supplement measure sent back, and thus delayed for ages. It was not a well-planned plot, but the European parliament's sittings are so thinly attended it did not need to be. Their procedural move failed by just one vote: 16-15, with 595 members missing, presumed at dinner.

This would have been a routine oppositional ploy at Westminster, but other (non-British) MEPs were incensed. "Immoral!" they kept saying. The British view is more phlegmatic. It is accepted that the debating chamber is a waste of time. Except for votes (members have to vote to get paid), the room is empty even when it is not dinner-time. "The place where you change minds is in committee," says Huhne. "You can actually alter legislation quite effectively there, and that's where Ukip doesn't play a part. They're a waste of space."

"Yes, it's true," says Richard North, the Ukip staffer who was so proud of his leader's timekeeping. "If you're very, very good, and work very, very hard, you can get to change a couple of words. Wow!"

"I'm supposed to be on the fisheries committee," says Farage. "The cod recovery scheme was introduced with no reference to the committee whatever, because total competence rests with the commission. There's no point in going. We send a staff member to observe instead. We haven't come here to do a Billy Graham bit and convert everybody. We haven't come to change Europe. We've come to find out how it works and what it costs, and take that message back to the British people."

They take the message round tirelessly, despite Mrs Titford's reservations. And there is no doubt it keeps being well received. What that means in electoral terms remains to be seen in May, and in the referendum on the euro that will follow. But clearly few people in Britain doubt that much of what goes on in European institutions is damnable. The question, which we all have to ask ourselves, is whether it is an acceptable price to pay for the greatness of the project.

The two Ukip men left doubt behind long ago. In the members' cafe I asked how they would vote if the European commission proposed a motion in favour of motherhood and apple pie.

"I'd abstain," said Farage, "on the grounds that it's none of Europe's business."

"I'd vote against," said Titford. "There'd probably be a hidden agenda."
fields.bodyText: It is 10.19pm when the party leader rises to make his speech to parliament. When he sits down, the clock has moved on to 10.20pm. There is total silence. It is broken only by the sound of an orgasmic stage-whispered scream of approval from the balcony: "Yessssssssss!" It is coming from the leader's speechwriter: "He did it! He did it! To the second! One minute 30 seconds precisely. Perfect!" By now the next speaker is already on his feet. He is greeted with silence too. Silence is the characteristic response to speeches here, especially when it is well past dinner time in the best city for eating out in Europe. This is the European parliament in Strasbourg, where the debate - on the harmonisation of laws relating to food supplements - is being attended by precisely 17 of the 626 parliamentarians, plus 18 members of staff, eight people in the public galleries and 33 interpreters (three for each of the European Union's 11 official languages). The vast and stunning egg-shaped chamber is lit for the occasion by enough wattage to illuminate a fair-sized third world capital. The strict time limit is one of the mercies. Hence the speechwriter's delight: a fraction longer than the allotted 90 seconds and the microphone would have been switched off. But the silence that greeted this particular leader's speech was more than normally profound. The speaker was Jeffrey Titford of the UK Independence party, which - according to its 7% win of the vote in the 1999 European elections - is the fourth-largest party in Britain. (The big four party leaders are thus Tony Blair, William Hague, Charles Kennedy and Titford.) It is also the only one of the dozens of parties represented in this place totally committed to withdrawal from the EU. Titford was against harmonisation, surprisingly enough, arguing that British law was perfectly adequate. He's always against. He is the clergyman addressing the sinners in the whorehouse. Or Lucifer in the cathedral, depending on your point of view. Somewhere between a half and three-fifths of Britain's electorate agree with Titford that Britain should seek an amicable divorce from the EU, and in 1999 Ukip (pronounced you-kip) won three MEPs. However, the former party leader, Michael Holmes, has not been sighted in almost a year, partly through ill-health, partly through disaffection. He is rumoured to be on the brink of joining the Greens, leaving just Titford and his sidekick, Nigel Farage. Holmes's disappearance is merely one strand in a skein of vituperation and hatred that characterises Ukip. Earlier this month, the party's founder, Dr Alan Sked, claimed in the Spectator that the party was now enmeshed with the extreme right. The front page advertised "Ukip and the fascists". Sked's evidence seemed slender. Much rested on a meeting between Farage and a party member who also belonged to the openly racist British National party. Farage says this was someone recruited by Sked, and that the meeting was to tell the man he was unwanted. If there was serious evidence linking the party with racists, at least 600 people in Strasbourg would be delighted to use it. But even Chris Huhne, the Liberal Democrat MEP who is one of their sternest critics, admits: "They're not fascists, they're not corrupt and they're not morons. Some of their members are headbangers, though." They certainly are. The party's Scottish organiser has just been kicked off the executive for a year after questioning, in letters to newspapers, the extent of the Holocaust. Farage claims Ukip is the victim of "entryism". For what it's worth, the two men sit dead-centre of the parliament's semi-circle, close to the Lib Dems but at the back: traditional refuge of the most truculent members of any class. They are in a loose alliance known as EDD (Europe of Democracy and Diversities): a ragbag of 16 anti-federalists, comprising six French rustics, four Danes, three Dutch Calvinist ministers and the two Britons, but not rightwingers such as Jean-Marie Le Pen. Even in the EDD, the Britons are out on a limb. Farage and Titford want Britain out, plain and simple. Thus John Bowis, the former Tory minister who is now an MEP, can say: "They are a tiny, tiny extreme element of a fringe part of the parliament. I just think they're irrelevant." But they may be very relevant in many rural constituencies come the general election. And they do at least have a coherent position - unlike the Tories, whose representatives here are horribly split. Ukip, however, is an incoherent party, and its internal schisms are certainly worthy of the far right. It was founded in 1993 by Sked, a lecturer at the London School of Economics, and bumbled on quietly until the 1997 election, when it was totally swamped in the anti-Europe market by Jimmy Goldsmith's big-money, high-profile Referendum party. Then Goldsmith died, leaving a vacuum which Ukip filled with vicious infighting. But at the 1999 European elections, it was suddenly well-placed to pick up protest votes. And, since Britain was now using a regional proportional representation system, it was even better placed to turn them into seats. "It was a delicious double irony," says Farage, elected from the south-east region. "For a parliament I want no part of, under a system I despise, I found myself blinking into the cameras at one in the morning saying how proud I was." With just a few more votes, Ukip might have won five seats. But when Holmes, the abrasive millionaire who had succeeded Sked, was dumped and then had a stroke, only this odd couple were left. Titford is usually referred to as the Frinton undertaker (Frinton-on-Sea is generally presumed to be a good place for the trade). Actually, he had a string of funeral businesses on the east coast until he sold up in 1989 and retired at 55 to concentrate on sea fishing and golf. He had been in politics before, as a Tory, reaching the dizzy heights of chairman of the public health committee (and vice-chairman of recreation and gardens) on the old Clacton urban district council. Titford was a bit bored by retirement, but he has now ridden his little anti-Euro hobby-horse out of control. In 45 years of marriage, his job never took him much further than Harwich. Now he is away perpetually, spreading Frinton's world-view; his wife is "supportive but a bit exasperated". Except when talking about Sked ("he's demented"), Titford is an emollient man, a sort of Willie Whitelaw figure, and an ideal leader for such a fractious party - "8,000 members and 9,000 egos", as one supporter put it. Titford says little, which means he is outshone by Farage, a 36-year-old metals broker with wild eyes and the air of a successful estate agent. Both men are rather obviously British: non-linguists in a building of suave polyglots. Together, they can come over like Caldicott and Charters, the old buffers who kept talking about the Test score while travelling Europe in Strangers on a Train. But they are not obvious xenophobes (Farage's wife is German) and have a nice - very British - line in self-deprecating humour. Indeed, the Ukip's European parliament contingent laugh a lot, a rarity in Strasbourg. They have a fair bit to laugh about. It is not difficult for them to embarrass the establishment, and their most successful ongoing stunt has been to pool the excess on their travel expenses and use it to fund the defence of "the metric martyr", the Sunderland greengrocer prosecuted last month for selling fruit in pounds and ounces. The parliament has demanded the MEPs return £11,500. Last Wednesday, Titford and Farage were summoned to appear before Richard Balfe, a long-serving Labour MEP who is on the College of Quaestors, a souped-up privileges committee. The meeting was inconclusive. Balfe refused even to confirm it had taken place. "Can you tell me what the issue is?" I asked Balfe. "Of course not. It's the College of Quaestors, not a public meeting," said Balfe indignantly. "Isn't it public?" "It never has been. Whoever I talked to, [it] is between me and them." In a Europe full of Balfes, it is not difficult to portray the whole project as ludicrous. It is easy to subvert the parliamentary process as well. At the EDD group meeting last Tuesday, it was decided on the spur-of-the-moment to turn up en masse at that night's plenary session to try to get the food supplement measure sent back, and thus delayed for ages. It was not a well-planned plot, but the European parliament's sittings are so thinly attended it did not need to be. Their procedural move failed by just one vote: 16-15, with 595 members missing, presumed at dinner. This would have been a routine oppositional ploy at Westminster, but other (non-British) MEPs were incensed. "Immoral!" they kept saying. The British view is more phlegmatic. It is accepted that the debating chamber is a waste of time. Except for votes (members have to vote to get paid), the room is empty even when it is not dinner-time. "The place where you change minds is in committee," says Huhne. "You can actually alter legislation quite effectively there, and that's where Ukip doesn't play a part. They're a waste of space." "Yes, it's true," says Richard North, the Ukip staffer who was so proud of his leader's timekeeping. "If you're very, very good, and work very, very hard, you can get to change a couple of words. Wow!" "I'm supposed to be on the fisheries committee," says Farage. "The cod recovery scheme was introduced with no reference to the committee whatever, because total competence rests with the commission. There's no point in going. We send a staff member to observe instead. We haven't come here to do a Billy Graham bit and convert everybody. We haven't come to change Europe. We've come to find out how it works and what it costs, and take that message back to the British people." They take the message round tirelessly, despite Mrs Titford's reservations. And there is no doubt it keeps being well received. What that means in electoral terms remains to be seen in May, and in the referendum on the euro that will follow. But clearly few people in Britain doubt that much of what goes on in European institutions is damnable. The question, which we all have to ask ourselves, is whether it is an acceptable price to pay for the greatness of the project. The two Ukip men left doubt behind long ago. In the members' cafe I asked how they would vote if the European commission proposed a motion in favour of motherhood and apple pie. "I'd abstain," said Farage, "on the grounds that it's none of Europe's business." "I'd vote against," said Titford. "There'd probably be a hidden agenda."

fields.headline: The baby vote
fields.standfirst:
Child-friendly policies are central to an election victory, so Labour needs to put its money where its mouth is

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Child-friendly policies are central to an election victory, so Labour needs to put its money where its mouth is, writes Madeleine Bunting.
fields.body:
Think elections, think babies. There will be lots of them. Any nursery or playschool, be warned, the politicians will soon be queuing up for their photo opportunities with your cuddly charges. Politicians, who have little enough time to spend with their own offspring, will be dangling babes on their knees and getting stuck into the water play. Babies are shaping up to be one of the key battlegrounds in the election; we're being subjected to a blizzard of policies from paid paternity leave, baby bonds, free childcare for teenage mums, to the Tory promise of tax cuts for stay-at-home married mums. There's nothing to debate on the economy, so here's where the parties can put clear blue water between them; each dresses up its baby bid with its own ideological flavouring.

For New Labour, babies are totemic - remember Tony Blair's 1999 conference speech about the babies side by side in the labour ward - they are the emotive call for a meritocratic society: everyone should be on the same starting line in the great race of life. The focus on opportunity neatly bypasses the need to deal with structural inequality: babies fit the future-orientated New Labour - they are, quintessentially, new. Meanwhile, the Tories struggling to keep up, dig into their old war chest of nostalgia: back to the Oxo mum with a wedding ring on her finger. It's a ruse which while self-evidently tokenistic (the Tories admitted it would only benefit a small proportion of families) could be easily underestimated - it taps into some powerful concerns about the marginalisation of caring for children.

The sceptical audience for all these baby policies is the woman voter. She is largely credited with delivering New Labour its last election victory and there have been increasing signs - most recently in a Fawcett Society survey - that she is not overly impressed by its performance. So the election strategists talk of feminisation: more stories, more real people and more emotion and they scratch their heads over their depleted female line-up - Tessa and Margaret H are headed for a gruelling campaign and Yvette's developing bump will be exploited for all its worth. David Miliband (head of Number 10's policy unit) charged with the task of drawing up the manifesto, is now up there with Freud and Mel Gibson, trying to figure out what women want.

The answer last Friday in Bolton Institute in Lancashire was blindingly clear. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, was dutifully listening to a group of women giving him a short but very expensive shopping list of exactly what they want. It was the last of a series of meetings as part of the consultation exercise on the green paper, Work and Parents; Byers's recommendations will be in the manifesto. There were only two things which exercised these women: firstly, accessible, affordable, good quality childcare, and secondly, the right to flexible working. Compared to these two, a couple of weeks of paternity leave or a few more weeks extra of paid maternity leave were welcome, but wouldn't make that much difference to women's lives. What mattered was not so much the few months at the beginning of the child's life, but the day-to-day juggling for 15-20 years of raising a family as a working parent.

For all Byers's listening, the things women really want are the least likely to appear in the Labour manifesto. Firstly, the kind of childcare needed will cost the earth. As ever, the devil is in the detail. One woman in Bolton described how nurses couldn't find nurseries which opened earlier than 8.30am when their shifts started at 7.30am; another told of the expense of paying for breakfast clubs, after-school clubs and holiday play schemes on a single mother's salary. Shift working and the 24/7 service culture means that childcare arranged around the old 9-5 day is useless. The childcare has to be local or you'll be late for work. Kids left alone between one parent going on shift and another returning. This is just-in-time family life.

For the state to ease the strain requires an investment equal (perhaps more) to what we spend on primary education. Nursery provision with its need for high adult-child ratios is massively expensive, but if it is to accommodate contemporary working patterns and be local enough to be useful, the scale of the challenge becomes truly enormous, as the Kids' Clubs Network report last month made clear. One day, childcare could be up there along with health, education and transport as one of the government's big spending departments. But that's blue-sky thinking for now. New Labour has enough difficulty in delivering on its traditional commitments without launching a huge, new ambitious role for the state. Besides, to be fair, the pressure isn't strong enough, the care of children outside of school hours is not yet seen as the responsibility of the state but of their parents. Over the next two decades, for good or ill, that will change driven by the need to facilitate women's participation in the labour market. In the meantime, the government inches its way into this territory with such initiatives as the national childcare strategy.

The second item on the shopping list, the right to flexible working, is where things get really contentious. New Labour is caught between its desire to feminise and its cosy relationship with business. Blair, in his speech in Glasgow last weekend, gave an indication of which side they might come down on: he promised two weeks of paid paternity leave but the right to flexible work was out. It seems women ministers have fought hard and lost; the green paper admits that this issue dominated the ministerial group's discussions. Business is implacably opposed to any legislation on this; the women's lobby is equally convinced that it is the only option which reflects that the vast majority of women want to work and to look after their children. On both sides, there are "fundamentalists", says Byers darkly, while insisting that the issue has not yet been decided.

The most striking feature of Friday's meeting was the high sense of expectation from women that the government is going to do something big. The small business representatives became more and more depressed and eventually silent; they feel they've lost the battle already. While campaigners believe, encouraged by Byers, that they are on the verge of an historic breakthrough. The women's groups greeted the green paper last year with delight - it scored eight out of ten in Bolton on Friday - what they failed to notice was that it assiduously avoided committing the government to anything, it simply laid out options. The time of reckoning is fast approaching. If Byers gets it wrong, there'll be a lot of disappointed women and in constituencies like Bolton West, where Ruth Kelly is defending a switch in 1997 from long-term Tory to Labour on a miserable 30% turnout, that could matter. Mary Anne Stephenson, director of the Fawcett Society, argues that a big cause of the slipping female vote is that Labour has raised women's expectations but failed to deliver on them. The biggest single thing Labour could do for women in the manifesto is the legal right to flexible work - that would make all the rhetoric on work/life balance mean something. If Labour fudges that one, and thinks it can seduce women with a few weeks here or there of paternity and extra maternity leave, plus lots of pictures of adorable babies, it had better think again.

webTitle: Face Slap is an instant hit in macho Brazil

fields.headline: Face Slap is an instant hit in macho Brazil
fields.trailText: Top Brazilian performers refuse to sing it. A big-city mayor begged radio stations not to play it and women say it is degrading and dangerous. It's the Face Slap, a lilting, uptempo ditty about a woman who asks her lover to hit her.
fields.byline: Peter Muello in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Top Brazilian performers refuse to sing it. A big-city mayor begged radio stations not to play it and women say it is degrading and dangerous. It's the Face Slap, a lilting, uptempo ditty about a woman who asks her lover to hit her.

"When we make love, what does she ask for? S-S-Slap in the face," sings Alex Xela, 19, vocalist of the samba group Pagod'art. "Come on, I'll let you have it, mama."

In the dance that goes with the song, men pretend to slap their partners, women sway right and left as if reeling from the fake blows.

Face Slap was an instant hit although occasionally the slaps are real - rowdies use the song as an excuse to brawl.

The notoriety and the whiff of censorship has made the song a national phenomenon, and the dance a feature of this week's Rio carnival. The theme of violence - especially towards women - has become more common in Brazilian music. Much of it comes from a hard-edged, rap-influenced music called "funk", which has spread from the shantytowns.

The current funk rage is a song called Tapinha (Little Slap). Dancers slap their hips to the catchy refrain: "Just a little slap doesn't hurt, just a little slap."

Some experts think the trend poses little danger beyond gradually dulling sensibilities or trivialising a problem still prevalent in Latin America's male-oriented society.

"It's all make-believe - pretend sex and pretend pain," said Anna Veronica Mautner, a Sao Paulo sociologist and psychoanalyst. "It's not insidious, because the woman joins the dance as an equal, provoking the man but ducking away from him."

webTitle: Milosevic soon to face his interrogators

fields.headline: Milosevic soon to face his interrogators
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: A close associate of Slobodan Milosevic disclosed yesterday that the fallen Yugoslav president expects to be called in for questioning any day now by prosecutors investigating his financial affairs.
fields.body:
A close associate of Slobodan Milosevic disclosed yesterday that the fallen Yugoslav president expects to be called in for questioning any day now by prosecutors investigating his financial affairs.

Questions hanging over Mr Milosevic range from whether he got his Belgrade house though improper means and whether he looted state money and shipped it out of the country in the 13 years before he was ousted last October, to whether he issued orders to Serb forces in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo though the 1990s that resulted in war crimes or crimes against humanity.

For the new Belgrade government, the least contentious issue to examine first is how Mr Milosevic got his house in the Dedinje district of the capital. Serbia's interior minister, Dusan Mihajlovic, alleged on radio yesterday that Mr Milosevic was given the house toward the end of his time in power after giving a false picture of his assets.

The Milosevic associate, an official of the former leader's Socialist party, said: "He knows that they will question him soon, in the coming days, about the house.

The interior minister said Mr Milosevic may soon face criminal charges.

The arrest of the secret police chief who served under him will help officials of the newly installed government build a case, senior government officials indicated yesterday. "I believe that all connections between the former regime and various criminal activities will now be fully uncovered," Serbia's deputy prime minister, Zarko Korac, told the Associated Press.

The arrest of Rade Markovic was announced late on Saturday. If he cooperates with authorities, he has potent information for any prosecution of his former boss, whose own arrest could be within weeks.

The UN war crimes tribunal has already charged Mr Milosevic in connection with atrocities in the province of Kosovo, but leaders in Belgrade would rather try him at home than risk angering nationalists by extraditing him for trial at the tribunal in the Hague.

Mr Markovic, 53, and two unidentified police officers were detained on Friday in connection with a 1999 incident suspected of being an assassination attempt. A lorry crashed into the motorcade of Vuk Draskovic, then an opposition leader. Four people were killed and he was injured.

Serbia's present justice minister, Vladan Batic, says the truck was owned by the police. And the Belgrade daily paper Vecernje Novosti reported that the driver of the vehicle has admitted that he ran into the convoy on the orders of the secret police.

Mr Markovic is also suspected of being behind the murder of a newspaper publisher, Slavko Curuvija, gunned down after criticising Mr Milosevic during the Nato bombing campaign against Yugoslavia in mid-1999.

And he is alleged to have helped Mr Milosevic's son Marko flee the country with his family last October.

If charged, tried, and convicted of first-degree murder, Mr Markovic would face at least 10 years in prison. The maximum penalty is death.

But many people assume he will bargain for leniency in exchange for becoming a prosecution witness.

"We are entering an intensive war against crime, which will leave no one untouchable," said Mr Batic, alluding to Mr Milosevic and his coterie.

The arrest of Rade Markovic was announced late on Saturday. If he cooperates with authorities, he has potent information for any prosecution of his former boss, whose own arrest could be within weeks. The UN war crimes tribunal has already charged Mr Milosevic in connection with atrocities in the province of Kosovo, but leaders in Belgrade would rather try him at home than risk angering nationalists by extraditing him for trial at the tribunal in the Hague. Mr Markovic, 53, and two unidentified police officers were detained on Friday in connection with a 1999 incident suspected of being an assassination attempt. A lorry crashed into the motorcade of Vuk Draskovic, then an opposition leader. Four people were killed and he was injured. Serbia's present justice minister, Vladan Batic, says the truck was owned by the police. And the Belgrade daily paper Vecernje Novosti reported that the driver of the vehicle has admitted that he ran into the convoy on the orders of the secret police. Mr Markovic is also suspected of being behind the murder of a newspaper publisher, Slavko Curuvija, gunned down after criticising Mr Milosevic during the Nato bombing campaign against Yugoslavia in mid-1999. And he is alleged to have helped Mr Milosevic's son Marko flee the country with his family last October. If charged, tried, and convicted of first-degree murder, Mr Markovic would face at least 10 years in prison. The maximum penalty is death. But many people assume he will bargain for leniency in exchange for becoming a prosecution witness. "We are entering an intensive war against crime, which will leave no one untouchable," said Mr Batic, alluding to Mr Milosevic and his coterie. AP

fields.headline: Labour removes 1.2m young from poverty
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: More than 1.2m children have been lifted out of poverty as a result of government policies introduced since the last election, according to a comprehensive audit of deprivation published today by the Child Poverty Action Group.
fields.body:
More than 1.2m children have been lifted out of poverty as a result of government policies introduced since the last election, according to a comprehensive audit of deprivation published today by the Child Poverty Action Group.

It says Labour ministers' record over their first two years in office was "dire for poor children". They implemented plans inherited from the previous Conservative administration to cut income support for lone parents.

This was "arguably the first real-terms cut in the level of social assistance paid to any group of claimants since social assistance was introduced in 1948".

But reforms to the tax and benefits systems over the past two years will lift 1.2m children out of poverty - defined by the CPAG to include households living at below 50% of average income.

"Possibly another 320,000 will have been lifted out of poverty as a result of their parents obtaining employment. So Labour may have halved child poverty in five years," the CPAG audit says.

Its figures are based on computer modelling techniques to predict the consequences of government policies before they show up in national statistics. The latest official data - based on a household income survey in 1998-99 - showed no reduction in child poverty compared with 1996-97, when 35% of children were living in poverty.

The CPAG said: "If the rate of progress achieved in the last two years is maintained, income poverty ... could be ended in 10, not 20, years' time, as aimed for by the government. However, the task of ending child poverty will get harder, as the least poor are the first to be lifted above the poverty line.

"Whilst policies to tackle income poverty are measurable and more immediate, poverty is also about the quality of children's lives. The jury is still out on the government's success in tackling inequalities and disadvantage in areas such as health, education and neighbourhood renewal."

It warned that effective action to eradicate child poverty was not compatible with tax cuts. More than 600,000 extra children could have been lifted out of income poverty had the £2.4bn spent on cutting the basic rate of income tax from April last year been used to increase benefits for the poorest children.

Martin Barnes, director of CPAG, said: "After a poor start during its first two years in office, substantial progress in reducing child poverty has been made. But progress should be seen against the horrendously high levels of poverty the government inherited."

fields.headline: Fewer arms, more unions
fields.trailText: The news that the Labour party pension fund holds 34,721 shares in British arms company BAe Systems (Arms investors named and shamed, February 22), exposes the conflict of interest at the heart of government's so-called "ethical" foreign policy.
fields.body:
The news that the Labour party pension fund holds 34,721 shares in British arms company BAe Systems (Arms investors named and shamed, February 22), exposes the conflict of interest at the heart of government's so-called "ethical" foreign policy. War on Want recently exposed the government's decision to ignore arms export guidelines by granting a licence to BAe subsidiary, Royal Ordnance, to supply Morocco with gun parts to continue its occupation of Western Sahara.

Serious questions must now be answered about why the Labour party is happy for its money to be invested in arms companies. After all, this is a party that has made big play of its ethical credentials.
Steve Tibbett
War on Want
stibbett@waronwant.org

 Nike can afford to pay more than £300m pounds to produce Manchester United's kits, but they consider Indonesian wages and very limited workers' protection to be too expensive (Abuse rife in Indonesian Nike plants, February 23). It spends more on advertising than on its entire labour bill.

Only by allowing free trade unions to organise in these factories can workers start to win decent pay, basic health and safety provision, an end to harassment and so on. No Sweat is campaigning for a trade union labour mark on garments sold in the UK, so shoppers have a guarantee the clothes they buy are produced by workers who were free to organise against abuses.
M Duncan
No Sweat Campaign
nosweatcamp@yahoo.co.uk

webTitle: Painting on way back to Constable country

fields.headline: Painting on way back to Constable country
fields.standfirst: Dedham's fortune
fields.trailText: A canvas of the risen Christ by John Constable, famous for his lyrical rural landscapes under brooding East Anglian skies, will be returned to the heart of Constable country on Ascension Thursday, saved by a local trust from auction and export.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A canvas of the risen Christ by John Constable, famous for his lyrical rural landscapes under brooding East Anglian skies, will be returned to the heart of Constable country on Ascension Thursday, saved by a local trust from auction and export.

The painting has had a chequered history: the church for which it was originally commissioned was demolished, and it was later sold to pay for a new heating system for its second home. After failing at auction it was provisionally acquired by the trust, and is awaiting resurrection in a cupboard at the house of another East Anglian artist, the Gainsborough Museum in Sudbury, Suffolk.

The campaign to save it for the Stour valley has won local support. A further £10,000 anonymous donation came at the weekend, leaving the trust with less than £20,000 to raise of the £70,000 cost of purchase and conservation work.

The picture will be placed on long loan in the parish church at Dedham, the centre of Constable country. Hordes of cultural pilgrims visit each year, but no major works by Constable are on display in the area.

The Risen Christ is one of only three religious paintings known by Constable. The priest for whom it was commissioned died, and Constable was uncertain that he would be paid. Hugh Belsey, director of the trust, can find no evidence in the records that he ever got the promised £200.

The Risen Christ was commissioned in 1821 by the brewer Edward Alston, who hoped to present it to Archdeacon John Jefferson for the church in Manningtree, Essex, and in return win permission to open more local pubs. Jefferson died but the church got the painting, and it remained as an altarpiece until 1965, when the 17th century building was condemned as unsafe and demolished.

A local priest, the Rev Aubrey Moody, bought it for £1,250 with his own money, for his church at Feering, Essex, where it remained until last year when the ancient heating system finally expired. With the agreement of his parish council, he sent the picture to Christie's and got a full size reproduction for the church.

webTitle: Thousands flee bloody Borneo ethnic cleansing

fields.headline: Thousands flee bloody Borneo ethnic cleansing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Ethnic cleansing perpetrated by indigenous tribal fighters against migrants in Central Kalimantan engulfed the capital of the Indonesian province for the first time yesterday as tens of thousands of refugees fled hordes of head hunters.
fields.body:
Ethnic cleansing perpetrated by indigenous tribal fighters against migrants in Central Kalimantan engulfed the capital of the Indonesian province for the first time yesterday as tens of thousands of refugees fled hordes of head hunters.

As the official death toll from eight days of carnage on the island of Borneo rose to 270, hundreds of local Dayaks swept through the city of Palangkaraya looking for settlers from the island of Madura. Police did nothing to prevent them burning dozens of homes and setting up roadblocks across the city to stop the Madurese escaping.

Gangs armed with spears and machetes stopped cars on the main roads out of the city to check for Madurese. Many terrified people rushed to the police headquarters for refuge.

In Sampit, 120 miles to the west, 5,000 Madurese boarded a passenger ferry for Java. Thousands more who had been hiding in the forest for up to a week tried to slip past Dayaks patrolling the countryside to the relative safety of the refugee camp in Sampit. At one point police were forced to open fire on advancing Dayak fighters to protect the camp.

While thousands made it, many did not get past the search parties. The fate of three men caught six miles outside the town was typical. After being stripped naked and having their hands tied behind their backs, they were beheaded, according to Fabrian Charles, who boasted of his role in the executions.

The gangs hacked a V into one man's chest and extracted his heart. This and the heads were dispatched to the Dayaks' headquarters in Sampit.

Kamelu, an unemployed engineer who was hanging around the Dayak headquarters yesterday, said the heads are distributed to villages: "To protect the people."

The slaughter was sparked by two local government officials who paid a group of Dayaks to attack a Madurese housing complex. Indonesia's Antara news agency reported yesterday that the death toll is at least 400; Madurese in the Sampit refugee camp reckon it is several times that figure.

Matt Umbut, who has been in the camp since Friday, said he believes several hundred died in his town alone when it was attacked three days ago. "My wife and daughter were killed in front of me as we ran away," he said.

During a visit to the camp yesterday Indonesia's chief security minister promised that the Dayak fighters would soon be brought under control.

"We will control the situation, we will enforce the law," said Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono. The security and the humanity [of the refugees] is our priority. That should be solved in a few days."

Meanwhile, conditions in the camp, which houses 15,000 refugees, are deteriorating rapidly. Many refugees have not eaten for days and at least five have died of starvation.

fields.headline: Roll out the bandwidth
fields.standfirst:
Urgent action is needed to stop collapse

More net news
fields.trailText: Fifteen years ago the Conservatives set up a committee to decide the best way to deliver "broadband" or high-capacity telephone connections to homes and businesses. Fifteen years on, we are still waiting.
fields.body:
Fifteen years ago the Conservatives set up a committee to decide the best way to deliver "broadband" or high-capacity telephone connections to homes and businesses. The aim was to exploit the new world of two-way video phones, cinema-sharp films, home banking, home shopping and all the promises of the digital revolution. Fifteen years on, we are still waiting. Mrs Thatcher rejected proposals for BT to invest £15-20bn over a decade to deliver optic fibre to homes. BT would only invest such capital it if could send profitable entertainment services down its lines. The government rejected this as it would have reinforced BT's monopoly and suffocated the new cable companies that were being encouraged. It was decided to leave it to market forces.

As a result, there are now no plans to create a fibre optic grid to the home - the fibre stops at the local exchange. A minority of consumers can get broadband through cable but the rest will have to make do with ADSL, a technology enabling telephone companies to send more data down existing copper wires. ADSL or assymetric digital subscriber line is what it says it is - assymetric: data goes much faster when you are downloading films etc than when you are sending something. This contrasts with fibre optic wires that offer almost unlimited capacity in both directions.

This is a long way from the vision of a national fibre grid. And even this diluted vision is coming apart. BT is accused by rivals of cherry-picking the areas where it offers its own ADSL and being wantonly slow in opening up its exchanges to allow competing companies to install their ADSL. In recent weeks a lot of rival telcos have pulled out, alleging high costs, excessive red tape and stalling measures by BT. Whatever the truth of all this, the government's policy of having the "the most extensive and competitive" broadband services among all major industrialised countries by 2005 is in danger of collapsing. And the further north you go in Britain the worst the availability is. Fifteen years ago BT was flush with cash. Now it is so overloaded with debt that its credit rating could be downgraded. One of the reasons for this is that it had to pay through the nose for its licence to operate the so-called third generation (3G) of high-bandwidth mobile phones.

There are two things the government ought to do urgently to make sure Britain does not get left behind in the communications race. First, either directly or through the regulator, it should ensure that rival companies get speedy, affordable access to as many BT exchanges as possible. Second, it should examine how it could use some of the £22.5bn windfall it unexpectedly got from the 3G auction to expedite the roll-out of broadband. Ironically, the windfall is not unadjacent to the £15-20bn that BT said it needed to build a full-blown optic fibre grid 15 years ago.

fields.headline: Clare's wrong about Gats
fields.trailText: It is encouraging to see ministers are at last talking publicly about the general agreement on trade in services (Gats), even if it is in the letters column of the Guardian rather than in parliament (Letters, February 22).
fields.body:
It is encouraging to see ministers are at last talking publicly about the general agreement on trade in services (Gats), even if it is in the letters column of the Guardian rather than in parliament (Letters, February 22). Gats has been described by the World Trade Organisation as the most important trade agreement since 1948. Yet few MPs or members of the public have been told of its existence.

Clare Short suggests that countries voluntarily sign service sectors up to Gats. But some Gats provisions apply to all service sectors, including public services that are supplied commercially or in competition with the private sector. For example, article vi on domestic regulation aims to remove "unnecessary" regulation across the board. What is deemed "unnecessary"? Regulation has been overruled in 10 out of 11 WTO cases, including rules to stop by-catch of dolphins, protect turtles or restrict cigarette imports.

The key question is whether deregulated markets can deliver services to the poor. The experience of rich and poor countries alike shows the importance of government regulation that puts poverty reduction and sustainable development above the interests of foreign companies.

The implications of Gats should be investigated by parliament - particularly given that, once agreed, Gats will be effectively irreversible. Negotiations start again next month. It is not too late for Ms Short and her colleagues to take a closer look at this agreement, rather than using soundbites to try to dismiss any concerns.
Barry Coates
Director, World Development Movement
Barry@wdm.org.uk

 Unlike the IMF and World Bank, the WTO actually does include rights that mean all member countries have an equal right to vote and a majority vote on regulations is possible - the thing is that it has never been used. Furthermore, by their very membership of WTO, developing countries will be obliged to accept new terms of Gats under the proposed expansion of article vi, whereby a country's labour laws, safety guidelines, licensing standards, subsidies, grants or environmental protection may be called "trade restrictive" and thus subject to court action from multinational service providers.

Globalisation, led by multinationals, is failing and will, under its current form, continue to fail the poor. Where developing countries are held to ransom by policies such as structural adjustment in return for debt relief, they are never given the chance to be choosers. Under Gats things are no different. If it is indeed "bottom-up" it's hard to see why Bolivia's government would have sold its water rights to a British company which then charged peasants one-third of their income for drinking rain water. The government about-turn, after mass protest from the people, would be illegal under proposed Gats provisions.

Clare Short would do well to listen to the voices of concern raised throughout South America, Africa and Asia, at Seattle, Prague and Nice and that will be raised again at the G8 Summit in Genoa in July.
Brian Garvey
Department of geography, University of Sheffield
b.garvey@sheffield.ac.uk

 Barry Coates's exposure of the Gats threat to public services (Letters, February 16) is right to point out that Gats will lock in privatisation and deregulation. Any "bound" commitments a country makes to open up sectors of its economy cannot be reversed unless the country pays compensation to other Gats members. The sum would amount to billions of pounds and be totally out of reach of any developing country.
Chris Keene
Canvey Island, Essex
chris.keene@which.net

fields.headline: Languages are not enough
fields.trailText: We are thrilled that it is beginning to be understood that this country is losing out if it continues to be "monolingual" (Letters, February 21).
fields.body:
We are thrilled that it is beginning to be understood that this country is losing out if it continues to be "monolingual" (Letters, February 21). However, it is also surprising that in an earlier article (UK at bottom of languages class, February 20), there is absolutely no mention of the wealth of non-European languages which exist among the ethnic minorities and which are totally undervalued and neglected within the education system. Just another example of the hegemonic Anglo-Saxon culture?
Martha Worsching
Dept of European studies, Loughborough University
M.M.Worsching@lboro.ac.uk

 I was astonished to see Tony Blair on television a week or two ago, in the market place at Cahors, greeting an aged peasant with: "Et tu vas bien?" He may have worked as a barman on the Left Bank, where it is de rigueur (as we say in English) to tu-toi everybody all the time, but it is not acceptable when talking to a gnarled old peasant in the Midi, and is in fact extremely rude. It is not good enough to know a few words of a language, but to have no idea about the social mores and cultural diversity of our near neighbours.
Anita Pheby
Castle Cary, Somerset

 Jean Holmes and her pupil (Letter, February 23) who ordered coffee in French in Brussels were, unlike me, not solemnly warned about rule one of visiting Belgium: do not try to practise your French there as only about half the citizens speak it and the other half get very offended indeed (as the waiter she mentions duly did).
Frank Desmond
London
fields.bodyText: We are thrilled that it is beginning to be understood that this country is losing out if it continues to be "monolingual" (Letters, February 21). However, it is also surprising that in an earlier article (UK at bottom of languages class, February 20), there is absolutely no mention of the wealth of non-European languages which exist among the ethnic minorities and which are totally undervalued and neglected within the education system. Just another example of the hegemonic Anglo-Saxon culture? Martha Worsching Dept of European studies, Loughborough University M.M.Worsching@lboro.ac.uk  I was astonished to see Tony Blair on television a week or two ago, in the market place at Cahors, greeting an aged peasant with: "Et tu vas bien?" He may have worked as a barman on the Left Bank, where it is de rigueur (as we say in English) to tu-toi everybody all the time, but it is not acceptable when talking to a gnarled old peasant in the Midi, and is in fact extremely rude. It is not good enough to know a few words of a language, but to have no idea about the social mores and cultural diversity of our near neighbours. Anita Pheby Castle Cary, Somerset  Jean Holmes and her pupil (Letter, February 23) who ordered coffee in French in Brussels were, unlike me, not solemnly warned about rule one of visiting Belgium: do not try to practise your French there as only about half the citizens speak it and the other half get very offended indeed (as the waiter she mentions duly did). fields.headline: Turkish view
fields.trailText: Chris Morris's article (Turkey fights over memory of exiled poet, February 22) raises the intriguing question whether the remains of Nazim Hikmet, the Turkish poet who died in Moscow in 1963, should be reburied in Anatolia.
fields.body:
Chris Morris's article (Turkey fights over memory of exiled poet, February 22) raises the intriguing question whether the remains of Nazim Hikmet, the Turkish poet who died in Moscow in 1963, should be reburied in Anatolia. The poet's dream of being buried in "a village cemetery in Anatolia" is certainly poignant, but at present he lies buried in distinguished company - in the Novodevichy cemetery alongside Pushkin and Mayakovsky. The poet was certainly proud of his Turkish heritage, but - as we have shown in our book Romantic Communist: The Life and Work of Nazim Hikmet - he was above all an internationalist.

It will be the centenary of his birth in January 2002 and there will be various celebratory activities, including a multicultural poetry festival at the South Bank.
Saime Göksu Edward Timms
Brighton
saime@umut34.freeserve.co.uk

 I cannot but see the reference (Europe holds its breath as Turkish lira dives, February 23) to Turkey as a Nato country "guarding the alliance's south-eastern border", as classic Crusader mentality. It is as though the Arabs/Muslims present an immediate and ever present threat against which Turkey is the buffer; on one side the civilised west, on the other the heathen, dark-skinned, irrational Arab.

The ease with which this language is employed shows how deeply embedded orientalism is in the western psyche. It is a disappointment to see it in the Guardian.
Shahed Saleem
London

fields.headline: War crime against women
fields.trailText: The women who testified at the Hague tribunal on rape as a war crime deserve the thanks of all civilised societies (Mass rape ruled a war crime, February 23). Rape as an instrument of war - a deliberate tactic - developed late in the last, awful, century.
fields.body:
The women who testified at the Hague tribunal on rape as a war crime deserve the thanks of all civilised societies (Mass rape ruled a war crime, February 23). Rape as an instrument of war - a deliberate tactic - developed late in the last, awful, century. As I heard time and again when I was in Kosovo after the Nato campaign had stopped, it is these raped women who might bear the burden of social exclusion. Their partners may abandon them, family shy away, their prospects for a happy and fulfilled life wrecked. Perhaps the west could offer them a helping hand - or would we call them "economic migrants" and turn them away?
Lesley Abdela
Lamberhurst, Kent
lesley.abdela@shevolution.com

 Thousands of women have not only deliberately been made pregnant during wars, but many were intentionally infected with Aids. In Rwanda, Avega (Widows of the Genocide of April 1994) reports that two to three of its members die every day from the Aids virus contracted when they were raped seven years ago. The rapists knew they carried the virus and told them "you will die a slow death".

However, many of the victims wait in vain to be called to give their testimonies to the international tribunals for war crimes. If justice is to be done, they have a right to be kept informed on the processes of these tribunals.
Margaret Owen
Empowering Widows in Development
Margieowen@cs.com
