webTitle: Letters: WTO threat to Aids drugs

fields.headline: WTO threat to Aids drugs
fields.trailText: Glaxo SmithKline's offer of cheaper drugs for treating HIV/Aids is a welcome response to the crisis in Africa (Glaxo relents on Aids drugs, February 22), which VSO health workers witness daily. But the announcement should not deflect from longer-term solutions.
fields.body:
Glaxo SmithKline's offer of cheaper drugs for treating HIV/Aids is a welcome response to the crisis in Africa (Glaxo relents on Aids drugs, February 22), which VSO health workers witness daily. But the announcement should not deflect from longer-term solutions. HIV/Aids requires more radical and far-reaching solutions than one-off donations. We need global cuts by the major pharmaceutical companies, setting price levels affordable to the poor.

Experience has also shown that the production of copy generics has, in some circumstances, been an effective means of reducing prices of drugs. New WTO patent rules are likely to damage developing countries' abilities to produce generics unless there is global political support for them to do so. Recognising that developing countries have legitimate rights to buy medicines from the cheapest sources, even if that source is not GSK, would be extremely significant.
Mark Goldring
Chief executive, VSO

 Tax incentives to drug companies in return for vaccine development may bring vital drugs to the market (Fund to beat third world disease, February 23). But it is hard to see how this will address the absolute lack of resources needed for effective health care in the poorest countries. In Liberia, it takes four months to procure a vaccine supply. In one county there is only one doctor per 850,000 people and in another only one health vehicle for 1m people. The chancellor, in his global child poverty initiative, being launched today, must lead a call to governments around the world to spend more on the systems needed to actually deliver health care.
Regina Keith
Save the Children

fields.headline: Shipwreck reveals trade secrets
fields.trailText: A shipwrecked cargo of Greek wine is expected to unlock secrets about the Mediterranean after being discovered in one of its deepest recesses, undisturbed for 2,300 years.
fields.body:
A shipwrecked cargo of Greek wine is expected to unlock secrets about the Mediterranean after being discovered in one of its deepest recesses, undisturbed for 2,300 years.

Video and sonar imagery taken by a robot located the contents of a wreck at a depth of almost 10,000 feet on what is known as the Herodotus abyssal plain, half-way between Rhodes and Alexandria.

Nauticus Corporation, a deep sea exploration firm, found the cargo in 1999 while seeking a sunken Israeli submarine, but according to a report in the current issue of Archaeology magazine it is only now, after analysis of the images by oceanographers in Texas, that the wreck has been confirmed.

The magazine says the discovery suggests that sailors in the 4th century BC had the skills to cross open seas rather than hug the coastline as previously thought.

In the ship was a cargo of up to 2,500 amphoras, many containing wine from Rhodes and Kos. Sediment caught in a metal cauldron is expected to offer clues to tides, temperatures and erosion.

Oceanographers from the Institute of Nautical Archaeology at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas, are studying ways of extracting a core sample of this accumulated sand, fish bone and detritus without disturbing the sediment.

The stern of the ship, the likely area of the crew's quarters, contains kitchenware, including a serving bowl and pitcher. It is hoped that the sea's depth and cold may have preserved parts of the hull. Four other possible wrecks are said to lie nearby.

"The discovery turns conventional wisdom on its head," said Kristin Romey of Archaeology magazine, which called this the first evidence of significant open-water trade with ancient Egypt by Crete, Cyprus and Turkey.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Chechen bodies discovered
fields.body:
Chechen bodies discovered

The corpses of possibly dozens of dead Chechen civilians have been found in an abandoned village close to Russia's main garrison at Khankala outside the capital, Grozny yesterday.

Russia and Chechen loyalists said the corpses were of local residents who may have been killed in a "clash of clans" but human rights groups said that is unlikely and alleged that hundreds of young Chechens have been tortured at Khankala.

Ian Traynor, Moscow

Landmark Iran trip for Mowlam

Mo Mowlam became the first British cabinet minister to visit Tehran since the 1979 Islamic revolution after she met the head of the parliament, Mehdi Karubi, yesterday to discuss the fight against drugs. Ms Mowlam will spend four days in Iran.

AFP, London

New line in Clinton inquiry

A House of Representatives committee is investigating whether the fugitive financier Marc Rich funnelled donations into Bill Clinton's presidential library via a third party in return for a pardon.

Republican congressman Dan Burton, who heads the government reform committee looking into the affair, said he has stepped up his personal security after receiving death threats.

Reuters, Washington

Balloon drops down under

A huge unmanned balloon sprang a leak and was guided back to Earth yesterday hours after starting a 20-mile-high round-the-world study of near space meant to last 100 days.

Nasa landed the balloon - as big as a domed football stadium - near the launch site in Alice Springs, central Australia.

AP, Sydney

fields.headline: Opera club blackballs soprano
fields.trailText: The members of the exclusive Cercle del Liceu club at Barcelona's opera house yesterday refused to end 150 years of male domination by blackballing the Spanish soprano Montserrat Caballé and nine other women applicants.
fields.body:
The members of the exclusive Cercle del Liceu club at Barcelona's opera house yesterday refused to end 150 years of male domination by blackballing the Spanish soprano Montserrat Caballé and nine other women applicants.

Opponents of the women's applications turned out in force over the weekend to vote at the recently rebuilt Liceu opera house on the city's central Las Ramblas boulevard.

The club turned down all 10 women but approved membership for three men.

The rules of the Cercle club meant that only a third of the 1,000 members needed to vote with a blackball to block the women's applications. The applicants gained only 60% of the vote and, under club rules, cannot reapply for five years.

Caballé made no comment about the vote, which followed a recent change in club rules allowing women to apply.

Opponents of the change, led by younger members, said the reform had been forced through by the Cercle's ruling committee. That committee vowed yesterday to change the statutes again so that new members could join with a simple majority vote in favour.

"Some members just do not realise that this is the 21st century and that an organisation whose aim is to promote cultural life in Barcelona cannot exclude women," said a committee spokesman.

The club's decision to blackball the women may face a court challenge under Spain's equal opportunity laws.

webTitle: Leader: learning from the migratory pattern of eels

fields.headline: Slippery theories
fields.standfirst: Scientists have turned head over eels
fields.trailText: People like Conrad Black, the newspaper proprietor who campaigns for Britain to join the North American Free Trade Association (Nafta) rather than Europe's single currency zone, might profitably spend more time studying the migratory pattern of eels.
fields.body:
People like Conrad Black, the newspaper proprietor who campaigns for Britain to join the North American Free Trade Association (Nafta) rather than Europe's single currency zone, might profitably spend more time studying the migratory pattern of eels. It has been one of life's delightful mysteries why the eel absconds from Europe every year to mate, spawn and die in the mysterious Sargasso Sea, that 2m square miles of exceptionally clear, warm, blue water cast adrift in the North Atlantic. For most of this century scientists believed that eels from Europe and America mingled and mated randomly in the Sargasso Sea in a sort of maritime equivalent of the North Atlantic Free Trade Area.

Not any more. Researchers using DNA techniques to discover genetic differences between the migratory creatures have found that European eels actually stick together in a common market of their own. Just why they bother to swim thousands of miles just to mate with each other in the Sargasso Sea when the Mediterranean provides a warm alternative is not clear. Nor is the even deeper mystery of how the larvae from the eels find their own way back to where their mothers and fathers came from - without any parental guidance at all. Perhaps it is time for the EU commission in Brussels to take seriously the idea of establishing a new EEC, a European Eels Community, to find out whether these slippery creatures are trying to tell us something we ought to know about.

webTitle: Quest for truth over Dublin bomb massacre

fields.headline: Quest for truth over Dublin bomb massacre
fields.standfirst:
'Forgotten' victims of 1974 blasts fight on for justice amid claims of British involvement

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: While dramatic stories of an army lethally out of control tumble out of the public inquiry into Bloody Sunday in Derry, a parallel investigation into a potentially more controversial event is being conducted in Dublin behind closed doors.
fields.body:
While dramatic stories of an army lethally out of control tumble out of the public inquiry into Bloody Sunday in Derry, a parallel investigation into a potentially more controversial event is being conducted in Dublin behind closed doors.

The four car bombs which exploded in Dublin and Monaghan in May 1974, taking the lives of 33 people and wounding more than 200, constituted the worst single massacre of the entire Irish Troubles. Because of its long obscurity in the British and Irish public consciousness, the families of the victims and wounded called themselves the Justice for the Forgotten campaign.

It is alleged that the principal perpetrators, members of the Ulster Volunteer Force from Portadown, were aided and abetted by members of the British security services and that the Garda's initially promising investigation - it had the names of 20 suspects within weeks - was frustrated by the RUC.

At least three of the bombing team, all now dead, have been identified as paid informers.

After years of obfuscation and resistance, the Irish government finally gave in to pressure from the families and a commission of inquiry was set up in January last year under the retiring chief justice Liam Hamilton.

Collusion

His work was expected to take nine months but last October he became ill and he died a month later. The inquiry is now being quietly conducted by the retired supreme court judge Henry Barron. Three weeks ago he slipped over to Southend-on-Sea, in Essex, to interview a former military intelligence officer who has evidence of British collusion with the loyalist paramilitaries involved.

Another former intelligence officer he has contacted told the Guardian: "He has a healthy streak of independence and he seems pretty convinced that the bombers were assisted from the outside."

The Northern Ireland Office and Adam Ingram, the security minister, have promised to cooperate "as positively as possible".

But it remains to be seen whether the British army, the RUC and, crucially, MI5 are prepared to open their files from what was one of the murkiest periods of the conflict. The Forgotten campaigners are acutely aware that British ministers, despite personal representations from the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, may invoke the Official Secrets Act and issue public interest immunity certificates to conceal the evidence.

Judge Barron's fact-finding report, however, will eventually see the light of day. In a compromise made possible by the Irish constitution, it will be delivered to the Irish parliament's joint committee on justice, equality and women's rights. The committee then plans to hold public, televised hearings to decide whether to recommend a full public inquiry.

"You have always got to be a bit cynical because it's been going on for years," says Margaret Urwin, the campaign's secretary. "We have to put our faith in Judge Barron."

On the morning of May 17 1974, two cars were hijacked in loyalist areas of Belfast and a third was stolen. A fourth was taken from a car park in Portadown. In the late afternoon, during Dublin's Friday rush-hour, the three from Belfast exploded without warning in the city centre within 90 seconds of each other. The Monaghan bomb went off 1 hours later. No one claimed responsibility. There have been no prosecutions.

Harrowing accounts of the carnage have been brought together in a book by the human rights activist and writer Don Mullan, whose previous work on Bloody Sunday influenced the British government's decision to set up the Saville inquiry.

Derek Byrne, 14, was working as a petrol pump attendant in Parnell Street, Dublin, when the first bomb went off. He appeared so badly injured that he was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital. "It was a very scary thing to wake up in the morgue," he recalls.

"I was just lying on the table. It was full of bodies. I just let out a scream. The mortuary attendant then let out a scream." He spent the next 19 hours in the operating theatre.

"I could never understand why no one was held responsible for the terrible atrocity," said Bernie O'Hanlon, then a 16-year-old shop assistant whose badly scarred right eye finally had to be removed three years ago. "The Irish government should leave no stone unturned until it finds the truth and justice we deserve. Then and only then can we heal."

The explosions happened at a time of intense political crisis. Two days earlier the Ulster Workers Council strike against the Sunningdale power-sharing agreement had begun to paralyse Northern Ireland and the new Labour government of Harold Wilson.

Among hardline unionists, with support from elements in the army and MI5, it was feared that the Wilson administration was about to go soft on the republic. There was also a fierce turf war in the intelligence community between MI5, which was determined to prosecute the war against the IRA, and the secret intelligence service, MI6, which realised that only a political solution could end the violence.

Suspicions of British collusion were immediately raised because of the technical precision needed for the attacks, and it is now accepted that covert army units ran loyalist assassins in the north. But it took nearly 20 years before some light was shed on the bombings.

In 1993, after a 2-year investigation, Yorkshire TV's First Tuesday broadcast Hidden Hand: the Forgotten Massacre. Given unprecedented access to Garda files and personnel, the programme made the following assertions:

 Witnesses were able to identify eight suspects, including two of the drivers.

 Within weeks both the Garda and the RUC had a list of 20 suspects, all from the UVF.

 The Garda was not allowed to interview suspects in Northern Ireland and its investigation was wound down after three months. The Irish government remained indifferent.

 British military intelligence, which had infiltrated the UVF in Portadown, was willing to allow the outlawed organisation to carry out terrorist acts.

Allegations

Nearly two years later the Irish department of justice said the Garda had no new evidence that would enable anyone to be charged. Since then there have been further allegations about the botched Garda forensic investigation and links between senior Gardai and British intelligence officers. A former sergeant in the RUC, John Weir, convicted of a loyalist murder in 1980, has claimed that the explosives were provided by an Ulster Defence Regiment captain and assembled on the Amagh farm of an RUC officer. The first breakthrough for the families came with the Good Friday agreement and the establishment of a victims commissioner in 1998. Commissioner John Wilson caused an uproar when he recommended in August 1999 that an inquiry into the bombings be held entirely in private.

"We were thrown into a quandary," a senior Dublin official told the Guardian. "Because the matter involved two jurisdictions we were afraid that we would not have full control over a public inquiry." But at the suggestion of the Irish Labour party, the compromise of a judicial fact-finding report followed by public hearings before the joint committee was agreed.

Judge Barron is navigating turbulent and murky waters but the families of the dead remain determined to get at the truth. Martha O'Neill, who lost her husband, Edward, says: "I want to see justice before I die. I really, really do."

The Dublin & Monaghan Bombings. Don Mullan, Wolfhound Press, Dublin.

"It was a very scary thing to wake up in the morgue," he recalls. "I was just lying on the table. It was full of bodies. I just let out a scream. The mortuary attendant then let out a scream." He spent the next 19 hours in the operating theatre. "I could never understand why no one was held responsible for the terrible atrocity," said Bernie O'Hanlon, then a 16-year-old shop assistant whose badly scarred right eye finally had to be removed three years ago. "The Irish government should leave no stone unturned until it finds the truth and justice we deserve. Then and only then can we heal." The explosions happened at a time of intense political crisis. Two days earlier the Ulster Workers Council strike against the Sunningdale power-sharing agreement had begun to paralyse Northern Ireland and the new Labour government of Harold Wilson. Among hardline unionists, with support from elements in the army and MI5, it was feared that the Wilson administration was about to go soft on the republic. There was also a fierce turf war in the intelligence community between MI5, which was determined to prosecute the war against the IRA, and the secret intelligence service, MI6, which realised that only a political solution could end the violence. Suspicions of British collusion were immediately raised because of the technical precision needed for the attacks, and it is now accepted that covert army units ran loyalist assassins in the north. But it took nearly 20 years before some light was shed on the bombings. In 1993, after a 2-year investigation, Yorkshire TV's First Tuesday broadcast Hidden Hand: the Forgotten Massacre. Given unprecedented access to Garda files and personnel, the programme made the following assertions:  Witnesses were able to identify eight suspects, including two of the drivers.  Within weeks both the Garda and the RUC had a list of 20 suspects, all from the UVF.  The Garda was not allowed to interview suspects in Northern Ireland and its investigation was wound down after three months. The Irish government remained indifferent.  British military intelligence, which had infiltrated the UVF in Portadown, was willing to allow the outlawed organisation to carry out terrorist acts. Allegations Nearly two years later the Irish department of justice said the Garda had no new evidence that would enable anyone to be charged. Since then there have been further allegations about the botched Garda forensic investigation and links between senior Gardai and British intelligence officers. A former sergeant in the RUC, John Weir, convicted of a loyalist murder in 1980, has claimed that the explosives were provided by an Ulster Defence Regiment captain and assembled on the Amagh farm of an RUC officer. The first breakthrough for the families came with the Good Friday agreement and the establishment of a victims commissioner in 1998. Commissioner John Wilson caused an uproar when he recommended in August 1999 that an inquiry into the bombings be held entirely in private. "We were thrown into a quandary," a senior Dublin official told the Guardian. "Because the matter involved two jurisdictions we were afraid that we would not have full control over a public inquiry." But at the suggestion of the Irish Labour party, the compromise of a judicial fact-finding report followed by public hearings before the joint committee was agreed. Judge Barron is navigating turbulent and murky waters but the families of the dead remain determined to get at the truth. Martha O'Neill, who lost her husband, Edward, says: "I want to see justice before I die. I really, really do." The Dublin & Monaghan Bombings. Don Mullan, Wolfhound Press, Dublin.

webTitle: Celebrity chefs feel heat from Michelin

fields.headline: Celebrity chefs feel heat from Michelin
fields.trailText: In a warning to celebrity chefs who have no time left to cook, the Michelin Red Guide has dethroned Alain Ducasse, France's gastronomic grandee and until this weekend the only chef to hold a total of six of the food bible's stars.
fields.body:
In a warning to celebrity chefs who have no time left to cook, the Michelin Red Guide has dethroned Alain Ducasse, France's gastronomic grandee and until this weekend the only chef to hold a total of six of the food bible's stars.

The editors of the 2001 guide, published this week, decided that Mr Ducasse no longer deserved the ultimate accolade for the cuisine at his Monte Carlo eatery, where the price of a three-course meal averages £180, and demoted the establishment to two stars.

But Mr Ducasse, who between TV appearances, product endorsements and half a dozen restaurants worldwide, is a one-man haute cuisine industry, did collect three stars for his Paris flagship hangout at the Plaza Athénée hotel.

Succeeding him as the uncrowned king of French cuisine is Marc Veyrat, 50, a Savoyard chef who already held three stars for his Auberge de l'Eridan near Annecy and this year wins another three for his new Alpine establishment, La Ferme de mon père in Mégeve.

But in underlining the fact that Mr Veyrat's two restaurants are open consecutively - the first in summer, the second in winter - while Mr Ducasse's establishments in Paris and Monte Carlo serve supper all year round, the Michelin guide appears to have made its point: no top chef can be in more than one kitchen at the same time, or his cooking will suffer.

The decision by the reviewers, whose judgment is so feared that chefs have been known to commit suicide on losing a star, will send shivers down the spine of more than one celebrity cook.

Paul Bocuse, another three-star Gallic culinary wizard, has admitted to being so busy that he is forced to use ghost chefs, saying: "Do you seriously think Enzo Ferrari puts all the nuts on all the cars he sells?"

By rewarding Mr Veyrat, the guide has also recognised adventurousness rather than tradition. The chef, who wears a broad-brimmed black hat rather than the customary white toque, specialises in an original cuisine based on fresh mountain herbs and plants.

"Today I'm delighted, but tomorrow I could be desolate," Mr Veyrat said. "You always have to be vigilant, but it is true that during all of last year I was out of my kitchen for just two sittings."

webTitle: Japan in dock for 'inhuman' treatment on death row

fields.headline: Japan in dock for 'inhuman' treatment on death row
fields.standfirst: Tokyo could have its Council of Europe observer status revoked after delegation is refused access to 'secretive' execution facilities
fields.trailText: Tokyo could have its Council of Europe observer status revoked after delegation is refused access to 'secretive' execution facilities.
fields.body:
Japan has been attacked for its "inhuman" and secretive treatment of death row prisoners after a European human rights delegation was refused access to inmates and execution facilities.

The delegation of lawmakers from the Council of Europe (which is wider than and unconnected to the European Union) was on a first ever international fact-finding mission into one of the world's most secretive systems of capital punishment.

But the delegation ran into a brick wall when it attempted to investigate how convicts are looked after and executed, raising the prospect of a diplomatic row that would be embarrassing for Japan.

The mission was invited by one of the 28 death row convicts - whose name cannot be revealed under Japanese regulations - at the Tokyo detention house, but their request to see him as turned down by the justice ministry and the prison warden.

"They told us that we couldn't meet any inmates because it might disturb their peace of mind," said the mission's leader, Gunnar Jansson, the chairman of the council's human rights committee. "I've never heard anything like it."

The group's mission is to determine whether Japan and other countries which still enforce the death penalty should retain their observer status at the Council of Europe, all of whose members promised in 1997 to abolish capital punishment.

But while they have received offers of full cooperation in the US and other countries, in Japan they were only permitted to view an empty cell.

"It is extremely sad that the Japanese justice ministry has taken such an attitude," said Nobuto Hosaka, the leader of a group of Japanese MPs in favour of abolishing the death penalty. "Clearly, Japan is trying to hide its executions from the international community."

Japan has hanged 39 people since 1993 and 54 remain on death row. It gives no advance warning of executions, which are carried out in secret, usually during the New Year holiday when they are least likely to attract publicity.

Prisoners are not informed of impending execution until an hour before it takes place. Their families have no advance warning and the names of those killed are never made public.

The average hanging takes 23 minutes. No relatives or other observers are allowed to be present. On at least one occasion, the rope has failed to do the job and executioners have strangled the convict.

"The treatment of the inmates is inhuman," said Mr Jansson. "The system of announcing the execution order on the same morning could be seen as torture."

Citing this as a "problem" in relations between Japan and the Council of Europe, he said it was "completely possible" that he would recommend that Japan's observer status, granted in 1996, be revoked. The council's visit comes a week after the EU petitioned the Japanese government to abolish the death penalty.

"The EU calls on Japan to renew its commitment to promoting respect for human rights by joining it in abolishing capital punishment in line with the international community view," the request said.

The Japanese justice minister, Masahiko Komura, has rejected calls for abolition or a moratorium.

"Eighty per cent of the public say the death penalty is imperative so it should be maintained," he said during a meeting with the EU delegation this week. "The nation's court rulings on the death penalty are based on an extremely thoughtful judgement and the actual executions are based on careful consideration. As a result, there is no need for a moratorium."

The man who spent 30 years expecting each day to be his last

The most terrifying aspect of Japanese capital punishment is the unusually high risk that innocent people may be executed, according to the man who knows life on death row better than anyone.

Sakae Menda, now 78, spent more than 30 years thinking that each day could be his last after being sentenced to death in 1951 for a murder he did not commit.

As in 99% of criminal trials in Japan, the judge (there are no juries) ruled in favour of the prosecution. The main evidence was a confession extracted from Mr Menda while in police custody.

"They tied a rope around my ankles and hung me upside down from the ceiling. They took it in shifts to kick me and beat. I wasn't allowed to eat, sleep or drink until I told them what they wanted to hear," recalls Mr Menda, one of a handful of death-row prisoners to win a retrial.

As is true today, detectives were able to hold him for more than three weeks without charging him and he had no legal right to insist that a lawyer be present at all interrogations. Although Mr Menda later retracted his confession at the high court, he was sent to Fukuoka prison to await execution.

"Words can never describe the constant dread of being faced with death every single day," he says. "The first time I saw another inmate being taking to the execution room, I went insane."

His fit of screaming earned him chobatsu, the toughest form of punishment. For two months, he was handcuffed to a metal belt tied around his waist, forcing him to eat like a dog.

Although he was well behaved for the rest of his long incarceration, he was allowed out of his toilet-sized cell for only two hours a day.

Prisoners believed their guards' reports determined the timing of executions. "Those who misbehaved seemed to be chosen first for hanging. We felt that guards had the power of life or death over us," he says.

When Mr Menda first entered prison, inmates were informed the night before their executions, but that system was changed after one man committed suicide before he could be hanged.

Mr Menda won his freedom in 1983 after five previous attempts to secure a retrial had failed. On his release, he was given 7,000 yen (£40) for every day of his wrongful imprisonment. He has given half of that 90m yen (£500,000) to a lawyers' group fighting for the release of death-row prisoners who are protesting their innocence.

webTitle: Mexican rebels take demands to the capital

fields.headline: Mexican rebels take demands to the capital
fields.standfirst: Zapatour will press president on indigenous bill of rights
fields.trailText: Seven years after bursting out of the jungle in the southern state of Chiapas at the head of a group of rebels claiming they would march on the capital to force recognition of indigenous rights, Sub-Comandante Marcos is finally leading the promised journey - only without the guns.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman  in San Cristobal de las Casas
fields.body:
Seven years after bursting out of the jungle in the southern state of Chiapas at the head of a group of rebels claiming they would march on the capital to force recognition of indigenous rights, Sub-Comandante Marcos is finally leading the promised journey - only without the guns.

Together with the 23 other Zapatista rebel leaders, Marcos set off at the weekend on a 15-day tour through much of southern and central Mexico. The tour is due to arrive in the capital on March 11.

But the idea is no longer to bring down the government, despite the continued existence of the Zapatista declaration of war, but to lobby the national congress on an indigenous rights bill they have made a key condition for restarting peace talks that broke down four years ago.

"Never again will we be left in Mexico's forgotten corner, never again be the object of disdain, the motive of disgust, the charity that cleans consciences," Marcos told the thousands gathered on Saturday night in the highland city of San Cristobal de las Casas. "That is why this is the march of indigenous dignity the march of those of us we who are the colour of the earth."

His words were heard by the Zapatista faithful bussed into the rally, and by sympathetic observers who filled the city's main square to see the masked men and women many regard as their only hope for an end to chronic discrimination. Infant mortality in indigenous communities is 48 per 1,000 live births, almost double the national average.

The Zapatour - as it is known here - is an attempt to relaunch the movement in the new political context created by the demise of the seven-decade regime of the authoritarian Institutional Revolutionary Party in the presidential election last July.

The rebels' new adversary is the democratically elected and popular president, Vicente Fox of the conservative National Action party. Mr Fox is eager to sign a peace deal in Chiapas to prove his political credentials and calm the nerves of potential foreign investors.

As soon as he took office in December, Mr Fox made a series of bold pro-peace gestures, sending to congress a bill promising indigenous communities cultural and political autonomy, which had been shelved by his predecessor, Ernesto Zedilllo, ordering a partial pull-back of troops and securing the release of dozens of Zapatista prisoners.

But Sub-Comandante Marcos clearly has no intention of letting a rightwing president, with as much media savvy as himself, set the peace agenda, and the Zapatour is a spectacular attempt to rally national and international support to strengthen the Zapatistas' hand if talks restart, and to justify their retreat back into the jungle if they do not.

In his speech, Marcos sought to reinforce the Zapatista demands for justice and liberty for Mexico's 10m indigenous people by questioning the president's sincerity. He invited all those who feel forgotten by the system to feel at home in his movement.

"Our voice alone cannot open the ears of the 'senor' of many words who listens little [Fox]," said the revolutionary.

His message struck a particular cord with the hundreds of foreigners who have signed up to accompany the march to Mexico City. Dozens of Italians dressed in white overalls to symbolise the anonymity of the struggle against injustice thrust their fists into the air, repeating Zapatista slogans with gusto. "We are fascinated by the way that Marcos speaks, by the profound issues he touches," said one who added that the Zapatistas had inspired his own participation in the Prague, Nice and Davos anti-capitalism protests. Asked his name, he said: "Call me Marcos."

"The European left needs something like this to absorb new ideas," said Alfio Nicota who was part of the civilian escort that accompanied Marcos out of the jungle to San Cristobal on Saturday, where he ceremoniously laid down his weapons.

The issue of security is a delicate one, given the strong opposition to the march expressed by the Mexican far right, and Marcos's refusal to accept the president's offers of escorts. A special government security operation is due to accompany the tour at a distance, and the caravan will be surrounded by the world's press.

But even if it all goes off without a hitch the Zapatour's objective of spreading Zapatista fervour beyond the converted is far from easy to fulfil, and Marcos is under pressure to sit down and talk peace.

Since talks broke down in 1996 the armed rebels have been virtually confined to their jungle hideouts by a strategy of military containment and so unable to protect their supporters from the newly formed anti-Zapatista paramilitary groups.

Meanwhile, support further waned as the living conditions of many Indians they claimed to represent got worse instead of better, and the army of leftwing intellectuals who once rushed to the Marcos magnet began to lose enthusiasm.

"People began to ask what is it that they really want," said Antelmo Velazquez, a Tsotzil Indian, who joined the rebels in 1993 and participated in the uprising, but left after he became impatient to see improvements.

Although still generally sympathetic to his former comrades, for Mr Velazquez the armed struggle has run its course. "We need peace urgently," he said.

fields.headline: Leading from the front
fields.standfirst: Receptionists are the public face of a company. So why, asks Laura Burton, are they so undervalued?
fields.trailText: Receptionists are the public face of a company. So why, asks Laura Burton, are they so undervalued?
fields.body:
While you are reading this I would like you to smile. Think chipmunk, think Carol Smillie. No flagging you there at the back. And why am I asking you to grin loonishly in the office, or on the train, or while pouring out your cornflakes? Because I would like you to understand what it is like to be a receptionist. I would like you to have an inkling of how it feels to smile, unwaveringly, for a sizeable part of the day. But beneath this chirpy exterior, the life of the receptionist is, allegedly, a miserable affair. It is like Judy Garland, concealing her tragedy behind that glittering showbiz persona, or Smokey Robinson, his smile looking so very out of place, as he tried to hide The Tracks of His Tears. For receptionists are bored, isolated, and frankly want a little r-e-s-p-e-c-t. Or so says a survey conducted by recruitment consultants Maine-Tucker.

A third of surveyed receptionists complained that they were bored in their job. One hesitates to point out that being bored in your job is rather par for the course. It is like going to school and hating double maths lessons, even if you are the maths teacher. Show me a chartered accountant who isn't bored rigid with the tedium of spreadsheets. That said, of course, the receptionist has the responsibility of not looking bored in the slightest. All yawns must be stifled, and there is no slouching on the job. The receptionist simply does not have the luxury of being able to slump, head in hands, and curse loudly in the middle of the afternoon.

One fifth claimed that they felt cut off from the rest of the company, especially those working in larger organisations. Just a tip of the hat and a brief hello as the rest of the office shuffles past first thing in the morning, and last thing at night. There is no camaraderie, no banter, no picking over the details of last night's escapades. The receptionist is often viewed as the face of a company. She or he is more than likely the first person visitors will meet when they enter the building. Therefore, the receptionist has to be well-groomed and smartly turned out. There can't be any Pot Noodle on your blouse, or spinach stuck between your teeth in this game. Some large firms even give their receptionists a clothing allowance to ensure that they always look presentable.

Crucially, the receptionist has to appear approachable. It is the absolute antithesis of the sneery reception you get in designer clothing stores, where no one wants to help you, and you really don't want to ask whether they have this spangly frock in your size. This is where the smiling comes in. A genuine-looking, open-lipped smile suggests warmth and openness. It puts a visitor at ease.

But being a receptionist is not merely about answering telephones and calling up to the fourth floor to say "Mr Jones, Mr Garfunkel is in reception". It is often about dealing with customers or clients who are upset, or annoyed, or downright livid. The receptionist may have to bear the brunt of a visitor's dissatisfaction with the company as a whole, or with having to wait to speak to somebody in the firm, or even with the fact that he missed his train to work this morning and had to fork out for a cab. Some customers may even be violent or threatening. Indeed, the Maine-Tucker report found that 28% of those surveyed wanted to be treated with more respect by both staff and visitors.

At a time when the role of the secretary is viewed as increasingly vital, where a business can't tick without someone who understands the technology and all the nitty-gritty of running the office, receptionists are feeling particularly overlooked. The potential for promotion from a secretarial position is ever more likely. But for a receptionist to hotfoot it up the career ladder from the lobby is a substantially more difficult task. It is in smaller companies, especially in start-ups, that receptionists feel their role is more valued. fields.bodyText: While you are reading this I would like you to smile. Think chipmunk, think Carol Smillie. No flagging you there at the back. And why am I asking you to grin loonishly in the office, or on the train, or while pouring out your cornflakes? Because I would like you to understand what it is like to be a receptionist. I would like you to have an inkling of how it feels to smile, unwaveringly, for a sizeable part of the day. But beneath this chirpy exterior, the life of the receptionist is, allegedly, a miserable affair. It is like Judy Garland, concealing her tragedy behind that glittering showbiz persona, or Smokey Robinson, his smile looking so very out of place, as he tried to hide The Tracks of His Tears. A third of surveyed receptionists complained that they were bored in their job. One hesitates to point out that being bored in your job is rather par for the course. It is like going to school and hating double maths lessons, even if you are the maths teacher. Show me a chartered accountant who isn't bored rigid with the tedium of spreadsheets. That said, of course, the receptionist has the responsibility of not looking bored in the slightest. All yawns must be stifled, and there is no slouching on the job. The receptionist simply does not have the luxury of being able to slump, head in hands, and curse loudly in the middle of the afternoon. One fifth claimed that they felt cut off from the rest of the company, especially those working in larger organisations. Just a tip of the hat and a brief hello as the rest of the office shuffles past first thing in the morning, and last thing at night. webTitle: Mass pyre consumes hundreds of pigs

fields.headline: Mass pyre consumes hundreds of pigs
fields.standfirst:
Grim task gets under way in Northumberland

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Grim task gets under way in Northumberland.
fields.body:
In any other circumstances, it might have seemed like a giant celebration: a flicker of lights from a string of torches thrown into a giant bonfire. Within seconds, flames were licking the Northumberland sky. Traffic came to a halt. Roads were closed, aircraft were diverted. Soon a long column of smoke was drifting eastwards, smothering the stars on a crystal clear night and the grim reality of the exercise became apparent.

This was a funeral, of sorts - the first in a series of mass cremations designed to rid Britain of a 21st-century scourge that many thought had been consigned to history a quarter of a century ago.

The pyre lighting up Northumberland marked the first visible sign of a crisis that could bring British farming to its knees as hundreds of pigs identified as the likely source of Britain's foot and mouth outbreak were incinerated on tonnes of coal, brushwood and railway sleepers.

After a weekend operation to kill 850 pigs from two farms at Heddon-on-the-Wall, along with 35 cattle, animals doused with oil and diesel were placed on a 150 metre-long trench, and slowly set alight just before 9pm last night. By all accounts, the stench of rotting, burning flesh near the trench was all-pervading. But from a hill less than half a mile away, just above the Tyne Valley - the closest anyone was allowed to the pyre - the reality of death for this little corner of British farming, and the agricultural community, was hard to appreciate. This was simply a spectacle.

In below-freezing temperatures, Ministry of Agriculture vets worked against the clock under arc lights to dispose of the carcasses on the pyre - likely to burn for 24 hours - before more heavy snow was due. They will be at it again, possibly tomorrow, at a farm barely four miles away where 40 cattle have been slaughtered.

Hours earlier ministry officials revealed they had been concerned about activities at Burnside farm, Heddon-on-the-Wall, for months after complaints about poor welfare at the holding. Vets had served its operators with a notice in December warning that conditions must be improved within a month, it was revealed. When they returned late in January, vets reported that conditions had got better - although they were still not adequate, the ministry said. A further visit had been planned for this month but plans were overtaken by the foot and mouth outbreak.

But the ministry said that, late in January, there were no traces of foot and mouth in pigs at the farm, in effect a fattening centre where animals were sent before a long journey to abattoirs in the south.

Death came speedily to Burnside yesterday. Carefully laying 250 railway sleepers across the pit, ministry experts and labourers piled 75 tonnes of coal and two lorry loads of straw onto a giant pyre before adding the pigs and cattle in what amounted to a two-day long construction exercise. Cremations on this scale do not come quickly, or cheaply.

Clad in bright yellow and red overalls, they had supervised mechanical excavators and tractors hauling dumper trucks carrying the remains of pigs from two farms at Heddon-on-the-Wall - Bobby and Ronald Waughs holding at Burnside, with its 500 animals, believed to be the original source, and Jimmy and Joan Brown's neighbouring unit at Heddon View, with 350 pigs and 35 cattle.

After taking blood samples from the pigs, ministry vets had been humanely killing the animals over two days with stun guns, carefully recording particulars from each beast. After slaughter, they soon discovered that the Heddon View pigs, initially condemned to death as a precaution, also had traces of foot and mouth - making the outbreak far bigger than initial estimates suggested.

The Browns, who have been keeping pigs at Heddon View for 35 years, are reluctant to criticise their neighbours and have refused to join in the chorus of disapproval against the Waugh brothers, who have insisted in a statement issued through the National Farmers' Union that it was not in their interest to have unhealthy pigs. But Joan Brown told a local paper yesterday: "It's just unfortunate they didn't farm the same way we farmed."

With farmers in Northumberland fearful of the disease spreading - cattle at another farm beside Newcastle airport four miles away have already been condemned - the ministry said last night it had been forced to take action after the RSPCA was refused access to Burnside following a complaint to the Association by the Norfolk-based Hillside Animal Sanctuary on December 18. The sanctuary said it had been told by a reliable Northumberland contact that rotting pig carcasses had been left alongside live pigs and that pieces of raw meat were left lying around the farm.

After visiting the stricken area yesterday, Joyce Quin, minister of state for agriculture, said that while the ministry was always concerned about welfare matters, it would be wrong to prejudge the outcome of any inquiry. Asked about local people raising fears over Burnside several months ago, she said officials on January 24 saw no sign of disease at the farm.

"Obviously, welfare-related problems are pursued also - sometimes by a slightly different avenue - but the responsibility of the department on that inspection was to see whether there was disease on the farm and at that point they did not find disease. But let me say a number of inquiries are being made as a result of the outbreak here and while I cannot prejudge the outcome of those I am very keen that the inquiry should be as thorough as possible."

She said the department took welfare concerns very seriously and took action when there was enough evidence to prosecute.

webTitle: Farmers' hopes go up in flames

fields.headline: Farmers' hopes go up in flames
fields.standfirst:
 Epidemic looms as foot and mouth spreads to south-west
 Fires lit to burn slaughtered beasts
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A new outbreak of foot and mouth disease at a cattle and sheep farm in Devon yesterday demolished hopes of containing the disease and raised the spectre of a countrywide epidemic. There were even fears the disease might have already reached mainland Europe.
fields.body:
A new outbreak of foot and mouth disease at a cattle and sheep farm in Devon yesterday demolished hopes of containing the disease and raised the spectre of a countrywide epidemic. There were even fears the disease might have already reached mainland Europe.

As fires burned the carcasses of hundreds of condemned animals in Northumberland and Essex last night, the latest outbreak in cattle was confirmed at Burdon Farm, Highampton, the home of a large-scale sheep dealer, Willy Cleave, who exports to Europe via Dover.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said the European commission had been informed of the risk that infected sheep might have been exported from the Highampton farm. A large number of sheep were exported on February 17 and the last live exports were at 3am last Tuesday - hours before the first case of foot and mouth was confirmed at an Essex abattoir.

A suspected case of the disease was also being investigated at an abattoir on Anglesey, north Wales, last night. Samples were taken for analy sis from premises at Gaerwen. The area around the abattoir was sealed off.

Mr Cleave has 13 farms and travelled as far north as Carlisle last week to visit markets. It emerged last night that some of the sheep he exported might have come from Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland, providing the link with other outbreaks for which the Ministry of Agriculture is looking.

Mr Cleave said last night that the disease could have come on to his farm through animals bought at market. "We buy a lot of sheep and deal in a lot, and we were unlucky. Some must have been contaminated with foot and mouth.

"I was checking them and I noticed something was wrong. It has been a big shock."

The grim task of burning the carcasses of 450 cattle, 1,300 pigs and 250 sheep has begun, with a pyre lighting up Northumberland, and giant bonfires on a farm at Little Warley, Essex, last night.

Jim Scudamore, the government's chief vet, confirmed that the Devon outbreak was the largest so far. The farm has 600 cattle and 1,500 sheep.

The other 12 farms involved, 10 in Devon and two in Cornwall, have also been isolated. Ministry policy is to destroy all animals which might develop the disease through contact with infected animals.

Mr Brown, who hopes to make a Commons statement today, said: "This new Devon case is clearly a very serious development which means there could be other cases out there. It vindicates the decision we made on Friday to stop all animal movements."

The National Farmers' Union president, Ben Gill, said: "The latest outbreak will send a chill through farmers. Our hopes that the disease could be contained have been horribly shattered."

Longtown market, near Carlisle, where Mr Cleave was a trader, took sheep from Heddon, where pigs are now known to have had the disease for up to a month before it was discovered on Thursday.

The disease can travel many miles on the wind. So far no sheep have been confirmed with foot and mouth, but they were present on Prestwick Hill Farm, Ponteland, Northumberland, four miles from Heddon, which became the sixth confirmed case on Friday.

The dramatic events in Devon unfolded overnight on Saturday as samples from a sick cow were rushed to the World Reference Laboratory for foot and mouth disease at Pirbright in Surrey. The disease was confirmed yesterday.

Ian Johnson, regional spokesman for the National Farmers' Union, said: "This is potentially a nightmare scenario for the south-west, which is Britain's biggest livestock area. In good times it would be a disaster but in times like these it is a catastrophe."

Mr Brown will fly to Brussels tomorrow to brief his EU opposite numbers, who are concerned that the UK may have exported foot and mouth.

webTitle: Kournikova came to stay - and bugged us all day long

fields.headline: Kournikova came to stay - and bugged us all day long
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The internet only appears to be making news these days when things go wrong. Online porn scandals and the latest high profile company going bust makes for interesting, if sometimes shocking, reading.
fields.body:
The internet only appears to be making news these days when things go wrong. Online porn scandals and the latest high profile company going bust makes for interesting, if sometimes shocking, reading.

Recently it was the return of computer virus headlines - this time concerning one whose success in propagating itself was based on the appeal of Russian tennis player Anna Kournikova.

Recipients of a rogue email were invited to open an attachment to view pictures of the popular player. On doing so the recipient unwittingly made the email reproduce, sending itself to everyone in the recipient's address book.

Of course, it gave the media another opportunity to print pictures of the glamorous Ms Kournikova.

It was also the first virus to successfully evade our security systems. We avoided the largest previous scare, when the "I love you" virus struck in May last year, damaging thousands of computer files and causing millions of pounds worth of damage.

Thankfully the Kournikova virus was less malevolent. The primary risk was that the reproduction of emails would overload email systems. With the email capacity we have in place, this was never going to be a danger.

The virus did spread amazingly fast - evidence of how highly interconnected businesses and consumers are these days - or perhaps of the sad nature of email users.

The first reported notification of the virus occurred around 1.20pm on the Monday afternoon. We received our copy by 3pm. At this time, there was no remedy. By 6pm we were able to visit our anti-virus software company's website to download a patch to sort out the problem.

As might be imagined, as an online financial services business, we have incredibly strict processes involved to protect ourselves from precisely this sort of attack. We scan every incoming mail and every file downloaded from the internet. For this we employ a virus scanning software that is one of the most highly rated in the market.

Normally we update the software every two days to protect against the latest viruses. Recently we have been updating it automatically every four hours - the period around Valentine's day is believed to be a favourite time for those producing the viruses.

The only additional precaution remaining to us would be to ban all attachments from incoming emails.

Several banks and firms in specific, sensitive, functional areas have taken this step. We have not done so yet because we believe that the benefits of being able to freely exchange files and data outweigh the risks.

What this recent virus outbreak confirms is that you cannot plan and protect yourself against every possible scenario.

Our chief technology officer has been warning of this fact since we started. What is as important is that you have the right processes in place to check the problem when it does occur.

In this case staff were sufficiently aware of the dangers posed by viruses to identify when "Kournikova" had been released. Quick communication meant we caught it quickly before it could do any damage.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools, an online payments service for teenagers

webTitle: Liberalisation? Don't reject it just yet

fields.headline: Liberalisation? Don't reject it just yet
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: A monstrous plot is afoot. Public schools and hospitals are under threat. So is the right of governments to set standards that protect our health and environment. The World Trade Organisation is trying to resurrect the ill-fated Multilateral Agreement on Investment, or MAI. It must be stopped before it is too late.
fields.body:
A monstrous plot is afoot. Public schools and hospitals are under threat. So is the right of governments to set standards that protect our health and environment. The World Trade Organisation is trying to resurrect the ill-fated Multilateral Agreement on Investment, or MAI. It must be stopped before it is too late.

WTO critics have always taken liberties with the truth. But the lies and distortions they are peddling about the WTO's services agreement, Gats, are astounding.

Freeing up trade in commercial services - everything from telecoms and tourism to finance and freight transport - offers huge benefits for every part of the world.

That is why the WTO's 140 member governments are negotiating further services liberalisation in Geneva. Those talks, and the WTO's existing services agreement, do not threaten governments' ability to provide public services, their right to regulate, or their scope to impose restrictions on foreign investment.

Commercial services account for three fifths of the world economy but only a fifth of world trade.

Clearly, there is huge scope to expand services trade. Just as liberalising trade in goods has boosted economic growth over the past 50 years, so liberalising trade in services could bring huge benefits over the next 50.

Allowing foreign suppliers to compete with domestic ones lowers prices, improves quality and increases choice.

For developing countries it also means access to vital tech nology and capital investment in underdeveloped infrastructure. An efficient service sector is also the backbone of a successful economy: without efficient finance, telecoms and transport, a country cannot competitively produce textiles, tomatoes or whatever.

An added bonus of liberalising at the WTO is that governments can credibly commit to keep their markets open. That provides stability and predictability for business, which encourages trade and investment and means more jobs and more tax revenue for participating governments.

Gats is an incredibly flexible agreement. It spells out a few general obligations, notably that countries must not discriminate between foreign suppliers. But otherwise, governments have huge scope to choose the areas to which they want to commit themselves.

They can choose which sectors they want to agree to open up to foreigners - and in the sectors in which they choose to make commitments, governments can set limits on how far they want to open their markets to foreigners and the extent to which they want to treat foreign suppliers like domestic ones.

For instance, they might allow cross-border software trade, but prevent a foreign software company from setting up shop in their domestic market. Or they might encourage tourists to visit, but prevent foreign tourist guides from coming to work. Last, governments can even request exemptions, which in principle would be limited to 10 years, to their general obligation not to discriminate between foreign suppliers.

This is hardly an MAI mark II by the back door.

The ill-fated MAI was an agreement on foreign investment. Governments can, if they want, use Gats to attract inward funding by guaranteeing to potential investors that they will not suddenly change the rules of the game.

But multinationals or other service suppliers cannot simply go into any WTO member country and buy anything and everything. Member governments decide which services foreigners are allowed to provide and under which conditions. Nothing stops governments from favouring domestic suppliers of a service over foreign ones if they want to.

Of course, most governments now welcome foreign investment with open arms rather than trying to protect themselves from it.

It is the lack of investment that is the problem for many countries: Singapore gets more investment than the whole of Africa. It is also nonsense that Gats undermines governments' ability to set standards to protect the public or the environment. The right to regulate the supply of services is one of the basic principles. Foreign suppliers have to comply with all domestic regulations; the rules do not have to be modified for their benefit.

Liberalisation means allowing foreign suppliers to compete - it does not imply deregulation. Moreover, governments can take any measures necessary to protect human, animal or plant life or health, so long as they do not constitute unjustifiable discrimination or disguised protectionism. This overrides any other provision in Gats.

Perhaps the most damaging claim is that Gats threatens governments' ability to provide the public services that we all cherish, such as schools and hospitals. Gats, it is said, will force governments to privatise public services and open them up to foreign competition.

That is just not true. Gats explicitly excludes services supplied by governments. True, governments can agree to allow foreign suppliers to provide private healthcare or education.

But that is not the same as privatising public services. Nor does that imply compromising standards - governments can enforce the same standards on foreign suppliers as on nationals. They can even impose additional requirements on foreigners if they wish.

Lopping a third off barriers to trade in services would add $390bn to the world economy, according to a study by Robert Stern of the university of Michigan. That means more jobs, higher living standards and more for governments to spend. It is too big a prize to let slip because of misplaced fears about the WTO's services talks.

webTitle: New fears of a fixture wipeout

fields.headline: New fears of a fixture wipeout
fields.standfirst:
Jockey Club meets this morning to discuss crisis

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: With grim predictions that the current foot and mouth outbreak could be worse than in 1967, racing must face up to the fact that a total shut down of activity is beginning to look much more likely.
fields.body:
With grim predictions that the current foot and mouth outbreak could be worse than in 1967, racing must face up to the fact that a total shut down of activity is beginning to look much more likely.

This and contingency plans for the postponement of the Cheltenham Festival will be discussed by the racing authorities and the Ministry of Agriculture this morning, although no definitive decision is likely at this stage.

It was Anthony Gibson, south west director of the National Farmers' Union, who warned yesterday about the severity of the crisis facing the country following another confirmed case of foot and mouth in a farm in North Devon. Gibson said: "I fear that the latest outbreak of this disease could be even worse than 33 years ago."

On that occasion racing ground to a halt for six weeks and depending on when it was imposed a similar suspension could mean that the Grand National, scheduled for April 7, could be lost as well as Cheltenham.

Whether these fixtures can be rearranged will be part of the agenda this morning when representatives of the British Horseracing Board, the Jockey Club, the National Trainers' Federation, the Racecourse Association and the Animal Health Trust will get their heads together.

Tristram Ricketts, secretary general of the BHB, said: "We have been keeping in touch with the appropriate authorities and there is no indication as yet that a cessation of racing is necessary other than in the exclusion zones. We are, of course, carrying out disinfectant precautions at all tracks.

"If it continues to spread, however, then anything is possible and the Cheltenham Festival is only two weeks away. But as yet no contingency plans have been drawn up."

One piece of good news is that the suspected outbreak of the disease at Stroud, less than 30 miles from Cheltenham, has not been confirmed.

A spokesperson for the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food commented yesterday: "MAFF has not said anything about stopping racing yet as long as all correct precautions are taken."

However, the agriculture minister Nick Brown is likely to take a much stronger line if the country's worse fears are realised in the next few days.

Horses cannot catch foot and mouth, but it can spread rapidly among livestock and the movement of horseboxes and people around the country is regarded as potentially dangerous.

Peter Webbon, chief veterinary advisor to the Jockey Club, said: "By pulling people together, and racing crowds are often mainly from rural areas, there is a possibility that the disease could be spread. But as I see it this would apply to rugby matches just as much, although not football as this is mainly an urban game."

The Irish agriculture minister Joe Walsh is far from happy and is reported to be considering imposing a ban on Irish runners at the Cheltenham Festival. Ireland missed the outbreak in this country 33 years ago and there has been no sign of the disease in the country since 1941.

Any ban, however, by the Irish would not necessarily be as drastic as it sounds and Aidan O'Brien's Istabraq could still defend his Champion Hurdle crown provided the gelding remained in this country until after the disease had subsided.

Willie Mullins, trainer of Cheltenham Gold Cup hope Florida Pearl, commented: "If there was a risk that the horses may not be allowed back into Ireland straight away then most of mine would probably stay at home and wait for Punchestown in April."

But Francois Doumen, the French trainer, is determined to press ahead with the Gold Cup favourite First Gold's Cheltenham challenge.

Speaking at Kempton on Saturday, he said: "My runners here will go home tonight and I see no reason to change my plans at the moment.

"There is no question of them staying in this country until Cheltenham.

"I cannot see the French authorities intervening to say there should be no movement across the Channel at this stage, but if they did my horses would come over as normal and stay on after Cheltenham."

fields.headline: Sir Donald Bradman dies, aged 92
fields.standfirst: Greatest cricketer of the 20th century dominated his sport
fields.trailText: Greatest cricketer of the 20th century dominated his sport.
fields.body:
Sir Donald Bradman, the greatest cricketer of the 20th century, has died in Adelaide at the age of 92.

The Australian batsman, whose Test batting average of 99.94 has never been rivalled, died at his home, according to ABC radio reports.

From 1930 until his fourth tour of England in 1948 Bradman dominated the world batting scene. As Australia's captain he displayed the same clinical judgment and unbroken concentration that were the essence of his batsmanship.

His batting possessed a ruthlessness and singlemindedness and his domination over all types of bowling eventually became so complete that even his greatest admirers admitted that a contest could often lose interest for becoming too one-sided.

For years after his retirement as a player, he was the eminence grise of Australian cricket with a journalist once dubbing him "the Australian cricketing Tsar".

But ironically, this month saw the 30th anniversary of his resignation as a Test selector - during the 1970-71 Ashes series, which England won 2-0.

That was only England's second series win in Australia since the notorious 1932-33 Bodyline series in which Bradman had played.

For all the adulation, Bradman had a lonely side. He preferred to remain apart from team camaraderie and after his retirement in 1948 protected his privacy.

He averaged a century in every three innings he played in a 21-year first-class career.

Early this year Bradman was reported to be resting at home in Adelaide after a bout of pneumonia had put him into hospital before Christmas. His son John issued a statement on January 11 about his father's health following a rash of speculation that he was close to death.

"Prior to Christmas he was in hospital with pneumonia," John Bradman said. "He was very pleased to return home and is now there resting under medical supervision.

"The family recognises that there is legitimate interest in the health and wellbeing of my father but we ask that everyone respects his privacy."

Wisden, the cricket bible, last year named Bradman the best cricketer of the 20th century. He scored 6,996 Test runs during the 1930s and 1940s.

The director of the Bradman Foundation, Richard Mulvaney, confirmed his death yesterday. "Sir Donald Bradman died yesterday morning, peacefully at his home, after a short illness with pneumonia," Mr Mulvaney said.

In August, Bradman broke a long public silence to deliver a message about the state of cricket. "As my days on earth rapidly draw to a close," he said, "I am proud to have set an example of all that is best in our noble game.

"Despite recent sad developments, cricket will survive and remain our most noble game and I shall always remain proud of the part I played in its history and development."

webTitle: Russian faces spy trial over UK trip

fields.headline: Russian faces spy trial over UK trip
fields.standfirst:
British contacts vanish after meeting arms control expert

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Facing charges of state treason and spying for the west, Igor Sutyagin, a 36-year-old father of two and academic expert on Russian-American arms control, goes on trial this morning in the district court of Kaluga, south of Moscow.
fields.body:
When Igor Sutyagin turned up at an international security conference at the University of Birmingham three years ago last week the brilliant young Russian had little inkling that the contacts he struck up could bring him a 20-year term rotting in a Russian jail.

Facing charges of state treason and spying for the west, the 36-year-old father of two and academic expert on Russian-American arms control goes on trial this morning in the district court of Kaluga south of Moscow.

The case, brought by Russian counter-intelligence, the FSB, will be heard in closed session. The investigation is also secret. After being held on remand for more than a year it was only recently that Mr Sutyagin learned that the charges relate to the handover to alleged American agents of information on Russian nuclear submarines. He could be sentenced to 20 years if found guilty, and there are few precedents for acquittals in Russian treason trials.

Mr Sutyagin's relatives, fellow scholars, and international associates are fearful for the fate of a respected colleague they insist could never have been a spy.

Letters have been written, appeals dispatched, and websites organised complaining of harassment and intimidation of researchers in President Vladimir Putin's Russia.

But the British subject Mr Sutyagin admits he met that February weekend in 1998 in Birmingham has failed to surface to assist the suspect. Nor has that person's alleged British business associate, whom Mr Sutyagin met several times. And the London-based company the two men claimed to represent has also mysteriously vanished.

The alleged risk analysis consultancy is no longer at the London address known to Mr Sutyagin, although the Russian has visited the putative firm's London office and described the premises to his FSB interrogators. Nor is the firm responding to emails.

"I wish these people would just come out and tell their story," said Sergei Rogov, Mr Sutyagin's boss and director of the USA-Canada Institute, one of the most prestigious foreign and security policy thinktanks in Moscow. "I've no idea who the hell these people are. It sounds like something from John Le Carré. Are they just going to wash their hands of it and see a young man destroyed?"

A physicist and historian from the town of Obninsk, a Soviet-era closed town of scientists south of Moscow, Mr Sutyagin joined the Moscow thinktank as a postgraduate student in 1988 and had risen to head its military-political studies department by the time he was arrested in October 1999. He was charged with treason shortly thereafter.

Mr Sutyagin worked exclusively with open sources and his institute has no access to Russian classified materials, although the 1987 law on treason is deliberately vague and the passing of unclassified analysis to foreign agents can be prosecuted as espionage.

After being approached by the Briton in Birmingham, Mr Sutyagin, who was paid £70 a month by his institute, agreed to work as a consultant for the alleged London firm. Over the next 18 months, he has told the FSB, he earned some £14,000 pounds from the company, which also paid his travel expenses to around a dozen meetings with either or both of his British contacts in Birmingham again, London, Brussels, Budapest, Warsaw, and Rome.

"The prosecution," said Boris Kuznetsov, Mr Sutyagin's lawyer, "claims the company was a front organisation for US military intelligence. The two men were British subjects, the firm was British, but they were working for the Americans."

The names of the two men and the firm are known to the Guardian.

"The FSB says 30 subjects were discussed, 12 of them classified as secret, including naval affairs, submarines, nuclear missiles, deployments of Russian armed forces and the processes of Russian military decision-taking," Mr Kuznetsov said.

"Igor doesn't deny being at these meetings. He doesn't deny discussing these issues. He does not deny taking the money. But he did not know they were intelligence agents."

"He's a rare species, Igor," said Mr Rogov. "I've known him for 22 years. He's much more patriotic and nationalistic than me. I could never believe he's the kind of person who would intentionally harm Russia."

fields.headline: Turkey's central bank governor resigns
fields.trailText: Turkey's central bank governor, Gazi Ercel, has resigned following the financial crisis that saw the lira drop 36% last week, according to reports published in Turkish newspapers yesterday.
fields.body:
Turkey's central bank governor, Gazi Ercel, has resigned following the financial crisis that saw the lira drop 36% last week, according to reports published in Turkish newspapers yesterday.

Mr Ercel did not attend a meeting of cabinet ministers including the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, on Saturday with the heads of private and state banks.

The Hurriyet newspaper reported that it appeared likely that the treasury secretary, Selcuk Demiralp, and the head of a state bank would also resign.

Saturday's meeting came in the wake of the arrival on Friday in Ankara of a deputation of IMF officials to discuss a new structural reform programme for the country. On the same day, President George Bush rang Mr Ecevit to offer his support for the administration amid widespread domestic speculation about a cabinet reshuffle.

The crisis erupted last Monday when, after a series of public disagreements, Mr Ecevit stormed out of a meeting with President Ahmet Necdet Sezer. The premier said he was upset by the president's criticism of the government's anti-corruption measures.

The political turmoil sent the stock market into a freefall and interest rates rocketing. On Thursday the government ended the lira's crawling peg against the US dollar after money market interest rates reached 5,000%.

fields.headline: Tube journey times getting longer
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Journeys on the tube are taking an average of eight minutes longer than they should, even by London Underground management's own calculations, according to a series of performance indicators just prepared for the board of Transport for London and seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Journeys on the tube are taking an average of eight minutes longer than they should, even by London Underground management's own calculations, according to a series of performance indicators just prepared for the board of Transport for London and seen by the Guardian.

In October and November about 10% of escalators were out of service. There were more than 1000 peak train cancellations in December and a third of those were because no driver had turned up.

The Piccadilly line lost more than a fifth of its scheduled trains, the Bakerloo line nearly a quarter. Across the whole network, more than 10% of scheduled trains did not run that month.

The figures reveal remarkable differences between lines and highlight areas where there seem to be particular management and absenteeism problems.

The Bakerloo, District, Circle and Hammersmith lines stand out as having problems with "no operator" - that is, no driver arriving for a scheduled train.

The information on the tube's performance has been collected by the greater London authority's Transport for London board as it tries to work out what it will take on when the transport commissioner, Robert Kiley, and the government agree a new structure for the underground.

Wrangling over the underground reached a new intensity over the weekend, with Mr Kiley accusing the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of blocking progress on talks about a new structure of ownership. Mr Kiley's team said that the government's public-private partnership (PPP) scheme would cost up to £800m more in its first period than its own proposals.

Mr Kiley maintains that the public-private partnership plan is fatally flawed, and that there must be unified management control of the underground.

Tensions within the government have become apparent. The prime minister, Tony Blair, Mr Brown and the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, are expected to meet today to try to reach an agreement.

The cost of financing investment in the tube could be 25% higher, or £800m more in the first 7 years, under the PPP proposal than under revised plans put forward by Mr Kiley.
