fields.headline: Pressure mounts on Mugabe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: International pressure is mounting for measures to be taken against the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, to protest against his assaults on judges, journalists and opposition leaders.
fields.body:
International pressure is mounting for measures to be taken against the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, to protest against his assaults on judges, journalists and opposition leaders.

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, yesterday called for a delegation of Commonwealth leaders to be sent to Harare to demand the president's resignation, while the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, said he would meet Mr Mugabe to encourage him to abide by the rule of law.

"It is high time Britain called for the Commonwealth to withdraw the cloak of respectability that its membership gives to Mr Mugabe," Mr Maude said at the end of a two-day visit to Zimbabwe.

"Such strong action is needed because of the wholesale human rights abuses, the beatings and intimidation, Mr Mugabe's recent actions to suppress the media, the breakdown of the rule of law, the attacks on the judiciary and his management of an economy which is cratering. The list of objections is a long one."

Moving beyond his previous calls for Zimbabwe to be suspended from the Commonwealth, Mr Maude said the British government should work for international measures to be taken against Mr Mugabe's senior deputies. "There should be targeted action by the international community against the individuals who support Mr Mugabe and who are responsible for appalling conduct. Such action could include bans on international travel, investigations into overseas bank accounts and investigations into past wrongdoings that could go all the way back to the Matabeleland massacres in the mid 1980s."

Mr Maude suggested that Britain and the Commonwealth could send a delegation of eminent persons to offer "a dignified exit for Mr Mugabe".

Mr Mbeki said he planned to express his "serious concern" to Mr Mugabe. He said Mr Mugabe's policies had created such chaos in Zimbabwe that it had "impacted negatively" on South Africa. The spectre of Zimbabwe's rapid economic decline and the erosion of respect for the law is widely blamed for falls in the South African currency and a drop in the Johannesburg stock exchange.

Mr Mbeki has been criticised for being too soft on Mr Mugabe, despite telling him publicly last year that he should follow Zimbabwe's existing laws to resolve the country's land problems.

South Africa's state-owned power company, Escom, provides Zimbabwe with more than 30% of its electrical power. Zimbabwe has run up an estimated $20m debt with Escom, so Mr Mbeki could threaten to turn off the lights.

webTitle: Many ignored advice to stay away from the countryside

fields.headline: Many ignored advice to stay away from the countryside
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: It was billed as possibly Britain's quietest weekend in the country for years, with farm leaders, the government and recreation groups all advising people to stay out of fields and away from livestock. Fat chance.
fields.body:
It was billed as possibly Britain's quietest weekend in the country for years, with farm leaders, the government and recreation groups all advising people to stay out of fields and away from livestock. Fat chance.

It was a beautiful day with clear skies, a watery sun, and overnight snow sprinkling the fells and hills of Britain from the Lake District to Devon. But what Keith Alcroft, in the High Peak national park, Derbyshire, saw yesterday afternoon from his remote farm, took his breath away.

Normally on a February weekend, he would be able to see 20 miles of footpath and bridleway and there would be just a few people around. Instead he could see lines of walkers, horse riders, motorcross enthusiasts, mountainbikers and hang-gliders.

"They just don't bloody well care at all, do they? There's more people out there today than there usually are. The public's attitude to the crisis is quite appalling," he said.

"In the 1967 outbreaks, they shut all the footpaths and there was no one out at all. Now they are walking through the farms, going everywhere. What are we farmers meant to do?"

But in the Lake District it was a different story, with "most people observing the official advice", according to veteran Guardian country diarist Harry Griffin, 90. "The weather is crisp, it's an outstandingly marvellous day," he reported, "but I have seen no one out on the footpaths at all.

"The local ramblers have asked everyone to stay away from the fells and there are big signs in Keswick advising people not to go out on the fells, and that seems to have been followed. People are highly sympathetic to the farmers here."

Shropshire, where the 1967 outbreak started, was deserted. "It's the silent spring here," said ecologist Paul Evans. "The woods are full of deer but there's no one about at all. You can almost feel the tension in the land. There are no signs saying that anything is wrong but you can feel it. A lot of older people here remember the 1967 foot and mouth outbreaks. There's a lot of paranoia, but it seems very unreal for the youngsters."

In Somerset, one of the heartlands of the livestock industry, there were few signs that anything could be wrong. "Life is very much as normal, here," said John Vallins, who lives near Glastonbury.

"There are lots of walkers out. The advice seems not to have been heeded, but there's no sign of disinfected straw at farm gates. The farmers have taken in most of their cattle, so there are only sheep and people about."

But in the Yorkshire Dales, most people were observing the advice, said Peter Bowler, who works with the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust. "There's little traffic around. Walkers are going on woodland trails rather than over open fields. There's far fewer people than you would expect," he said.

Elsewhere, it was a mixed story. In Pembrokeshire, west Wales, there were prayers for farmers in the local churches, but no great agitation on the land or signs of trouble. "Most farmers have taken their cattle indoors, but the sheep are lambing on the hills and the farmers seem unaffected at the moment," said one woman. "There does seem to be fewer people around, even though it's the end of half term," she said.

Colin Luckhurst, another Guardian country diarist, drove from Plymouth to Gloucestershire yesterday morning, but saw no signs of the crisis. "In 1967 you could see the smoke of funeral pyres and the land was silent. It's very early still, but you would be hard put to tell that something's wrong."

Leading countryside writer Richard Mabey said there was little sign in the Chilterns that people had taken the official advice. "There are lots of walking parties out and people in the villages," he said.

webTitle: Lehman boost for Luke Johnson's pub ambitions

fields.headline: Lehman boost for Luke Johnson's pub ambitions
fields.trailText: Pizza entrepreneur Luke Johnson's plan to become one of Britain's leading pub landlords by buying 3,000 pubs from Whitbread received a boost yesterday after it emerged that Lehman Brothers is prepared to fill the financing void left by his original backer pulling out.
fields.body:
Pizza entrepreneur Luke Johnson's plan to become one of Britain's leading pub landlords by buying 3,000 pubs from Whitbread received a boost yesterday after it emerged that Lehman Brothers is prepared to fill the financing void left by his original backer pulling out.

Mr Johnson had first teamed up with Schroder Ventures to bid for Whitbread's £1.5bn pub estate, but the private equity specialist is understood to have decided against any deal about 10 days ago, leaving his bid to founder.

US investment bank Lehman and the venture capital firm, Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, now appear ready to back the entrepreneur, whose other interests include Belgo, the mussels and chips restaurant group that also owns the Ivy and Le Caprice outlets.

Mr Johnson could not be reached for comment yesterday, but a source close to the deal confirmed that the two institutions were prepared to back him.

Lehman is said to be ready to provide a loan of £1.5bn over 10 years. Morgan Grenfell, which has bought into formula one and bookmaker Coral with mixed success, appears to still have an appetite for high profile transactions, and may provide some of the required £150m equity.

The auction of Whitbread's pubs is well under way, and Mr Johnson faces some stiff competition. Venture capital firm Candover is thought to be backing a management buy-out team at Whitbread, while Japanese bank Nomura - which is Britain's biggest pub landlord - is thought to be preparing a bid.

Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, the investment bank handling the auction, hopes to find a preferred bidder within the next month.

If Mr Johnson were successful he would be pitched into a battle of landlords with his PizzaExpress co-founder Hugh Osmond. Punch Taverns, Mr Osmond's pub firm, has built up a portfolio of 5,000 pubs in less than two years. He epitomises the younger entrepreneurs taking over from big firms as Britain's most influential landlords.

The principal architect of Nomura's foray into pubs has been fortysomething finance chief Guy Hands. About 10% of Britain's 65,000 pubs are on the market as companies focus on branded bar chains. Some analysts think fashions are changing, and that local pubs could represent solid long-term investments at their share prices' present depressed levels.

webTitle: Lira collapse driven by panic not logic

fields.headline: Lira collapse driven by panic not logic
fields.trailText: Is the financial collapse in Turkey the start of another emerging markets meltdown like the Asian crisis?
fields.body:
Is the financial collapse in Turkey the start of another emerging markets meltdown like the Asian crisis?

So far, no, but it's a bit early to declare the danger over. The lira has lost more than 30% of its value since the government stopped trying to prop it up last week.

That makes Turkey's large foreign debt more expensive to repay because most of the loans were made in dollars. As a result, Turkey's already wobbly banking system is under further pressure.

Why did the government devalue?

It had to. Overnight interest rates had risen to 4,000% as it desperately tried to hold the lira's value to the dollar. Just as in the Asian crisis, floating the currency swaps one problem for another. Interest rates have fallen back, but now foreign, not domestic borrowing is putting the strain on the financial system.

Isn't that what happened in some Asian countries?

Yes, although Turkey's debt is nothing like as big. South Korea owed foreign lenders $150bn when its financial system started crumbling. Turkish banks have borrowed around $45bn.

It's a much smaller economy and has limited trade links outside of Europe. Asia's crisis spread rapidly because many countries in the region proved to be weak when their economies came under pressure.

Luckily for Turkey it has some strong neighbours. Germany is the country most exposed to bad losses and its economy is scarcely going to be troubled by a $10bn sour investment.

So are the risks limited to Europe?

The trouble with financial crises is that they are about panic not logic.

If investors decide that emerging markets are looking dodgy again, they may pull out of the countries they consider weak, regardless of whether there is any logical link with events in Turkey.

Which countries are the likely victims?

Countries with lots of short term international borrowing are vulnerable. Within Europe, the Czech republic is a possible candidate, though its total bill isn't very high.

Argentina and Brazil owe a lot, and about half of it is short term borrowing. Another factor is currency pegs which are looking increasingly like bad idea.

When speculators take on governments, they usually win because they have more money - as is demonstrated by the ejection of the pound from the exchange rate mechanism.

Which countries still have fixed currencies?

Malaysia and Argentina still fix their currencies to the dollar.

Hong Kong has a fixed currency but it operates a system whereby it holds as many US dollars as are needed to buy every single Hong Kong dollar in circulation, thus ensuring a speculative run on the currency can always be stopped.

Most Latin American countries have abandoned pegs in favour of currency boards - like Hong Kong's - or fully adopting the dollar.

However, Africa is a different story. It has two big regional currency blocs which are pegged to the French franc and therefore the euro.

The economies of the region are weak because of falling commodity prices, and political upheaval which is also shutting down western aid programmes.

A devaluation would make political and economic sense and would have limited impact on the rest of the world because the economies are so small to begin with.

So which country is the number one candidate if the crisis spreads?

Probably Argentina. It owes a lot of money, it has a pegged currency, which is coming under increasing pressure, and it has had big inflows of "hot money" from investors in search of a quick return taking a bet that the currency peg will hold.

If the peg crumbles there will be a mad rush for the exits.

webTitle: 'Super bobbies' to go on the beat

fields.headline: 'Super bobbies' to go on the beat
fields.standfirst:
Blair will become first prime minister to visit a jail as he launches plan to tackle e-crime and reoffending

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A new strategy to tackle cyber-crime and a scheme to create a new cadre of "super bobbies" will feature alongside radical reforms to "break the cycle of reoffending" in a 10-year national crime plan to be launched by Tony Blair today.
fields.body:
A new strategy to tackle cyber-crime and a scheme to create a new cadre of "super bobbies" will feature alongside radical reforms to "break the cycle of reoffending" in a 10-year national crime plan to be launched by Tony Blair today.

Labour will outline a root-and-branch overhaul of the criminal justice system designed to drive up detection and conviction rates and begin to drive down reoffending rates among the 66,000 prison population.

This morning Mr Blair will become the first serving prime minister to visit a prison and will outline new treatment and training schemes to turn the 100,000 most persistent offenders away from an adult life as career criminals. Ministers say the reforms could provide a "pathway back to a lawful life" for many offenders.

Mr Blair will also stress the need to be ready to tackle future trends in e-crime and the threat it poses to the new media and communications industries. He will promise to build upon a new squad of 80 "cyber cops" currently being formed into a national hi-tech crime unit.

In a key element of today's package, the prime minister will signal a fundamental change of the 1991 Criminal Justice Act to allow judges to take account of previous offences when sentencing.

Downing Street sources said the change was intended to underline the government's determination to break the so-called "revolving door syndrome" in which offenders leave custody only to commit similar offences and return to court.

Ministers are also keen to see greater transparency over sentencing, along the lines of the points system for motoring offences under which a series of minor offences can lead to the loss of a licence. Sources said: "There won't be a points system as such for crime, but if, for example, an offender comes before the courts for a sixth time for shoplifting they should know beforehand where they stand and that their sentence would be harder than the first time round."

The leak of a confidential memo to the home secretary, Jack Straw, from his special adviser, Justin Russell, yesterday cast a cloud over the launch of the crime plan, which alongside a similar blueprint for the future of secondary schools forms a key part of Labour's pre-election campaign.

Paul Boateng, the Home Office minister, rejected criticism that a new plan for "custody-plus" sentences could be portrayed as a "softening" of sentencing arrangements. Currently inmates sentenced to 12 months are released after four to six months without any further supervision. The custody-plus scheme will see some offenders getting out after three to four months but then facing a further eight or nine months under rigorous supervision and monitoring. "It will not be a softer sentence but a much harder one," said Mr Boateng.

Probation sources say if current "what works" schemes were applied to those serving these shorter sentences it could cut reoffending rates by 15% to 20%. "It must make economic sense," said Harry Fletcher of the National Association of Probation Officers.

Labour intends to boost the presence of police patrols that provide reassurance to the public by creating a new class of "super bobbies" who are to be offered cash incentives to turn down promotion to other policing tasks. Ministers are concerned that too many constables give up their beat patrols just as they are getting known by their local communities.

The leaked memo confirms the government's plans to set a new target to drive up initial detection and conviction rates by ensuring that a further 100,000 crimes will end in conviction within three years partly by employing an extra 300 crown prosecutors. They will also ensure that the crown courts sit for a further 7,000 days each year to cut delays.

But the private memo counsels Mr Straw to be careful about the way he announces this part of the package as "it draws attention to the fact that clear-up rates have not improved since 1997" and points out that only 1.2m of the 5m crimes recorded by the police each year end in a conviction.

webTitle: Inquiry will clear me, says Mandelson

fields.headline: Inquiry will clear me, says Mandelson
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson said last night he was confident he would be cleared by the inquiry into the "cash for passports" affair, but insisted he would not seek a return to government.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson said last night he was confident he would be cleared by the inquiry into the "cash for passports" affair, but insisted he would not seek a return to government.

Addressing Labour party members in his Hartlepool constituency, the former Northern Ireland secretary spoke as speculation mounted that the inquiry would not clear his name over suggestions that he made inconsistent statements to cover up his role in the Hinduja passports affair.

Sir Anthony Hammond's report, due to be presented to Tony Blair shortly, is expected to absolve ministers of any impropriety over the granting of British passports to the billionaire businessmen Gopichand and Srichand Hinduja.

However, it is not expected to resolve the question of whether Mr Mandelson lied when he denied making a phone call on the matter to the Home Office minister Mike O'Brien.

Mr Mandelson, who friends have said will fight on if his name is not cleared, told his local party's annual meeting that he would concentrate on serving another full term as MP for Hartlepool.

Expressing confidence that the inquiry would focus on evidence and not be swayed by "media pressures", he said: "I firmly believe it will show I have done nothing wrong.

"But whatever the outcome, for personal reasons which I hope you will understand, I am not looking for any return to government. I want to be a parliamentarian rather than a minister, a good constituency MP and someone who continues to serve the country from that base and no other."

Friends of Mr Mandelson insist that his denial that he harbours ambitions of office should be "taken as read", though critics will point to his recent off-the-record briefings which led to reports that he could be made a European commissioner.

webTitle: Allies struggle to find 'smart' sanctions on Iraq

fields.headline: Allies struggle to find 'smart' sanctions on Iraq
fields.standfirst:
A decade after the Gulf war, experts say west will have trouble inventing acceptable new ways to bring Baghdad to heel

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A decade after the Gulf war, experts say west will have trouble inventing acceptable new ways to bring Baghdad to heel.
fields.body:
Sanctions against Iraq are "like Swiss cheese - that means they are not very effective," President George Bush said after his weekend meeting with Tony Blair. "We're going to work together to figure out a way to make them more effective," he added.

But, says Gary Sick of the Middle East Institute at Columbia University in New York, "it's really hard to come up with any kind of sanctions that people have not thought about in the last 10 years" that would pile more pressure on Saddam Hussein without harming ordinary Iraqis.

Neil Partrick, of the Royal United Services Institute in London, is equally sceptical about the search for "smart" sanctions: "What is proposed is not so much genuinely smart as an attempt to make sanctions appear smarter and more presentable."

Foreign Office sources acknowledge that smartness in presentation - grabbing the public relations initiative back from Saddam Hussein - will be at least as important as any changes in the sanctions.

Gary Hufbauer, of the Washington-based Institute for International Economics, has studied smart - or targeted - sanctions dating back to 1932, and has found about 20 examples, usually implemented as part of a broader policy.

Just five of these were successful in achieving their intended aims, he says - a worse record than the 34% success rate for sanctions in general during the 20th century.

"It's hard to say there's a silver bullet here," Mr Hufbauer says. "But the silver bullet - if there is any - is that you're not imposing so much collateral damage on people who have no power."

Sanctions against Haiti in the 1990s to restore democracy were an example of the knock-out approach. After a trade embargo, the UN stopped private flights, banned visas for the junta and froze Haitian assets. These failed to achieve a return to democracy; military intervention followed.

The purpose of any sanctions against Iraq is going to be unchanged: to keep pressure on the regime until it lets UN inspectors return to monitor its weapons.

Weekend reports that Iraq may be just three years from acquiring nuclear weapons, and another claiming that it secretly tested a bomb in 1989, have heightened the concern.

But there is doubt whether Iraq will ever allow inspectors back, regardless of the pressure. Sir John Moberly, a former British ambassador to Jordan, believes that deterrence should be the focus, so that "if Saddam starts to deploy nuclear, chemical or biological weapons he will risk being hit extremely hard by the United States or other UN security council members".

That, he goes on, would mean rebuilding a security council consensus on Iraq, bringing France, Russia and China back on board: "Ease sanctions but agree on a response to Iraqi deployment of weapons."

Two years ago a group of American foreign policy experts proposed a tougher plan: a "systematic air campaign" against President Saddam's Republican Guard and the setting up of an alternative government inside Iraq with US military and financial backing.

Among this group were Donald Rumsfeld, now President Bush's defence secretary, Paul Wolfowitz, number two at the Pentagon, and Richard Armitage, number two at the state department.

Such ideas, however, are not likely to appeal to the secretary of state, Colin Powell, who has said he believes the policy of containment is working.

Targeting regime leaders is no simple matter

This is what experts say about the pros and cons of ways to penalise Iraq:

 Economic sanctions

Nothing has done more to discredit economic sanctions than hold-ups in the delivery of essential goods to Iraq, on the grounds that they might have a military use.

"Sanctions that were genuinely smarter," says Neil Partrick, of the Royal United Services Institute in London, "would shift the situation from saying that everything is forbidden, with certain exceptions, to saying that everything is permitted except some items, such as those with seriously potential dual use." Or, says Gary Sick of Columbia University, New York, don't allow unlimited quantities of dubious items.

As for exports, all Iraqi oil revenue must go into a UN account. The UN is unlikely to relinquish this lever, as it uses part of the money to feed Iraq's Kurds and compensate victims of Baghdad's 1990 invasion of Kuwait - the act that unleashed the Gulf war and led to sanctions.

But easing the policy on imports could be balanced by being tougher on smuggling, to stop illicit oil getting out and weapons getting in.

Border checks are far from rigorous now. Stricter ones, however, would require total support from all six of Iraq's neighbours - "hard in the case of Jordan, Turkey and Syria. Turkey has lost a lot of trade," Mr Partrick says.

 Travel restrictions

The most successful example was the EU's ban on 600 named supporters of Serbia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, which cut them off from their business activities around Europe. But such bans need support from a lot of countries and airlines, and can be evaded with false passports. Mr Saddam stays home.

 Financial targeting

Freezing the foreign bank accounts of regime leaders looks smart, but finding the accounts takes a lot of work.

The tactic has had some impact elsewhere, but for a country with oil wealth it might prompt leaders simply to steal state funds, further depriving the Iraqi people of food and medicines.

 Indictment

Charging leaders with war crimes or crimes against humanity would be a clearly targeted move and one that countered any impression that an easing of economic sanctions meant weakness.

The main issue here is timing. Actual arrests are unlikely in the near future and the threat of arrest might give the regime a further disincentive to make peace.

"It would not be particularly helpful while trying to get weapons inspectors in," Mr Partrick says.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Blair little to fear from Hague

fields.headline: No glory for Hague and his heroes
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair has little to fear from the Tory leader's 'popular' touch

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Tony Blair continues to warn his party workers that cynicism is the Tories' secret weapon. He need not worry. Whenever William Hague deploys his ultimate deterrent to voting Labour, it blows up in his face.
fields.body:
Tony Blair continues to warn his party workers that cynicism is the Tories' secret weapon. He need not worry. Whenever William Hague deploys his ultimate deterrent to voting Labour, it blows up in his face. The latest explosion echoes round Gartree prison, where Tony Martin - the farmer who was convicted of murdering a teenage burglar - has been considering an appeal. At the time of his trial, Martin was one of Hague's heroes - a noble yeoman who set the nation an example by defending his property against the sort of teenage hooligan who was encouraged by socialism's welfare dependency culture. According to the Daily Telegraph, Mr Martin's "history of mental illness" means that he may be judged not responsible for his actions.

Now, it looks as though the leader of the opposition's blatant opportunism is about to be exposed again. When Peter Mandelson resigned from the government, Hague attacked the prime minister for allowing him back so quickly after his first resignation at the time of the Geoffrey Robinson home loan scandal. Then, when Mandelson claimed that he had evidence which proved him innocent, the allegation shifted to a diametrically opposed complaint. Poor Peter had been dismissed in a fit of panic without being given a proper chance to defend himself. If, as last weekend's leaks suggest, the Hammond inquiry vindicates Tony Blair's decision, it seems unlikely that Hague will apologise for his errors of judgment.

From his own narrow political point of view, it would be far better if he did. The voters are not as stupid as Mr Hague supposes. They recognise his infinite capacity for reacting to issues of great principle with a miscalculation of where the Conservative party's best interests lie.

Over the past couple of days that fatal flaw has been reflected in the whispers that Tony Blair has become George Bush's poodle. I recognise the frustration that the Tory leadership feels after witnessing the clear rapport which has been established between the two men. It must be particularly galling for Iain Duncan Smith, the Tory defence spokesman, who has been busily telling rightwing Republicans that the Labour government will undermine the Atlantic alliance. But the opposition's attempt to have it both ways can only hold it up to ridicule. Every sensible person who reads that the prime minister rolled over for the president will be able to imagine what the Conservatives would have said if the Camp David meeting had ended in a dogfight.

In an attempt to retrieve lost ground, Duncan Smith has claimed that Tony Blair "misled George Bush during the discussions of the European Rapid Reaction Force". Unlike the Tory defence spokesman, I have always realised that the president of the United States is not very bright. But I took it for granted that clever men and women from the Pentagon and the state department would brief him about what the European Union's proposals meant and involved. If they did, and the prime minister fooled them all, I can only say that it makes me proud to be British. A more likely explanation is that the Tory leadership, having made a collective ass of itself, thought that inventing the deception story was the best way to get out of the hole. So it dug deeper.

The relationship between the prime minister and president was, in part, cemented by Tony Blair's acceptance (at least in principle) of America's nuclear defence system. Hague and Duncan Smith would have done the same. I regard the "hardening" of Fylingdales, and all that goes with it, as a waste of money which, by prejudicing the non-proliferation treaty, may make the world a more dangerous place. But I cannot resist being reasonable about how the prime minister behaved in America. Whether or not he shares my judgment or President Bush's prejudice, he had no choice but to agree to help at the birth of son of star wars. To refuse would have been to announce that Britain was no longer an ally of the United States. That would have brought Nato crashing down about the EU's head. The Rapid Reaction Force might have become the only defence on which Europe could rely.

By his actions, Tony Blair preserved the real possibility of Britain assuming the historic role which Harold Macmillan and John F Kennedy thought, 40 years ago, was our rightful destiny. The twin pillars of western democracy should be held together by the keystone of British diplomacy. There is a long way to go before that happy arrangement can be achieved. Britain cannot play anything like a leadership role in Europe while we remain outside the single European currency. But it is clearly a status which only a Labour government can promote. A Tory government, sulking on the fringes of the EU, could only make Britain an offshore island. It is a small ambition promoted by small-minded men and women, whose cynicism will only increase the size of their defeat.

fields.headline: Lord Sieff of Brimpton
fields.standfirst: Successful and progressive chairman of Marks and Spencer in the 70s and 80s
fields.trailText: Lord Sieff of Brimpton, who has died aged 87, was chairman of Marks and Spencer from 1972 to 1984 during a highly successful period. He believed strongly that social and human concern was not the enemy of good business, but an essential part of it. He was also a prominent Zionist.
fields.body:
Lord Sieff of Brimpton, who has died aged 87, was chairman of Marks and Spencer from 1972 to 1984 during a highly successful period. He believed strongly that social and human concern was not the enemy of good business, but an essential part of it. He was also a prominent Zionist.

In his working life, in his autobiography Don't Ask the Price (1987), and in his later book, Marcus Sieff On Management (1990), he argued that unhappy workers were inefficient workers. "The development of good human relations in industry is very important," he wrote. "I use the term 'good human relations in industry' rather than 'industrial relations' because we are human beings at work, not industrial beings."

With 48,500 employees in the 80s, the firm could claim that half of them had stayed for more than five years and consequently had benefited from the firm's profit-sharing scheme. Some cynics argued that it was a way of resisting any tendencies towards unionisation, but the fact remained that employees had non-contributory pensions, free medical and dental care, and inexpensive chiropody.

Sieff was a large, burly man. One relative claimed that "modesty is not his strongest point," and his comments did not lack frankness. But the cigar-smoking storekeeper was as alert to the needs of his employees as he was to the needs of his customers. He realised that the customer would not be served happily if the reasonable needs of the employee were not met. This shaft of perception (and Sieff in Hebrew means "brilliant") has not seemed so obvious to many in business who lacked his shrewdness.

Although he was a non-partisan member of think-tanks for prime ministers Harold Wilson, Edward Heath and James Callaghan, it was under Mrs Thatcher, who conferred his peerage in 1980, that Sieff, the first son of a life peer to be awarded a peerage in his own right, became a national hero. He was just the type of thrusting, impresario-esque, not-quite-establishment shopkeeper that appealed to Britain's first daughter-of-a-grocer prime minister. She was known to buy food from him, just as Neil Kinnock was known to have bought suits from him.

Sieff was born into the dynasty in Didsbury, Manchester, as the youngest son of Israel Sieff and Rebecca Marks, and worked in the stores as a boy. After Manchester grammar school and London's St Paul's school, he graduated in economics from Corpus Christi College, Cambridge. In 1935, aged 22, he went into the business at the Hammersmith Broadway branch. He started the second world war as a subaltern, and ended it having served in the Royal Artillery in north Africa, Sicily - which won him an OBE - and Italy, as a colonel.

Sieff, who came from a strongly Zionist family, had first visited Palestine in 1929. In 1948, he was invited by David Ben Gurion, Israel's first prime minister, to become adviser on transportation and supplies for the Israeli defence ministry. He pointed out that, as a colonel in the British army reserve, he could not take the oath of allegiance to Israel, though his family had actively campaigned for its creation. He did act as an adviser, on leave of absence from Marks and Spencer, until 1951.

Sieff became a director of Marks and Spencer in 1954, and by 1963 was its assistant managing director. He was made vice-chairman in 1965, joint managing director from 1967 to 1983, deputy chairman in 1971, and chairman from 1972 to 1984. Under his chairmanship the firm, born in the 1880s as Michael Marks's stall in Leeds market, had a rule that managers must eat in the employees' restaurants and visit their washrooms and lavatories, on the principle that if these were not "good enough for those in charge, they are not good enough for anyone".

But he could hardly have been accused of being a trendy lefty. Five years after assuming the chairmanship, and with a Labour government in office, he claimed that general living standards were falling. There were, he said, three reasons. Initiative was being stifled through taxation policies, there was conflict between management, and free enterprise was being progressively destroyed. He argued that employees must share in the success of a company, but that the taxman took too much of whatever he gave to his employees away. Marks and Spencer was finding it harder to recruit good people. Many preferred to go into the "feather-bedded" government service, where they had a secure life and inflation-proof pension - which no company that had to "earn its keep" could afford.

"No Marks and Spencer could build up a business like ours from scratch under conditions prevailing today," he said. Two years later, Labour was voted out and Mrs Thatcher was in power, soon providing him with a peerage and a taxation attitude congenial to him.

When he retired from the Marks and Spencer chairmanship in 1984, he handed over to the chief executive, Lord Rayner, the first chairman from outside the family. Sieff was president for a year, and then honorary president from 1985. "I use the term 'good human relations in industry' rather than 'industrial relations' because we are human beings at work, not industrial beings." He realised that the customer would not be served happily if the reasonable needs of the employee were not met. fields.headline: Barry Burman
fields.standfirst: His paintings had a visceral, disturbing beauty
fields.trailText: In 1991, Mike Goldmark of the Goldmark Gallery in Uppingham saw an extraordinary painting reproduced in the Observer Colour Supplement: Manac Es, the winner of the Hunting Group/Observer award. It was by a painter unknown to Goldmark, Barry Burman, who has now taken his life aged 57.
fields.body:
In 1991, Mike Goldmark of the Goldmark Gallery in Uppingham saw an extraordinary painting reproduced in the Observer Colour Supplement: Manac Es, the winner of the Hunting Group/Observer award. It was by a painter unknown to Goldmark, Barry Burman, who has now taken his life aged 57.

Goldmark had published Iain Sinclair's first novel, White Chappell, Scarlet Tracings, in 1987, and Manac Es was the title of one of the book's chapters, which concerned the Jack the Ripper killings, and represented the initials of the Ripper's victims in chronological order.

It took Goldmark a while to track the artist down, for Burman was always a very private man, and deeply suspicious of publicity. But finally, Goldmark offered him a show, whose success enabled him to realise his full potential, and resulted in Burman giving up teaching and joining that small band of creative artists who are able to make a living from their art.

Burman was always a figurative artist. His early paintings were meticulous and controversial images which addressed his ideas on women's sexuality; provocative schoolgirls on black leather sofas; malevolent nudes clutching Victorian dolls; and threatening femmes fatales grasping severed male heads.

During the 70s, his images were attacked by certain feminist critics - and on one occasion were attacked in a BBC2 television programme. Yet a careful reading of his work showed an investigation of male insecurities, rather than an intention to violate women.

Burman was born in Bedford. After a first in fine art at Coventry College of Art, and studying at the Royal College of Art, he taught part-time at Mid-Warwickshire College of Art in Leamington for 20 years.

In the 80s, Burman tightened his meticulous technique in images of mask-like faces expressing a disturbing sense of pain and decay. These allegories of the Thatcherite utopia were in the tradition of Bosch's 16th-century Mocking Of Christ, and Ensor's late 19th-century Entry Of Christ Into Brussels. These were followed by paintings prompted by Burman's infatuation with serial killers of the past and present, whom he painstakingly researched. He spoke of being "terrified and literally enthralled, held captive" by such crimes. But his was a philosophical interest in the meaning behind sexual violence - rather than a vicarious enjoyment of its sensational aspects - responding especially to the writings of De Sade and Georges Bataille.

His paintings used oil, acrylic, ink and wax crayon mixed with egg yolk and vinegar on thick paper, producing an extraordinary leathery surface which he found more flexible than canvas. In this manner he created frightening images inspired by the likes of Jack the Ripper, Hannibal Lecter and Ed Gein - whose crimes inspired the film Psycho - which had the power of tribal fetishes and were all the more chilling for the inclusion of human hair. The uniform browns and reds gave these often large, monumental, mask-like faces a feeling of slow decay. "I want to achieve objectness," Burman said. "Some power that certain images possess, something inexplicable."

Burman had 10 one-man shows, in places including the Ikon Gallery, Birmingham, the Herbert Art Gallery, Coventry, Leamington Art Gallery, Warwick Gallery and the Nicholas Treadwell Gallery, London, and was featured in many mixed exhibitions in London and abroad.

Goldmark gave Burman three exhibitions, Barry Burman: Paintings (1992), Loyal to the Nightmare (1997) and Pilgrim's Progress (1999). The last consisted of images inspired by John Bunyan's book, but with an overlay that marked them out as very much Burman's own vision. In recent months he had begun a series of papier-mché figures that promised to develop his themes in a new direction.

Bearing in mind how difficult Burman's work was, it sold well. Many collectors were impressed but felt they could not live with the images; others bought one and then became firm admirers, continually adding to their collections and becoming faithful followers, appreciating the beauty of such disturbing work, and the subtle use of materials.

Burman was always amazed by the sales - he was a genuinely humble and charming person.

"Masks fascinate me," he said. "They have a sort of power. There is a darkness behind the eyeholes. They are human in one way, yet inhuman. We look at the eyes to confirm humanity, but they are absent. The mask somehow hides yet hints at something more terrible, which isn't revealed."

His images possess that extraordinary, evocative and inexplicable power that only a few paintings convey, and Burman will be long remembered and valued. There is often a price to be paid for work that is so visceral, draining and painful. Burman spoke of the demons that were always with him. In the end, he took an overdose. He leaves his beloved wife, Rosy, and many faithful friends.

 Barry Burman, artist, born June 14 1943; died February 17 2001

webTitle: Portillo attacked over earnings from oil firm

fields.headline: Portillo attacked over earnings from oil firm
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague was last night challenged to suspend his shadow chancellor amid revelations that Michael Portillo had not spelt out the full extent of his earnings from an oil corporation.
fields.body:
William Hague was last night challenged to suspend his shadow chancellor amid revelations that Michael Portillo had not spelt out the full extent of his earnings from an oil corporation.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, led Labour demands that Mr Portillo make clear his involvement with the American oil giant Kerr-McGee after it emerged that payments of £5,000 to £10,000 for "parliamentary services" declared by the shadow chancellor were only a fraction of larger earnings from the company.

Meanwhile, Fraser Kemp, a Labour backbencher speaking with the authority of his party's high command, called on the Conservative leader to remove Mr Portillo from his shadow chancellor's brief until after the Budget on March 7 while details of the payments were clarified.

A letter from Kerr-McGee, placed by Mr Portillo in the register of members' interests in the Commons, states that the MP received the fee for parliamentary services, which it says "form a small proportion of our much wider agreement". Mr Portillo was employed by the corporation between 1981 and 1983 and from 1997 to the present, to advise in particular on international affairs, according to the letter, signed by Kerr-McGee's chairman, Frank Sharratt.

The Tories claimed that Mr Portillo had complied with parliamentary rules on declaring interests, which require MPs to detail remuneration for parliamentary services but only to list other interests.

Labour, keen to land blows on Mr Portillo in advance of the Budget and general election, admitted that parliamentary rules had apparently not been broken, but argued that the revelation of a multi-thousand pound contract raised questions about the shadow chancellor's dealings with business.

Mr Cook told Sunday with Adam Boulton on Sky News: "The public are entitled to know what arrangements he has had with oil companies, to whom, of course, taxation is meat and drink in their relation with politicians. Michael Portillo last year did propose a deep cut in fuel duty. We need to know to what extent he has a relationship with an oil company that might have influenced that thinking."

Mr Kemp questioned how the oil company could quantify the advice it received from the MP affecting UK matters as against international affairs.

Mr Cook said: "Because of the seriousness of this and because we are literally only 10 days away from the Budget, Hague must pull out Portillo from the Budget so these matters can be cleared up."

A Tory party spokesman said yesterday: "Mr Portillo is confident that he complied with the rules of the house."

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Booking celebrities
fields.trailText: Booking celebrities
fields.body:
A celebrity presence is a popular strategy for giving a corporate event a lift. But some of Britain's top speakers, although famous on the circuit, are unknown outside it. David Gunson, for example, is an air traffic controller in his day job, and John Welsh is a retired regimental sergeant major. Both are popular acts on the books of Now You're Talking, a specialist agency that supplies both well-known and unknown speakers for conferences, trade association dinners and corporate events.

As variety clubs wane, many comedians now tread the corporate podium instead - but Now You're Talking stresses that it is not in the cabaret business. It provides speakers "not bands, paper-tearers or tap-dancing penguins". Neither does it hand-over famous people's phone numbers. Part of the service is to offer advice on the best speaker for the event. Fees start at £400, but run to much more for a key-note speaker with an established business reputation.

An established agency will have a genuine relationship with the big names it advertises. If you just want a famous face, there is always the lookalike, although you don't save much by hiring a fake. A basic double will cost £350, and an all-singing, all-dancing Stars In Their Eyes winner can cost £2,500. Derricks Doubles says that, for corporate events, the most popular lookalikes are Absolutely Fabulous's Patsy and Edina, followed by Del Boy.

When hiring an act-a-like (a double who behaves in character rather than standing around and making people look twice), remember they will only be effective if people know how the real thing behaves. For example, off camera Richard Branson is very shy (believe it or not), so a good impersonator will be shy, too, which can be disappointing if you've paid him £500 to mingle.

Without a doubt, the World's top celebrity speaker is Neil Armstrong. Who knows how much he will cost, but should you get him (he's with Celebrity Speakers International) you'll have a lot to talk about. His boss was always asking for the moon, too.

webTitle: Blair tries to widen weapons debate

fields.headline: Blair tries to widen weapons debate
fields.trailText: Tony Blair wants to broaden the debate over US plans for a national missile defence system to include the wider question of weapons proliferation and arms reductions, Whitehall officials said yesterday.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  and Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
Tony Blair wants to broaden the debate over US plans for a national missile defence system to include the wider question of weapons proliferation and arms reductions, Whitehall officials said yesterday.

By doing so, the prime minister hopes to dilute opposition to the US "Son of Star Wars" project at home and among Britain's European allies, notably France and Germany, as well as in Russia.

Despite the show of total accord at Mr Blair's meeting with President Bush last week, it is clear the missile defence system and the EU's plans for joint military operations will remain the two main battlegrounds in bilateral relations for a long time to come, officials concede.

They will be discussed by EU foreign ministers in Brussels today, and at a special meeting of Nato ministers tomorrow called at the request of the US secretary of state, Colin Powell.

In a joint statement on Friday, Mr Bush and Mr Blair committed themselves to face up to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. "We need to obstruct and deter these new threats with a strategy that encompasses both offence and defensive systems," they said.

Asked about the US missile shield project on his return to Britain, Mr Blair said: "Let's wait to see how this situation develops."

By linking missile defence to international arms control - including cuts in America's arsenal of long-range strategic missiles - the British government hopes to entice Russia into a constructive debate.

At a meeting in Cairo on Saturday Mr Powell and the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, agreed that weapons experts from both countries should begin a dialogue on the topics of missile defence and strategic arms reduction.

webTitle: Male PAs on the fast track

fields.headline: Eyes wide shut
fields.standfirst: Male PAs are on a fast track to the top. Or so their female counterparts think.  Kate Hilpern  on whether women have a true perception of the gender divide
fields.trailText: Male PAs are on a fast track to the top. Or so their female counterparts think. Kate Hilpern on whether women have a true perception of the gender divide
fields.body:
Picture the scene: you are a woman who works alongside a man who does exactly the same job as you in exactly the same office. One day, you both go for promotion. Who do you think gets it? Him, of course. At least, that's what women overwhelmingly believe, according to a new survey by recruitment consultancy OfficeTeam.

"Most female PAs have a perception that their male counterparts will always get promoted faster than them - even though it's a profession that is female-dominated," says Sarah Thomas, who was involved in the research. But, she insists, "Our study also found that the reality is that there is no truth in this concern whatsoever. PAs, no matter what their gender, get promoted on merit."

Indeed, similar studies that have been carried out since men started entering the profession have come to the same conclusion - that blokes are by no means treated as superior in the secretarial world. So why the female fear?

Alison Stimpson, a careers adviser, claims it stems from the fact that "men increasingly use support roles as a first rung on their career ladder. With around double the number in higher education than a decade ago, graduates have had to find news ways into professions. Secretarial work has proved to be the most popular route, particularly for men. In other words, while it appears that men are mega-quick at getting promotion, the reality is that they are mega-quick at proactively seeking out higher status roles."

Indeed, a recent report by the TUC found that the number of men in secretarial jobs has risen by 56% over the past three years and that most of these are graduates. Alistair Smith, an analyst in the City, is one of them. "I decided to use a PA role as a stepping-stone because I realised I'd learn far more about business by working day-to-day with a top businessman than I ever would have from a graduate trainee scheme, where I might be one of 20 people struggling to get noticed. I had access to high-level people and had every intention from day one to have his job one day. I succeeded," he says.

Meanwhile, Sarah Eldoori of recruitment consultancy Office Angels believes that rather than men talking themselves into promotion, women tend to talk themselves out of it. "It's my experience that female secretaries say things like, 'Oh, I'm not that great at my job,' whereas men boast about their achievements. That's the real gender split among support staff." This claim is backed by a new study by Gallup which found that women are far more likely to underrate their performance at work than men are - and that this could be one of the reasons why many women fail to get high-ranking jobs.

"If, as our research reveals, women's self-assessments are less positive than those given to them by other people, they may not progress as fast as men," explains Haihai Yuan, co-author of the a Gallup report on appraisals.

Mick Cooper, senior lecturer in applied social science at Brighton University, believes women may have every reason to be worried about the re-entry of men into the profession. "What research hasn't yet concluded is whether it's the increased responsibilities and status of secretarial work that has led to more men doing the job, or whether the fact that more men do the job has led to the increased responsibilities and status," he says. "If it's the latter, men are in danger of pushing women back out of the picture."

Consider Russia in the 1920s and 1930s, he says. "There was a sudden influx of women becoming doctors, and the status of doctors then dropped, with men opting out. Sadly, it is still possible for gender to have this kind of influence, and what we could be witnessing here is the flip side of the coin."

In fact, as James Reed, chief executive of Reed Employment Services, points out: "Originally, secretarial work was restricted to men, as mastering a keyboard was felt to be too technical for women. Forty years ago, that trend was reversed and it was seen as almost inevitably a female domain. Today, however, it's changing again and could theoretically become male-dominated once more."

For now, however, there appears to be no such threat. Indeed, Steven Durham, PA to the assistant director at Camden Local Education Authority, says: "Despite men now accounting for 25% of support staff and women panicking that we'll take over, the gender divide has been eradicated in other professions a lot quicker than in the secretarial world. I have found, for instance, that there is a resistance - particularly among male employers - to employ male support staff."

A spokesperson from recruitment consultancy Marshall Tapp agrees: "Five per cent of respondents to one of our surveys said they would not give a man's CV the same consideration as a woman's. One said he wouldn't consider it because the idea was so odd, and another said he would assume that they were homosexual."

Who do you think gets it? Him, of course. At least, that's what women overwhelmingly believe, according to a new survey by recruitment consultancy OfficeTeam. "Most female PAs have a perception that their male counterparts will always get promoted faster than them - even though it's a profession that is female-dominated," says Sarah Thomas, who was involved in the research. But, she insists, "Our study also found that the reality is that there is no truth in this concern whatsoever. PAs, no matter what their gender, get promoted on merit." fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: * Q: How many council workers does it take to change a lightbulb?
fields.body:
* Q: How many council workers does it take to change a lightbulb?

A: Quite a few, at quite a cost, if Doncaster city council is to be believed. News reaches WPM that council workers in this fair northern city are being sent on a two-and-a-half-hour course to teach them how to change a lightbulb. Dozens have attended the course, on which the council has spent an estimated £4,000. A council spokesman said that the authority takes the Health and Safety Act very seriously and that it is the duty of any employer to provide such information and training as is necessary to ensure the safety of employees.

But Martin Williams, an independent councillor on the authority said: "The council needs to switch on to the fact that it is a laughing stock. This is just a crazy waste of time and effort." An entrepreneurial WPM would like to offer her services to the spendthrift council. She can teach you how to change a fuse for £2k; how to swap bottles on the watercooler for a cool £1k; and how to refill the photocopier for a bargain fifty quid. Cheap at the price, she's sure you'll agree, and a nice little money earner for her to boot. Now that really would be a bright idea.

*We've had dress-down Friday, so how about a work-free Wednesday? The idea doesn't sound so unpalatable to WPM, who was quite taken with the idea of a "stress-free day" put forward by recruitment consultancy Media Contacts. The basic concept is that employees spend one day a week taking part in social activities organised by the boss. The nice people at Media Contacts say letting staff enjoy time off from heavy workloads and stringent deadlines could boost staff productivity. The company also claims that such initiatives could help combat the rising numbers of workers who are taking days off sick because of stress, as well as taking the pressure off bosses facing claims against them over employees' stress-related health problems. WPM would like to give her wholehearted endorsement to this brilliant idea, simply because it sounds like a euphemism for bumming about, doing nothing and getting paid for it. Splendid.

*Generous to the last, WPM is happy to lend colleagues money, riches, even the shirt off her back, if she thinks it will be of use to the poor, less fortunate souls. What's hers is theirs. Until, of course, she decides they are taking liberties, and wants her wonga back. Such is the case with Sharon in accounts, who still hasn't refunded the 26p WPM put up for a Mars bar last November.

Which is why WPM is aghast to learn that British bosses owe their employees £737m in unpaid expenses. A new report from BACS, the UK's automated financial clearing house, has said nearly 2m workers have to wait an unnecessary long time before expenses are paid. Most British businesses pay employees' salaries via the BACS Direct Credit electronic fund transfer service, which means they also have the facility to pay expenses direct into workers' bank accounts. However, the BACS survey found that 57% of companies still pay expenses by cheque, which means it takes longer for the funds to be available for withdrawal from the employees' account. Those sneaky sons-of-an-accountant are trying to pull a fast one. But they should be warned. Like Sharon in accounts, WPM' got their number.

*WPM has always found something amusing about men in tight trousers. So imagine, if you can, her delight when she learned about the antics of staff at the Berwick-upon-Tweed Citizens Advice Bureau. Granted £1,000 to spend on improving the working environment for its overstressed employees, it drafted in a counsellor to teach them how to relax. After weeks of practising positive statements about how it was going to be A Good Day, and listening to sage advice such as "Drink less coffee", bureau manager Jennifer Hall noticed that here was £40 left in the kitty (these counsellors don't come cheap y'know; and then you've got to fork out for all those complimentary biscuits and extra jars of Nescafe). Presumably fed up with practising deep-breathing techniques and feng shui-ing the office, Jennifer blew the lot (well, almost) on some good old- fashioned Billy Connolly videos. She felt a little comic relief might do them as much good as all the yoga sun saluting. Customers have not been quite so happy about the bureau staff's new trend for cursing in a Glaswegian accent.

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 22. Interviews
fields.trailText: 22. Interviews
fields.body:
It's challenging, time-consuming and, at times, frustrating. But recruiting staff is also extremely rewarding. Either way, it's not a task to take on lightly, and having been an interviewee yourself does not mean you'll be a natural interviewer.

* Have a clear idea of the skills and experience you're looking for. Write them out and keep them in view, so you don't get derailed by other attractive, but less essential skills.

*Read each applicant's CV and letter carefully, and refresh your memory before the interview. Mark areas you want to explore, and any issues that concern you.

*Seek guidance on questioning techniques or subjects that may suggest prejudice. A simple inquiry about age, or plans to have children, may be inappropriate. Employment law does not look kindly on discrimination, even if inadvertent.

*Arrange furniture in a comfortable way in the interview room, and help candidates to relax. Make small talk, and explain how the interview will run. Ensure that you are not distracted or interrupted.

*It's easy to make snap judgments about people, but try to control the urge. Take note of how candidates present themselves, but keep an open mind until the interview is over.

*Make notes as you go along. After two or three interviews, each candidate's strengths and weaknesses begin to merge. If you have particular worries about a candidate's suitability, jot down your feelings at the time. This may help if you are later asked to justify a decision to reject a candidate.

*Ask open questions to elicit more than a simple "Yes" or "No". Ask "Why?", "To what extent?" and "How?" to get more information. Keep in mind the key skills you need and ask tightly targeted questions. If you need to know if a candidate can run a budget, ask him or her to explain briefly how they do it.

*Give them a chance to ask you questions- one statistic recommends a 75/25 split on talking time, the candidate doing the lion's share. Before they leave, tell them when they can expect to hear from you, and thank them for their time.

*An interview can be stressful for both parties, but it is within the interviewer's power to make it enjoyable. Planning, effort and, most importantly, a smile go a long way.

fields.headline: Music to your ears
fields.standfirst: As you settle down to watch this week's Brit Awards, spare a thought for Jo Johnson. She talks to  Dolly Dhingra  about a year spent ensuring its success
fields.trailText: As you settle down to watch this week's Brit Awards, spare a thought for Jo Johnson. She talks to Dolly Dhingra about a year spent ensuring its success
fields.body:
I'm not a great celeb spotter. I always find that the fantasy is nicer than the reality," says Jo Johnson, 23, production secretary for the Brit Awards. Often described as the pop industry's answer to the Oscars, the event - which takes place at Earls Court in London this evening - includes performances from some of the music industry's finest and most controversial artists.

Johnson, who is based in Soho, has been working on the event since last November (her contract expires in a couple of weeks so she is already looking for her next job). Originally from Bristol, she studied design at Nottingham Trent University but has always been passionate about music. A regular face at college gigs and local record shops, she got roped into organising club nights, concerts and other live events during her student years.

"I was always told that it's all about who you know in the pop industry and I used to think, 'Who am I going to meet? I'm just a graduate from Nottingham Trent.'" Luck was on her side. One of her contacts at college moved to London to work in music PR. "That one contact led to so much and I got a job in the same PR company without making a formal application. My whole career since leaving university has been like that, and I know it's a cliché but it really is true - it's all about who you know."

Rehearsals have been going on for the past two days. Johnson's duties will include making final checks to ensure that all artists will be arriving on time, that they are happy in their hotels and that transport is booked to and from the venue. She is looking forward to meeting Eminem and U2. "They are just people, but it would be incredible to see them because of the impact they've had on the globe - there are very few people in the world who wouldn't know a U2 song."

The awards will be aired exactly 24 hours after taking place and Johnson will be on hand to make sure that the director and producer are looked after. "On the day, they are going to be under such enormous pressure. I will be making sure that they have absolutely everything they need - it could be as simple as getting them some food, or making sure that they have some rest."

All staff need to know exactly where they should be and what they should be doing on the night. Numbers run into hundreds, and Johnson's responsibility is not to be taken lightly. Issuing passes, distributing running orders and making sure everyone has updated contact sheets is all down to her.

But what about having fun? "Ideally, I'd like to be at some secret little vantage point watching the performances, but I can't imagine that being the case - it all depends on how well things are going," she says.

As part of her research, Johnson has been watching previous recordings of The Brits to understand how the staging works. "I was always an enormous fan when I was growing up - I even watched it back in the seminal year of Sam Fox and Mick Fleetwood. Let's just say things have got a lot better since," she says.

Johnson doesn't like talking about the stars she's met. She visibly cringes. "I'm not very good at name- dropping," she says. But she eventually admits that she has met Mel B, Craig David and Sade. "Sade still looks as beautiful as she did when I was five years old. I was really impressed."

Johnson is certainly ambitious, but despite working in a high-profile industry, she doesn't wear her ambition on her sleeve. She currently manages a band called Contempo and is a co-founder of a record label that she continues to work for after hours. "It's not a hobby, that trivialises it. They're a local band from Kingston via Staines - no jokes. I love them, they remind me of the Clash with a modern edge. They knew I had done work in the industry and just came up to me and asked me for my help, and I thought: 'why not?'"

Johnson is obviously defensive, arguing that women in the music industry still come in for a lot of stick. "There's this notion that if you're a girl you're just here to see the boys on stage. Unfortunately there's that whole groupie image attached to women in rock and dance music who consistently get labelled jockie sluts."

It's a term she despises, believing that "the women who are getting places are so focused. They know what they want and they work damn hard to get to the top, they're there on merit and they know the industry inside out, and they are completely passionate about it."

Still, after tonight's awards the talk will be about the after-show parties. But Johnson is adamant that she will not be going. "I imagine that I might be able to find some spurious excuse to get in if I wanted to, but it doesn't really do it for me. I went to the after party at the Mobo awards and was totally bored."

webTitle: John Patterson  gets on the Graceland trail

fields.headline: Elvis lives
fields.standfirst: With his weekly preview of US movies,  John Patterson  gets on the Graceland trail
fields.trailText: With his weekly preview of US movies, John Patterson gets on the Graceland trail
fields.body:
As any reader of America's gothic supermarket tabloids knows full well, Elvis never really left the building. If we're to believe the many breathless accounts in the World Weekly News and National Inquirer, he walks among us to this day, or gazes down benignly from his UFO.

And Kevin Costner believes. In 3,000 Miles to Graceland, he plays a psychotic armed robber named Murphy, and you'd better not say "The King is dead" when he's around, or you might end up the same way. Costner and Kurt Russell play ex-cellmates who, along with four others, steal $3.5m from the count-room of a Las Vegas casino during an Elvis Impersonators' Convention. The best way to disguise oneself in a venture like this is to dress exactly like everyone else - in this case, like Elvis. Ten minutes in, we're treated to a sub-John Woo machine gun battle between hapless casino security guards and five guys dressed like Presley in his tubbier years.

It looked promising, as movies with tight, funny trailers often do, and it certainly benefits from the amiable presence of Russell, who in John Carpenter's 1979 TV movie Elvis!, staked his claim as the greatest Elvis impersonator of all time. But it's the kind of bland fast-food flick you don't have to chew.

A lot of American women my age admit to lusting after the young Kurt Russell as teenagers, in Disney movies like The World's Strongest Man. But when he revived his note-perfect Elvis voice in Graceland - "Thankyou ver' ver' much, ma'am - there were several feminine yowls in the auditorium. Whether these were for Kurt or for Elvis was hard to tell. Certainly, they weren't for Costner, whose sideburns are so absurdly abundant that he looks like some reprobate meth-lab crankster-gangster.

Costner is, by a hair's breadth, the more powerful of the two stars and this means that the film ends up being suffocated by his dimwit blandness, rather than the jovial, piss-taking atmosphere that pervades most movies in which Russell plays top banana. You wait for 3,000 Miles to Graceland to get up off its knees, but it never happens.

Monkey Bone, the weekend's other new offering, more than makes up for Graceland's shortcomings, with an abundance of energy and inventiveness, and with another fantastic performance by one of my favourite actors, Brendan Fraser.

Fraser's presence in a movie is, for me at least, a solid-gold quality- guarantee. If he's in the credits, either the movie will be great (The Mummy, Gods and Monsters) or Fraser himself will be so good that the relative crappiness of the movie won't matter (Blast from the Past, Bedazzled).

Fraser plays Stu Miley (S.MILEY on his name-tag), a shy cartoonist who channels all his anger into his work. His creation is the metaphorical equivalent of both an ungovernable hard-on and Stu's rampant id. Stuck in a coma after an accident, Stu is cast into a parallel universe called Down Town, redolent of both Dr Seuss and R Crumb, in which his manic and depressive sides must confront one another while he waits for his ticket back to consciousness. Things go wrong when Monkey Bone (voiced by John Turturro) steals the exit-pass and goes back to inhabit and revive Stu's long inert body for his own nefarious ends.

Monkey Bone is a grown-up, highly intelligent movie dripping with Freudian in-jokes, psychological turmoil and nightmarish surrealism. Its thematic density and narrative flexibility put me in mind of Being John Malkovich, which also had funny and disturbing things to say about madness and identity. There's also a surfeit of fart jokes, hard-on jokes and body-parts humour alongside Monkey Bone's naughtiness and Fraser's game performance. Let's hope The Mummy 2's half this good.

Ten minutes in, we're treated to a sub-John Woo machine gun battle between hapless casino security guards and five guys dressed like Presley in his tubbier years. It looked promising, as movies with tight, funny trailers often do, and it certainly benefits from the amiable presence of Russell, who in John Carpenter's 1979 TV movie Elvis!, staked his claim as the greatest Elvis impersonator of all time. But it's the kind of bland fast-food flick you don't have to chew. A lot of American women my age admit to lusting after the young Kurt Russell as teenagers, in Disney movies like The World's Strongest Man. But when he revived his note-perfect Elvis voice in Graceland - "Thankyou ver' ver' much, ma'am - there were several feminine yowls in the auditorium. Whether these were for Kurt or for Elvis was hard to tell. Certainly, they weren't for Costner, whose sideburns are so absurdly abundant that he looks like some reprobate meth-lab crankster-gangster. Costner is, by a hair's breadth, the more powerful of the two stars and this means that the film ends up being suffocated by his dimwit blandness, rather than the jovial, piss-taking atmosphere that pervades most movies in which Russell plays top banana. You wait for 3,000 Miles to Graceland to get up off its knees, but it never happens. Monkey Bone, the weekend's other new offering, more than makes up for Graceland's shortcomings, with an abundance of energy and inventiveness, and with another fantastic performance by one of my favourite actors, Brendan Fraser. Fraser's presence in a movie is, for me at least, a solid-gold quality- guarantee. If he's in the credits, either the movie will be great (The Mummy, Gods and Monsters) or Fraser himself will be so good that the relative crappiness of the movie won't matter (Blast from the Past, Bedazzled). Fraser plays Stu Miley (S.MILEY on his name-tag), a shy cartoonist who channels all his anger into his work. His creation is the metaphorical equivalent of both an ungovernable hard-on and Stu's rampant id. Stuck in a coma after an accident, Stu is cast into a parallel universe called Down Town, redolent of both Dr Seuss and R Crumb, in which his manic and depressive sides must confront one another while he waits for his ticket back to consciousness. Things go wrong when Monkey Bone (voiced by John Turturro) steals the exit-pass and goes back to inhabit and revive Stu's long inert body for his own nefarious ends. Monkey Bone is a grown-up, highly intelligent movie dripping with Freudian in-jokes, psychological turmoil and nightmarish surrealism. Its thematic density and narrative flexibility put me in mind of Being John Malkovich, which also had funny and disturbing things to say about madness and identity. There's also a surfeit of fart jokes, hard-on jokes and body-parts humour alongside Monkey Bone's naughtiness and Fraser's game performance. Let's hope The Mummy 2's half this good.
