fields.headline: What women eat
fields.standfirst: There's no denying it: for many women, food is an issue. Even Uma Thurman, it was revealed last week, thinks she's fat. But what does the average woman put in her mouth on the average day, and how does she feel about it? We asked four to keep food diaries
fields.trailText: There's no denying it: for many women, food is an issue. Even Uma Thurman, it was revealed last week, thinks she's fat. But what does the average woman put in her mouth on the average day, and how does she feel about it? We asked four to keep food diaries
fields.body:
Tina Woods, 36: Director of medical education company

6.30am One glass of orange juice, two cups of coffee with full fat milk. This is what the kids drink and skimmed milk tastes horrible in coffee!

8am Secret half teaspoon of peanut butter - I've been on a diet for over a week now and I'm suffering withdrawal. I've gained two and a half stone since I had the kids and my target is to lose two by the summer. I'm being pragmatic about healthy eating, cutting out fat and trying to be more active, but I'm not sticking to any particular foods. I used to feel guilty and obsessive about eating chocolate and other bad foods, and I was close to being anorexic, but now I have a healthier body image. I think it's because I'm happier as a person and my attitude is more mature. But I still don't like wearing a bathing suit if I don't feel slim.

1pm Chicken, bacon and salad sandwich but no butter or mayonnaise (usually do), no crisps (usually do). One can of Rio diet fizzy drink (I always get this because it includes 33% extra for free). I'm trying to get back into going to the gym - I used to go six times a week, including five aerobics sessions, right up till the last week of pregnancy, but when you're a working mother of two boys under five, that's difficult to do. I'm aiming for once a week at the moment. If you stop looking at your muscles in the mirror and comparing your body with other people in the gym, you don't think about your weight so much.

7pm Minestrone Slim-a-Soup (only 60 calories) and two halves of an oatcake that dropped on the floor after the kids raided the cupboard for a snack . Half a bite of chicken nugget that they haven't eaten. Remember by second bite that I shouldn't be eating chicken nuggets - habits are not easily broken. When I had children, I discovered I was unconsciously finishing the food on their plates. That put on a few pounds and breast-feeding means you keep the weight on, too. The other reason is that after you have kids, self is not a priority, so body image is less important.

9.30pm Loads of lettuce, leftover pork chop from two nights ago, leftover mushrooms from last week (yikes, they must be used up by tonight and I hate wasting food). One slice of leftover potato and parsnip, and a spoonful of mashed potato from my husband's plate to remind myself how delicious it tastes. I didn't grow up in a family in which we were force-fed the last morsels on our plates; my desire to use up every scrap of leftover food stems from a need to control things. I get irritated if I make too much because it shows I haven't planned well.

10.30pm Do not allow myself leftover mash. One glass diet tonic with ice and lemon (in a nice glass to try to fool myself it is almost as good as my usual stiff gin and tonic, which is fattening and reduces my willpower). Lots of fizzy water. ( Do not have two glasses of wine.)

11pm Diet hot chocolate. Three big spoonfuls to make it seem creamy.

Allegra McEvedy, 30: Food writer and chef at The Good Cook restaurant in west London

8.30am Cup of Earl Grey in bed. Two teabags, one sugar and a good shot of milk - organic semi-skimmed. I've never been able to kick sugar in tea, but I use unrefined because it contains beneficial trace elements.

9.30am I have no pattern for breakfast - if I'm cooking or writing at home, I'll skip it altogether, but this week I've got a friend over from NYC, Jodi, who is bonkers about crumpets (not available in Brooklyn). I've recently scored some fantastic Turkish honeycomb, so crumpets and honey make a great start to the day.

2pm Lunch is another variable: if I'm on a shoot or a deadline, I won't stop. One good thing about having a guest is you tend to punctuate your day with meals at the correct time. Left to my own devices, I often won't eat until late afternoon. Take Jodi to the Honest Cabbage in Bermondsey, which is like a gastro pub without the pub bit. Being a good New York girl, she has a salad, but I go for calves' liver with black pudding and French beans. I suppose black pudding isn't exactly good for you but it tastes fantastic. Drink a pint of bitter and two glasses of water.

4pm Take Jodi and Alfie, my three-year-old nephew, to Tate Modern. Alfie gets bored, so the two of us go to the cafeteria. Alfie goes into a mantra about chips and gets lucky: I'm a Good Aunt - and I know I'm not responsible for his overall diet.

6.30pm It's London fashion week and a friend is showing his collection. I don't eat anything, but it's worth a mention because it illustrates the antithesis of my attitude. Six-foot women with alien bodies. I look at them quizzically rather than enviously. My mum was one of those fabulous homey cooks who had a fridge magnet saying: "Life is uncertain, eat pudding first." Admittedly, times have changed and, more specifically, my life has changed - I'm in development for a TV series and more than one person has pointed out that the camera puts 8lb on you. So I've been going to the gym, drinking lots of water, rationing alcohol, keeping fruit in the house and chocolate out. I'm one of the least calorie-counting people I know - I think you can tell whether something is good for you.

9pm Make dinner at home. Out of four of us eating, two are chefs, so we take a course each. I make a herby ful madamas (Middle Eastern broad bean) salad, backed with a healthy amount of chilli. Fred scours the fridge for soup ingredients and comes up with a delicious number involving chicken stock I made yesterday, salami, baby spinach and the new season's garlic. The meal was perfect, delicious and healthy. Sometimes I feel Sarah, my partner, headhunted me because she loves good food but doesn't feel au fait in the kitchen. I have a passion for food and live to eat. I'd be upset if I got to sumo proportions, but I believe you should do what feels right for you - after all, you are what you eat.

Clara Coleridge, 25: Editorial assistant at handbag.com

8am Muesli with milk. This is what I have for breakfast most days, because I like it and also because I reckon the fibre's pretty healthy. Generally I'm not that hungry in the morning. If I'm late leaving for work and/or hungover, I'll skip the muesli and buy take-out croissant or toast to eat at my desk.

11am Tangerine. My flatmate had bought a bag, so I've brought one to work. I haven't eaten one since Christmas and I love the taste, but also I think I should eat some fruit because I don't buy it that often. I know you're supposed to have five portions a day and I don't think about fulfilling that every day, but I do enjoy healthy food when I eat it.

12.30pm Microwave-able Asda chicken in caesar sauce with bacon and pasta. I only eat half of this because it's too rich and a bit yucky. I don't have a problem with leaving food on my plate, probably because I went to boarding school and still have nightmares about being sent back to table because I hadn't finished what was on my tray. You had no choice over what you ate and often just had to hold your nose and get it down your throat. Either that or spit it into your napkin. Then I'd cheer myself up with Mum's home-made biscuits in my tuck box. When I was a teenager I went to a girls' boarding school and that was even worse because it was fashionable to be anorexic. I wasn't, but I used to have to pretend to be on a diet like everyone else. Often the dining room would be pretty empty, so many girls were starving themselves. Now at lunchtime, I might bring in a sandwich from home but normally I'll eat it too early, then want a second lunch later.

4pm Packet of paprika crisps. I bought these from Boots in my lunch hour. They're my favourite flavour and I was worried because I noticed they were running out. I didn't trust myself to buy two packets because I might eat both. So I hid a couple of packets in the salt and vinegar flavour box for later. Usually at this time I think about some kind of snack. If I'm going out for drinks in the evening, supper might get forgotten about, so I'll grab a sausage roll or something at my desk.

7.30pm Get home and have a slice of cheese and a few bits of ham from the fridge with a glass of wine. I tend to eat according to my mood, I don't diet. After a hangover, I might just eat pizza all day. I once joined a gym but got depressed at using all this equipment with nothing to do but watch EastEnders with the sound turned down. Then I only went to the sauna, so I stopped going and now I run up escalators for exercise. When I was 18, I used to compare myself with skinny, beautiful models but I've got over that now. What's important is to be healthy and active. In my job, we are bombarded with images of models, but we try to use only ones who are a healthy weight.

8.30pm Chicken (again!) with mini roasted potatoes and mange-tout, followed by apple crumble and cream. My two flatmates and I did a bulk shop and cooked a meal for two other friends. Everything is home-made and really nice. I haven't had pudding for ages. If I'm in the supermarket, I couldn't buy a whole cake unless I was having a tea, because I know if I did then I'd finish it all and feel sick. Lots of water pre-bed (after about five glasses of wine).

Darshan Kent, 44: Assistant to partner in management consultancy

7.30am Arrive early at work. Grapes and sharon fruit. Eighteen months ago, I made a decision to start eating fruit for breakfast and cut out bread and cheese. The reason? The guy who sits next to me turned round one day and asked: "Why are you so fat?" In an office, people do tend to notice colleagues' eating habits. He told me where he saw me going wrong and pointed out that yeast makes some people bloated. Now I call him my dietitian, I have a bowl of fruit on my desk and I've lost a stone and a half just by doing that. I've always been happy with myself, so I would never go on a diet, and I never weigh myself - it doesn't do you any good.

8am Coffee. Normally I just drink hot water, but I worked for 16 hours yesterday at a conference and need a boost.

9am Cafe latte made with skimmed milk - I don't like the taste of full fat.

11am Three plums. Fruit fills me up in a different way from bread; there is a lightness to it and it's very refreshing. I don't bring in boring things like apples, I try to go for nice, exotic types. I buy cases of sharon fruit from my greengrocer, he's got to know me very well.

12.30pm Go out for coffee with friends. I don't like to eat with them because it gets in the way of talking!

2pm Eat lunch at my desk. Normally I have a massive salad but there isn't much left in the canteen so I have to settle for a jacket potato with tuna. It's horrible. We've got a new chef and his hot meals smell tempting, but I know afterwards I'll be disappointed - hot food at lunchtime is always like that and can be greasy. If I feel in the mood for something naughty, like chips, I'll go right ahead and have them. Life is for living, you shouldn't feel guilty.

4pm Kiwi fruit and a banana. At this time of day, I need a pep-up.

8pm Coffee and a chocolate biscuit at my teacher's house (I've recently started a degree in business studies). If I want chocolate, I'll have it. You can diet till you drop dead but it won't make much difference. Usually people revert to the body type they are born with. I go to the gym three times a week - it used to be six but I don't have time now I'm studying.

10pm Mediterranean vegetable casserole, with peppers and aubergines and plain boiled rice, then a plate of sharon fruit. Made by my 19-year-old daughter, who is the best cook in the world. Unlike me, she eats meat. I became vegetarian 20 years ago. I used to be vegan but started eating fish and eggs recently and feel more energised now. I think I wasn't getting enough nutrients before. My parents didn't bring me up to eat healthily - I wish I'd known years ago what I know now. Now we never eat frozen vegetables, it's just as quick to cook fresh.

11pm Glass of hot water. I do drink alcohol - on Fridays, that's my drinking day. A group of us go to a wine bar that does a special offer on a magnum of champagne.

 Michele Hanson returns next week.

fields.headline: Top of the shops
fields.standfirst: One little store inspired a new breed of musician and turned the record industry on its head.  Dave Simpson celebrates 25 years of Rough Trade
fields.trailText: One little store inspired a new breed of musician and turned the record industry on its head. Dave Simpson celebrates 25 years of Rough Trade
fields.body:
Twenty-five years ago, a young self-described "music junkie" called Geoff Travis started a record shop dedicated to showcasing the future. The shop spawned a distribution network that changed the face of music in this country, and the record label that brought us such influential groups as the Smiths and the Fall.

An awful lot of people are getting very nostalgic about Rough Trade. Mute is releasing a 50-track CD featuring acts, from Nick Cave to the Chemical Brothers, that owe something to Rough Trade, while London's Rough Trade shops (there are now two of them) are presenting 10 days of live music at various venues across the capital. Young Marble Giants are reforming after 20 years, and the whole thing promises to be a marvellous - if slightly misty-eyed - affair.

One man won't be too nostalgic. Ten years after the label and distribution side of Rough Trade went into receivership, Geoff Travis has other things to take care of. He has bought back the record label name from indie operation One Little Indian and is starting again. "I'm pleased about the anniversary because I don't have to do very much," laughs Travis, ensconced in his new offices in London's Golborne Road. "I would feel really weird if I was just looking back, but I'm as excited as I've ever been."

Already, rave notices have greeted his new signings David Kitt and New York rockers the Strokes, with the latter generating the kind of hubbub that once surrounded the Smiths. "We're having sleepless nights about the Strokes," says Travis. "When they played last week, people told me it was among the top 10 gigs they'd been to in their lives."

The record scene certainly needs this sort of enthusiasm. Perhaps the most intriguing aspect of Rough Trade's re-emergence as a label is that the industry is in almost exactly the same condition as when Travis started his shop at 202 Kensington Road, pushing Television, Blondie and reggae imports. Again, big companies dominate, peddling manufactured, cynically backward-looking sounds to a generation of buyers who don't know there is an alternative. But having started as a cottage industry and taken on the world, is Travis in a position to do it all again?

"I've already made mis takes," he admits. "At the moment, for example, the whole thing is funded by me, which is insane."

British music would have been very different if Travis hadn't hitch-hiked around America in 1975, and returned with the crateloads of records he used - as well as £4,000 from his father - to start the Rough Trade shop. It became a focal point for the emerging punk and DIY culture, as Travis championed records by the likes of Scritti Politti and Desperate Bicycles, whose motto was: "It's easy, it's cheap - go and do it." Bands formed in the shop and independent empires began there. One early customer was Daniel Miller, who walked in with a tape of his band the Normal. Travis paid for 2,000 copies to be pressed, and Miller founded the Mute label, which has since sold millions with Depeche Mode and Moby. Rough Trade became a record label after French punk band Metal Urbain realised that some shop in London was importing hundreds of their Panique single. They presented Travis with a tape of their next effort, Paris Maquis, and asked him to put it out.

Like Factory's Tony Wilson, Travis was a Cambridge-educated "pseudo- intellectual" grounded in political theory. Teaming up with similar regional record shops such as Red Rhino in York and Probe in Liverpool, he devised a national network capable of distributing the music. In those days Rough Trade was run as a co-op, with everybody on the same money, although Travis led music policy as a "benevolent dictator".

The label's first album, Inflammable Material by Stiff Little Fingers, shifted 100,000 copies and was sold in Asda, an astonishing feat for an album with a sleeve that looked like a bomb. For years, unveiling innovative bands from the Raincoats to Aztec Camera, Rough Trade ran riot in the music industry, with a combination of instinct and sheer gall. Cabaret Voltaire were lured to the label with the promise of a drum machine; the Smiths for just £4,000. Many groups were won over by Rough Trade's 50/50 profit split between artist and label.

By the mid-1980s, the label had become more professional, winning awards for its marketing campaigns, which helped the Smiths reach number one but enraged indie purists. Eventually, the pressure of constantly battling the mainstream took its toll. From Stiff Little Fingers to the Smiths (who decamped to EMI but split before recording a note, to Travis's delight), the record label had always lost bands to the majors' chequebooks, but had either "made money, or lost a little bit". But, unbeknown to Travis, the distribution end was in trouble.

"Fundamentally, it got too big too quickly for the people running that side of the business," Travis claims. "Human nature being what it is, nobody said, 'Help, we're drowning.'"

Thus, in 1991 Travis's entire empire - apart from the shop, which had been handed over to its workers in 1983 - went down "like a pack of cards". As the entire back catalogue was sold to pay off debts, Travis says he was left "like Morrissey sang, 'without a stitch to wear' ", although he has since done far better than most of the Rough Trade workers who were made redundant. In the 1990s Travis managed, among others, Pulp and the Cranberries. He also devoted energies to Blanco Y Negro, the Warner subsidiary he set up in 1983 to work with independent bands such as the Jesus and Mary Chain and Everything But the Girl, who sought help in making the difficult transition to a major label. He is now overseeing the debut album from Elizabeth Fraser of the Cocteau Twins. But even Travis's keenest admirers concede that the man can be fickle, flitting from cause to cause like a bee from flower to flower. However, he seems sincere when he says his heart is with Rough Trade.

Rough Trade's revival comes at an intriguing time for independent music. Following years of fake "indies" set up by the majors to make their bands look cool, genuine independents - such as Domino and City Slang - are again infiltrating the top 20, retaining Rough Trade's blueprint of a 50/50 profit split. There are also scores of dance independents. "There's a real line now between what a major label wants and what an independent label wants," says Travis's former protege, Mute's Daniel Miller. "Hopefully, artists and some managers will now understand that there are two ways of working. One is huge advance, lots of money for the video, and if it doesn't work - fuck off. The other one is not a big advance, not a big marketing spend, but the right approach for the right group, who will hopefully grow over the space of a few albums."

Perhaps, as Travis says of 1976, there are again "possibilities in the air". He is already enthusing about his next great new band, the Mouldy Beaches, whom he describes as "a fantastic cross between Beck and the Television Personalities, with really outrageous but endearing songs".

"It was never about having hits," says Travis. "It was about making fantastic records. There are still amazing things in music; you've just got to look for them. My job is to make that process easier."

webTitle: The BBC explains the future of television

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.standfirst: TV producers gathered earlier this month to watch a man in his underpants being spanked by a leather-clad woman. Why? Because the BBC was explaining the future of television.
fields.trailText: TV producers gathered earlier this month to watch a man in his underpants being spanked by a leather-clad woman. Why? Because the BBC was explaining the future of television.
fields.body:
The BBC recently held an intimate cheese and wine do for 1,000 independent producers at the National Film Theatre on London's South Bank. Rows of 40-something men with furrowed brows and crumpled linen suits sat obediently through the briefing, jotting down buzzwords like BOLD, INVENTIVE, MODERN, read from an invisible lectern by commissioning editors half their age, wearing low-slung denim.

In the break, they piled into the foyer muttering "we've heard it all before" and "same old crap" to one another, before returning to the theatre to watch clips of a middle-aged man in underpants being spanked by a leather-clad dominatrix, a taster of things to come on BBC3. One producer said the clip felt like a metaphor for his relationship with the BBC.

The aim of the briefing was to show programme-makers the kind of shows wanted for the new BBC digital channels. The real news was that the corporation wanted to kill off docusoaps, that trusty ratings-cow of the 90s. Now deemed, of course, too 90s.

So, no more stressed travel reps, frantic flight attendants, shirty traffic wardens, batty driving instructors. No more ballet boys, neighbours from hell, salesmen from hell, rat catchers, debt collectors, sick children, sick animals, or camp airport staff called Jeremy who - once the nation had embraced him as the next Dale Winton - confessed that he was married with two kids.

The BBC's Controller of Factual Commissioning, Nicola Moody, believes that reports of the death of docusoap are premature. "Docusoaps aren't dead. They're simply [pause] changing."

Changing, yes, because two Channel 4 shows, Big Brother and The 1940s House, have pulled the carpet from under the corporation's feet. Two ideas which combined docusoap with a clever twist and, compared to watching a camp man at Heathrow fielding complaints about the luggage carousel, were BOLD, INVENTIVE and, yes, MODERN too.

Controller of BBC3's channel-in-waiting, Stuart Murphy, the man responsible for the spanking session at the NFT, has a different explanation for the demise of docusoap. "When Driving School began, there was an innocence about the format, but as a deluge of contrived ideas rained down, viewers came to trust the broadcaster less and less."

At 27, Murphy is the corporation's youngest ever controller, tipped by many to be ruling everything by 30. At present, he's in charge of reviving factual programmes by commissioning docusoaps like - cough - The Clap Clinic (yes, it's about a clap clinic, but no prospect of Robin Asquith chasing nurses round in suspenders).

Though old-style docusoap is evidently on its way out, the genre had a brief honeymoon period, coinciding with Maureen from Driving School's elevation to L-plated celebrity. From wildly swerving lunatic to icon for batty middle-aged women everywhere.

Maureen was the first star of docusoap, and Anna from Big Brother the last. Both emerged as kooky heroines, their fame guaranteed by the fact that they seemed largely untouched by it (at least, not until Maureen released a cover of the Madness hit Driving In My Car).

By the time we got to The Cruise, with karaoke queen Jane McDonald, the honeymoon was over. Massacring Tony Bennett songs and fronting her own spin-off show, the aptly named Star For A Night, the audience had had enough.

Docusoap had to change, but intimations of its imminent demise would carry more conviction were it not for the fact the BBC are transmitting a spanking new one, Heart Of Harlesden, on Tuesday.

Set in what estate agents might call London's "vibrant" (ie black) community, Heart Of Harlesden follows three prime-time-friendly residents through the local rubbish-strewn streets, desperate to capture some Bad Bwoy Gun Business on camera.

Why Harlesden? The producers were, according to the BBC press office, interested in looking at what kind of community survives in an area of high drug-related crime.

Actually, they wanted a black Paddington Green. A gritty, gun-toting version of life on da streets, far, far away from cruise ships and driving instructors. Peckham would have been on the BBC's shortlist, but the Damilola tragedy put paid to that.

"Harlesden is", says local journalist Martin Edwards in episode one, "the murder capital of Britain, synonymous with Harlem." This must have given it the edge over Chalfont St Peter on the BBC shortlist.

Located a mere ciabatta's throw from Television Centre, Heart Of Harlesden aims to prove a renewed commitment by the corporation to BOLD, MODERN subject matter. The sort of subject matter, ironically, that the BBC would have tackled in the 70s.

"Heart Of Harlesden has traditional observational film-making at its heart," says Nicola Moody, "but goes deeper into the subject than a docusoap would have done in the past."

Yet there's little evidence of this from episode one, which seems curiously muted and distinctly reticent to explore the heart of its title.

Moody's reference to "traditional observational film-making", however, is designed to quell a much deeper worry for those independent producers' furrowed brows, peeking over the tops of notepads at the NFT.

Namely, that as controllers come under increasing pressure to deliver high ratings with BOLD, MODERN entertainment shows, and as entertainment becomes their sole remit, serious TV journalism will be squeezed out altogether.

Murphy's counterpart at E4, Danny Cohen, agrees that there's a natural conflict of interest. "The first thing you realise when you make factual programmes is how disloyal viewers can be. If there's a dull second in a show, you've lost them."

For all the speak of sexy, in-your-face programming for a digital future, TV is actually going back to the 50s - to a period of safe, depoliticised television, on the cusp of a big commercial shake-up, and hence obsessed with providing commercial entertainment at the expense of anything more challenging to the viewer.

The real story for many of the independent producers present at the NFT briefing wasn't the death of docusoaps, but the death of documentary film-making as a whole.

When I ask Moody about this, she poo-poos the idea, pointing to Heart Of Harlesden and the recent Boston Law as proof of the BBC's commitment to factual programming.

It's significant, however, that Moody defends factual by emphasising its entertainment potential: "Many new developments in TV have come from factual. Big Brother is simply traditional observational film-making with a game-show twist. Survivor, when it arrives in Britain, will push the genre still further."

Retaining serious documentaries in a marketplace stuffed with programmes about lobotomised teenagers stranded on islands or learning how to become S Club 7 (preferably at the same time) is a noble aim, but ultimately futile.

As television splinters into 1,000 Balkanised digital channels, each fighting over custody of 12 viewers, documentary will disappear.

Stuart Murphy believes that factual programmes will survive, but only by mutating into 57 varieties of twisted entertainment. E4's Danny Cohen agrees. "Docusoaps may be an unfashionable 90s buzzword, but there'll always be an appetite for snapshots of real life."

And snapshot is the word. As TV undergoes its biggest shake-up since the creation of ITV, channel controllers have bigger fish to fry than the survival of reality TV. Namely, will TV programmes themselves survive when channels cease to look like channels at all? Someone should make a documentary about it.

 Heart Of Harlesden, tomorrow, 10pm, BBC2

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst:
5. Julia Barfield
Wonder: Palm House, Kew
Blunder: Mondial House
fields.trailText: 5. Julia Barfield
fields.body:
My all-time favourite building is the Palm House at Kew. It is such a wonderful synthesis of architecture and engineering. There is a very organic feel to the symmetry of the building. The roof of the new Great Court in the British Museum shares the same incredible quality of light, but doesn't have the delicacy of structure that the Palm House has.

I was lucky to have the opportunity to see the Palm House when the recent refurbishment had just been finished. It was before they put all the plants back, so it was completely empty. Experiencing the pure space was wonderful. I think the success of the Palm House and other Victorian glasshouses is down to the use of so many small elements of structure. The restrictions on the size of glass used meant that the end result was far more delicate and fine than many modern buildings. At the risk of admitting to being a hopeless romantic, I think the Alhambra in Grenada is one of the most magical buildings I have ever seen. The structure is such an intoxicating combination of colour, light, moving water and landscape - it has everything in one building.

Mondial House, a British Telecom office building on the north bank of the river in London, looks like a computer that has been left by a careless giant. There are so many important institutions and absolute jewels of British architecture such as Lambeth Palace, the Houses of Parliament and Tower Bridge standing cheek by jowl with really vile buildings on the riverside. So many of them are nothing more than nameless, faceless and offensive examples of 1980s developers' architecture. The river is London's greatest asset and should showcase our best architecture, not our worst.

 Julia Barfield co-designed the London Eye.

fields.headline: Raw Blues
fields.standfirst: The Metropolitan Police have been badly stitched up by documentary makers in the past. But the latest series about them, Raw Blues, is little more than a slick PR job
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan Police have been badly stitched up by documentary makers in the past. But the latest series about them, Raw Blues, is little more than a slick PR job
fields.body:
There was a famous row in the 1980s when it was revealed that MI5 maintained an office in the BBC for the purposes of vetting staff. The spymasters were subsequently evicted, and promises given that desk-space would be restricted to those working in television. It increasingly feels, though, that the Metropolitan Police is sub-letting premises within Television Centre.

Crimewatch UK, which screens its February edition this week, has not only survived the extraordinary circumstances of the murder of its co-presenter, Jill Dando, but has encouraged a copycat morning programme, Crimewatch Daily. These animated wanted posters have long been an obsession of this column because of the departure from usual BBC editorial policy, which they often seem to represent.

In most areas of politics, the BBC correctly insists on balance, a commitment fiercely policed by the thick red lines of editorial felt-tip. Yet, though law enforcement is a huge political issue, the force seems assured of what you might call copper-bottomed support. Crimewatch UK and its new partner in crime-detection surely offer a romanticised picture of the both the methods and detection rate of the police.

Though the confidence in the forces is probably - after the Lawrence case and McPherson Report - lower than at any time in history, BBC1 is currently running 21 editions each month of shows which feature unfailingly polite, diligent, sensitive and, where possible, multi-ethnic detectives.

Serious analysis of the police is left to news programmes and dramas such as Tony Garnett's Cops, where bent and racist coppers are to be found, but with the inevitable implication that such disgraces to the uniform are only fictional.

The criminal softness towards cops in magazine and documentary output is especially worthy of investigation because it was factual programmes on the BBC - through Roger Graef's justly famous series Police - which first exposed the troubling assumptions of many officers.

Raw Blues, BBC1's new cop-observing series, which starts this week, has nothing to do with Graef, but any DNA test would find the fingerprints of his inspiration. The problem is that Graef caught the police unawares, like burglars in the early days of CCTV who were amazed when their denials were silenced with snapshots of them climbing through the window. When Police was made, no one understood how damning the cameras could be. But the police now regard TV as a photo-opportunity, and show their best face.

Scheduled suspiciously shoulder-to-shoulder on Wednesday between Crimewatch UK and Crimewatch UK Update, Raw Blues frequently feels as if it could have been made by the Met as a recruitment video. The opening shots, admittedly, are surprising and apparently damning. It's before dawn in London and police have a problem with a stabbing victim. The man, who is black, stands in the street, his body patched with red like a stigmatic. He refuses, though, to let the police help him. Bizarrely stealing their lines, he commands: "I want to see you now against the wall." The implication is shocking and clear. After Lawrence and McPherson, a black stabbing victim sees the arrival of the police as a moment of danger. As their car shrieks near, sirens go off in his mind.

This feels a Graef-like moment. But it soon becomes clear that we've picked the wrong film out of the identity parade. The documentary's initial pessimism is merely a downpayment on optimism, as the scene switches to a proud exhibit for the defence. At Hendon Police College, the latest recruits are arriving. A stern instructor warns that anyone who's "racist, sexist, homophobic or who's a bully" should walk out of the room.

Cynics or readers of McPherson might feel at this point that police would be needed to control the stampede. But the cameras are present and the speech is, anyway, advertising rhetoric. From this moment, the documentary is dead. You always feel that the police are letting us see what they want us to see, as surely as if they were printing posters. In Graef's day, people were so naive about TV that they behaved naturally. Now most know to be vile in private.

Candour does occasionally peep through the cracks in the PR façade.

It's intriguing that, despite the speeches about exclusivity, some intolerances are still accepted. Classism, for example. Mike, a graduate entrant, is clearly despised by his tutors as a toff. When he scores 100% in one exam, a sarky sarge mutters that it's not the ones who get top marks who make the best officers.

And, while racial prejudice is now apparently outlawed from the law, facial prejudice remains OK. New recruit Craig gets into trouble for his stubble. Police must be either clean-shaven or full-bearded, he is told. Presumably it helps to distinguish them from the criminals - photofits always make people look unshaved.

The most interesting sequence is a training exercise on stereotyping. The cadets are shown six cars and asked to guess the owner from clues strewn around the vehicle. Does a box of wine mean middle-class? Do rust and scratches denote lower-class? Raw Blues is clearly designed - by the Metropolitan Police, if not the BBC - to end the widespread assumption that people who drive white four-door Fords with numbers and a blue light on the top are sexist, racist, thugs. But it doesn't reassure as much as it wants to, because of a feeling that the evidence is rigged.

 Raw Blue, Wednesday, 10.35pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: A very British protest
fields.trailText: Protest Song | The Exeter Riddles
fields.body:
My one brush with the law while making a political protest came in the mid-1980s, when the US bombed Libya. Driving home from a Shirley Bassey concert (yes, I know, Naomi Klein take a seat, love), I hooted my support for the crowd gathering at Downing Street to make complaint. Stopped by the police, treated like Carlos the Jackal, I somehow got through interrogation without bursting into a chorus of Big Spender, and continued home feeling all anarchic, muttering about "pigs".

What I loved about Protest Song (Radio 3), the first half of Saturday's Between The Ears double bill, was that it included this kind of surreal, embarrassing and strange moment in its history of the British way of protesting, told through news footage and personal recollections from seven decades.

Last year's fuel crisis, the 1931 hunger march from Glasgow to London, Poll Tax protests, the Miners' Strike, the voices of Iraqi refugees... a reminder of Britain's radical past, so battered by Thatcherism. A 77-year-old, caught up in the edges of a demonstration, is told the demonstrators are fighting for his freedom. "I told them," he said - and you could hear him shaking his head in disbelief - "I fought for my own freedom, thank you, in Burma. My freedom indeed!"

There was a fruity-voiced gent of a farmer and his pig in a state of some confusion in Hyde Park ("We weren't sure if we were going to be unloading it"), a miner's wife provoked into violence ("I'd never thrown a stone before - on the second morning I took a bloody bagful") and the emergence of the 1990s protester, "the double crusty", hardcore and with nothing to lose.

My favourite story, as it involves clueless people looking silly, as I did post-Bassey, was of folk queuing for returns to see Peter Ustinov's one-man show on St Martin's Lane, caught up in a demo. Police went in with batons, not discriminating between double crusties and Ustinov fans. Ustinov came out - to join in the protest? Nope. "These are my people," he yelled to the police, meaning only the ticket queue. "Leave them alone."

Just as we have the right to peaceful protest, and the right to queue to see Peter Ustinov, so we have a right to experimental broadcasting. This often brings gems in Between The Ears, but The Exeter Riddles , the second half of Saturday's double bill, really did abuse that right. However much setting medieval riddles to witchypoo music, complete with bat noises and deranged operatic singing, might look like a good idea on paper - actually, it doesn't, does it? - the reality was shrill torture. It sounded like an underfunded amateur opera society doing an avant-garde remake of The Wicker Man. Under protest.

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you
fields.body:
Ballykissangel returns to BBC1 on Thursday, with a couple of hot new cast members. Susannah Doyle, who joins the cast as Avril Burke, a horse trainer, is an unusual (and slightly freaky) piece of casting because her father, the late Tony Doyle, graced the show as Quigley for the first five series. Quigley himself, one can't help but feel, would have been gratified to know that nepotism is flourishing in BallyK's sleepy corner of County Wicklow. But typecasting certainly isn't an issue. Also joining the new series, playing Father Vincent Sheahan, is Robert Taylor - probably best known before now as the insidious Agent Brown in sci-fi blockbuster The Matrix.

The makers of the forthcoming celebrity edition of Big Brother, to be broadcast over one week starting on March 9, have announced that - unlike the original - there will be no cameras in the toilet or shower room. Is this a cop out, or just a canny realisation that the world is not yet ready for images of Frank Skinner (one of the rumoured contestants) astride the throne?

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Beautiful Girls | Live Futsal | Five Go Dating
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton and Richard Vine
fields.body:
Films

Beautiful Girls (Ted Demme, 1996) 8pm, FilmFour Timothy Hutton's club pianist returns to a high-school reunion and ponders marriage to lawyer girlfriend Annabeth Gish while hanging out with his old pals (a bratty gang comprising Matt Dillon, Max Perlich, Michael Rappaport, Noah Emmerich). Sex, relationships and the unreconstructed male are the subject of Demme's (brother of Jonathan) perceptive and entertaining tale. Among the beautiful girls are Rosie O'Donnell, Martha Plimpton, Mira Sorvino, Uma Thurman and the precocious Natalie Portman.

The Hand That Rocks The Cradle (Curtis Hanson, 1992) 8pm, Sky Cinema Rebecca De Mornay is splendidly icy as the nanny from hell, an inverted Mary Poppins out to terrorise the family she blames for all her woes (miscarriage, divorce). But Hanson, director of LA Confidential, is none too subtle here, settling for the over-the-top tone of a child's tantrum, when some of the teasing play on parental fears suggests he might have nurtured a genuinely scary movie.

8MM (Joel Schumacher, 1999) 11.05pm, Sky MovieMax This low-life wallow stars Nicolas Cage in world-weary private investigator mode, hired by a widow to find out whether the snuff movie found among her dead husband's possessions is the real thing. The trail through LA's hardcore underworld is long and sludgy, enlivened by Joaquin Phoenix as the sex-shop assistant who agrees to be the gumshoe's guide, and Peter Stormare's frantic porn-maker.

Hammett (Wim Wenders, 1982) 1.15am, Studio The first US film by German wunderkind Wenders, made at Francis Ford Coppola's Zoetrope Studios. It was a fraught affair, delayed for three years of extensive revision before its release, but worth the wait. Set in San Francisco 1928, it has detective-turned-writer Dashiell Hammett dragged into the deeply noir case of a missing Chinese prostitute. Frederic Forrest is almost Bogartian as Hammett, living Sam Spade's adventures; hard-boiled Peter Boyle is brilliant as Pinkerton man Jimmy Ryan. Elisha Cook Jr and Sam Fuller are one pair of craggy faces among many.

Sports

Live Futsal 1.30pm, 4pm, British Eurosport There's something about Mondays. Perhaps the television companies, in their wisdom, believe us to be worn out by a weekend of sporting over-indulgence. Or perhaps it's they that are worn out. But either way, something is consistently going wrong. Thank heavens, then, for Eurosport, who will broadcast absolutely anything that's going, whatever the hour, and who today bring us the semi-finals of the Futsal European Cup from Moscow. And roll on Tuesday.

Entertainment

Five Go Dating 5pm, E4 A new dating show exploring the maths of love. Five girls. Five boys. Two London flats, and lots of dates - but can any of them find The One?

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: View from the ridge
fields.trailText: View from the ridge
fields.body:
The Lake District

On a lovely, sunny February day, for my first little outing after illness, we ambled along Loughrigg Terrace from White Moss Common, then down through Deerbolts Wood, back along the lakeshore footpath and by the sparkling Rothay. We could just pick out people scrambling along the top of Eagle Crag, and the closer views were even more interesting. Down below, the brimming lake of Grasmere, like a huge, burnished mirror, reflected the distant snow patches on the heights. Then the first tiny ripples on the beach, and we spotted a canoe, paddles glinting in the sunlight, slowly gliding across the lake and, a few moments later, attempting, unsuccessfully, the Rothay rapids a few hundred feet below us. Passing Rydal Water, we'd noticed the mere was lightly skimmed with ice and I remembered much colder winters when we skated here - the first of the lakes to freeze, week after week.

Today, there wasn't a whisper of wind; it was warm enough to sit in the sunshine by the lake shore or in a beer garden by the roadside. Indeed, it was so windless and still that a manned balloon, perhaps from Holker Hall, remained stationary in the air above the lake for several minutes. Loughrigg, not traversed this time, is one of the most magical little hills in Lakeland - splendidly girt with woodlands, scattered with tarns, crags and caves and traversed by many tracks around the summits. A favourite round of mine from Ambleside is to seek out all the summits in turn, continue along the ridge to Silver How and then, on the return, deliberately avoid them, finding different ways - a pleasant exercise in gentle route-finding.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Fictional Familiars | The Brit Awards | Night Waves
fields.body:
Authors in search of a plot have increasingly taken to revisiting characters created by others. Memorably, the story of Dr Jekyll's maid or that of Mrs Rochester, locked in a Yorkshire attic while her husband dallies with the governess. Similar new perspectives on well-known books are offered by Fictional Familiars (Radio 4, 3.30pm). Whitbread Book Of The Year-winner Matthew Kneale takes on Charles Dickens in the first episode. Oliver Twist is no longer a cherubic lad; Jack Dawkins, aka the Artful Dodger, has done his time in Australia. An unexpected meeting reveals that while Jack has gone to the dogs and back, Oliver isn't living the expected happy ending.

A cynic might see Eminem's invitation to The Brit Awards (Radio 1, 8pm; Richard Allinson, Radio 2, 10.30pm) as a desperate plea for the kind of behaviour for which this awards bash is remembered, but whether or not the rap "bad boy" performs, there will be contributions from U2 (outstanding achievers), Coldplay, Craig Charles, and presenters Ant and Dec.

Night Waves (Radio 3, 9.30pm) offers a cerebral alternative. Patrick Wright talks to Richard Latham, a former RUC man who has just published his account of working for one of the world's most notorious police forces. And as a prelude to World Book Day, Wright discusses a Unesco project to make a selection of every culture's important literary works available worldwide.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Army runaways surrender | Man accused of 1968 murder | Four killed in plane crash | Children take up mobiles | DNA check on students | Five share £6m jackpot
fields.body:
Army runaways surrender

Senior officers are questioning two soldiers who have given themselves up at Colchester barracks in Essex after months on the run.

Heidi Cochrane, 24, a lance-bombardier in the Royal Artillery, and Jason Archer, 30, a sergeant in the same regiment, went absent without leave last July in Cyprus.

Man accused of 1968 murder

A gardener has been charged with murdering a 14-year-old schoolboy in 1968, police said yesterday.

webTitle: Prescott has his say before £1bn Railtrack bail out

fields.headline: Prescott has his say before £1bn Railtrack bail out
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack is to be issued with tough conditions before ministers agree to release a further £1bn to help the company get back to normal after the Hatfield rail disaster.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to be issued with tough conditions before ministers agree to release a further £1bn to help the company get back to normal after the Hatfield rail disaster.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is expecting a team of inspectors, who will be paid for by Railtrack, to pore over the company's spending plans to make sure that they are properly managed. The team will report directly to the rail regulator.

Government sources confirmed last night that Mr Prescott is also anxious for Railtrack to have its new chairman in place by the election. The present chairman, Sir Philip Beck, is due retire in July, but has agreed to speed up the recruitment process, which will result in the appointment being made before May.

Ministers cannot directly influence the choice, but there is a tacit understanding that the new chairman will make sweeping changes on the board. This could include the eventual replacement of Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, hurriedly brought in to replace the sacked Gerald Corbett at the end of last year.

Industry sources said that the Labour Party was working on a statement on the railway industry for the election. The prime minister is furious that Railtrack will have failed to return the industry to normal working by then.

He has taken exception to the post-Hatfield panic measures which almost closed the railway, and where rail cracking is still being discovered. Some replacement work has had to be done again, swelling the £900m Hatfield bill.

Labour could play an election card by announcing the re-nationalisation of Railtrack but is reluctant to make the move, though no final decisions have been made.

The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, is sending in a team of consultants to report on how far behind Railtrack has fallen on normal maintenance work because of Hatfield. The company faces heavy fines if it is found guilty of incompetence.

Railtrack has also been found guilty of compromising safety by the regulator after appointing its company secretary, Simon Osborne, to the same role at Rail Safety, a Railtrack subsidiary set up after the Paddington rail crash.

Mr Winsor has told Railtrack that it is not legitimate for Mr Osborne to carry out both jobs and that a separate appointment must be made.

webTitle: Everyone's anxious to forget the stench of British sleaze

fields.headline: Everyone's anxious to forget the stench of British sleaze
fields.standfirst: The best defence against corruption in public life is vigilance
fields.trailText: We live in dirty old times. There is Bill Clinton and his pardons, Jacques Chirac and his deals, Helmut Kohl and his party cash; there is Yoshiro Mori and some dubious Japanese cronies, Bulent Ecevit and some dodgy Turkish ministers. And that's before the stinking legacy of François Mitterrand or matters Italian get tossed in the pot. Dirty old times round a dirty old world.
fields.body:
We live in dirty old times. There is Bill Clinton and his pardons, Jacques Chirac and his deals, Helmut Kohl and his party cash; there is Yoshiro Mori and some dubious Japanese cronies, Bulent Ecevit and some dodgy Turkish ministers. And that's before the stinking legacy of François Mitterrand or matters Italian get tossed in the pot. Dirty old times round a dirty old world.

Who can doubt (with the leader writer of the Daily Mail this weekend) that, against such a background, "the British experience may seem almost pristine"? Have we a home-grown "philandering scoundrel" to match the ex-president of the United States for "tawdriness and venality"? Against the "dishonesty and deceit of European politics", the travails of Peter Mandelson and Derry Irvine "hardly register on the Richter scale of sleaze".

Well, jolly good - though, this being the Mail, Tony Blair and the "arrogance of New Labour" naturally get their warning bumps along the way. Nevertheless, Britain starts this election with the comforting assumption that, compared to the damned foreigners, our escutcheon is pretty blot free. Charges of sleaze will be thrown around - they usually are - but the body politic can cope.

To which there are two vital responses. One involves a little thoughtfulness about the nature of corruption itself and the way the media pack chooses its targets. Mr Clinton, for instance, may have been an idiot over his 171 pardons, but none of the money involved is yet tied to him personally and he didn't invent the practice of dishing out free exit passes to the rich and powerful. His brother-in-law spent eight barren years while Hillary was in the White House not getting rich.

The fascination of this business, for the moment, is observing the way that those who leave office (especially working-class boys from the wrong state and the wrong school) get shafted once they lose power. Those who inherit that power, meanwhile, seem to have very few questions asked. I was baffled in the States last year to understand why vice-president Cheney's pay-off from the big oil company he ran, and the stock options he continued to hold, didn't make it beyond page 327 of the New York Times. Thirty million dollars seemed a tidy sum. But Dick, like George W, was a coming man. Dick can now be made America's energy supremo, among other things, and nobody blinks. Perhaps they're right - or perhaps we shall only hear about it again much later. But the moving finger, to these eyes anyway, writes in a baffling scrawl.

The other response, however, starts and stays much nearer to home. It is rooted in that fundamental assumption of relative cleanliness which still underpins the attitudes of our great and good leaders - best shown, a few years ago, when a supposedly investigating cabinet secretary chose to believe Jonathan Aitken's wholly mendacious account of events without even an ephemeral check - because the minister had given his word. We believe ourselves "almost pristine". We discern few tremors on our Richter scale.

There is, in sum, a curious dislocation between experience and expectation. Take Robert Maxwell. He is history, a scoundrel 10 years in his grave: the amazingly delayed DTI report into his dealings seems to be history, too. Nobody in particular gets blamed and those who collect modest opprobrium are dead anyway. The ocean of assumption remains blissfully calm. Such things, in our benign mantra, can never happen again.

Equally, when Mohamed Al Fayed blows the whistle on a bevy of corrupt MPs, the boomerang comes back with predictable complacency. Who doled out the cash for questions in the first place? Why, Mr Fayed: what a very unsuitable British citizen! Yet no one has the spunk to recall that we only knew about these dealings because Mr Fayed told us so in the first place.

Another great old British tradition: abuse the whistleblower and make yourself feel better, cloak the past and the dead in benevolence. (Just compare the kindly obituaries of Sir Michael Grylls in the papers last week with Andrew Roth's lonely Guardian remembrance of the "most senior and voracious MP run by the lobbyist Ian Greer".)

I don't set out here to play witchfinder general. On the contrary, a reverse assumption of chronic mistrust is neither sensible nor merited. But there are crucial things to keep in mind; and there are crucial defences which need sustaining.

Do you, for instance, remember how the committee on standards and privileges published its report on the activities of the then Scottish secretary, John Reid, at the last gasp before Christmas, embarrassment buried in mistletoe and holly? Can we expect the same committee's verdict on Keith Vaz to appear before or after the next election? (No, don't bother to bet.) And meanwhile the weevils are clearly chomping at the whole framework of parliamentary self-regulation. John Major could be found giving evidence to that committee the other day, attacking the "unnecessarily intrusive" rules the commissioner worked to and wanting the entire underpinning of the system "to go back to basics" (and more lawyers). It will be more than interesting to see whether the commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, gets her contract renewed this summer - or whether some kinder, gentler soul will be found to serve.

Thus, once more, we instinctively consign unpleasing experience to history, deem the stables cleaned and honorable members suitably disinfected at the farm gate. Thus we move on. Rules once made are there to be ameliorated.

It is a dotty, self-deluding way to go. It leaves us frothing over surface matters - Lord Irvine, after all, wasn't exactly fundraising in private - and lowering a blanket over deeper trends. Yet the real basics of anti-corruption defences couldn't be clearer. They are eternal vigilance and the mechanisms to exercise it properly. And for that to work, those mechanisms have (in Major's words) to have "clarity and certainty".

Heaven knows what the Hammond report on Peter Mandelson - as variously spun yesterday - actually says, but clarity and certainty would only have come if they'd been on offer before the event, if an independent investigation had been ordered before the resignation, not fudged together too late. Heaven knows what the eventual report on Keith Vaz will say, but it would have been better, far better, if HMG had stayed out of the briefing game and let the designated authorities get on with their job.

Politics, in its fungoid creep, is not the natural defender of probity. Nor, at least automatically, is a press which might easily have been part-owned by the brothers Hinduja. "Pristine" is as pristine does. Independence is mandatory. Due process means being fair to Michael Portillo and Peter Mandelson. And memory is more than Christine Keeler rattling away 40 years later; it is being brave enough to keep the past alive.

webTitle: Eads may pull out of air traffic control bidding

fields.headline: Eads may pull out of air traffic control bidding
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Government plans to sell off Britain's national air traffic control system received another setback yesterday when it was revealed that an important bidder may withdraw from the deal.
fields.body:
Government plans to sell off Britain's national air traffic control system received another setback yesterday when it was revealed that an important bidder may withdraw from the deal.

Eads, the European aerospace and defence company, yesterday refused to deny that it had pulled out of the Nimbus consortium, one of the two groups left in the bidding.

Industry sources said the Eads board had rejected a proposal to join Nimbus earlier this month.

They said that some board members are concerned that such a move would anger the company's airline customers, who have backed a rival bid for the privatisation.

Nimbus, led by the outsourcing group Serco, is said to be the government's favourite in the privatisation race.

The winner will take a 46% stake in the air traffic business, and become the effective provider of air traffic control.

The government still faces pressure to delay the project at least until after the election, however.

Paul Noon, leader of air traffic controllers' union, IPMS, said last night: "Every bidder is flawed.

"You just cannot throw open control of our skies to the private sector."

The political temperature has been increased by disclosures that the safety group advising Nats has said it will resign if the contract is awarded to Nimbus.

webTitle: Slaughter begins as dirty farm row grows

fields.headline: Slaughter begins as dirty farm row grows
fields.standfirst:
Controls Northumberland 'source' farm was inspected last month

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The full horror of the Northumberland farm believed to be the source of the foot and mouth outbreak began to emerge last night as the Ministry of Agriculture prepared for the mass incineration of hundreds of infected pigs in a field beside the Tyne Valley.
fields.body:
The full horror of the Northumberland farm believed to be the source of the foot and mouth outbreak began to emerge last night as the Ministry of Agriculture prepared for the mass incineration of hundreds of infected pigs in a field beside the Tyne Valley.

Amid concern about welfare conditions at Burnside Farm, Heddon-on-the-Wall, after a string of complaints, ministry vets had served its operators with a special notice last December warning that conditions must be improved within a month, it was revealed.

When they returned late in January, vets reported that conditions had improved, although they were still not adequate, a Maff spokesman told the Guardian.

A further visit was planned this month but plans were overtaken by the foot and mouth outbreak.

Some of those who had complained to local councils and animal welfare organisations, triggering the special inspections by the ministry and effectively setting alarm bells ringing, were adamant yesterday that Burnside was a disaster waiting to happen.

But the ministry went out of its way to stress that, late in January, there were positively no traces of foot and mouth in pigs at the farm, which is effectively a fattening centre where animals are sent before a long journey to abattoirs in the south.

Death came speedily to Burnside yesterday. Ministry experts and labourers built a giant pyre by carefully laying 250 railway sleepers across a 150ft long pit, and piling 75 tonnes of coal and two lorry-loads of straw on top.

Eight hundred and fifty pigs and 35 cattle, covered with oil and diesel, were placed on the pyre in what amounted to a two-day long construction exercise. Cremations on this scale do not come quickly, or cheaply.

Clad in bright yellow and red overalls, the workers had supervised mechanical excavators, tractors and dumper trucks carrying the remains of pigs from two farms at Heddon-on-the-Wall - Bobby and Ronald Waugh's holding at Burnside, with its 500 pigs, believed to be the original source, and Jimmy and Joan Brown's neighbouring unit at Heddon View, with 350 pigs and 35 cattle.

After taking blood samples from the pigs, ministry vets spent two days "humanely" killing the animals with stun guns, carefully recording particulars from each beast.

After slaughter, they soon discovered that the Heddon View pigs, initially condemned to death as a precaution, also had traces of foot and mouth - making the outbreak far bigger than initial estimates suggested.

The Browns, who have been keeping pigs at Heddon View for 35 years, are reluctant to criticise their neighbours and have refused to join the chorus of disapproval against the Waugh brothers, who have insisted in a statement issued through the National Farmers' Union that it was not in their interest to have unhealthy pigs.

But Mrs Brown told a local newspaper yesterday: "It's just unfortunate they didn't farm the same way we farmed."

With farmers in Northumberland fearful of the disease spreading - cattle at another farm beside Newcastle airport four miles away have already been condemned - the Ministry of Agriculture revealed last night that Burnside had been giving its officials cause for concern since last December.

It was forced to take action after the RSPCA was refused access to Burnside following a complaint to the charity by the Norfolk-based Hillside animal sanctuary on December 18.

The sanctuary said it had been told by a reliable Northumberland contact that rotting pig carcasses had been left alongside live pigs and that pieces of raw meat were left lying around the farm.

The RSPCA complained to Northumberland county council trading standards department, which has animal welfare functions, and on December 22 ministry vets visited Burnside with county officials.

A notice warning the Waughs to improve conditions was served, the ministry said. "Conditions were described as rather dirty and not ideal," said a spokesman.

By January 24, when a follow-up visit was made, conditions had improved, although the ministry said they were still not adequate. "But the pigs at that time were said to be healthy and not in any way distressed," the spokesman said.

A further visit was scheduled for a month later.

After visiting the stricken area yesterday, Joyce Quin, the minister of state for agriculture, said that while they were always concerned about welfare matters, it would be wrong to pre-judge the outcome of any inquiry.

Asked about locals raising fears about Burnside several months' ago, she said officials on January 24 saw no sign of disease at the farm.

"Obviously, welfare related problems are pursued also - sometimes by a slightly different avenue - but the responsibility of the department on that inspection was to see whether there was disease on the farm and at that point they did not find disease.

"But let me say a number of inquiries are being made as a result of the outbreak here and while I cannot prejudge the outcome of those I am very keen that the inquiry should be as thorough as possible.

"We believe we are taking every measure possible to contain the outbreak but a lot of tracing has to go on.

"There are trading links between various parts of the country and they have to be investigated."

She said the department took welfare concerns very seriously and acted when there was enough evidence to prosecute.

webTitle: NHS systems firm to float at £100m

fields.headline: NHS systems firm to float at £100m
fields.trailText: System C Healthcare, which specialises in installing computer systems in NHS hospitals, is considering a stock market flotation that could value it at up to £100m.
fields.body:
System C Healthcare, which specialises in installing computer systems in NHS hospitals, is considering a stock market flotation that could value it at up to £100m.

The firm, based in Kent, will move a step away from its start-up roots and closer to public limited company status this morning, when it appoints two senior industry figures as chief executive and finance director.

Jim Horsburgh, former head of international sales and marketing at software firm Vision, last year sold to Microsoft for $1.5bn (£1bn), has agreed to return to Britain from the US to become chief executive. Steve Emery, a senior member of the NHS information authority, is to be finance director.

Their first task will be to complete a £3m fundraising round ahead of the flotation. System C's present external financing comes from the personal account of Tom Teichman, the chairman of New Media Spark, who was one of the initial backers of Lastminute.com, Arc International and Brightstation.

"Following five years of investment in the development of patient systems for the NHS, System C is now entering a period of rapid growth," said founder Markus Bolton. "I'm delighted to be strength ening the management team with strong executives who have grown businesses successfully before."

System C competes against larger listed firms such as i-soft and Torex in bidding for the NHS's private finance initiative contracts to install patient management systems in hospitals. It has installed systems for 22 NHS trusts; the government has pledged funds of £1.1bn to help improve NHS computer systems.

webTitle: Britain's first new racecourse in more than 70 years

fields.headline: A kingdom for a horse
fields.standfirst: Will jetsetting racegoers one day abandon Dubai and Kentucky for Fairlop Water in Essex? They will if Norman Foster gets his way.  Jonathan Glancey on the plans to build Britain's first new racecourse in more than 70 years
fields.trailText: Will jetsetting racegoers one day abandon Dubai and Kentucky for Fairlop Water in Essex? They will if Norman Foster gets his way. Jonathan Glancey on the plans to build Britain's first new racecourse in more than 70 years
fields.body:
There hasn't been a new racecourse in Britain for donkey's years. Not, in fact, since the track at Taunton was laid out in 1927. There have been many new grandstands - Ascot, Newbury, Newmarket, Cheltenham among them - but because racecourses occupy so much land, and because we already have 59 of them stretching from Perth down to Newton Abbot, they have come low down on the scale of desirable new sporting venues. Especially, perhaps, now that interactive TV and the internet mean that those who like to bet on horses can do so from the comfort of their sofas.

So, if you happened to want, as the Wiggins Group does, to encourage tens of thousands of people out to a new £100m racecourse, you would need to provide something pretty special. In May a month-long public enquiry will examine the proposed design by Foster and Partners for a brand new venue, the London City Racecourse, set in a new leisure park at Fairlop Water on green belt land in Essex. The land is owned by the London Borough of Redbridge; the Wiggins Group holds a 125-year lease on the site, where it runs a golf course with a lake for boating and fishing.

The design, as you might expect from Foster, is special - seductive, space-age modern, a thing of great swooping wings and curves. It echoes the design of the same architects' magnificent Chep Lap Kok airport serving Hong Kong and, if approved, seems sure to bring racing a new audience. Not that racing isn't popular already. Each year five million people turn up at British racecourses primarily to bet, but also to enjoy a very particular day out. There is something special about the excitement generated by gleaming horses being ridden at full tilt by jockeys in colours that rival those of a medieval European battlefield. Many more people follow the horses on TV, of course, or curse and swear in a drunken haze in smoky high street bookies, yet these grim, addictive activities have little to do with the visceral pleasure of a day at the races.

The rituals can be baffling. The byzantine betting system, the arcane semaphore of the tic-tac men, bets of "ponies" and "monkeys" rather than pounds, the comical dress of toffs and would-be toffs in the members' or club enclosures. Measures in furlongs (220 yards) and lengths (the distance between a horse's head and the base of its tail). The bizarre names of the horses themselves: Crepello, St Paddy, Shergar, Nijinsky, Prince Palatine. The hierarchical nature of it all, a parody of the old British class system - upper, middle and working - in the organisation and layout of public enclosures.

From an architectural perspective, few racecourses in spire, although their settings can help. Goodwood - Glorious Goodwood - is set high on the Sussex Downs with views of the sea beyond. It boasts one of Britain's more modern grandstands, but this seems very old-fashioned when set against the bravura design of London City Racecourse. The plan is for this to be set in a new landscaped park, complete with a lake for sailing, a gym and health centre, covered children's play area, golf-driving range and paths for rambling. Although there will be plenty of parking, the course is close to London Underground Central Line stations at Fairlop and Barkingside. Despite the sailing and golfing, the heart of the development will be the racecourse and grandstand.

Unlike most traditional racecourses, which have grown up bit by bit over many years, the grandstand's sightlines are focused on the finishing line; and it's there that the curved roof reaches its high point. The roof, designed like the wing of an aircraft, contains a glazed public walkway between its two skins that will offer views not just across the racecourse and its park, but right down the Lea Valley to the towers of Canary Wharf and the dome of St Paul's. The stables, also designed by Foster and following the same sinuous aesthetic as the grandstand, are on the far side of the finishing line across a natural amphitheatre, so racegoers can see the horses being led into the parade ring without having to leave their seats.

The grandstand will be able to accommodate 10,000 spectators, all of them in direct contact with the track. The bars, restaurants and boxes gathered under the roof will all have windows that actually open - you'd be surprised just how many bars isolate spectators entirely from the events they are meant to have come to see. This is simply a reflection of the way in which buildings increasingly cut us off from the world outside; it's fine for an operating theatre, not much fun in an office, absurd at a cricket ground or racecourse.

Although the design looks sensational - there are few racecourses as grand this side of Dubai - there is no guarantee that the Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport will put it under starter's orders. Expert witnesses for Wiggins - trainer John Gosden; Paul Greeves, racing director of the British Horseracing Board; Tote chairman Peter Jones; and Brough Scott, journalist and Channel 4 racing presenter - will be up against local objectors, including environmental and residents' protest groups. Ron Jeffries, chairman of the local Aldborough Hatch Defence Association (Aldborough Hatch is a suburb of 8,000 residents directly south of the proposed site) has said that the new course will lead to crowding on the Tube and local roads and lower the quality of local life for both people and animals. He worries further, although there is no evidence for this, that Wiggins will want to use the site for other leisure activities such as pop concerts. No one particularly objects to development per se here, because although the site is designated green belt, it has been improved by the developers in recent years. Before it became a park and golf course, it was a waste dump and before that used for gravel extraction. Earlier still, it was an airfield used in both world wars.

It's hard to say what the odds are for the project getting the go-ahead; a decision is likely to be made quickly after the public inquiry. But Oliver Iny, Wiggins's chief executive, is positive. "It most definitely won't be used for pop concerts," he says. "Weddings and Bar Mitzvahs maybe. The point is that this will be London's own racecourse and, as well as a great place to go, it will be connected to the rest of the world. We want it to compete with Dubai and Kentucky, to be the best."

fields.trailText: • According to the Indy's Basildon Peta, Mugabe-expelled Joseph Winter was either "a British correspondent working for the Independent in Harare" (19/2) or a "BBC correspondent (and Independent contributor)" (20/2). But, curiously, Winter's byline has not appeared since July 2000, when he gave way as Our Man in Zimbabwe to ... Basildon Peta.
fields.body:
 According to the Indy's Basildon Peta, Mugabe-expelled Joseph Winter was either "a British correspondent working for the Independent in Harare" (19/2) or a "BBC correspondent (and Independent contributor)" (20/2). But, curiously, Winter's byline has not appeared since July 2000, when he gave way as Our Man in Zimbabwe to ... Basildon Peta.

 After anchoring a record nine Newsnights on the trot (Paxo's prostrate with flu), depping for Jimmy Young all last week and hosting R4's Broadcasting House, BBC utility player Jeremy Vine has a new nickname: News 24. Less wounding than "Mini-Me", the Austin Powers-inspired tag sometimes wickedly attributed to the senior Jeremy.

 Concrete evidence that the special relationship is not dead: as a friendly gesture to Tony Blair, George W Bush has arranged for the Camp David presidential retreat to get BBC America. But what does TB want to watch? Would the almost Westminster-like poisonous ambience of The Weakest Link help him to feel at home?

 Following last week's item on ITN staffers' eagerness to peruse Cosmo's Bedside Book of Kinky Sex, news reaches Monkey of a well-known ITV anchor spotted reading the guidebook at Waterloo station. Vital journalistic research, clearly, but discreet on-air publicity for Media Guardian - a lapel badge, say - will ensure that his name need never appear in this column.

 Newly promoted Mirror news editor Richard Wallace has penned a three-page pep-talk/blistering bollocking telling hacks that if they aren't producing exclusives every day, they can go elsewhere - because he is the guy who has to face Piers Morgan "empty-handed" at morning conference. In a sinister touch, Wallace adds: "We know who you are." And, worse, he knows where they live - the memo was posted to reporters' homes. Taking a rather different approach is the Mail on Sunday's new sports supremo, ex-Sun man Paul Ridley. Underlings now have to high-five their boss each day.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth strikes C4
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A new C4 comedy show pilot has unexpectedly fallen victim to foot and mouth disease, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 23: Agency steps up food-safety publicity
fields.body:
Head Farm, the new Channel 4 comedy show pilot, has unexpectedly fallen victim to foot and mouth disease.

The titles for the new show were to have featured comic Johnny Vegas being dragged along a field by a horse.

But a planned shoot for the item has had to be put on hold as the government announces a ban on moving livestock, or entering farms.

Head Farm is being touted as the big Friday night replacement for TFI Friday.

It is written by This Morning with Richard Not Judy writer Stewart Lee.

It will star a plethora of talent, including Vegas, Garth Marenghi and Jason Freeman from Sky One's Time Gentleman Please.

Mr Lee said: "Its difficult enough to make comedy programmes in the current climate of the cable revolution and cross-channel budget cuts without having the world of virus and microbes turn against you as well as the commissioning editors."

The pilot is being recorded on March 20.

fields.headline: V&A seeks new image
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Interbrand is working with the V&A to help bring its image into the 21st century, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Brand consultancy Interbrand is working with the beleaguered Victoria & Albert museum to help bring its image into the 21st century.

The company behind Barclays Bank's "big world" rebranding campaign, which starred Anthony Hopkins, has been brought on board to help the V&A ditch its "stuffy" and "dusty" image.

The company has already produced a confidential report advising the V&A on what it needs to do.

The national audit office report revealed that visitor numbers had fallen by 200,000 last year.

This makes the V&A Britain's most expensive museum in terms of government subsidy per visitor.

Last year, the V&A hired Lowe Broadway to create its advertising.

Up till now the agency has concentrated on campaigns for specific exhibitions.

However, V&A head of marketing Sarah Gray said the museum was likely to commission a generic branding campaign when the museum's new director Mark Jones arrives.

"We can't make any final decisions until he arrives, obviously, but I think it is likely that we will have a rebranding campaign," she said.

"We've been doing some preliminary work with Interbrand to help us with the brand and we will take it from there."

The report attributed the museum's difficulties to poor marketing and an excessively highbrow image.

Although the V&A has tried to appeal to younger consumers - most recently with an exhibition called Brand.new that featured brands such as Levi's and Nike - it is still viewed as a "dusty" and "stuffy", according to the report.

The V&A has been relatively quiet in recent years, but it was once known for its aggressive marketing methods.

In the early 1990s Saatchi & Saatchi won awards for a poster for the V&A that used the slogan, "An ace caff with quite a nice museum attached".
