webTitle: How can I pay less capital gains tax?

fields.headline: How can I pay less capital gains tax?
fields.trailText: You can offset £7000 by investing in an individual savings account (Isa) if you have not already done so.
fields.body:
You can offset £7000 by investing in an individual savings account (Isa) if you have not already done so.

There are two ways you can use your Isa allowance: a maxi Isa or a series of mini Isas. With a maxi Isa, you can put your whole annual allowance of £7000 into one Isa which can hold a combination of cash savings accounts, stock market investments and life insurance.

Alternatively, you can have up to three mini Isas, one for each of the three types of savings options. In the current tax year, you can invest £3,000 in a cash mini Isa, £3,000 in a stocks and shares mini Isa and £1,000 in a life insurance mini Isa.

If you've still got some spare cash to invest and you're willing to take a risk, you could explore the world of enterprise investment schemes (Eis) and venture capital trusts (VCTs). An Eis allows you to claim tax relief of 20% on investments of up to £150,000 in shares in smaller quoted companies issued after January 1994. There is no capital gains tax to be paid when the shares are first disposed of and any losses on disposal can be offset against an income or capital gains tax bill.

The beauty of an Eis is that tax on capital gains can be deferred by re-investing the money in Eis shares. And there's no limit to the amount of chargeable gains you can defer in this way.

The Revenue permits you to invest up to £100,000 a year in VCTs. These trusts operate like to conventional investment trusts, but invest in small, unquoted trading companies and consequently the risk is greater, but the tax advantages are better. Firstly, you get income tax relief at 20% on the purchase of the shares provided they are held for at least five years. Secondly, dividends from VCTs are free from income tax, and thirdly, any profit from the disposal of your shares is free of capital gains tax too.

If you own an investment jointly, each of you is taxed on half the income or gains unless you have made a declaration that you actually own the investment in unequal proportions, in which case the tax liability is apportioned accordingly.

Consider changing the proportions in which you own investments if one of you pays tax at a lower rate than the other, or if only one of you uses up the annual capital gains tax exemption. You could, for example, make an outright gift of shares to your husband or wife if he or she has no taxable income. But this must be a real gift and you are not permitted to keep control of the money.

Alternatively, you can have up to three mini Isas, one for each of the three types of savings options. In the current tax year, you can invest £3,000 in a cash mini Isa, £3,000 in a stocks and shares mini Isa and £1,000 in a life insurance mini Isa. webTitle: How can I pay less income tax?

fields.headline: How can I pay less income tax?
fields.trailText: There are many reasons why both employed and self-employed people could be paying more tax than they need to, but with a little simple planning, you can cut your tax bill.
fields.body:
There are many reasons why both employed and self-employed people could be paying more tax than they need to, but with a little simple planning, you can cut your tax bill.

First, check your tax code. The Inland Revenue has been known to make mistakes and around one in 10 tax codes are incorrect, mostly because it has been given the wrong information. Take a closer look at your tax coding notice to ensure that it includes your personal allowances and any additional allowances you might be entitled to.

The code is the total figure you are allowed to earn in any tax year before you start paying tax, without the final digit. For example, a code of 512H means that you start paying tax after you have earned £5,120.

The letter shown after your code defines your status. L represents a basic personal allowance entitlement, H a personal allowance plus married couple's allowance or additional personal allowance at basic rate, whilst D represents a higher rate tax payer. The letters OT mean that no allowances have been given, and could be used when you have overdue tax returns, or that your tax affairs are very complicated.

Sometimes your taxable benefits will exceed your allowances, an example being if you are taxed on a company car or you owe money to the Inland Revenue from previous tax years. In these cases, a K code is used so that your employer can recoup this tax on behalf of the Revenue.

So, You need to check the figures on your notice of tax code very carefully. If the estimates are excessive, write to your tax office requesting a code change. And if your code is incorrect, it is more than likely that your previous year's code was wrong so make sure this is also rectified.

Another way to pay less tax is to make the best use of your tax-free personal allowances. This is particularly relevant if you are married and you and your spouse pay different rates of tax. If, for example one of you is a top-rate taxpayer and the other a basic rate or non-taxpayer, you can cut your tax liability in half by transferring income-yielding assets like building society deposits or shares to the lower earner.

Rental income on a property can also be split between you and your spouse in proportions that minimise tax liability, but the Inland Revenue must be informed. Ask your tax office for a notice of Declaration of Beneficial Interest in Joint Property and Income, or more simply, an IR17.

There are pitfalls to all this money juggling. If you change the name on a building society account you could forfeit the right to future windfall bonuses from demutualising societies. And of course, if your spouse runs off with the money all the tax efficiency in the world won't get it back.

We might enjoy moaning about Hector the taxman, but to be fair to the guy he does offer taxpayers several other allowances which sometimes get overlooked. For example, if you have children, are you ensuring that your children's tax-free personal allowances are being used to the full? Are they needlessly paying tax on bank and building society deposits because you've forgotten to fill in tax form R85?

And at work, are there any expenses you could set against tax such as training fees to professional bodies or travelling costs? Are your donations to charities benefiting from tax relief via the Gift Aid scheme or deeds of covenant?

Make the most of your pension. It's common knowledge that pensions are the most tax efficient investments around, but are you making the most of yours? If you are in a company scheme you can salt away up to 15% of your employment earnings into your pension and get tax relief at your highest rate. If your employer's scheme is non-contributory, you can make up the shortfall by making additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) to your company scheme or free-standing additional voluntary contributions (FSAVCs) to a personal free-standing AVC scheme of your choice.

If you contribute to a personal pension scheme instead, the taxman will limit the amount of pension contributions you can make which will qualify for tax relief. These limits vary according to your age and the type of personal plan you have, but they are set as a percentage of your net relevant earnings. For the self-employed this basically means your profits before tax. If you are under the age of 35, for example, the most you can pay into a personal pension in any given tax year is 17.5% of net relevant earnings.

However, there are a couple of rules which permit you to make contributions in excess of your particular limit. Under carry-back provisions, you can make a contribution in one tax year, but have it treated as if it had been paid in the previous year. Of course, you have to have enough unused tax relief from the previous year, but if you had no net relevant earnings in the previous year, you can even carry the contribution back two years. Carrying back contributions can be particularly useful if you are self-employed, because the delay in making pension contributions for a particular year gives you time to assess your tax position.

fields.trailText: If you are employed, employers have to deduct tax from your pay.
fields.body:
If you are employed, employers have to deduct tax from your pay.

If you are self-employed, you are responsible for keeping records of your earnings and calculating and paying the tax due to the Inland Revenue.

fields.headline: The Daughter-in-Law
fields.standfirst:
The Daughter-in-Law
Orange Tree, Richmond
*****
fields.trailText:
The Daughter-in-Law
Orange Tree, Richmond
*****
fields.body:
Watching Sam Walters's masterly revival of Lawrence's sixth (and arguably best) play, one can only wonder at the bovine laziness of a British theatre that neglects its own native, working-class drama.

Two ingredients make for strong theatre: a protagonist driven to desperation and a seamless interweaving of private and public worlds. Both are on view in Lawrence's play, where the newly-married Minnie discovers that her miner husband Luther has got another woman pregnant.

The tension stems from Minnie's attempt to reclaim him: not so much from the pregnant Bertha, to whose family he has to pay £40 in compensation, but from his own mother, to whose apron-strings he remains firmly tied. "How is a woman to have a husband?" Minnie asks in a classic Lawrentian line, "if all the men belong to their mothers?"

Sex, class and economics all effortlessly combine in Lawrence's masterpiece. In a play full of great scenes, possibly the finest is that in which Luther admits to Minnie that he has fathered a bastard child: Luther's guilt takes the form of an unreasoning anger while Minnie taunts him with being mollycoddled, "marded" and sexually inadequate. Strindberg never did anything finer in the exploration of marital tension. But Lawrence also subtly reminds us that Luther's hatred is heightened by his sense of economic dependence: not only is he aware that his wife could easily cancel his sexual debt but that, with a miners' strike looming, he will be unable to provide for her.

Freud and Marx combine in this great English play. On one level, Lawrence is writing about men's oedipal attachment to their mothers. But the play is also about the economic injustice of a system where miners' pay was dependent on local price lists while the pit manager got a fixed £1,200 a year. Lawrence doesn't just use money to spice up the play's background: he makes it integral to the human relationships.

All this comes out clearly in a finely-cast production where character is revealed through action. Octavia Walters as Minnie has just the right refined determination in her battle with Rowena Cooper's tight-lipped, ball-breaking Mrs Gascoigne. Alan Cox's Luther perfectly blends virility and weakness, Steven Elder is a hauntingly dreamy Joe and there is a peach of a performance from Jeanne Hepple who, as the "werriting" mother of the pregnant Bertha, might have stepped straight out of the pages of Dickens. A great evening.

Until March 24. Box office: 020-8940 3633.

fields.headline: Arab Strap and the gallows of love
fields.standfirst:
Arab Strap
Sheffield University
***
fields.trailText:
Arab Strap
Sheffield University
***
fields.body:
In Arab Strap's world, people get hopelessly drunk, then harangue their partners with intoxicated and uncomfortable home truths. They frequently decide to tell the truth, whatever the consequences. And, mostly, they engage in a pitiful, contemptuous subsequent orgy of guilt and recrimination. And that's just on a quiet night - because Arab Strap have made the particularly grisly fallout of relationships their musical stock-in-trade.

If Frank Sinatra's Songs for Swinging Lovers evoked the pzazz and joy of fledgling love affairs, any lovebirds in Strap songs are more likely to be swinging from a gallows. Four years in, the band are certainly not mellowing. The fabulous new single, Love Detective, concerns the awful consequences of looking under a partner's bed, unlocking a private box, and finding diaries of betrayal and a secret sexual life. You'd expect such material to produce a stark live performance, and it does. However, in person the audience is treated to the Falkirk band's often unheralded capacity for black humour. Vocalist Aidan Moffat is almost a visual gag in himself. A tall, imposing person, he hasn't shaved for weeks prior to this tour and often stumbles around like a drunken refugee from a certain kind of 1970s European film.

With Moffat revelling in this sort of amiably sinister persona, the band can barely restrain wry grins at his heavily-breathed, narrated excesses. One song, Moffat tells us with particular relish, is about spunk.

The evening becomes more curious when it becomes apparent that the band are seriously rusty. One minute they're creating a Joy Division-like scarring intensity, or adding a drum machine to produce an inverted version of rave, the next minute songs collapse in a heap. However, Moffat's twisted sense of mischief is indefatigable. Noticing that the audience is almost entirely young, male and single, he introduces a guest singer ("This is a girl") as if she were some mysterious alien creature.

Cheekily blaming the technical problems on his musicians' fondness for hashish, Moffat eventually gets down to the serious business of exposing himself and every female he's ever been out with. His tales of dark sexual activity, stalking, mutual loathing, and girl-friends who "grunt" will win him only the most psychotic paramours, but you suspect he'd be utterly appalled if it were any other way.

At London's Kings Cross Scala February 26; Manchester Planet K, 27; and Glasgow Arches, 28.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: A little girl torments her mother's new boyfriend and a gunslinger is too angst-ridden to pull his piece.
fields.trailText: A little girl torments her mother's new boyfriend and a gunslinger is too angst-ridden to pull his piece.
fields.body:
Yellow
(www.in-movies.co.uk)
How can you forget that it's nearly March and you're still scraping the ice off your windscreen with a credit card? Try warming your eyes on Simon 'The Full Monty' Beaufoy's scorching short which is packed with the hot yellows and reds of a summer afternoon. This tense drama, a child's-eye-view of a disastrous outing in which little Nathalie torments her mother's new boyfriend, gets under its characters' skins in a matter of moments. With its stifling, hazy look, and use of closely observed detail, the film is helped rather than hindered by streamed video. And how nice to see Ray Winstone (as the unlucky Jim) play the tortured, rather than the torturer, for once. (KS)
 View the film

Tex : The Passive-Aggressive Gunslinger
(www.ifctv.com)
Director Brian Sawyer's hilarious take on the Old West shows us a place where a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do. Which in Tex's case means guilt-tripping rather than gunslinging, as he outmanoeuvres his opponent, the evil Bart, with consumate skill. Pocket-sized veteran actor Bob Balaban plays Tex like a tumbleweed Woody Allen, all shrugs and apologies, as a man who is simply too smart to draw his gun. A beautifully photographed battle of wits, featuring the strangest bar-room brawl you'll ever see - it's right up there with Doc Holliday's 'Latin tag duel' in Tombstone. (KS)
 View the film

fields.headline: Women and property inheritance
fields.trailText: Every year there are cases where husbands die and the wife presumes the property will automatically pass to her. But, this only happens automatically if a property is registered in both names.
fields.body:
Every year there are cases where husbands die and the wife presumes the property will automatically pass to her. But, this only happens automatically if a property is registered in both names.

This can be the case with older people where a home can be registered in the name of the husband only. If this is the case, there needs to be a grant of probate to dispose of the property and it then needs to be re-registered in the name of the surviving spouse. This needs to be done with the Land Registry, takes several months and also incurs a cost.

If you are a married woman and have been living in a property for many years, it is worth checking you are registered as a joint owner.

Unmarried women living with a man have no right to a property if no will is made and they are not a joint owner.

fields.headline: What are 'Potentially Exempt Transfers'?
fields.trailText: Potentially Exempt Transfers (Pets) is just another term used for gifts made within the seven year period to friends and relatives. If you die within the seven years, the value is added on to your estate. If you don't, then the gift is exempt.
fields.body:
Potentially Exempt Transfers (Pets) is just another term used for gifts made within the seven year period to friends and relatives. If you die within the seven years, the value is added on to your estate. If you don't, then the gift is exempt.

You do not have to tell the tax office about gifts you have made, but the recipient is required to report the gift within 12 month's of the donor's death. If the death is within three years, 40% is charged, after this, a sliding scale is applied. This is equivalent to a reduction of a fifth if the gift was made between three and four years before your death, another fifth if between four and five years and so on until the seventh year.

webTitle: Can I avoid paying inheritance tax through gifts?

fields.headline: Can I avoid paying inheritance tax through gifts?
fields.trailText: Gifts made in the seven years before your death can be subject to inheritance tax, but a number are exempt from tax. A list of these can be found in the leaflet, 'An introduction to Inheritance Tax' from the Inland Revenue.
fields.body:
Gifts made in the seven years before your death can be subject to inheritance tax, but a number are exempt from tax. A list of these can be found in the leaflet, 'An introduction to Inheritance Tax' from the Inland Revenue.

Gifts include sums of money of up to £5,000 given as wedding gifts to children, maintenance payments to ex partners and children and other gifts of up to £3,000 made in any one tax year.

Everyone has this £3,000 limit and if it's not used up in one year, the amount can be carried forward to the next. After three years, the tax payable on a gift starts reducing until it reaches nil at year seven.

Small gifts of up to £250 can be made to any number of people. This is known as taper relief.

The crucial issue with making gifts to below the inheritance threshold is that they are made seven years before you die - it is in a sense a clock ticking when you can beat the tax office.

The situation concerning gifts can be complicated and again, it is an area where many people will want to seek advice from an experienced financial adviser.

Gifts include sums of money of up to £5,000 given as wedding gifts to children, maintenance payments to ex partners and children and other gifts of up to £3,000 made in any one tax year. Everyone has this £3,000 limit and if it's not used up in one year, the amount can be carried forward to the next. After three years, the tax payable on a gift starts reducing until it reaches nil at year seven. Small gifts of up to £250 can be made to any number of people. This is known as taper relief. The crucial issue with making gifts to below the inheritance threshold is that they are made seven years before you die - it is in a sense a clock ticking when you can beat the tax office. The situation concerning gifts can be complicated and again, it is an area where many people will want to seek advice from an experienced financial adviser.

fields.trailText: A will should be viewed as a valuable item and be kept in a safe place, such as a bank deposit box.
fields.body:
A will should be viewed as a valuable item and be kept in a safe place, such as a bank deposit box.

Only the original is recognised legally - copies are worthless and you should be aware of this if you ever need to send a will in the post.

fields.headline: What are Chargeable Transfers?
fields.trailText: Although there is no inheritance tax charged on a gift made seven years before you die, chargeable transfers can incur tax.
fields.body:
Although there is no inheritance tax charged on a gift made seven years before you die, chargeable transfers can incur tax.

These are sums of money transferred typically to trusts for which tax payable at 20% is normally levied on the excess above £234,000.

These can also be known as discretionary trusts, which are administered by trustees and where the individual may have no immediate right to income.

Gifts to companies are also known as chargeable transfers.

fields.headline: Lie back and think of England
fields.standfirst:
A British manager has resigned after a clash of cultures with his Italian chairman. Annabelle Thorpe on the approach to work of our European neighbours

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: A British manager has resigned after a clash of cultures with his Italian chairman. Annabelle Thorpe on the approach to work of our European neighbours
fields.body:
For most office workers, the concept of working through lunch is a way of life. Certainly that was the case at World Online, an internet service provider where desktop lunches were generally expected by the UK manager, Paul Kinsella. Until, that is, the company was bought by an Italian firm, whose chairman, Renato Soru, was horrified to see his new staff slaving away over their sandwiches. The difference in style was so great that Kinsella resigned over the issue - a move that was reported in several national papers last week.

It might seem a storm in a teacup, but Soru's reaction to UK working conditions is an indication of the difference between our corporate world and that of our European neighbours. "In Italy, offices simply shut down at lunchtime," says Nicholas Whitehead, who works for DTZ Debenham Thorpe in Milan. "We are closed from 1pm to 2.30pm and although we have a rota so that there's always someone in the office, basically we go out and have a sit- down lunch."

That includes the secretaries. Unlike in the UK where often the senior members of staff go out to lunch and leave support staff manning the phones, in Italy everyone takes their turn. "The role of a secretary is very different in Italy," says Whitehead. "For a start, we all do our own typing - including things like presentations. Instead of fast typing speeds and good knowledge of software packages, Italian secretaries are more likely to have skills such as accountancy and book-keeping. In many ways they're more like administrators than secretaries."

In Italy the working day may be longer - most offices open at 9am and business doesn't close until 6.30pm - but the extended lunch makes the extra hours more palatable by breaking up the day and transforming the office atmosphere. "Working here is far more sociable," believes Whitehead. "If you sit and stare at your screen all day, as we do in the UK, you very rarely chat to your colleagues. If you have a long lunch with them each day, then it makes everyone a lot closer, and the office a nicer place to be."

We may pride ourselves on the frequency of our teabreaks, but a lengthy afternoon break is common in southern European countries - in Madrid, for example, lunch can go on for hours. The catch is that the more relaxed atmosphere is balanced by a less impressive salary. In Italy, most secretaries earn little more than £12,000, and in Spain, unless you are a top PA, you'll earn much the same. But there are other advantages to working abroad.

"Sun for a start," says Karen McIntosh, who is on secondment as a PA in Madrid. "It sounds superficial, but it makes such a difference. But gradually you notice other differences; people treat secretarial staff very differently here - we are on a much more equal footing. Obviously for really senior managers we make coffee, pop out to get sandwiches - but with other people on the team there is far less hierarchy. We all go out for drinks together, for lunch - and everybody helps each other out when we're busy. In the UK, I used to get great stacks of files dumped on my desk and orders barked at me. No-one would dream of behaving like that here, they're all just too relaxed."

According to McIntosh, office life is so much less stressful in Spain that she wants to extend her secondment. "The only downside is holidays," she says. "It's harder to take holidays when you want." Spain has many more bank holidays than Britain (a generous 14 a year), but everybody tends to take their leave in August because of a virtual nationwide shutdown which, claims McIntosh, can be a bit of a problem "if you want to go off on a girlie holiday all together".

Judith Brooke, who worked in the South of France, found a similar situation. "It's very hard not to take holiday in August because everything just shuts. So if you're looking for temp work it's impossible to find any agencies that are open - by the time September comes, and you would actually like to take a holiday, you can't because you're desperate to earn some money."

Although getting work abroad might seem like a huge step, it can be quite simple. The main stipulation is the ability to speak another language. "We have positions throughout Europe," says Sandra Dawson, who works for an international employment agency, "but we won't consider anyone who isn't fluent in a second language." If you are, working in another country is simple. You can register at the UK branch for jobs abroad, or apply through agency websites that often post vacancies from their overseas branches. The fact is, however, that you are far more likely to find work in France or Germany than any of the more southerly European countries - their job markets simply aren't as buoyant.

Germany may not sound as appealing as sunny Spain or Italy, but the rewards are greater; a good PA can start on as much as £24k. But work starts early in Germany - usually about 8am - and employers tend to be far less flexible than in the UK and other parts of Europe. "In Germany, education is centred around work - so you study for a particular vocation," says Judith Brooke. "If you haven't got the right qualifications it can be hard to get work - the concept of taking someone on and training them up is not a concept that really exists in Germany."

The other factor to consider is that in Germany, secretaries tend to stay secretaries, whereas attitudes in other European countries are far less restricted. "I have been told that if I want to train to be a project manager that's not a problem," says McIntosh "In the UK, you tend to be pigeonholed as a secretary; people don't like it if you try to cross over into a different role. Here, it's positively encouraged - if your boss thinks you do a good job, he or she will help you progress as far as you want to."

In many ways, working abroad is less about salary or career progression and more about the chance to live in a different country and experience a different way of life. Secretarial work doesn't have to be restricted to offices; most holiday companies employ secretarial and admin staff to work in their larger resorts and often hotels may be happy to employ British PAs and administrative staff if they are fluent in a second language.

It's not only the hot countries that offer a more relaxed alternative to UK office life. "I really wanted to work abroad," says Jemma Warden, who works for a London consulting firm, "and after waiting for months all they would offer me was Stavanger in Norway. So I took it - and had the most fantastic time. We started work at 7.30am but left the office at 4pm. In Norway no one lives far from the office and everyone eats early, so by 5.30pm I would have got home, changed, had dinner and be ready for the evening. I've never been so relaxed. I felt as if I spent the same amount of time at home as I did at work. The government has laid down laws to ensure that no one does too much overtime. There is a real emphasis on ensuring that everyone has enough time to spend with friends and family."

For Warden, there really was only one downside to her overseas experience. "It was a real shock to the system when I came back to the UK."

For further info, visit www.adecco.co.uk - apply online for jobs abroad

fields.headline: Living abroad and inheritance tax
fields.trailText: A growing number of older people choose to retire in the sun, for example by moving to Spain or Cyprus.
fields.body:
A growing number of older people choose to retire in the sun, for example by moving to Spain or Cyprus.

But, some people mistakenly believe they have escaped the clutches of the Inland Revenue by moving abroad. Although this means they have no longer have to pay income or capital gains tax, they remain liable for inheritance tax.

Graham Collins of Advisory & Brokerage says many people fail to understand the implications of going abroad. "Just because you change your residence, it does not mean you change your domicile, which in the case of many people remains the UK."

He explains that the domicile as opposed to residence concept is harder to define and is linked to "ultimate association". In some cases, it is possible to change your domicile and so avoid tax, but this is rare. Added to this, many people return to the UK before they die.

If you are considering moving abroad, you should seek advice without delay on how to tackle potential inheritance tax problems.

Insurance company Scottish Equitable International, which operates financial planning solutions such as offshore bonds held in trust, says thousands of people store up inheritance tax problems by moving abroad and dying there. It claims that some people could face a double whammy in tax bills - a charge from the UK and the European country were they were living. This does not apply those if they die in the UK.

fields.headline: Big Daddy Kane
fields.standfirst:
Big Daddy Kane
The Scala, London
***
fields.trailText:
Big Daddy Kane
The Scala, London
***
fields.body:
"Big Daddy Kane has entered the building," says the MC at midnight to roars from the crowd. New Yorker Antonio M Hardy - alias Kane, which stands for King Asiatic Nobody's Equal) was once the crucial fourth man to Chuck D, KRS-1 and Rakim. With his smooth yet intense delivery and the Marley Marl-produced hard funk of his records, he bridged the gap between early rap's primitive bluster and the gangsta (NWA), militant (Public Enemy) and conscious (Jungle Brothers) styles of the late 1980s.

A mixture of young and old hip-hop fans have come to see what rappers were like "back in the day". By 12.20am, they find out: the erstwhile rap lothario (his debut LP sleeve saw him being fed grapes by female minions), now in his 30s and more than slightly filled out, slouches onstage in what appears to be designer prisonwear (a grey boiler suit), and with a gold goblet, presumably containing alcohol, held indelicately in his right hand. The reaction is warm to say the least.

Compared to the rapacious narcissism of Puff Daddy, Big Daddy Kane's was a benign form of self-assertion. He was a sort of People's Rogue with a penchant for what used to be called "edutainment" - he used to go on speaking tours of black high schools in Detroit. Tonight's Lyrical Lounge programme (BDK plus support from singer Mary Pearce and rapper Ty) has a similar spirit, having been assembled by Urban Development, an organisation funded by the Arts Council and London Arts via the National Lottery, to promote black artists and black music in London.

There is even a "freestyle" section of Kane's show devoted to encouraging raw talent: several aspiring microphone fiends are pulled from the audience to prove their MC skills. Over a simple machine beat courtesy of turntable maestro DJ Pogo, a procession of young hopefuls expose their aggressive but whiny voices as Big Daddy smiles benevolently from centrestage, as if suddenly realising the symbolic baton will not be passed on just yet. It is like amateur night at the local youth club. Maverick US rapper Jeru the Damaja joins in the fun, emerging stage left to acknowledge his debt to Kane before making a bizarre reference to northern English homosexuals.

Kane injects a note of solemnity when he pays tribute to "the fallen soldiers of hip-hop": Notorious B.I.G., Big Pun, Tupac Shakur and Freaky Tah from the Lost Boyz, all victims of rap's gang culture. Before things get too grim, we are instructed to "make some motherfucking noise!" and Big Daddy, assisted by DJ Pogo, treats us to a selection of his greatest hits - not the whole songs, just the opening bars to Raw, Ain't No Half-Steppin', Wrath of Kane and Smooth Operator. It's like a glorified Beat the Intro competition, adding to the party atmosphere.

After an hour, Kane heads towards his dressing room as MC Ty, onstage throughout the performance, prostrates himself in a "We are not worthy" fashion. So he brought our childhoods back with a Proustian rush. With a Best Of collection and a brand new album on the way, it remains to be seen whether this avuncular ghost of hip-hop past can still cut it in today's cut-and-thrust world.

At Creation in Bristol on March 1.

fields.headline: Buttock-clenching sincerity from Westlife
fields.standfirst:
Westlife
Manchester Arena
*
fields.trailText:
Westlife
Manchester Arena
*
fields.body:
As the band remind us from the stage, they are the only group to have their first five British singles enter the chart at number one. Before Christmas, Bob the Builder kept their sixth from reaching the top slot, but their grip has proved unshakable. Westlife have returned with three Brit nominations and their first ever tour, which for the casual bystander feels like being hit by an enormous crate of sugar falling from the sky.

Their female - screaming - audience at Manchester Arena bears all the tell-tale signs of ravages. Some have placards proclaiming love for band members, most wear flashing horns that make them look like little devils. It's like dying and going to hell, only to discover that the devil has a few of the best tunes, but that they're all performed by a band that has made the worst bits of the Osmonds the biggest influence on British pop.

The oddest thing is that, despite their run of hits, Westlife's blockbusters haven't exactly lodged in the memory like Take That's chart-toppers. This is underlined by the eyebrow-raising amount of covers. Buttock-clenchingly "sincere" on their own songs, they relate to others like schoolchildren reading Latin - Terry Jacks's suicide anthem Seasons in the Sun is "interpreted" by grins.

Mark and Shane can certainly sing, although, taking no chances, the band's voices are bolstered by banks of squeaking keyboards. Despite the big production (dancers, videos, aliens) Westlife themselves are reassuringly human. Their outfits (particularly the silk numbers) have as much style as Vera Duckworth. They spend an inordinate amount of time sitting down or sliding off for another costume change, or to do their hair, which obviously doesn't work those waistlines. It's taken them two years to get around to touring, and perhaps they should have done more training.

There are several films, some terrible jokes, the musicians get to indulge their jazz-funk fantasies and occasionally Waistlife sing one of their hits. For Flying Without Wings they - gasp! - fly without wings over the audience! This is encouraging. If only they had a song called Plunging into Vats of Boiling Oil.

At Nottingham Arena February 27 and 28; Birmingham NEC March 2-4; then touring.

Despite the big production (dancers, videos, aliens) Westlife themselves are reassuringly human. Their outfits (particularly the silk numbers) have as much style as Vera Duckworth. They spend an inordinate amount of time sitting down or sliding off for another costume change, or to do their hair, which obviously doesn't work those waistlines. It's taken them two years to get around to touring, and perhaps they should have done more training. There are several films, some terrible jokes, the musicians get to indulge their jazz-funk fantasies and occasionally Waistlife sing one of their hits. For Flying Without Wings they - gasp! - fly without wings over the audience! This is encouraging. If only they had a song called Plunging into Vats of Boiling Oil. At Nottingham Arena February 27 and 28; Birmingham NEC March 2-4; then touring.

fields.headline: A rudderless Aida
fields.standfirst:
Aida
Royal Albert Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Aida
Royal Albert Hall, London
**
fields.body:
Raymond Gubbay could not have chosen a better opera than Verdi's Aida for his latest Royal Albert Hall extravaganza. Verdi's glorious depiction of the decadence of the Egyptian Pharaohs represents 19th century opera at its most lavish and spectacular. Even Gubbay's controversial use of technology in his stagings (the soloists and orchestra are amplified throughout) has a parallel in the circumstances of Aida's commission: Verdi wrote the work in 1871 for the opening of a theatre in Cairo, built to celebrate the engineering miracle of the Suez Canal.

In director David Freeman's production, the central area of the Albert Hall forms the stage, while the conductor, Peter Robinson, and the BBC Concert Orchestra are stationed behind the singers. The audience envelops the entire area. Not only does this arrangement present huge acoustic problems, it also distorts the audience's sightlines.

But Freeman solves these problems with imagination and flair. The triumphant scene at the end of Act 2, as Radamès celebrates victory over the Ethiopians, is a cinematic pièce de résistance. There are brilliantly choreographed fights, seductions and arcane rituals. The chorus and dancers, under the intense scrutiny of an unusually intimate audience, play their parts with conviction. Although it's impossible to keep your eyes on the drama between Radamès and Aida in the midst of this melee, Freeman creates a complex chaos that would be impossible to replicate on a conventional operatic stage.

But where the public side of the story is told convincingly, the central relationships are much less compellingly realised. The problems are not just to do with the quality of the individual singers, but also the effect of hearing them through amplification. Both Tamsin Dives's Aida and John Keyes's Radamès sound strained by Verdi's high-octane vocal-writing, and Renata Skarelyte's performance of Amneris is full of effort but little reward. In this first of the three casts who will sing in Aida's two-week run, only Phillip Joll's Amonasro is strongly characterised.

The love triangle between Aida, Radamès and Amneris lacks intensity and passion. In the delicacy of the great duet in the final scene, the problems with the production's sound design are most apparent. Paradoxically, the attempt to bring the singers closer through amplification makes their voices sound disembodied and removed. It's like listening to a recording being played at enormous volume in the Albert Hall rather than watching a live performance.

Whilst there's no doubting the success of the spectacle of Freeman and Gubbay's Aida, the production is dramatically rudderless. The arena of pharaohs, wars and triumphs is dislocated from the love between Radamès and Aida.

Until March 10. Box office: 020-7589 8212.

webTitle: Treves tools up for Equitable's reform

fields.headline: Treves tools up for Equitable's reform
fields.standfirst:
Disaster-struck insurer's new boss is ready to make room at the top - with an axe

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: An impeccably groomed, plain-speaking whirlwind will descend on the Aylesbury headquarters of insurer Equitable Life on Thursday, when Vanni Treves arrives for his first day as chairman and embarks on a root and branch shake-up of the organisation and its much maligned top executives.
fields.body:
An impeccably groomed, plain-speaking whirlwind will descend on the Aylesbury headquarters of insurer Equitable Life on Thursday, when Vanni Treves arrives for his first day as chairman and embarks on a root and branch shake-up of the organisation and its much maligned top executives.

The insurer's battle scarred policyholders will be hoping the 60-year-old will blow away the pall of arrogance, double speak and complacency which - along with some catastrophic decisions - brought the once proud company to its knees and forced it to seek a cut-price sale.

Equitable reached crisis point last July, when the law lords ruled that it had treated 90,000 policyholders unfairly and left the world's oldest mutual insurer facing a bill of at least £1.5bn.

Mr Treves - a wealthy man who is forgoing the £300,000 a year salary - has the Herculean task of trying to unite Equitable's warring policyholders behind a yet to be formulated compromise deal that has been described as the only chance of allowing the insurer to put its troubled past to rest. He is also seeking to introduce "a new and different climate where not everything that the board says and does is viewed with the deepest suspicion".

Mr Treves's arrival promises to be akin to lighting the touch paper. He revealed that he is reviewing the position of every member of staff, including chief executive Chris Headdon, and indicated he will not hang around when it comes to wielding the axe.

"I expect key decisions will be made within days of my taking office," he said.

At the same time he will be starting to put together a new team of non-executive directors to replace the present eight-strong team, who announced in December they would be resigning en masse as soon as suitable replacements have been found.

This week will also see Mr Treves setting up a war room to try to formulate a compromise deal aimed at capping the insurer's liabilities - which will require the approval of both the 90,000 policyholders with guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) policies and those without them.

A team of executives, lawyers, actuaries and others will be charged with devising a scheme that achieves the delicate balancing act of giving enough to those people with guarantees but not so much that it leaves those without guarantees feeling cheated, that is legally watertight and easily understood. "I want these people to do nothing else but to work on this," said Mr Treves - who is also chairman of Channel 4.

In broad terms, this deal will involve one-off payments being made to the people with GAR policies in return for them giving up their rights to the guarantee. These payments will be funded from the £1.5bn Equitable raised last year by depriving all the 1m or so with-profits policyholders of seven months' worth of bonuses.

Although he says it is "a long shot," Mr Treves is prepared to try to overturn last year's law lords decision if he can find any legal basis for doing so.

He will soon know if the respected counsel he has hired can find any hope. Nicholas Warren, QC, will deliver his initial view on the company's chances early next month, raising the possibility of Equitable returning to the position it was in before the devastating court case.

"It has been suggested that consideration be given to whether or not that judgement could be reconsidered in some way. There are precedents for that, and that seems to me a very worthwhile exercise and we are undertaking it."

Broken promises

The highest court in the land found the insurer had tried to renege on the promises it made to GAR policyholders by cutting the final bonus payments for those who chose to exercise the guarantee.

The law lords ruled Equitable must meet the guarantees in full. Following this, the company put itself up for sale but when no buyer was found, it shut its doors to new business and warned the 1m with-profits policyholders they would face lower investment returns in future.

The recent sale of Equitable's operations to Halifax means things are looking brighter, but £500m of the money the bank is paying will be handed over only on condition that the compromise deal is accepted by policyholders.

Mr Treves said the Halifax deal cannot be undone, but in the unlikely event of the judgment being amended, the fortunes of Equitable's policyholders would change dramatically. It would mean the GAR policyholders would not be owed the £1.5bn in payments the law lords ruled they had been unfairly denied.

Mr Treves, a senior lawyer at City firm Macfarlanes, is too diplomatic to attack Equitable, but concedes the words "introspective" and "complacent" have been used by others when describing the company.

That is putting it mildly. At the recent Commons Treasury select committee inquiry into the Equitable affair, MPs lambasted the management and suggested they misled policyholders by concealing the real potential cost of meeting the guarantees. In the run-up to the crucial court battle, the then chief executive, Alan Nash, continued to insist that this liability would be only £50m.

Despite all they have been through, Equitable's high command appear still not to have learned about effective communication. At the select committee inquiry, outgoing chairman John Sclater was accused by one MP of giving responses that were "glib, possibly even deceptive".

Mr Treves says "a lot of policyholders feel the communications have been disappointing", adding, "They will be told exactly what's what by me."

If he does not win the support of policyholders, however, he says he will not hang around. "I'll pack up my bags and hand over to somebody else. I have other chairmanships I could have done. I would not feel I'd lost face."

fields.headline: Abbey plans rate cut
fields.standfirst:
Sweetener pitches lender into high street mele for homeowners' business

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Sweetener pitches lender into high street mele for homeowners' business.
fields.body:
Abbey National is this week expected to enter the multimillion-pound fight for mortgage customers which began when Nationwide and Halifax cut their rates last week.

Abbey, at present in the middle of a takeover tussle, is understood to be planning the launch of cheaper deals for homeowners to prevent them defecting to rivals.

Last week's rate cuts by Nationwide and Halifax will mean customers with an average sized interest-only mortgage of £60,000 are about £30 a month better off. The reductions left other lenders - Abbey National included - offering rates as much as one full percentage point higher and facing a revolt by their customers.

Such is the fight for customers that Nationwide chief executive Brian Davis on Friday fired off an unprecedented attack on the Halifax, accusing the former building society of misleading its customers about its new rates.

The banks' shares prices were also hit last week as the battle ignited and Abbey's retaliation, expected this week, may only serve to justify the anxieties that the banks' profitability will fall.

Second only in size to Halifax with 2m customers, Abbey is thought to be planning to take action designed to retain the 1.3m or so homeowners who are on special deals such as fixed and discounted rates.

Abbey, facing an unwanted £19bn bid from Lloyds TSB, is understood to be determined to keep its rates competitive.

It is likely to abandon the higher rate to which customers on special deals automatically shift at the end of the lifetime of their product. This would usually have been to its standard variable rate - at 7.5%, a full percentage point higher than Nationwide's 6.5% new "base rate mortgage". But Abbey will now move these customers to its so-called flexible mortgage package, which offers a rate of 6.75%, matching Halifax's new standard variable mortgage rate.

It is unclear what changes Abbey plans to make to the standard variable rate - which 700,000 of its mortgage customers at present pay - of 7.5%, almost two percentage points higher than the Bank of England's base rate of 5.75%.

Abbey National's "flexible" mortgage rate pledges to be no more than one percentgage point above the Bank of England's base rate, as does Halifax's newly reduced standard variable mortgage rate. This is also a pledge made by HSBC, the tenth biggest lender.

Halifax, the biggest lender with 2.5m customers, also insists that its new rates are designed not only to retain existing customers but also to attract new customers.

This is why it set itself a new target last week to win 15% of all new business in the mortgage market this year.

Rivals expect Abbey National, which last night refused to comment on its plans, to become an increasingly competitive player as it positions itself as a serious challenger to the "big four" on the high street while the competition commission reviews the implications of Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid.

The terms of the referral of the bid to the competition commission, announced on Friday, mentioned Abbey's position outside the "big four" - the term used to describe Lloyds TSB, HSBC, NatWest and Barclays.

Meanwhile, Abbey National and Bank of Scotland, its preferred merger partner, are expected to restart talks this week to take advantage of the delay the referral will cause to Lloyds TSB's bid.

webTitle: Who is liable to pay inheritance tax?

fields.headline: Who is liable to pay inheritance tax?
fields.trailText: There are three main taxes that affect most people - income, capital gains and inheritance. The good news is that most people don't pay inheritance tax - the Inland Revenue says that 96% of estates avoid it.
fields.body:
There are three main taxes that affect most people - income, capital gains and inheritance. The good news is that most people don't pay inheritance tax - the Inland Revenue says that 96% of estates avoid it.

But, it is an area that is now concerning far more people. Graham Collins, a financial planner with inheritance tax specialists Advisory & Brokerage, says this is largely because of rising property prices. Particularly in the south of England, many people now own valuable homes and their total assets exceed the inheritance tax threshold.

Many people do manage to avoid inheritance tax, however, through either leaving assets to their spouse, which means it is not payable, or through good planning.

No inheritance tax is payable, if you leave everything to your husband or wife, but you must both be domiciled in the UK.

fields.trailText: It needs to be paid six months after the end of the month when the person has died.

It needs to be paid six months after the end of the month when the person has died.

The authority to release the money held in the estate is known as probate in England and Wales and confirmation in Scotland.

fields.trailText: A will needs to be updated or changed as circumstances change, for example, if you marry or have children.
fields.body:
A will needs to be updated or changed as circumstances change, for example, if you marry or have children.

You also need to consider if you have children under 18 if money should be left in trust for them.

For more information, see the inheritance tax section.

fields.headline: Why make a will?
fields.trailText: A will lets those left behind know how you want your assets distributed. You are likely to need to make a will so you can make sure your estate, which includes property, savings and possessions is handed down to the beneficiaries of your choice.
fields.body:
A will lets those left behind know how you want your assets distributed. You are likely to need to make a will so you can make sure your estate, which includes property, savings and possessions is handed down to the beneficiaries of your choice.

If you die without making a will, there could be unpleasant legal wrangles and any money or property will be distributed according to the laws of intestacy. This does not recognise unmarried partners and what's more, in cases of large legacies, a spouse does not automatically inherit everything.

fields.headline: Downriver
fields.standfirst:
Downriver
Newcastle Playhouse
****
fields.trailText:
Downriver
Newcastle Playhouse
****
fields.body:
This was exactly what Newcastle needed over a snowy weekend: a fiery, cockle-warming tale of love and jazz, set in the near future but really harking back to the passion, glamour and seedy side of the 1930s jazz scene. A concert version of a new piece of music-theatre by poet Sean O'Brien and composer Keith Morris, these performances were the best kind of work-in-progress shows: a taster full of potential, an appetite-whetter leaving the audience wanting more.

In this format, the evening was more music than drama, more concert than musical. The stage was set for standard big-band business, with no distractions such as scenery or backdrop, and only a small table downstage, with candle and red tablecloth, suggested other possibilities. This was the table of our "floozy and fool" narrators, Lulu Banks (Libby Davidson) and Bobby Smart (Walter James), who got to say things like "Do you wanna know what happened to Susie?" between songs.

Both sang: Davidson with sweet songs of love gone wrong, James with hard man anthems including a tribute to the role of drugs in culture ("a spliff made all the difference to Rimbaud") - but for much of the evening they had to sit as if watching a concert just like us, toe-tapping and doing jazzy nods to the beat.

To this extent, the show was dramatically unsatisfying and the story they told us of jazz club owner Johnny Mack falling in love with Susie Rivers, who is also pursued by gangster Rantan O'Toole, felt more of a device linking songs than full plot. In the best of the musical numbers we quickly forgot character and story: the fact that Katharine Zeserson, as Susie, had a mesmerising voice drew us into her songs of woe more than the sketchy plot. Similarly, Richard Scott as the villain O'Hara relied more on his flinty singing voice to suggest his hardness than any character development or evidence of badness.

None of this mattered on a night when the music was very much the thing. The 11-piece band, including Annie Whitehead on trombone, swooped through the emotions, incorporating Latin rhythms and percussive workouts to turn up the musical and emotional heat. Not one note or arrangement was wrong and, particularly in the second set, there was an impressive intensity to the music given the always un- predictable work-in-progress nature of the performance.

Despite this format being more music than musical, and featuring more in the way of wry lyrics than fully-rounded characters, it remained a tantalising debut.

None of this mattered on a night when the music was very much the thing. The 11-piece band, including Annie Whitehead on trombone, swooped through the emotions, incorporating Latin rhythms and percussive workouts to turn up the musical and emotional heat. Not one note or arrangement was wrong and, particularly in the second set, there was an impressive intensity to the music given the always un- predictable work-in-progress nature of the performance. Despite this format being more music than musical, and featuring more in the way of wry lyrics than fully-rounded characters, it remained a tantalising debut.

fields.headline: Barclays plans 'one-stop' data site
fields.standfirst:
Clients can view all their assets, including those at other banks

Guardian Unlimited Money
More net news
fields.trailText: Barclays is planning to launch a new kind of online service that would shake up banking by allowing people to access all their financial accounts and assets in one place.
fields.body:
Barclays is planning to launch a new kind of online service that would shake up banking by allowing people to access all their financial accounts and assets in one place.

Data aggregation, as it is known, is becoming increasingly popular in America because it enables people to view and manage all their accounts, investments and other financial holdings, including those held with other banks and providers, on a single web page.

Such services have yet to arrive in Britain but Corillian, a US-based e-finance software company, said yesterday it was in talks with several British banks and predicted that by early summer there would be a number offering the beginnings of data aggregation.

Barclays said it was speaking to several such service providers. "We are working actively on it. We are seeking to move with speed but not with haste. It is not a question of if - it is a question of when and how and who," said Simon Newman, director of business-to-consumer commerce.

Industry sources also claim online bank Egg could be looking to launch a service soon.

Aggregation has been around in the United States for little more than a year but about 1m people there use the services, mainly to bring to gether their various online current, savings, credit card and share-dealing accounts in one place.

They have proved controversial because, when setting up their personal page, individuals have to enter their user names and passwords for all the accounts they wish to add to their page. Critics say this poses a serious security risk as it goes against the advice that people should not disclose their security details.

Mr Newman said security was one of the "big issues" that needed to be examined, and Barclays was exploring how best to obtain information on a customer's financial holdings with another bank and at the same time keep it secure and private.

One solution may be for a system to be put in place where banks and others offering aggregation services securely pass data between each other where a customer agrees this can happen.

Up until now little has been said by British banks on the subject, but this week Egg prepared its credit card users for the arrival of aggregation. In an email to customers it said it was altering the card's terms so that in future they will be allowed to disclose their security details to a third party offering such a service provided it is a company approved by Egg.

In recent months US financial services companies have been scrambling to launch aggregation services. American Express and stockbroker Charles Schwab are among the players that have announced services in the past few weeks.

Some analysts predict that by 2004, 36m people will be using the service in America.
